name: Comprehensive Rules: 100. General : 100.1.
text: These Magic rules apply to any Magic game with two or more players, including two-player games and multiplayer games.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 100. General : 100.1a
text: A two-player game is a game that begins with only two players.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 100. General : 100.1b
text: A multiplayer game is a game that begins with more than two players. See section 8, âMultiplayer Rules.â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 100. General : 100.2.
text: To play, each player needs their own deck of traditional Magic cards, small items to represent any tokens and counters, and some way to clearly track life totals.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 100. General : 100.2a
text: In constructed play (a way of playing in which each player creates their own deck ahead of time), each deck has a minimum deck size of 60 cards. A constructed deck may contain any number of basic land cards and no more than four of any card with a particular English name other than basic land cards. For the purposes of deck construction, cards with interchangeable names have the same English name (see rule 201.3).

name: Comprehensive Rules: 100. General : 100.2b
text: In limited play (a way of playing in which each player gets the same quantity of unopened Magic product such as booster packs and creates their own deck using only this product and basic land cards), each deck has a minimum deck size of 40 cards. A limited deck may contain as many duplicates of a card as are included with the product.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 100. General : 100.2c
text: Commander decks are subject to additional deckbuilding restrictions and requirements. See rule 903, âCommander,â for details.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 100. General : 100.2d
text: Some formats and casual play variants allow players to use a supplementary deck of nontraditional Magic cards (see rule 108.2a). These supplementary decks have their own deck construction rules. See rule 717, âAttraction Cards;â rule 901, âPlanechase;â and rule 904, âArchenemy.â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 100. General : 100.3.
text: Some cards require coins or traditional dice. Some casual variants require additional items, such as specially designated cards, nontraditional Magic cards, and specialized dice.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 100. General : 100.4.
text: Each player may also have a sideboard, which is a group of additional cards the player may use to modify their deck between games of a match.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 100. General : 100.4a
text: In constructed play, a sideboard may contain no more than fifteen cards. The four-card limit (see rule 100.2a) applies to the combined deck and sideboard.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 100. General : 100.4b
text: In limited play involving individual players, all cards in a playerâs card pool not included in their deck are in that playerâs sideboard.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 100. General : 100.4c
text: In limited play involving the Two-Headed Giant multiplayer variant, all cards in a teamâs card pool but not in either playerâs deck are in that teamâs sideboard.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 100. General : 100.4d
text: In limited play involving other multiplayer team variants, each card in a teamâs card pool but not in any playerâs deck is assigned to the sideboard of one of those players. Each player has their own sideboard; cards may not be transferred between players.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 100. General : 100.5.
text: If a deck must contain at least a certain number of cards, that number is referred to as a minimum deck size. There is no maximum deck size for non-Commander decks.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 100. General : 100.6.
text: Most Magic tournaments (organized play activities where players compete against other players to win prizes) have additional rules covered in the Magic: The Gathering Tournament Rules (found at WPN.Wizards.com/en/resources/rules-documents). These rules may limit the use of some cards, including barring all cards from some older sets.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 100. General : 100.6a
text: Tournaments usually consist of a series of matches. A two-player match usually involves playing until one player has won two games. A multiplayer match usually consists of only one game.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 100. General : 100.6b
text: Players can use the Magic Store & Event Locator at Wizards.com/Locator to find tournaments in their area.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 100. General : 100.7.
text: Certain cards are intended for casual play and may have features and text that arenât covered by these rules. These include Mystery Booster playtest cards, promotional cards and cards in âUn-setsâ that were printed with a silver border, and cards in the Unfinityâ¢ expansion that have an acorn symbol at the bottom of the card.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 101. The Magic Golden Rules : 101.1.
text: Whenever a cardâs text directly contradicts these rules, the card takes precedence. The card overrides only the rule that applies to that specific situation. The only exception is that a player can concede the game at any time (see rule 104.3a).

name: Comprehensive Rules: 101. The Magic Golden Rules : 101.2.
text: When a rule or effect allows or directs something to happen, and another effect states that it canât happen, the âcanâtâ effect takes precedence.

name: Example for Rule : 101.2.
text: If one effect reads âYou may play an additional land this turnâ and another reads âYou canât play lands this turn,â the effect that precludes you from playing lands wins.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 101. The Magic Golden Rules : 101.2a
text: Adding abilities to objects and removing abilities from objects donât fall under this rule. (See rule 113.10.)

name: Comprehensive Rules: 101. The Magic Golden Rules : 101.3.
text: Any part of an instruction thatâs impossible to perform is ignored. (In many cases the card will specify consequences for this; if it doesnât, thereâs no effect.)

name: Comprehensive Rules: 101. The Magic Golden Rules : 101.4.
text: If multiple players would make choices and/or take actions at the same time, the active player (the player whose turn it is) makes any choices required, then the next player in turn order (usually the player seated to the active playerâs left) makes any choices required, followed by the remaining nonactive players in turn order. Then the actions happen simultaneously. This rule is often referred to as the âActive Player, Nonactive Player (APNAP) orderâ rule.

name: Example for Rule : 101.4.
text: A card reads âEach player sacrifices a creature.â First, the active player chooses a creature they control. Then each of the nonactive players, in turn order, chooses a creature they control. Then all creatures chosen this way are sacrificed simultaneously.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 101. The Magic Golden Rules : 101.4a
text: If an effect has each player choose a card in a hidden zone, such as their hand or library, those cards may remain face down as theyâre chosen. However, each player must clearly indicate which face-down card they are choosing.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 101. The Magic Golden Rules : 101.4b
text: A player knows the choices made by the previous players when making their choice, except as specified in 101.4a.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 101. The Magic Golden Rules : 101.4c
text: If a player would make more than one choice at the same time, the player makes the choices in the order specified. If no order is specified, the player chooses the order.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 101. The Magic Golden Rules : 101.4d
text: If a choice made by a nonactive player causes the active player, or a different nonactive player earlier in the turn order, to have to make a choice, APNAP order is restarted for all outstanding choices.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 101. The Magic Golden Rules : 101.4e
text: If multiple players would make choices or take actions while starting the game, the starting player is considered the active player and each other player is considered a nonactive player.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 102. Players : 102.1.
text: A player is one of the people in the game. The active player is the player whose turn it is. The other players are nonactive players.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 102. Players : 102.2.
text: In a two-player game, a playerâs opponent is the other player.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 102. Players : 102.3.
text: In a multiplayer game between teams, a playerâs teammates are the other players on their team, and the playerâs opponents are all players not on their team.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 102. Players : 102.4.
text: A spell or ability may use the term âyour teamâ as shorthand for âyou and/or your teammates.â In a game that isnât a multiplayer game between teams, âyour teamâ means the same thing as âyou.â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 103. Starting the Game : 103.1.
text: At the start of a game, the players determine which one of them will choose who takes the first turn. In the first game of a match (including a single-game match), the players may use any mutually agreeable method (flipping a coin, rolling dice, etc.) to do so. In a match of several games, the loser of the previous game chooses who takes the first turn. If the previous game was a draw, the player who made the choice in that game makes the choice in this game. The player chosen to take the first turn is the starting player. The gameâs default turn order begins with the starting player and proceeds clockwise.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 103. Starting the Game : 103.1a
text: In a game using the shared team turns option, there is a starting team rather than a starting player.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 103. Starting the Game : 103.1b
text: In an Archenemy game, these methods arenât used to determine who takes the first turn. Rather, the archenemy takes the first turn.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 103. Starting the Game : 103.1c
text: One card (Power Play) states that its controller is the starting player. This effect applies after this determination has happened and supersedes these methods.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 103. Starting the Game : 103.2.
text: Some games require additional steps that are taken after the starting player has been determined. Perform the actions listed in 103.2aâe in order, as applicable.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 103. Starting the Game : 103.2a
text: If any players are using sideboards (see rule 100.4) or cards being represented by substitute cards (see rule 713), those cards are set aside. After this happens, each playerâs deck is considered their starting deck.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 103. Starting the Game : 103.2b
text: If any players wish to reveal a card with a companion ability that they own from outside the game, they may do so. A player may reveal no more than one card this way, and they may do so only if their deck fulfills the condition of that cardâs companion ability. The revealed card remains outside the game. (See rule 702.139, âCompanion.â)

name: Comprehensive Rules: 103. Starting the Game : 103.2c
text: In a Commander game, each player puts their commander from their deck face up into the command zone. See rule 903.6.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 103. Starting the Game : 103.2d
text: In a constructed game, each player playing with sticker sheets reveals all of their sticker sheets and chooses three of them at random. In a limited game, each player chooses up to three sticker sheets from among those in the sealed product they opened and reveals them. In either case, that player has access to only the stickers on the chosen sheets during the game, and those sticker sheets remain revealed. (See rule 123, âStickers.â)

name: Comprehensive Rules: 103. Starting the Game : 103.2e
text: In a Conspiracy Draft game, each player puts any number of conspiracy cards from their sideboard into the command zone. See rule 905.4.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 103. Starting the Game : 103.3.
text: After the starting player has been determined and any additional steps performed, each player shuffles their deck so that the cards are in a random order. Each player may then shuffle or cut their opponentsâ decks. The playersâ decks become their libraries.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 103. Starting the Game : 103.3a
text: In a game using one or more supplementary decks of nontraditional cards (see rule 100.2d), each supplementary deckâs owner shuffles it so the cards are in a random order. Each player may then shuffle or cut their opponentsâ supplementary decks.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 103. Starting the Game : 103.4.
text: Each player begins the game with a starting life total of 20. Some variant games have different starting life totals.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 103. Starting the Game : 103.4a
text: In a Two-Headed Giant game, each teamâs starting life total is 30.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 103. Starting the Game : 103.4b
text: In a Vanguard game, each playerâs starting life total is 20 plus or minus the life modifier of their vanguard card.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 103. Starting the Game : 103.4c
text: In a Commander game, each playerâs starting life total is 40.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 103. Starting the Game : 103.4d
text: In a two-player Brawl game, each playerâs starting life total is 25. In a multiplayer Brawl game, each playerâs starting life total is 30.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 103. Starting the Game : 103.4e
text: In an Archenemy game, the archenemyâs starting life total is 40.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 103. Starting the Game : 103.5.
text: Each player draws a number of cards equal to their starting hand size, which is normally seven. (Some effects can modify a playerâs starting hand size.) A player who is dissatisfied with their initial hand may take a mulligan. First, the starting player declares whether they will take a mulligan. Then each other player in turn order does the same. Once each player has made a declaration, all players who decided to take mulligans do so at the same time. To take a mulligan, a player shuffles the cards in their hand back into their library, draws a new hand of cards equal to their starting hand size, then puts a number of those cards equal to the number of times that player has taken a mulligan on the bottom of their library in any order. Once a player chooses not to take a mulligan, the remaining cards become that playerâs opening hand, and that player may not take any further mulligans. This process is then repeated until no player takes a mulligan. A player can take mulligans until their opening hand would be zero cards, after which they may not take further mulligans.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 103. Starting the Game : 103.5a
text: In a Vanguard game, each playerâs starting hand size is seven plus or minus the hand modifier of their vanguard card.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 103. Starting the Game : 103.5b
text: If an effect allows a player to perform an action âany time [that player] could mulligan,â the player may perform that action at a time they would declare whether they will take a mulligan. This need not be in the first round of mulligans. Other players may have already made their mulligan declarations by the time the player has the option to perform this action. If the player performs the action, they then declare whether they will take a mulligan.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 103. Starting the Game : 103.5c
text: In a multiplayer game and in any Brawl game, the first mulligan a player takes doesnât count toward the number of cards that player will put on the bottom of their library or the number of mulligans that player may take. Subsequent mulligans are counted toward these numbers as normal.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 103. Starting the Game : 103.5d
text: In a multiplayer game using the shared team turns option, first each player on the starting team declares whether that player will take a mulligan, then the players on each other team in turn order do the same. Teammates may consult while making their decisions. Then all mulligans are taken at the same time. A player may take a mulligan even after a teammate has decided to keep their opening hand.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 103. Starting the Game : 103.6.
text: Some cards allow a player to take actions with them from their opening hand. Once the mulligan process (see rule 103.5) is complete, the starting player may take any such actions in any order. Then each other player in turn order may do the same.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 103. Starting the Game : 103.6a
text: If a card allows a player to begin the game with that card on the battlefield, the player taking this action puts that card onto the battlefield.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 103. Starting the Game : 103.6b
text: If a card allows a player to reveal it from their opening hand, the player taking this action does so. The card remains revealed until the first turn begins. Each card may be revealed this way only once.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 103. Starting the Game : 103.6c
text: In a multiplayer game using the shared team turns option, first each player on the starting team, in whatever order that team likes, may take such actions. Teammates may consult while making their decisions. Then each player on each other team in turn order does the same.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 103. Starting the Game : 103.7.
text: In a Planechase game, the starting player moves the top card of their planar deck off that planar deck and turns it face up. If itâs a phenomenon card, the player puts that card on the bottom of their planar deck and repeats this process until a plane card is turned face up. The face-up plane card becomes the starting plane. (See rule 901, âPlanechase.â)

name: Comprehensive Rules: 103. Starting the Game : 103.8.
text: The starting player takes their first turn.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 103. Starting the Game : 103.8a
text: In a two-player game, the player who plays first skips the draw step (see rule 504, âDraw Stepâ) of their first turn.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 103. Starting the Game : 103.8b
text: In a Two-Headed Giant game, the team who plays first skips the draw step of their first turn.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 103. Starting the Game : 103.8c
text: In all other multiplayer games, no player skips the draw step of their first turn.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 104. Ending the Game : 104.1.
text: A game ends immediately when a player wins, when the game is a draw, or when the game is restarted.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 104. Ending the Game : 104.2.
text: There are several ways to win the game.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 104. Ending the Game : 104.2a
text: A player still in the game wins the game if that playerâs opponents have all left the game. This happens immediately and overrides all effects that would preclude that player from winning the game.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 104. Ending the Game : 104.2b
text: An effect may state that a player wins the game.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 104. Ending the Game : 104.2c
text: In a multiplayer game between teams, a team with at least one player still in the game wins the game if all other teams have left the game. Each player on the winning team wins the game, even if one or more of those players had previously lost that game.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 104. Ending the Game : 104.2d
text: In an Emperor game, a team wins the game if its emperor wins the game. (See rule 809.5.)

name: Comprehensive Rules: 104. Ending the Game : 104.3.
text: There are several ways to lose the game.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 104. Ending the Game : 104.3a
text: A player can concede the game at any time. A player who concedes leaves the game immediately. That player loses the game.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 104. Ending the Game : 104.3b
text: If a playerâs life total is 0 or less, that player loses the game the next time a player would receive priority. (This is a state-based action. See rule 704.)

name: Comprehensive Rules: 104. Ending the Game : 104.3c
text: If a player is required to draw more cards than are left in their library, they draw the remaining cards and then lose the game the next time a player would receive priority. (This is a state-based action. See rule 704.)

name: Comprehensive Rules: 104. Ending the Game : 104.3d
text: If a player has ten or more poison counters, that player loses the game the next time a player would receive priority. (This is a state-based action. See rule 704.)

name: Comprehensive Rules: 104. Ending the Game : 104.3e
text: An effect may state that a player loses the game.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 104. Ending the Game : 104.3f
text: If a player would both win and lose the game simultaneously, that player loses the game.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 104. Ending the Game : 104.3g
text: In a multiplayer game between teams, a team loses the game if all players on that team have lost the game.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 104. Ending the Game : 104.3h
text: In a multiplayer game using the limited range of influence option (see rule 801), an effect that states that a player wins the game instead causes all of that playerâs opponents within the playerâs range of influence to lose the game. This may not cause the game to end.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 104. Ending the Game : 104.3i
text: In an Emperor game, a team loses the game if its emperor loses the game. (See rule 809.5.)

name: Comprehensive Rules: 104. Ending the Game : 104.3j
text: In a Commander game, a player whoâs been dealt 21 or more combat damage by the same commander over the course of the game loses the game. (This is a state-based action. See rule 704. See also rule 903.10.)

name: Comprehensive Rules: 104. Ending the Game : 104.3k
text: In a tournament, a player may lose the game as a result of a penalty given by a judge. See rule 100.6.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 104. Ending the Game : 104.4.
text: There are several ways for the game to be a draw.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 104. Ending the Game : 104.4a
text: If all the players remaining in a game lose simultaneously, the game is a draw.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 104. Ending the Game : 104.4b
text: If a game thatâs not using the limited range of influence option (including a two-player game) somehow enters a âloopâ of mandatory actions, repeating a sequence of events with no way to stop, the game is a draw. Loops that contain an optional action donât result in a draw.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 104. Ending the Game : 104.4c
text: An effect may state that the game is a draw.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 104. Ending the Game : 104.4d
text: In a multiplayer game between teams, the game is a draw if all remaining teams lose simultaneously.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 104. Ending the Game : 104.4e
text: In a multiplayer game using the limited range of influence option, the effect of a spell or ability that states that the game is a draw causes the game to be a draw for that spell or abilityâs controller and all players within their range of influence. Only those players leave the game; the game continues for all other players.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 104. Ending the Game : 104.4f
text: In a multiplayer game using the limited range of influence option, if the game somehow enters a âloopâ of mandatory actions, repeating a sequence of events with no way to stop, the game is a draw for each player who controls an object thatâs involved in that loop, as well as for each player within the range of influence of any of those players. Only those players leave the game; the game continues for all other players.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 104. Ending the Game : 104.4g
text: In a multiplayer game between teams, the game is a draw for a team if the game is a draw for all remaining players on that team.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 104. Ending the Game : 104.4h
text: In the Emperor variant, the game is a draw for a team if the game is a draw for its emperor. (See rule 809.5.)

name: Comprehensive Rules: 104. Ending the Game : 104.4i
text: In a tournament, all players in the game may agree to an intentional draw. See rule 100.6.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 104. Ending the Game : 104.5.
text: If a player loses the game, that player leaves the game. If the game is a draw for a player, that player leaves the game. The multiplayer rules handle what happens when a player leaves the game; see rule 800.4.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 104. Ending the Game : 104.6.
text: One card (Karn Liberated) restarts the game. All players still in the game when it restarts then immediately begin a new game. See rule 724, âRestarting the Game.â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 105. Colors : 105.1.
text: There are five colors in the Magic game: white, blue, black, red, and green.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 105. Colors : 105.2.
text: An object can be one or more of the five colors, or it can be no color at all. An object is the color or colors of the mana symbols in its mana cost, regardless of the color of its frame. An objectâs color or colors may also be defined by a color indicator or a characteristic-defining ability. See rule 202.2.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 105. Colors : 105.2a
text: A monocolored object is exactly one of the five colors.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 105. Colors : 105.2b
text: A multicolored object is two or more of the five colors.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 105. Colors : 105.2c
text: A colorless object has no color.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 105. Colors : 105.3.
text: Effects may change an objectâs color or give a color to a colorless object. If an effect gives an object a new color, the new color replaces all previous colors the object had (unless the effect said the object became that color âin additionâ to its other colors). Effects may also make a colored object become colorless.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 105. Colors : 105.4.
text: If a player is asked to choose a color, they must choose one of the five colors. âMulticoloredâ is not a color. Neither is âcolorless.â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 105. Colors : 105.5.
text: If an effect refers to a color pair, it means exactly two of the five colors. There are ten color pairs: white and blue, white and black, blue and black, blue and red, black and red, black and green, red and green, red and white, green and white, and green and blue.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 106. Mana : 106.1.
text: Mana is the primary resource in the game. Players spend mana to pay costs, usually when casting spells and activating abilities.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 106. Mana : 106.1a
text: There are five colors of mana: white, blue, black, red, and green.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 106. Mana : 106.1b
text: There are six types of mana: white, blue, black, red, green, and colorless.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 106. Mana : 106.2.
text: Mana is represented by mana symbols (see rule 107.4). Mana symbols also represent mana costs (see rule 202).

name: Comprehensive Rules: 106. Mana : 106.3.
text: Mana is produced by the effects of mana abilities (see rule 605). It may also be produced by the effects of spells, as well as by the effects of abilities that arenât mana abilities. A spell or ability that produces mana instructs a player to add that mana. If mana is produced by a spell, the source of that mana is that spell. If mana is produced by an ability, the source of that mana is the source of that ability (see rule 113.7).

name: Comprehensive Rules: 106. Mana : 106.4.
text: When an effect instructs a player to add mana, that mana goes into a playerâs mana pool. From there, it can be used to pay costs immediately, or it can stay in the playerâs mana pool as unspent mana. Each playerâs mana pool empties at the end of each step and phase, and the player is said to lose this mana. Cards with abilities that produce mana or refer to unspent mana have received errata in the Oracleâ¢ card reference to no longer explicitly refer to the mana pool.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 106. Mana : 106.4a
text: If any mana remains in a playerâs mana pool after mana is spent to pay a cost, that player announces what mana is still there.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 106. Mana : 106.4b
text: If a player passes priority (see rule 117) while there is mana in their mana pool, that player announces what mana is there.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 106. Mana : 106.5.
text: If an ability would produce one or more mana of an undefined type, it produces no mana instead.

name: Example for Rule : 106.5.
text: Meteor Crater has the ability â{T}: Choose a color of a permanent you control. Add one mana of that color.â If you control no colored permanents, activating Meteor Craterâs mana ability produces no mana.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 106. Mana : 106.6.
text: Some spells or abilities that produce mana restrict how that mana can be spent, have an additional effect that affects the spell or ability that mana is spent on, or create a delayed triggered ability (see rule 603.7a) that triggers when that mana is spent. This doesnât affect the manaâs type.

name: Example for Rule : 106.6.
text: A playerâs mana pool contains {R}{G} which can be spent only to cast creature spells. That player activates Doubling Cubeâs ability, which reads â{3}, {T}: Double the amount of each type of unspent mana you have.â The playerâs mana pool now has {R}{R}{G}{G} in it, {R}{G} of which can be spent on anything.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 106. Mana : 106.6a
text: Some replacement effects increase the amount of mana produced by a spell or ability. In these cases, any restrictions or additional effects created by the spell or ability will apply to all mana produced. If the spell or ability creates a delayed triggered ability that triggers when the mana is spent, a separate delayed triggered ability is created for each mana produced. If the spell or ability creates a continuous effect or replacement effect if the mana is spent, a separate effect is created once for each mana produced.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 106. Mana : 106.7.
text: Some abilities produce mana based on the type of mana another permanent or permanents âcould produce.â The type of mana a permanent could produce at any time includes any type of mana that an ability of that permanent would produce if the ability were to resolve at that time, taking into account any applicable replacement effects in any possible order. Ignore whether any costs of the ability could or could not be paid. If that permanent wouldnât produce any mana under these conditions, or no type of mana can be defined this way, thereâs no type of mana it could produce.

name: Example for Rule : 106.7.
text: Exotic Orchard has the ability â{T}: Add one mana of any color that a land an opponent controls could produce.â If your opponent controls no lands, activating Exotic Orchardâs mana ability will produce no mana. The same is true if you and your opponent each control no lands other than Exotic Orchards. However, if you control a Forest and an Exotic Orchard, and your opponent controls an Exotic Orchard, then each Exotic Orchard could produce {G}.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 106. Mana : 106.8.
text: If an effect would add mana represented by a hybrid mana symbol to a playerâs mana pool, that player chooses one half of that symbol. If a colored half is chosen, one mana of that color is added to that playerâs mana pool. If a generic half is chosen, an amount of colorless mana represented by that halfâs number is added to that playerâs mana pool.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 106. Mana : 106.9.
text: If an effect would add mana represented by a Phyrexian mana symbol to a playerâs mana pool, one mana of the color of that symbol is added to that playerâs mana pool.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 106. Mana : 106.10.
text: If an effect would add mana represented by a generic mana symbol to a playerâs mana pool, that much colorless mana is added to that playerâs mana pool.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 106. Mana : 106.11.
text: If an effect would add mana represented by one or more snow mana symbols to a playerâs mana pool, that much colorless mana is added to that playerâs mana pool.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 106. Mana : 106.12.
text: To âtap [a permanent] for manaâ is to activate a mana ability of that permanent that includes the {T} symbol in its activation cost. See rule 605, âMana Abilities.â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 106. Mana : 106.12a
text: An ability that triggers whenever a permanent âis tapped for manaâ or is tapped for mana of a specified type triggers whenever such a mana ability resolves and produces mana or the specified type of mana.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 106. Mana : 106.12b
text: A replacement effect that applies if a permanent âis tapped for manaâ or tapped for mana of a specific type and/or amount modifies the mana production event while such an ability is resolving and producing mana or the specified type and/or amount of mana.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 106. Mana : 106.13.
text: One card (Drain Power) causes one player to lose unspent mana and another to add âthe mana lost this way.â (Note that these may be the same player.) This empties the former playerâs mana pool and causes the mana emptied this way to be put into the latter playerâs mana pool. Which permanents, spells, and/or abilities produced that mana are unchanged, as are any restrictions or additional effects associated with any of that mana.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 107. Numbers and Symbols : 107.1.
text: The only numbers the Magic game uses are integers.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 107. Numbers and Symbols : 107.1a
text: You canât choose a fractional number, deal fractional damage, gain fractional life, and so on. If a spell or ability could generate a fractional number, the spell or ability will tell you whether to round up or down.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 107. Numbers and Symbols : 107.1b
text: Most of the time, the Magic game uses only positive numbers and zero. You canât choose a negative number, deal negative damage, gain negative life, and so on. However, itâs possible for a game value, such as a creatureâs power, to be less than zero. If a calculation or comparison needs to use a negative value, it does so. If a calculation that would determine the result of an effect yields a negative number, zero is used instead, unless that effect doubles or sets to a specific value a playerâs life total or the power and/or toughness of a creature or creature card.

name: Example for Rule : 107.1b
text: If a 3/4 creature gets -5/-0, itâs a -2/4 creature. It doesnât assign damage in combat. Its total power and toughness is 2. Giving it +3/+0 would raise its power to 1.

name: Example for Rule : 107.1b
text: Viridian Joiner is a 1/2 creature with the ability â{T}: Add an amount of {G} equal to Viridian Joinerâs power.â An effect gives it -2/-0, then its ability is activated. The ability adds no mana to your mana pool.

name: Example for Rule : 107.1b
text: Chameleon Colossus is a 4/4 creature with the ability â{2}{G}{G}: Chameleon Colossus gets +X/+X until end of turn, where X is its power.â An effect gives it -6/-0, then its ability is activated. It remains a -2/4 creature. It doesnât become -4/2.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 107. Numbers and Symbols : 107.1c
text: If a rule or ability instructs a player to choose âany number,â that player may choose any positive number or zero.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 107. Numbers and Symbols : 107.2.
text: If anything needs to use a number that canât be determined, either as a result or in a calculation, it uses 0 instead.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 107. Numbers and Symbols : 107.3.
text: Many objects use the letter X as a placeholder for a number that needs to be determined. Some objects have abilities that define the value of X; the rest let their controller choose the value of X.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 107. Numbers and Symbols : 107.3a
text: If a spell or activated ability has a mana cost, alternative cost, additional cost, and/or activation cost with an {X}, [-X], or X in it, and the value of X isnât defined by the text of that spell or ability, the controller of that spell or ability chooses and announces the value of X as part of casting the spell or activating the ability. (See rule 601, âCasting Spells.â) While a spell is on the stack, any X in its mana cost or in any alternative cost or additional cost it has equals the announced value. While an activated ability is on the stack, any X in its activation cost equals the announced value.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 107. Numbers and Symbols : 107.3b
text: If a player is casting a spell that has an {X} in its mana cost, the value of X isnât defined by the text of that spell, and an effect lets that player cast that spell while paying neither its mana cost nor an alternative cost that includes X, then the only legal choice for X is 0. This doesnât apply to effects that only reduce a cost, even if they reduce it to zero. See rule 601, âCasting Spells.â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 107. Numbers and Symbols : 107.3c
text: If a spell or activated ability has an {X}, [-X], or X in its cost and/or its text, and the value of X is defined by the text of that spell or ability, then thatâs the value of X while that spell or ability is on the stack. The controller of that spell or ability doesnât get to choose the value. Note that the value of X may change while that spell or ability is on the stack.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 107. Numbers and Symbols : 107.3d
text: If a cost associated with a special action, such as a suspend cost or a morph cost, has an {X} or an X in it, the value of X is chosen by the player taking the special action immediately before they pay that cost.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 107. Numbers and Symbols : 107.3e
text: If a spell or ability refers to the {X} or X in the mana cost, alternative cost, additional cost, or activation cost of another object, any X in that spell or abilityâs text uses the value of X chosen or defined for the other object.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 107. Numbers and Symbols : 107.3f
text: Sometimes X appears in the text of a spell or ability but not in a mana cost, alternative cost, additional cost, or activation cost. If the value of X isnât defined, the controller of the spell or ability chooses the value of X at the appropriate time (either as itâs put on the stack or as it resolves).

name: Comprehensive Rules: 107. Numbers and Symbols : 107.3g
text: If a card in any zone other than the stack has an {X} in its mana cost, the value of {X} is treated as 0, even if the value of X is defined somewhere within its text.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 107. Numbers and Symbols : 107.3h
text: If an effect instructs a player to pay an objectâs mana cost that includes {X}, the value of X is treated as 0 unless the object is a spell on the stack. In that case, the value of X is the value chosen or determined for it as the spell was cast.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 107. Numbers and Symbols : 107.3i
text: Normally, all instances of X on an object have the same value at any given time.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 107. Numbers and Symbols : 107.3j
text: If an object gains an ability, the value of X within that ability is the value defined by that ability, or 0 if that ability doesnât define a value of X. This is an exception to rule 107.3i. This may occur with ability-adding effects, text-changing effects, or copy effects.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 107. Numbers and Symbols : 107.3k
text: If an objectâs activated ability has an {X}, [-X], or X in its activation cost, the value of X for that ability is independent of any other values of X chosen for that object or for other instances of abilities of that object. This is an exception to rule 107.3i.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 107. Numbers and Symbols : 107.3m
text: If an objectâs enters-the-battlefield triggered ability or replacement effect refers to X, and the spell that became that object as it resolved had a value of X chosen for any of its costs, the value of X for that ability is the same as the value of X for that spell, although the value of X for that permanent is 0. This is an exception to rule 107.3i.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 107. Numbers and Symbols : 107.3n
text: If a delayed triggered ability created by a resolving spell or ability refers to X, X is not defined in the text of that triggered ability, and the spell or ability that created it had a value of X chosen for any of its costs, the value of X for the triggered ability is the same as the value of X for the spell of ability that created it.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 107. Numbers and Symbols : 107.3p
text: Some objects use the letter Y in addition to the letter X. Y follows the same rules as X.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 107. Numbers and Symbols : 107.4.
text: The mana symbols are {W}, {U}, {B}, {R}, {G}, and {C}; the numerical symbols {0}, {1}, {2}, {3}, {4}, and so on; the variable symbol {X}; the hybrid symbols {W/U}, {W/B}, {U/B}, {U/R}, {B/R}, {B/G}, {R/G}, {R/W}, {G/W}, and {G/U}; the monocolored hybrid symbols {2/W}, {2/U}, {2/B}, {2/R}, and {2/G}; the Phyrexian mana symbols {W/P}, {U/P}, {B/P}, {R/P}, and {G/P}; the hybrid Phyrexian symbols {W/U/P}, {W/B/P}, {U/B/P}, {U/R/P}, {B/R/P}, {B/G/P}, {R/G/P}, {R/W/P}, {G/W/P}, and {G/U/P}; and the snow mana symbol {S}.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 107. Numbers and Symbols : 107.4a
text: There are five primary colored mana symbols: {W} is white, {U} blue, {B} black, {R} red, and {G} green. These symbols are used to represent colored mana, and also to represent colored mana in costs. Colored mana in costs can be paid only with the appropriate color of mana. See rule 202, âMana Cost and Color.â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 107. Numbers and Symbols : 107.4b
text: Numerical symbols (such as {1}) and variable symbols (such as {X}) represent generic mana in costs. Generic mana in costs can be paid with any type of mana. For more information about {X}, see rule 107.3.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 107. Numbers and Symbols : 107.4c
text: The colorless mana symbol {C} is used to represent one colorless mana, and also to represent a cost that can be paid only with one colorless mana.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 107. Numbers and Symbols : 107.4d
text: The symbol {0} represents zero mana and is used as a placeholder for a cost that can be paid with no resources. (See rule 118.5.)

name: Comprehensive Rules: 107. Numbers and Symbols : 107.4e
text: Hybrid mana symbols are also colored mana symbols. Each one represents a cost that can be paid in one of two ways, as represented by the two halves of the symbol. A hybrid symbol such as {W/U} can be paid with either white or blue mana, and a monocolored hybrid symbol such as {2/B} can be paid with either one black mana or two mana of any type. A hybrid mana symbol is all of its component colors.

name: Example for Rule : 107.4e
text: {G/W}{G/W} can be paid by spending {G}{G}, {G}{W}, or {W}{W}.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 107. Numbers and Symbols : 107.4f
text: Phyrexian mana symbols are colored mana symbols: {W/P} is white, {U/P} is blue, {B/P} is black, {R/P} is red, and {G/P} is green. A Phyrexian mana symbol represents a cost that can be paid either with one mana of its color or by paying 2 life. There are also ten hybrid Phyrexian mana symbols. A hybrid Phyrexian mana symbol represents a cost that can be paid with one mana of either of its component colors or by paying 2 life. A hybrid Phyrexian mana symbol is both of its component colors.

name: Example for Rule : 107.4f
text: {W/P}{W/P} can be paid by spending {W}{W}, by spending {W} and paying 2 life, or by paying 4 life.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 107. Numbers and Symbols : 107.4g
text: In rules text, the Phyrexian symbol {P} with no colored background means any of the fifteen Phyrexian mana symbols.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 107. Numbers and Symbols : 107.4h
text: When used in a cost, the snow mana symbol {S} represents a cost that can be paid with one mana of any type produced by a snow source (see rule 106.3). Effects that reduce the amount of generic mana you pay donât affect {S} costs. The {S} symbol can also be used to refer to mana of any type produced by a snow source spent to pay a cost. Snow is neither a color nor a type of mana.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 107. Numbers and Symbols : 107.5.
text: The tap symbol is {T}. The tap symbol in an activation cost means âTap this permanent.â A permanent thatâs already tapped canât be tapped again to pay the cost. A creatureâs activated ability with the tap symbol in its activation cost canât be activated unless the creature has been under its controllerâs control continuously since their most recent turn began. See rule 302.6.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 107. Numbers and Symbols : 107.6.
text: The untap symbol is {Q}. The untap symbol in an activation cost means âUntap this permanent.â A permanent thatâs already untapped canât be untapped again to pay the cost. A creatureâs activated ability with the untap symbol in its activation cost canât be activated unless the creature has been under its controllerâs control continuously since their most recent turn began. See rule 302.6.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 107. Numbers and Symbols : 107.7.
text: Each activated ability of a planeswalker has a loyalty symbol in its cost. Positive loyalty symbols point upward and feature a plus sign followed by a number. Negative loyalty symbols point downward and feature a minus sign followed by a number or an X. Neutral loyalty symbols donât point in either direction and feature a 0. [+N] means âPut N loyalty counters on this permanent,â [-N] means âRemove N loyalty counters from this permanent,â and [0] means âPut zero loyalty counters on this permanent.â Loyalty symbols may also appear in abilities that modify loyalty costs.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 107. Numbers and Symbols : 107.8.
text: The text box of a leveler card contains two level symbols, each of which is a keyword ability that represents a static ability. The level symbol includes either a range of numbers, indicated here as âN1-N2,â or a single number followed by a plus sign, indicated here as âN3+.â Any abilities printed within the same text box striation as a level symbol are part of its static ability. The same is true of the power/toughness box printed within that striation, indicated here as â[P/T].â See rule 711, âLeveler Cards.â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 107. Numbers and Symbols : 107.8a
text: â{LEVEL N1-N2} [Abilities] [P/T]â means âAs long as this creature has at least N1 level counters on it, but no more than N2 level counters on it, it has base power and toughness [P/T] and has [abilities].â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 107. Numbers and Symbols : 107.8b
text: â{LEVEL N3+} [Abilities] [P/T]â means âAs long as this creature has N3 or more level counters on it, it has base power and toughness [P/T] and has [abilities].â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 107. Numbers and Symbols : 107.9.
text: A tombstone icon appears to the left of the name of many Odysseyâ¢ block cards with abilities that are relevant in a playerâs graveyard. The purpose of the icon is to make those cards stand out when theyâre in a graveyard. This icon has no effect on game play.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 107. Numbers and Symbols : 107.10.
text: A type icon appears in the upper left corner of each card from the Future Sightâ¢ set printed with an alternate âtimeshiftedâ frame. If the card has a single card type, this icon indicates what it is: claw marks for creature, a flame for sorcery, a lightning bolt for instant, a sunrise for enchantment, a chalice for artifact, and a pair of mountain peaks for land. If the card has multiple card types, thatâs indicated by a black and white cross. This icon has no effect on game play.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 107. Numbers and Symbols : 107.11.
text: The Planeswalker symbol is {PW}. It appears on one face of the planar die used in the Planechase casual variant. It has five tines at the top and tapers to a point at the bottom. See rule 901, âPlanechase.â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 107. Numbers and Symbols : 107.12.
text: The chaos symbol is {CHAOS}. It appears on one face of the planar die used in the Planechase casual variant, as well as in abilities that refer to the results of rolling the planar die. It looks like a swirling vortex. See rule 901, âPlanechase.â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 107. Numbers and Symbols : 107.13.
text: A color indicator is a circular symbol that appears to the left of the type line on some cards. The color of the symbol defines the cardâs color or colors. See rule 202, âMana Cost and Color.â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 107. Numbers and Symbols : 107.14.
text: The energy symbol is {E}. It represents one energy counter. To pay {E}, a player removes one energy counter from themselves.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 107. Numbers and Symbols : 107.15.
text: The text box of a Saga card contains chapter symbols, each of which is a keyword ability that represents a triggered ability. A chapter symbol includes a Roman numeral, indicated here as ârNâ. The text printed in the text box striation to the right of a chapter symbol is the effect of the triggered ability it represents. See rule 714, âSaga Cards.â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 107. Numbers and Symbols : 107.15a
text: â{rN}â[Effect]â means âWhen one or more lore counters are put onto this Saga, if the number of lore counters on it was less than N and became at least N, [effect].â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 107. Numbers and Symbols : 107.15b
text: â{rN1}, {rN2}â[Effect]â is the same as â{rN1}â[Effect]â and â{rN2}â[Effect].â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 107. Numbers and Symbols : 107.16.
text: The text box of a Class card contains class level bars, each of which is a keyword ability that represents both an activated ability and a static ability. A class level bar includes the activation cost of its activated ability and a level number. Any abilities printed within the same text box section as the class level bar are part of its static ability. See rule 716, âClass Cards.â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 107. Numbers and Symbols : 107.16a
text: â[Cost]: Level N â [Abilities]â means â[Cost]: This Classâs level becomes N. Activate only if this Class is level N-1 and only as a sorceryâ and âAs long as this Class is level N or greater, it has [abilities].â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 107. Numbers and Symbols : 107.17.
text: The ticket symbol is {TK}. It represents one ticket counter.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 107. Numbers and Symbols : 107.17a
text: A ticket symbol with a number inside it represents a ticket cost. To pay that cost, a player removes that many ticket counters from themselves.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 108. Cards : 108.1.
text: Use the Oracle card reference when determining a cardâs wording. A cardâs Oracle text can be found using the Gatherer card database at Gatherer.Wizards.com.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 108. Cards : 108.2.
text: When a rule or text on a card refers to a âcard,â it means only a Magic card or an object represented by a Magic card.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 108. Cards : 108.2a
text: Most Magic games use only traditional Magic cards, which measure approximately 2.5 inches (6.3 cm) by 3.5 inches (8.8 cm). Traditional Magic cards are included in playersâ decks. Certain formats also use nontraditional Magic cards. Nontraditional Magic cards are not included in playersâ decks. They may be used in supplementary decks. Additionally, they may be oversized, have different card backs, or both.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 108. Cards : 108.2b
text: Tokens arenât considered cardsâeven a card-sized game supplement that represents a token isnât considered a card for rules purposes.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 108. Cards : 108.3.
text: The owner of a card in the game is the player who started the game with it in their deck. If a card is brought into the game from outside the game rather than starting in a playerâs deck, its owner is the player who brought it into the game. If a card starts the game in the command zone, its owner is the player who put it into the command zone to start the game. Legal ownership of a card in the game is irrelevant to the game rules except for the rules for ante. (See rule 407.)

name: Comprehensive Rules: 108. Cards : 108.3a
text: In a Planechase game using the single planar deck option, the planar controller is considered to be the owner of all cards in the planar deck. See rule 901.6.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 108. Cards : 108.3b
text: Some spells and abilities allow a player to take cards they own from outside the game and bring them into the game. (See rule 400.11b.) If a card outside that game is involved in a Magic game, its owner is determined as described in rule 108.3. If a card outside that game is in the sideboard of a Magic game (see rule 100.4), its owner is considered to be the player who started the game with it in their sideboard. In all other cases, the owner of a card outside the game is its legal owner.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 108. Cards : 108.4.
text: A card doesnât have a controller unless that card represents a permanent or spell; in those cases, its controller is determined by the rules for permanents or spells. See rules 110.2 and 112.2.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 108. Cards : 108.4a
text: If anything asks for the controller of a card that doesnât have one (because itâs not a permanent or spell), use its owner instead.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 108. Cards : 108.5.
text: Nontraditional Magic cards canât start the game in any zone other than the command zone (see rule 408). If an effect would bring a nontraditional Magic card other than a dungeon card (see rule 309, âDungeonsâ) into the game from outside the game, it doesnât; that card remains outside the game.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 108. Cards : 108.6.
text: For more information about cards, see section 2, âParts of a Card.â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 109. Objects : 109.1.
text: An object is an ability on the stack, a card, a copy of a card, a token, a spell, a permanent, or an emblem.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 109. Objects : 109.2.
text: If a spell or ability uses a description of an object that includes a card type or subtype, but doesnât refer to a specific zone or include the word âcard,â âspell,â âsource,â or âscheme,â it means a permanent of that card type or subtype on the battlefield.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 109. Objects : 109.2a
text: If a spell or ability uses a description of an object that includes the word âcardâ and the name of a zone, it means a card matching that description in the stated zone.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 109. Objects : 109.2b
text: If a spell or ability uses a description of an object that includes the word âspell,â it means a spell matching that description on the stack.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 109. Objects : 109.2c
text: If a spell or ability uses a description of an object that includes the word âsource,â it means a source matching that descriptionâa source of an ability, of damage, or of manaâin any zone. See rules 113.7 and 609.7.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 109. Objects : 109.2d
text: If an ability of a scheme card includes the text âthis scheme,â it means the scheme card in the command zone on which that ability is printed.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 109. Objects : 109.3.
text: An objectâs characteristics are name, mana cost, color, color indicator, card type, subtype, supertype, rules text, abilities, power, toughness, loyalty, defense, hand modifier, and life modifier. Objects can have some or all of these characteristics. Any other information about an object isnât a characteristic. For example, characteristics donât include whether a permanent is tapped, a spellâs target, an objectâs owner or controller, what an Aura enchants, and so on.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 109. Objects : 109.4.
text: Only objects on the stack or on the battlefield have a controller. Objects that are neither on the stack nor on the battlefield arenât controlled by any player. See rule 108.4. There are six exceptions to this rule:

name: Comprehensive Rules: 109. Objects : 109.4a
text: The controller of a mana ability is determined as though it were on the stack. See rule 605, âMana Abilities.â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 109. Objects : 109.4b
text: A triggered ability that has triggered but is waiting to be placed on the stack is controlled by the player who controlled its source at the time it triggered, unless itâs a delayed triggered ability. To determine the controller of a delayed triggered ability, see rules 603.7dâf. See also rule 603, âHandling Triggered Abilities.â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 109. Objects : 109.4c
text: An emblem is controlled by the player who puts it into the command zone. See rule 114, âEmblems.â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 109. Objects : 109.4d
text: In a Planechase game, a face-up plane or phenomenon card is controlled by the player designated as the planar controller. This is usually the active player. See rule 901.6.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 109. Objects : 109.4e
text: In a Vanguard game, each vanguard card is controlled by its owner. See rule 902.6.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 109. Objects : 109.4f
text: In an Archenemy game, each scheme card is controlled by its owner. See rule 904.7.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 109. Objects : 109.4g
text: In a Conspiracy Draft game, each conspiracy card is controlled by its owner. See rule 905.5.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 109. Objects : 109.5.
text: The words âyouâ and âyourâ on an object refer to the objectâs controller, its would-be controller (if a player is attempting to play, cast, or activate it), or its owner (if it has no controller). For a static ability, this is the current controller of the object itâs on. For an activated ability, this is the player who activated the ability. For a triggered ability, this is the controller of the object when the ability triggered, unless itâs a delayed triggered ability. To determine the controller of a delayed triggered ability, see rules 603.7dâf.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 110. Permanents : 110.1.
text: A permanent is a card or token on the battlefield. A permanent remains on the battlefield indefinitely. A card or token becomes a permanent as it enters the battlefield and it stops being a permanent as itâs moved to another zone by an effect or rule.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 110. Permanents : 110.2.
text: A permanentâs owner is the same as the owner of the card that represents it (unless itâs a token; see rule 111.2). A permanentâs controller is, by default, the player under whose control it entered the battlefield. Every permanent has a controller.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 110. Permanents : 110.2a
text: If an effect instructs a player to put an object onto the battlefield, that object enters the battlefield under that playerâs control unless the effect states otherwise.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 110. Permanents : 110.2b
text: If an effect causes a player to gain control of another playerâs permanent spell, the first player controls the permanent that spell becomes, but the permanentâs controller by default is the player who put that spell onto the stack. (This distinction is relevant in multiplayer games; see rule 800.4c.)

name: Comprehensive Rules: 110. Permanents : 110.3.
text: A nontoken permanentâs characteristics are the same as those printed on its card, as modified by any continuous effects. See rule 613, âInteraction of Continuous Effects.â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 110. Permanents : 110.4.
text: There are six permanent types: artifact, battle, creature, enchantment, land, and planeswalker. Instant and sorcery cards canât enter the battlefield and thus canât be permanents. Some tribal cards can enter the battlefield and some canât, depending on their other card types. See section 3, âCard Types.â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 110. Permanents : 110.4a
text: The term âpermanent cardâ is used to refer to a card that could be put onto the battlefield. Specifically, it means an artifact, battle, creature, enchantment, land, or planeswalker card.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 110. Permanents : 110.4b
text: The term âpermanent spellâ is used to refer to a spell that will enter the battlefield as a permanent as part of its resolution. Specifically, it means an artifact, battle, creature, enchantment, or planeswalker spell.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 110. Permanents : 110.4c
text: If a permanent somehow loses all its permanent types, it remains on the battlefield. Itâs still a permanent.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 110. Permanents : 110.5.
text: A permanentâs status is its physical state. There are four status categories, each of which has two possible values: tapped/untapped, flipped/unflipped, face up/face down, and phased in/phased out. Each permanent always has one of these values for each of these categories.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 110. Permanents : 110.5a
text: Status is not a characteristic, though it may affect a permanentâs characteristics.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 110. Permanents : 110.5b
text: Permanents enter the battlefield untapped, unflipped, face up, and phased in unless a spell or ability says otherwise.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 110. Permanents : 110.5c
text: A permanent retains its status until a spell, ability, or turn-based action changes it, even if that status is not relevant to it.

name: Example for Rule : 110.5c
text: Dimir Doppelganger says â{1}{U}{B}: Exile target creature card from a graveyard. Dimir Doppelganger becomes a copy of that card and gains this ability.â It becomes a copy of Jushi Apprentice, a flip card. Through use of Jushi Apprenticeâs ability, this creature flips, making it a copy of Tomoya the Revealer with the Dimir Doppelganger ability. If this permanent then becomes a copy of Runeclaw Bear, it will retain its flipped status even though that has no relevance to Runeclaw Bear. If its copy ability is activated again, this time targeting a Nezumi Shortfang card (another flip card), this permanentâs flipped status means it will have the characteristics of Stabwhisker the Odious (the flipped version of Nezumi Shortfang) with the Dimir Doppelganger ability.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 110. Permanents : 110.5d
text: Only permanents have status. Cards not on the battlefield do not. Although an exiled card may be face down, this has no correlation to the face-down status of a permanent. Similarly, cards not on the battlefield are neither tapped nor untapped, regardless of their physical state.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 111. Tokens : 111.1.
text: Some effects put tokens onto the battlefield. A token is a marker used to represent any permanent that isnât represented by a card.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 111. Tokens : 111.2.
text: The player who creates a token is its owner. The token enters the battlefield under that playerâs control.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 111. Tokens : 111.3.
text: The spell or ability that creates a token may define the values of any number of characteristics for the token. This becomes the tokenâs âtext.â The characteristic values defined this way are functionally equivalent to the characteristic values that are printed on a card; for example, they define the tokenâs copiable values. A token doesnât have any characteristics not defined by the spell or ability that created it.

name: Example for Rule : 111.3.
text: Jade Mage has the ability â{2}{G}: Create a 1/1 green Saproling creature token.â The resulting token has no mana cost, supertypes, rules text, or abilities.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 111. Tokens : 111.4.
text: A spell or ability that creates a token sets both its name and its subtype(s). If the spell or ability doesnât specify the name of the token, its name is the same as its subtype(s) plus the word âToken.â Once a token is on the battlefield, changing its name doesnât change its subtype(s), and vice versa.

name: Example for Rule : 111.4.
text: Dwarven Reinforcements is a sorcery that says, in part, âCreate two 2/1 red Dwarf Berserker creature tokens.â The tokens created as it resolves are each named Dwarf Berserker Token and each have the creature types Dwarf and Berserker.

name: Example for Rule : 111.4.
text: Minsc, Beloved Ranger says, in part, âWhen Minsc, Beloved Ranger enters the battlefield, create Boo, a legendary 1/1 red Hamster creature token with trample and haste.â That tokenâs subtype is Hamster, but because Minsc specifies that the tokenâs name is Boo, neither âHamsterâ nor âTokenâ are part of its name.

name: Example for Rule : 111.4.
text: Spitting Image is a sorcery that says, in part, âCreate a token thatâs a copy of target creature.â All of that tokenâs characteristics will match the copiable characteristics of the creature targeted by that spell. If Spitting Image targets Doomed Dissenter, a Human creature, the name of the token the spell creates will be Doomed Dissenter, not Human Token or Doomed Dissenter Token.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 111. Tokens : 111.5.
text: If a spell or ability would create a token, but a rule or effect states that a permanent with one or more of that tokenâs characteristics canât enter the battlefield, the token is not created. Similarly, if an effect would create a token that is a copy of an instant or sorcery card, no token is created.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 111. Tokens : 111.6.
text: A token is subject to anything that affects permanents in general or that affects the tokenâs card type or subtype. A token isnât a card (even if represented by a card that has a Magic back or that came from a Magic booster pack).

name: Comprehensive Rules: 111. Tokens : 111.7.
text: A token thatâs in a zone other than the battlefield ceases to exist. This is a state-based action; see rule 704. (Note that if a token changes zones, applicable triggered abilities will trigger before the token ceases to exist.)

name: Comprehensive Rules: 111. Tokens : 111.8.
text: A token that has left the battlefield canât move to another zone or come back onto the battlefield. If such a token would change zones, it remains in its current zone instead. It ceases to exist the next time state-based actions are checked; see rule 704.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 111. Tokens : 111.9.
text: Some effects instruct a player to create a legendary token. These may be written âcreate [name], a . . .â and list characteristics for the token. This is the same as an instruction to create a token with the listed characteristics that has the given name.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 111. Tokens : 111.10.
text: Some effects instruct a player to create a predefined token. These effects use the definition below to determine the characteristics the token is created with. The effect that creates a predefined token may also modify or add to the predefined characteristics.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 111. Tokens : 111.10a
text: A Treasure token is a colorless Treasure artifact token with â{T}, Sacrifice this artifact: Add one mana of any color.â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 111. Tokens : 111.10b
text: A Food token is a colorless Food artifact token with â{2}, {T}, Sacrifice this artifact: You gain 3 life.â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 111. Tokens : 111.10c
text: A Gold token is a colorless Gold artifact token with âSacrifice this artifact: Add one mana of any color.â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 111. Tokens : 111.10d
text: A Walker token is a 2/2 black Zombie creature token named Walker.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 111. Tokens : 111.10e
text: A Shard token is a colorless Shard enchantment token with â{2}, Sacrifice this enchantment: Scry 1, then draw a card.â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 111. Tokens : 111.10f
text: A Clue token is a colorless Clue artifact token with â{2}, Sacrifice this artifact: Draw a card.â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 111. Tokens : 111.10g
text: A Blood token is a colorless Blood artifact token with â{1}, {T}, Discard a card, Sacrifice this artifact: Draw a card.â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 111. Tokens : 111.10h
text: A Powerstone token is a colorless Powerstone artifact token with â{T}: Add {C}. This mana canât be spent to cast a nonartifact spell.â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 111. Tokens : 111.10i
text: An Incubator token is a transforming double-faced token. Its front face is a colorless Incubator artifact with â{2}: Transform this artifact.â Its back face is a 0/0 colorless Phyrexian artifact creature named Phyrexian Token.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 111. Tokens : 111.10j
text: A Cursed Role token is a colorless Aura Role enchantment token named Cursed with enchant creature and âEnchanted creature has base power and toughness 1/1.â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 111. Tokens : 111.10k
text: A Monster Role token is a colorless Aura Role enchantment token named Monster with enchant creature and âEnchanted creature gets +1/+1 and has trample.â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 111. Tokens : 111.10m
text: A Royal Role token is a colorless Aura Role enchantment token named Royal with enchant creature and âEnchanted creature gets +1/+1 and has ward {1}.â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 111. Tokens : 111.10n
text: A Sorcerer Role token is a colorless Aura Role enchantment token named Sorcerer with enchant creature and âEnchanted creature gets +1/+1 and has âWhenever this creature attacks, scry 1.ââ

name: Comprehensive Rules: 111. Tokens : 111.10p
text: A Virtuous Role token is a colorless Aura Role enchantment token named Virtuous with enchant creature and âEnchanted creature gets +1/+1 for each enchantment you control.â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 111. Tokens : 111.10q
text: A Wicked Role token is a colorless Aura Role enchantment token named Wicked with enchant creature, âEnchanted creature gets +1/+1,â and âWhen this Aura is put into a graveyard from the battlefield, each opponent loses 1 life.â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 111. Tokens : 111.10r
text: A Young Hero Role token is a colorless Aura Role enchantment token named Young Hero with enchant creature and âEnchanted creature has âWhenever this creature attacks, if its toughness is 3 or less, put a +1/+1 counter on it.ââ

name: Comprehensive Rules: 111. Tokens : 111.10s
text: A Map token is a colorless Map artifact token with â{1}, {T}, Sacrifice this artifact: Target creature you control explores. Activate only as a sorcery.â See rule 701.40, âExplore.â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 111. Tokens : 111.11.
text: If an effect instructs a player to create a token that is a copy of a nonexistent object, no token is created (see rule 707, âCopying Objectsâ). This does not apply to an effect that would use the last known information of an object.

name: Example for Rule : 111.11.
text: Mimic Vat has a triggered ability whose effect gives you the option to exile a card and an activated ability that says âCreate a token thatâs a copy of a card exiled with Mimic Vat. It gains haste. Exile it at the beginning of the next end step.â If no card has been exiled with Mimic Vatâs triggered ability, no token is created.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 111. Tokens : 111.12.
text: A copy of a permanent spell becomes a token as it resolves. The token has the characteristics of the spell that became that token. The token is not âcreatedâ for the purposes of any replacement effects or triggered abilities that refer to creating a token.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 112. Spells : 112.1.
text: A spell is a card on the stack. As the first step of being cast (see rule 601, âCasting Spellsâ), the card becomes a spell and is moved to the top of the stack from the zone it was in, which is usually its ownerâs hand. (See rule 405, âStack.â) A spell remains on the stack as a spell until it resolves (see rule 608, âResolving Spells and Abilitiesâ), is countered (see rule 701.5), or otherwise leaves the stack. For more information, see section 6, âSpells, Abilities, and Effects.â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 112. Spells : 112.1a
text: A copy of a spell is also a spell, even if it has no card associated with it. See rule 707.10.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 112. Spells : 112.1b
text: Some effects allow a player to cast a copy of a card; if the player does, that copy is a spell as well. See rule 707.12.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 112. Spells : 112.2.
text: A spellâs owner is the same as the owner of the card that represents it, unless itâs a copy. In that case, the owner of the spell is the player under whose control it was put on the stack. A spellâs controller is, by default, the player who put it on the stack. Every spell has a controller.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 112. Spells : 112.2a
text: Some effects instruct a player to create a copy of a card and say they may cast it. In that case, the owner of that copy is the player who is instructed to create it and given permission to cast it.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 112. Spells : 112.3.
text: A noncopy spellâs characteristics are the same as those printed on its card, as modified by any continuous effects. See rule 613, âInteraction of Continuous Effects.â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 112. Spells : 112.4.
text: If an effect of a resolving spell or ability changes any characteristics of a permanent spell, the effect continues to apply to the permanent when the spell resolves. See rule 400.7.

name: Example for Rule : 112.4.
text: If an effect changes a black creature spell to white, the creature is white when it enters the battlefield and remains white for the duration of the effect changing its color.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 113. Abilities : 113.1.
text: An ability can be one of three things:

name: Comprehensive Rules: 113. Abilities : 113.1a
text: An ability can be a characteristic an object has that lets it affect the game. An objectâs abilities are defined by its rules text or by the effect that created it. Abilities can also be granted to objects by rules or effects. (Effects that grant abilities usually use the words âhas,â âhave,â âgains,â or âgain.â) Abilities generate effects. (See rule 609, âEffects.â)

name: Comprehensive Rules: 113. Abilities : 113.1b
text: An ability can be something that a player has that changes how the game affects the player. A player normally has no abilities unless granted to that player by effects.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 113. Abilities : 113.1c
text: An ability can be an activated or triggered ability on the stack. This kind of ability is an object. (See section 6, âSpells, Abilities, and Effects.â)

name: Comprehensive Rules: 113. Abilities : 113.2.
text: Abilities can affect the objects theyâre on. They can also affect other objects and/or players.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 113. Abilities : 113.2a
text: Abilities can be beneficial or detrimental.

name: Example for Rule : 113.2a
text: â[This creature] canât blockâ is an ability.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 113. Abilities : 113.2b
text: An additional cost or alternative cost to cast a card is an ability of the card.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 113. Abilities : 113.2c
text: An object may have multiple abilities. If the object is represented by a card, then aside from certain defined abilities that may be strung together on a single line (see rule 702, âKeyword Abilitiesâ), each paragraph break in a cardâs text marks a separate ability. If the object is not represented by a card, the effect that created it may have given it multiple abilities. An object may also be granted additional abilities by a spell or ability. If an object has multiple instances of the same ability, each instance functions independently. This may or may not produce more effects than a single instance; refer to the specific ability for more information.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 113. Abilities : 113.2d
text: Abilities can generate one-shot effects or continuous effects. Some continuous effects are replacement effects or prevention effects. See rule 609, âEffects.â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 113. Abilities : 113.3.
text: There are four general categories of abilities:

name: Comprehensive Rules: 113. Abilities : 113.3a
text: Spell abilities are abilities that are followed as instructions while an instant or sorcery spell is resolving. Any text on an instant or sorcery spell is a spell ability unless itâs an activated ability, a triggered ability, or a static ability that fits the criteria described in rule 113.6.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 113. Abilities : 113.3b
text: Activated abilities have a cost and an effect. They are written as â[Cost]: [Effect.] [Activation instructions (if any).]â A player may activate such an ability whenever they have priority. Doing so puts it on the stack, where it remains until itâs countered, it resolves, or it otherwise leaves the stack. See rule 602, âActivating Activated Abilities.â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 113. Abilities : 113.3c
text: Triggered abilities have a trigger condition and an effect. They are written as â[Trigger condition], [effect],â and include (and usually begin with) the word âwhen,â âwhenever,â or âat.â Whenever the trigger event occurs, the ability is put on the stack the next time a player would receive priority and stays there until itâs countered, it resolves, or it otherwise leaves the stack. See rule 603, âHandling Triggered Abilities.â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 113. Abilities : 113.3d
text: Static abilities are written as statements. Theyâre simply true. Static abilities create continuous effects which are active while the permanent with the ability is on the battlefield and has the ability, or while the object with the ability is in the appropriate zone. See rule 604, âHandling Static Abilities.â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 113. Abilities : 113.4.
text: Some activated abilities and some triggered abilities are mana abilities. Mana abilities follow special rules: They donât use the stack, and, under certain circumstances, a player can activate mana abilities even if they donât have priority. See rule 605, âMana Abilities.â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 113. Abilities : 113.5.
text: Some activated abilities are loyalty abilities. Loyalty abilities follow special rules: A player may activate a loyalty ability of a permanent they control any time they have priority and the stack is empty during a main phase of their turn, but only if no player has previously activated a loyalty ability of that permanent that turn. See rule 606, âLoyalty Abilities.â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 113. Abilities : 113.6.
text: Abilities of an instant or sorcery spell usually function only while that object is on the stack. Abilities of all other objects usually function only while that object is on the battlefield. The exceptions are as follows:

name: Comprehensive Rules: 113. Abilities : 113.6a
text: Characteristic-defining abilities function everywhere, even outside the game and before the game begins. (See rule 604.3.)

name: Comprehensive Rules: 113. Abilities : 113.6b
