text: An ability that states which zones it functions in functions only from those zones.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 113. Abilities : 113.6c
text: An ability that states which zones it doesnât function in functions everywhere except for the specified zones, even outside the game and before the game begins.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 113. Abilities : 113.6d
text: An objectâs ability that allows a player to pay an alternative cost rather than its mana cost or otherwise modifies what that particular object costs to cast functions on the stack.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 113. Abilities : 113.6e
text: An objectâs ability that restricts or modifies how that particular object can be played or cast functions in any zone from which it could be played or cast and also on the stack. An objectâs ability that grants it another ability that restricts or modifies how that particular object can be played or cast functions only on the stack.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 113. Abilities : 113.6f
text: An objectâs ability that restricts or modifies what zones that particular object can be played or cast from functions everywhere, even outside the game.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 113. Abilities : 113.6g
text: An objectâs ability that states it canât be countered or canât be copied functions on the stack.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 113. Abilities : 113.6h
text: An objectâs ability that modifies how that particular object enters the battlefield functions as that object is entering the battlefield. See rule 614.12.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 113. Abilities : 113.6i
text: An objectâs ability that states counters canât be put on that object functions as that object is entering the battlefield in addition to functioning while that object is on the battlefield.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 113. Abilities : 113.6j
text: An objectâs activated ability that has a cost that canât be paid while the object is on the battlefield functions from any zone in which its cost can be paid.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 113. Abilities : 113.6k
text: A trigger condition that canât trigger from the battlefield functions in all zones it can trigger from. Other trigger conditions of the same triggered ability may function in different zones.

name: Example for Rule : 113.6k
text: Absolver Thrull has the ability âWhen Absolver Thrull enters the battlefield or the creature it haunts dies, destroy target enchantment.â The first trigger condition functions from the battlefield and the second trigger condition functions from the exile zone. (See rule 702.55, âHaunt.â)

name: Comprehensive Rules: 113. Abilities : 113.6m
text: An ability whose cost or effect specifies that it moves the object itâs on out of a particular zone functions only in that zone, unless its trigger condition or a previous part of its cost or effect specifies that the object is put into that zone or, if the object is an Aura, that the object it enchants leaves the battlefield. The same is true if the effect of that ability creates a delayed triggered ability whose effect moves the object out of a particular zone.

name: Example for Rule : 113.6m
text: Reassembling Skeleton says â{1}{B}: Return Reassembling Skeleton from your graveyard to the battlefield tapped.â A player may activate this ability only if Reassembling Skeleton is in their graveyard.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 113. Abilities : 113.6n
text: An ability that modifies the rules for deck construction functions before the game begins. Such an ability modifies not just the Comprehensive Rules, but also the Magic: The Gathering Tournament Rules and any other documents that set the deck construction rules for a specific format. However, such an ability canât affect the format legality of a card, including whether itâs banned or restricted. The current Magic: The Gathering Tournament Rules can be found at WPN.Wizards.com/en/resources/rules-documents.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 113. Abilities : 113.6p
text: Abilities of emblems, plane cards, vanguard cards, scheme cards, and conspiracy cards function in the command zone. See rule 114, âEmblemsâ; rule 901, âPlanechaseâ; rule 902, âVanguardâ; rule 904, âArchenemyâ; and rule 905, âConspiracy Draft.â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 113. Abilities : 113.7.
text: The source of an ability is the object that generated it. The source of an activated ability on the stack is the object whose ability was activated. The source of a triggered ability (other than a delayed triggered ability) on the stack, or one that has triggered and is waiting to be put on the stack, is the object whose ability triggered. To determine the source of a delayed triggered ability, see rules 603.7dâf.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 113. Abilities : 113.7a
text: Once activated or triggered, an ability exists on the stack independently of its source. Destruction or removal of the source after that time wonât affect the ability. Note that some abilities cause a source to do something (for example, âProdigal Pyromancer deals 1 damage to any targetâ) rather than the ability doing anything directly. In these cases, any activated or triggered ability that references information about the source for use while announcing an activated ability or putting a triggered ability on the stack checks that information when the ability is put onto the stack. Otherwise, it will check that information when it resolves. In both instances, if the source is no longer in the zone itâs expected to be in at that time, its last known information is used. The source can still perform the action even though it no longer exists.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 113. Abilities : 113.8.
text: The controller of an activated ability on the stack is the player who activated it. The controller of a triggered ability on the stack (other than a delayed triggered ability) is the player who controlled the abilityâs source when it triggered, or, if it had no controller, the player who owned the abilityâs source when it triggered. To determine the controller of a delayed triggered ability, see rules 603.7dâf.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 113. Abilities : 113.9.
text: Activated and triggered abilities on the stack arenât spells, and therefore canât be countered by anything that counters only spells. Activated and triggered abilities on the stack can be countered by effects that specifically counter abilities. Static abilities donât use the stack and thus canât be countered at all.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 113. Abilities : 113.10.
text: Effects can add or remove abilities of objects. An effect that adds an ability will state that the object âgainsâ or âhasâ that ability, or similar. An effect that removes an ability will state that the object âlosesâ that ability.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 113. Abilities : 113.10a
text: An effect that adds an activated ability may include activation instructions for that ability. These instructions become part of the ability thatâs added to the object.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 113. Abilities : 113.10b
text: Effects that remove an ability remove all instances of it.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 113. Abilities : 113.10c
text: If two or more effects add and remove the same ability, in general the most recent one prevails. See rule 613 for more information about the interaction of continuous effects.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 113. Abilities : 113.11.
text: Effects can stop an object from having a specified ability. These effects say that the object âcanât haveâ that ability. If the object has that ability, it loses it. Itâs also impossible for an effect or keyword counter to add that ability to the object. If a resolving spell or ability creates a continuous effect that would add the specified ability to such an object, that part of that continuous effect does not apply; however, other parts of that continuous effect will still apply, and that resolving spell or ability can still create other continuous effects. Continuous effects created by static abilities that would add the specified ability wonât apply to that object.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 113. Abilities : 113.12.
text: An effect that sets an objectâs characteristic, or simply states a quality of that object, is different from an ability granted by an effect. When an object âgainsâ or âhasâ an ability, that ability can be removed by another effect. If an effect defines a characteristic of the object (â[permanent] is [characteristic value]â), itâs not granting an ability. (See rule 604.3.) Similarly, if an effect states a quality of that object (â[creature] canât be blocked,â for example), itâs neither granting an ability nor setting a characteristic.

name: Example for Rule : 113.12.
text: Muraganda Petroglyphs reads, âCreatures with no abilities get +2/+2.â A Runeclaw Bear (a creature with no abilities) enchanted by an Aura that says âEnchanted creature has flyingâ would not get +2/+2. A Runeclaw Bear enchanted by an Aura that says âEnchanted creature is redâ or âEnchanted creature canât be blockedâ would get +2/+2.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 114. Emblems : 114.1.
text: Some effects put emblems into the command zone. An emblem is a marker used to represent an object that has one or more abilities, but no other characteristics.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 114. Emblems : 114.2.
text: An effect that creates an emblem is written â[Player] gets an emblem with [ability].â This means that [player] puts an emblem with [ability] into the command zone. The emblem is both owned and controlled by that player.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 114. Emblems : 114.3.
text: An emblem has no characteristics other than the abilities defined by the effect that created it. In particular, an emblem has no types, no mana cost, and no color. Most emblems also have no name.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 114. Emblems : 114.4.
text: Abilities of emblems function in the command zone.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 114. Emblems : 114.5.
text: An emblem is neither a card nor a permanent. Emblem isnât a card type.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 115. Targets : 115.1.
text: Some spells and abilities require their controller to choose one or more targets for them. The targets are object(s) and/or player(s) the spell or ability will affect. These targets are declared as part of the process of putting the spell or ability on the stack. The targets canât be changed except by another spell or ability that explicitly says it can do so.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 115. Targets : 115.1a
text: An instant or sorcery spell is targeted if its spell ability identifies something it will affect by using the phrase âtarget [something],â where the âsomethingâ is a phrase that describes an object and/or player. The target(s) are chosen as the spell is cast; see rule 601.2c. (If an activated or triggered ability of an instant or sorcery uses the word target, that ability is targeted, but the spell is not.)

name: Example for Rule : 115.1a
text: A sorcery card has the ability âWhen you cycle this card, target creature gets -1/-1 until end of turn.â This triggered ability is targeted, but that doesnât make the card itâs on targeted.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 115. Targets : 115.1b
text: Aura spells are always targeted. An Auraâs target is specified by its enchant keyword ability (see rule 702.5, âEnchantâ). The target is chosen as the spell is cast; see rule 601.2c. An Aura permanent doesnât target anything; only the spell is targeted. (An activated or triggered ability of an Aura permanent can also be targeted.)

name: Comprehensive Rules: 115. Targets : 115.1c
text: An activated ability is targeted if it identifies something it will affect by using the phrase âtarget [something],â where the âsomethingâ is a phrase that describes an object and/or player. The target(s) are chosen as the ability is activated; see rule 602.2b.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 115. Targets : 115.1d
text: A triggered ability is targeted if it identifies something it will affect by using the phrase âtarget [something],â where the âsomethingâ is a phrase that describes an object and/or player. The target(s) are chosen as the ability is put on the stack; see rule 603.3d.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 115. Targets : 115.1e
text: Some keyword abilities, such as equip and modular, represent targeted activated or triggered abilities, and some keyword abilities, such as mutate, cause spells to have targets. In those cases, the phrase âtarget [something]â appears in the rule for that keyword ability rather than in the ability itself. (The keywordâs reminder text will often contain the word âtarget.â) See rule 702, âKeyword Abilities.â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 115. Targets : 115.2.
text: Only permanents are legal targets for spells and abilities, unless a spell or ability (a) specifies that it can target an object in another zone or a player, or (b) targets an object that canât exist on the battlefield, such as a spell or ability. See also rule 115.4.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 115. Targets : 115.3.
text: The same target canât be chosen multiple times for any one instance of the word âtargetâ on a spell or ability. If the spell or ability uses the word âtargetâ in multiple places, the same object or player can be chosen once for each instance of the word âtargetâ (as long as it fits the targeting criteria). This rule applies both when choosing targets for a spell or ability and when changing targets or choosing new targets for a spell or ability (see rule 115.7).

name: Comprehensive Rules: 115. Targets : 115.4.
text: Some spells and abilities that refer to damage require âany target,â âanother target,â âtwo targets,â or similar rather than âtarget [something].â These targets may be creatures, players, planeswalkers, or battles. Other game objects, such as noncreature artifacts or spells, canât be chosen.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 115. Targets : 115.5.
text: A spell or ability on the stack is an illegal target for itself.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 115. Targets : 115.6.
text: A spell or ability that requires targets may allow zero targets to be chosen. Such a spell or ability is still said to require targets, but that spell or ability is targeted only if one or more targets have been chosen for it.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 115. Targets : 115.7.
text: Some effects allow a player to change the target(s) of a spell or ability, and other effects allow a player to choose new targets for a spell or ability.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 115. Targets : 115.7a
text: If an effect allows a player to âchange the target(s)â of a spell or ability, each target can be changed only to another legal target. If a target canât be changed to another legal target, the original target is unchanged, even if the original target is itself illegal by then. If all the targets arenât changed to other legal targets, none of them are changed.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 115. Targets : 115.7b
text: If an effect allows a player to âchange a targetâ of a spell or ability, the process described in rule 115.7a is followed, except that only one of those targets may be changed (rather than all of them or none of them).

name: Comprehensive Rules: 115. Targets : 115.7c
text: If an effect allows a player to âchange any targetsâ of a spell or ability, the process described in rule 115.7a is followed, except that any number of those targets may be changed (rather than all of them or none of them).

name: Comprehensive Rules: 115. Targets : 115.7d
text: If an effect allows a player to âchoose new targetsâ for a spell or ability, the player may leave any number of the targets unchanged, even if those targets would be illegal. If the player chooses to change some or all of the targets, the new targets must be legal and must not cause any unchanged targets to become illegal.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 115. Targets : 115.7e
text: When changing targets or choosing new targets for a spell or ability, only the final set of targets is evaluated to determine whether the change is legal.

name: Example for Rule : 115.7e
text: Arc Trail is a sorcery that reads âArc Trail deals 2 damage to any target and 1 damage to another target.â The current targets of Arc Trail are Runeclaw Bear and Llanowar Elves, in that order. You cast Redirect, an instant that reads âYou may choose new targets for target spell,â targeting Arc Trail. You can change the first target to Llanowar Elves and change the second target to Runeclaw Bear.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 115. Targets : 115.7f
text: A spell or ability may âdivideâ or âdistributeâ an effect (such as damage or counters) among one or more targets. When changing targets or choosing new targets for that spell or ability, the original division canât be changed.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 115. Targets : 115.8.
text: Modal spells and abilities may have different targeting requirements for each mode. An effect that allows a player to change the target(s) of a modal spell or ability, or to choose new targets for a modal spell or ability, doesnât allow that player to change its mode. (See rule 700.2.)

name: Comprehensive Rules: 115. Targets : 115.9.
text: Some objects check what another spell or ability is targeting. Depending on the wording, these may check the current state of the targets, the state of the targets at the time they were selected, or both.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 115. Targets : 115.9a
text: An object that looks for a â[spell or ability] with [a number of] targetsâ checks the number of times any object or player was chosen as the target of that spell or ability when it was put on the stack, not the number of its targets that are currently legal. If the same object or player became a target more than once, each of those instances is counted separately.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 115. Targets : 115.9b
text: An object that looks for a â[spell or ability] that targets [something]â checks the current state of that spell or abilityâs targets. If an object it targets is still in the zone itâs expected to be in or a player it targets is still in the game, that targetâs current information is used, even if itâs not currently legal for that spell or ability. If an object it targets is no longer in the zone itâs expected to be in or a player it targets is no longer in the game, that target is ignored; its last known information is not used.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 115. Targets : 115.9c
text: An object that looks for a â[spell or ability] that targets only [something]â checks the number of different objects or players that were chosen as targets of that spell or ability when it was put on the stack (as modified by effects that changed those targets), not the number of those objects or players that are currently legal targets. If that number is one (even if the spell or ability targets that object or player multiple times), the current state of that spell or abilityâs target is checked as described in rule 115.9b.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 115. Targets : 115.10.
text: Spells and abilities can affect objects and players they donât target. In general, those objects and players arenât chosen until the spell or ability resolves. See rule 608, âResolving Spells and Abilities.â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 115. Targets : 115.10a
text: Just because an object or player is being affected by a spell or ability doesnât make that object or player a target of that spell or ability. Unless that object or player is identified by the word âtargetâ in the text of that spell or ability, or the rule for that keyword ability, itâs not a target.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 115. Targets : 115.10b
text: In particular, the word âyouâ in an objectâs text doesnât indicate a target.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 116. Special Actions : 116.1.
text: Special actions are actions a player may take when they have priority that donât use the stack. These are not to be confused with turn-based actions and state-based actions, which the game generates automatically. (See rule 703, âTurn-Based Actions,â and rule 704, âState-Based Actions.â)

name: Comprehensive Rules: 116. Special Actions : 116.2.
text: There are ten special actions:

name: Comprehensive Rules: 116. Special Actions : 116.2a
text: Playing a land is a special action. To play a land, a player puts that land onto the battlefield from the zone it was in (usually that playerâs hand). By default, a player can take this action only once during each of their turns. A player can take this action any time they have priority and the stack is empty during a main phase of their turn. See rule 305, âLands.â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 116. Special Actions : 116.2b
text: Turning a face-down creature face up is a special action. A player can take this action any time they have priority. See rule 708, âFace-Down Spells and Permanents.â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 116. Special Actions : 116.2c
text: Some effects allow a player to take an action at a later time, usually to end a continuous effect or to stop a delayed triggered ability from triggering. Doing so is a special action. A player can take such an action any time they have priority, unless that effect specifies another timing restriction, for as long as the effect allows it.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 116. Special Actions : 116.2d
text: Some effects from static abilities allow a player to take an action to ignore the effect from that ability for a duration. Doing so is a special action. A player can take such an action any time they have priority.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 116. Special Actions : 116.2e
text: One card (Circling Vultures) has the ability âYou may discard Circling Vultures any time you could cast an instant.â Doing so is a special action. A player can take such an action any time they have priority.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 116. Special Actions : 116.2f
text: A player who has a card with suspend in their hand may exile that card. This is a special action. A player can take this action any time they have priority, but only if they could begin to cast that card by putting it onto the stack. See rule 702.62, âSuspend.â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 116. Special Actions : 116.2g
text: A player who has chosen a companion may pay {3} to put that card from outside the game into their hand. This is a special action. A player can take this action any time they have priority and the stack is empty during a main phase of their turn, but only if they havenât done so yet this game. (See rule 702.139, âCompanion.â)

name: Comprehensive Rules: 116. Special Actions : 116.2h
text: A player who has a card with foretell in their hand may pay {2} and exile that card face down. This is a special action. A player may take this action any time they have priority during their turn. See rule 702.143, âForetell.â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 116. Special Actions : 116.2i
text: In a Planechase game, rolling the planar die is a special action. A player can take this action any time they have priority and the stack is empty during a main phase of their turn. Taking this action costs a player an amount of mana equal to the number of times they have previously taken this action on that turn. Note that this number wonât be equal to the number of times the player has rolled the planar die that turn if an effect has caused the player to roll the planar die that turn. See rule 901, âPlanechase.â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 116. Special Actions : 116.2j
text: In a Conspiracy Draft game, turning a face-down conspiracy card in the command zone face up is a special action. A player can take this action any time they have priority. See rule 905.4a.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 116. Special Actions : 116.3.
text: If a player takes a special action, that player receives priority afterward.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 117. Timing and Priority : 117.1.
text: Unless a spell or ability is instructing a player to take an action, which player can take actions at any given time is determined by a system of priority. The player with priority may cast spells, activate abilities, and take special actions.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 117. Timing and Priority : 117.1a
text: A player may cast an instant spell any time they have priority. A player may cast a noninstant spell during their main phase any time they have priority and the stack is empty.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 117. Timing and Priority : 117.1b
text: A player may activate an activated ability any time they have priority.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 117. Timing and Priority : 117.1c
text: A player may take some special actions any time they have priority. A player may take other special actions during their main phase any time they have priority and the stack is empty. See rule 116, âSpecial Actions.â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 117. Timing and Priority : 117.1d
text: A player may activate a mana ability whenever they have priority, whenever they are casting a spell or activating an ability that requires a mana payment, or whenever a rule or effect asks for a mana payment (even in the middle of casting or resolving a spell or activating or resolving an ability).

name: Comprehensive Rules: 117. Timing and Priority : 117.2.
text: Other kinds of abilities and actions are automatically generated or performed by the game rules, or are performed by players without receiving priority.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 117. Timing and Priority : 117.2a
text: Triggered abilities can trigger at any time, including while a spell is being cast, an ability is being activated, or a spell or ability is resolving. (See rule 603, âHandling Triggered Abilities.â) However, nothing actually happens at the time an ability triggers. Each time a player would receive priority, each ability that has triggered but hasnât yet been put on the stack is put on the stack. See rule 117.5.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 117. Timing and Priority : 117.2b
text: Static abilities continuously affect the game. Priority doesnât apply to them. (See rule 604, âHandling Static Abilities,â and rule 611, âContinuous Effects.â)

name: Comprehensive Rules: 117. Timing and Priority : 117.2c
text: Turn-based actions happen automatically when certain steps or phases begin. Theyâre dealt with before a player would receive priority. See rule 117.3a. Turn-based actions also happen automatically when each step and phase ends; no player receives priority afterward. See rule 703, âTurn-Based Actions.â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 117. Timing and Priority : 117.2d
text: State-based actions happen automatically when certain conditions are met. See rule 704. Theyâre dealt with before a player would receive priority. See rule 117.5.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 117. Timing and Priority : 117.2e
text: Resolving spells and abilities may instruct players to make choices or take actions, or may allow players to activate mana abilities. Even if a player is doing so, no player has priority while a spell or ability is resolving. See rule 608, âResolving Spells and Abilities.â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 117. Timing and Priority : 117.3.
text: Which player has priority is determined by the following rules:

name: Comprehensive Rules: 117. Timing and Priority : 117.3a
text: The active player receives priority at the beginning of most steps and phases, after any turn-based actions (such as drawing a card during the draw step; see rule 703) have been dealt with and abilities that trigger at the beginning of that phase or step have been put on the stack. No player receives priority during the untap step. Players usually donât get priority during the cleanup step (see rule 514.3).

name: Comprehensive Rules: 117. Timing and Priority : 117.3b
text: The active player receives priority after a spell or ability (other than a mana ability) resolves.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 117. Timing and Priority : 117.3c
text: If a player has priority when they cast a spell, activate an ability, or take a special action, that player receives priority afterward.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 117. Timing and Priority : 117.3d
text: If a player has priority and chooses not to take any actions, that player passes. If any mana is in that playerâs mana pool, they announce what mana is there. Then the next player in turn order receives priority.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 117. Timing and Priority : 117.4.
text: If all players pass in succession (that is, if all players pass without taking any actions in between passing), the spell or ability on top of the stack resolves or, if the stack is empty, the phase or step ends.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 117. Timing and Priority : 117.5.
text: Each time a player would get priority, the game first performs all applicable state-based actions as a single event (see rule 704, âState-Based Actionsâ), then repeats this process until no state-based actions are performed. Then triggered abilities are put on the stack (see rule 603, âHandling Triggered Abilitiesâ). These steps repeat in order until no further state-based actions are performed and no abilities trigger. Then the player who would have received priority does so.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 117. Timing and Priority : 117.6.
text: In a multiplayer game using the shared team turns option, teams rather than individual players have priority. See rule 805, âShared Team Turns Option.â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 117. Timing and Priority : 117.7.
text: If a player with priority casts a spell or activates an activated ability while another spell or ability is already on the stack, the new spell or ability has been cast or activated âin response toâ the earlier spell or ability. The new spell or ability will resolve first. See rule 608, âResolving Spells and Abilities.â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 118. Costs : 118.1.
text: A cost is an action or payment necessary to take another action or to stop another action from taking place. To pay a cost, a player carries out the instructions specified by the spell, ability, or effect that contains that cost.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 118. Costs : 118.2.
text: If a cost includes a mana payment, the player paying the cost has a chance to activate mana abilities. Paying the cost to cast a spell or activate an activated ability follows the steps in rules 601.2fâh.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 118. Costs : 118.3.
text: A player canât pay a cost without having the necessary resources to pay it fully. For example, a player with only 1 life canât pay a cost of 2 life, and a permanent thatâs already tapped canât be tapped to pay a cost. See rule 202, âMana Cost and Color,â and rule 602, âActivating Activated Abilities.â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 118. Costs : 118.3a
text: Paying mana is done by removing the indicated mana from a playerâs mana pool. (Players can always pay 0 mana.) If excess mana remains in that playerâs mana pool after making that payment, the player announces what mana is still there.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 118. Costs : 118.3b
text: Paying life is done by subtracting the indicated amount of life from a playerâs life total. (Players can always pay 0 life.)

name: Comprehensive Rules: 118. Costs : 118.3c
text: Activating mana abilities is not mandatory, even if paying a cost is.

name: Example for Rule : 118.3c
text: A player controls Lodestone Golem, which says âNonartifact spells cost {1} more to cast.â Another player removes the last time counter from a suspended sorcery card. That player must cast that spell if able, but doing so costs {1}. The player is forced to pay that cost if enough mana is in their mana pool, but the player isnât forced to activate a mana ability to produce that mana. If they donât, the card simply remains exiled.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 118. Costs : 118.4.
text: Some costs include an {X} or an X. See rule 107.3.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 118. Costs : 118.5.
text: Some costs are represented by {0}, or are reduced to {0}. The action necessary for a player to pay such a cost is the playerâs acknowledgment that they are paying it. Even though such a cost requires no resources, itâs not automatically paid.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 118. Costs : 118.5a
text: A spell whose mana cost is {0} must still be cast the same way as one with a cost greater than zero; it wonât cast itself automatically. The same is true for an activated ability whose cost is {0}.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 118. Costs : 118.6.
text: Some objects have no mana cost. This represents an unpayable cost. An ability can also have an unpayable cost if its cost is based on the mana cost of an object with no mana cost. Attempting to cast a spell or activate an ability that has an unpayable cost is a legal action. However, attempting to pay an unpayable cost is an illegal action.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 118. Costs : 118.6a
text: If an unpayable cost is increased by an effect or an additional cost is imposed, the cost is still unpayable. If an alternative cost is applied to an unpayable cost, including an effect that allows a player to cast a spell without paying its mana cost, the alternative cost may be paid.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 118. Costs : 118.7.
text: What a player actually needs to do to pay a cost may be changed or reduced by effects. If the mana component of a cost is reduced to nothing by cost reduction effects, itâs considered to be {0}. Paying a cost changed or reduced by an effect counts as paying the original cost.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 118. Costs : 118.7a
text: Effects that reduce a cost by an amount of generic mana affect only the generic mana component of that cost. They canât affect the colored or colorless mana components of that cost.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 118. Costs : 118.7b
text: If a cost is reduced by an amount of colored or colorless mana, but the cost doesnât require mana of that type, the cost is reduced by that amount of generic mana.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 118. Costs : 118.7c
text: If a cost is reduced by an amount of colored mana that exceeds its mana component of that color, the costâs mana component of that color is reduced to nothing and the costâs generic mana component is reduced by the difference.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 118. Costs : 118.7d
text: If a cost is reduced by an amount of colorless mana that exceeds its colorless mana component, the costâs colorless mana component is reduced to nothing and the costâs generic mana component is reduced by the difference.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 118. Costs : 118.7e
text: If a cost is reduced by an amount of mana represented by a hybrid mana symbol, the player paying that cost chooses one half of that symbol at the time the cost reduction is applied (see rule 601.2f). If a colored half is chosen, the cost is reduced by one mana of that color. If a generic half is chosen, the cost is reduced by an amount of generic mana equal to that halfâs number.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 118. Costs : 118.7f
text: If a cost is reduced by an amount of mana represented by a Phyrexian mana symbol, the cost is reduced by one mana of that symbolâs color.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 118. Costs : 118.7g
text: If a cost is reduced by an amount of mana represented by one or more snow mana symbols, the cost is reduced by that much generic mana.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 118. Costs : 118.8.
text: Some spells and abilities have additional costs. An additional cost is a cost listed in a spellâs rules text, or applied to a spell or ability from another effect, that its controller must pay at the same time they pay the spellâs mana cost or the abilityâs activation cost. Note that some additional costs are listed in keywords; see rule 702.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 118. Costs : 118.8a
text: Any number of additional costs may be applied to a spell as itâs being cast or to an ability as itâs being activated. The controller of the spell or ability announces their intentions to pay any or all of those costs as described in rule 601.2b.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 118. Costs : 118.8b
text: Some additional costs are optional.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 118. Costs : 118.8c
text: If an effect instructs a player to cast a spell âif able,â and that spell has a mandatory additional cost that includes actions involving cards with a stated quality in a hidden zone, the player isnât required to cast that spell, even if those cards are present in that zone.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 118. Costs : 118.8d
text: Additional costs donât change a spellâs mana cost, only what its controller has to pay to cast it. Spells and abilities that ask for that spellâs mana cost still see the original value.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 118. Costs : 118.9.
text: Some spells have alternative costs. An alternative cost is a cost listed in a spellâs text, or applied to it from another effect, that its controller may pay rather than paying the spellâs mana cost. Alternative costs are usually phrased, âYou may [action] rather than pay [this objectâs] mana cost,â or âYou may cast [this object] without paying its mana cost.â Note that some alternative costs are listed in keywords; see rule 702.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 118. Costs : 118.9a
text: Only one alternative cost can be applied to any one spell as itâs being cast. The controller of the spell announces their intentions to pay that cost as described in rule 601.2b.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 118. Costs : 118.9b
text: Alternative costs are generally optional. An effect that allows you to cast a spell may require a certain alternative cost to be paid.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 118. Costs : 118.9c
text: An alternative cost doesnât change a spellâs mana cost, only what its controller has to pay to cast it. Spells and abilities that ask for that spellâs mana cost still see the original value.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 118. Costs : 118.9d
text: If an alternative cost is being paid to cast a spell, any additional costs, cost increases, and cost reductions that affect that spell are applied to that alternative cost. (See rule 601.2f.)

name: Comprehensive Rules: 118. Costs : 118.10.
text: Each payment of a cost applies to only one spell, ability, or effect. For example, a player canât sacrifice just one creature to activate the activated abilities of two permanents that each require sacrificing a creature as a cost. Also, the resolution of a spell or ability doesnât pay another spell or abilityâs cost, even if part of its effect is doing the same thing the other cost asks for.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 118. Costs : 118.11.
text: The actions performed when paying a cost may be modified by effects. Even if they are, meaning the actions that are performed donât match the actions that are called for, the cost has still been paid.

name: Example for Rule : 118.11.
text: A player controls Psychic Vortex, an enchantment with a cumulative upkeep cost of âDraw a card,â and Obstinate Familiar, a creature that says âIf you would draw a card, you may skip that draw instead.â The player may decide to pay Psychic Vortexâs cumulative upkeep cost and then draw no cards instead of drawing the appropriate amount. The cumulative upkeep cost has still been paid.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 118. Costs : 118.12.
text: Some spells, activated abilities, and triggered abilities read, â[Do something]. If [a player] [does, doesnât, or canât], [effect].â Or â[A player] may [do something]. If [that player] [does, doesnât, or canât], [effect].â The action [do something] is a cost, paid when the spell or ability resolves. The âIf [a player] [does, doesnât, or canât]â clause checks whether the player chose to pay an optional cost or started to pay a mandatory cost, regardless of what events actually occurred.

name: Example for Rule : 118.12.
text: You control Standstill, an enchantment that says âWhen a player casts a spell, sacrifice Standstill. If you do, each of that playerâs opponents draws three cards.â A spell is cast, causing Standstillâs ability to trigger. Then an ability is activated that exiles Standstill. When Standstillâs ability resolves, youâre unable to pay the âsacrifice Standstillâ cost. No player will draw cards.

name: Example for Rule : 118.12.
text: Your opponent has cast Gather Specimens, a spell that says âIf a creature would enter the battlefield under an opponentâs control this turn, it enters the battlefield under your control instead.â You control a face-down Dermoplasm, a creature with morph that says âWhen Dermoplasm is turned face up, you may put a creature card with morph from your hand onto the battlefield face up. If you do, return Dermoplasm to its ownerâs hand.â You turn Dermoplasm face up, and you choose to put a creature card with morph from your hand onto the battlefield. Due to Gather Specimens, it enters the battlefield under your opponentâs control instead of yours. However, since you chose to pay the cost, Dermoplasm is still returned to its ownerâs hand.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 118. Costs : 118.12a
text: Some spells, activated abilities, and triggered abilities read, â[Do something] unless [a player does something else].â This means the same thing as â[A player may do something else]. If [that player doesnât], [do something].â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 118. Costs : 118.12b
text: Some effects offer a player a choice to search a zone and take additional actions with the cards found in that zone, followed by an âIf [a player] doesâ clause. This clause checks whether the player chose to search, not whether the player took any of the additional actions.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 118. Costs : 118.13.
text: Some costs contain mana symbols that can be paid in multiple ways. These include hybrid mana symbols and Phyrexian mana symbols.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 118. Costs : 118.13a
text: If the mana cost of a spell or the activation cost of an activated ability contains a mana symbol that can be paid in multiple ways, the choice of how to pay for that symbol is made as its controller proposes that spell or ability (see rule 601.2b).

name: Comprehensive Rules: 118. Costs : 118.13b
text: If a cost paid during the resolution of a spell or ability contains a mana symbol that can be paid in multiple ways, the player paying that cost chooses how to pay for that symbol immediately before they pay that cost.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 118. Costs : 118.13c
text: If the cost associated with a special action contains a mana symbol that can be paid in multiple ways, the player taking the special action chooses how to pay for that symbol immediately before they pay that cost.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 118. Costs : 118.14.
text: Some effects say that âmana of any type can be spentâ to pay a cost. This means that players may spend mana as though it were colorless mana or mana of any color to pay that cost. If that effect also gives a player permission to cast spells, this applies only to mana that player spends to cast spells that way. See rule 609.4b.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 119. Life : 119.1.
text: Each player begins the game with a starting life total of 20. Some variant games have different starting life totals.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 119. Life : 119.1a
text: In a Two-Headed Giant game, each teamâs starting life total is 30. See rule 810, âTwo-Headed Giant Variant.â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 119. Life : 119.1b
text: In a Vanguard game, each playerâs starting life total is 20 plus or minus the life modifier of their vanguard card. See rule 902, âVanguard.â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 119. Life : 119.1c
text: In a Commander game, each playerâs starting life total is 40. See rule 903, âCommander.â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 119. Life : 119.1d
text: . In a two-player Brawl game, each playerâs starting life total is 25. In a multiplayer Brawl game, each playerâs starting life total is 30. See rule 903.12, âBrawl Option.â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 119. Life : 119.1e
text: In an Archenemy game, the archenemyâs starting life total is 40. See rule 904, âArchenemy.â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 119. Life : 119.2.
text: Damage dealt to a player normally causes that player to lose that much life. See rule 120.3.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 119. Life : 119.3.
text: If an effect causes a player to gain life or lose life, that playerâs life total is adjusted accordingly.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 119. Life : 119.4.
text: If a cost or effect allows a player to pay an amount of life greater than 0, the player may do so only if their life total is greater than or equal to the amount of the payment. If a player pays life, the payment is subtracted from their life total; in other words, the player loses that much life.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 119. Life : 119.4a
text: If a cost or effect allows a player to pay an amount of life greater than 0 in a Two-Headed Giant game, the player may do so only if their teamâs life total is greater than or equal to the total amount of life both team members are paying for that cost or effect. If a player pays life, the payment is subtracted from their teamâs life total.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 119. Life : 119.4b
text: Players can always pay 0 life, no matter what their (or their teamâs) life total is, and even if an effect says players canât pay life.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 119. Life : 119.5.
text: If an effect sets a playerâs life total to a specific number, the player gains or loses the necessary amount of life to end up with the new total.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 119. Life : 119.6.
text: If a player has 0 or less life, that player loses the game as a state-based action. See rule 704.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 119. Life : 119.7.
text: If an effect says that a player canât gain life, that player canât make an exchange such that the playerâs life total would become higher; in that case, the exchange wonât happen. Similarly, if an effect redistributes life totals, a player canât receive a new life total such that the playerâs life total would become higher. In addition, a cost that involves having that player gain life canât be paid, and a replacement effect that would replace a life gain event affecting that player wonât do anything.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 119. Life : 119.8.
text: If an effect says that a player canât lose life, that player canât make an exchange such that the playerâs life total would become lower; in that case, the exchange wonât happen. Similarly, if an effect redistributes life totals, a player canât receive a new life total such that the playerâs life total would become lower. In addition, a cost that involves having that player pay life canât be paid.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 119. Life : 119.9.
text: Some triggered abilities are written, âWhenever [a player] gains life, . . . .â Such abilities are treated as though they are written, âWhenever a source causes [a player] to gain life, . . . .â If a player gains 0 life, no life gain event has occurred, and these abilities wonât trigger.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 119. Life : 119.10.
text: Some replacement effects are written, âIf [a player] would gain life, . . . .â Such abilities are treated as though they are written, âIf a source would cause [a player] to gain life, . . . .â If a player gains 0 life, no life gain event would occur, and these effects wonât apply.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 120. Damage : 120.1.
text: Objects can deal damage to battles, creatures, planeswalkers, and players. This is generally detrimental to the object or player that receives that damage. An object that deals damage is the source of that damage.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 120. Damage : 120.1a
text: Damage canât be dealt to an object thatâs not a battle, a creature, or a planeswalker.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 120. Damage : 120.2.
text: Any object can deal damage.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 120. Damage : 120.2a
text: Damage may be dealt as a result of combat. Each attacking and blocking creature deals combat damage equal to its power during the combat damage step.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 120. Damage : 120.2b
text: Damage may be dealt as an effect of a spell or ability. The spell or ability will specify which object deals that damage.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 120. Damage : 120.3.
text: Damage may have one or more of the following results, depending on whether the recipient of the damage is a player or permanent, the characteristics of the damageâs source, and the characteristics of the damageâs recipient (if itâs a permanent).

name: Comprehensive Rules: 120. Damage : 120.3a
text: Damage dealt to a player by a source without infect causes that player to lose that much life.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 120. Damage : 120.3b
text: Damage dealt to a player by a source with infect causes that sourceâs controller to give the player that many poison counters.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 120. Damage : 120.3c
text: Damage dealt to a planeswalker causes that many loyalty counters to be removed from that planeswalker.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 120. Damage : 120.3d
text: Damage dealt to a creature by a source with wither and/or infect causes that sourceâs controller to put that many -1/-1 counters on that creature.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 120. Damage : 120.3e
text: Damage dealt to a creature by a source with neither wither nor infect causes that much damage to be marked on that creature.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 120. Damage : 120.3f
text: Damage dealt by a source with lifelink causes that sourceâs controller to gain that much life, in addition to the damageâs other results.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 120. Damage : 120.3g
text: Combat damage dealt to a player by a creature with toxic causes that creatureâs controller to give the player a number of poison counters equal to that creatureâs total toxic value, in addition to the damageâs other results. See rule 702.164, âToxic.â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 120. Damage : 120.3h
text: Damage dealt to a battle causes that many defense counters to be removed from that battle.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 120. Damage : 120.4.
text: Damage is processed in a four-part sequence.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 120. Damage : 120.4a
text: First, if an effect thatâs causing damage to be dealt states that excess damage that would be dealt to a permanent is dealt to another permanent or player instead, the damage event is modified accordingly. If the first permanent is a creature, the excess damage is the amount of damage in excess of what would be lethal damage, taking into account damage already marked on the creature and damage from other sources that would be dealt at the same time. (See rule 120.6.) Any amount of damage greater than 1 is excess damage if the source dealing that damage to a creature has deathtouch. (See rule 702.2.) If the first permanent is a planeswalker, the excess damage is the amount of damage in excess of that planeswalkerâs loyalty, taking into account damage from other sources that would be dealt at the same time. If the first permanent is a battle, the excess damage is the amount of damage in excess of that battleâs defense, taking into account damage from other sources that would be dealt at the same time. If the first permanent has multiple card types from among the list of creature, planeswalker, and battle, the excess damage is the greatest of the calculated amounts for each of the card types it has.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 120. Damage : 120.4b
text: Second, damage is dealt, as modified by replacement and prevention effects that interact with damage. (See rule 614, âReplacement Effects,â and rule 615, âPrevention Effects.â) Abilities that trigger when damage is dealt trigger now and wait to be put on the stack.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 120. Damage : 120.4c
text: Third, damage thatâs been dealt is processed into its results, as modified by replacement effects that interact with those results (such as life loss or counters).

name: Comprehensive Rules: 120. Damage : 120.4d
text: Finally, the damage event occurs.

name: Example for Rule : 120.4d
text: A player who controls Boon Reflection, an enchantment that says âIf you would gain life, you gain twice that much life instead,â attacks with a 3/3 creature with wither and lifelink. Itâs blocked by a 2/2 creature, and the defending player casts a spell that prevents the next 2 damage that would be dealt to the blocking creature. The damage event starts out as [3 damage is dealt to the 2/2 creature, 2 damage is dealt to the 3/3 creature]. The prevention effect is applied, so the damage event becomes [1 damage is dealt to the 2/2 creature, 2 damage is dealt to the 3/3 creature]. Thatâs processed into its results, so the damage event is now [one -1/-1 counter is put on the 2/2 creature, the active player gains 1 life, 2 damage is marked on the 3/3 creature]. Boon Reflectionâs effect is applied, so the damage event becomes [one -1/-1 counter is put on the 2/2 creature, the active player gains 2 life, 2 damage is marked on the 3/3 creature]. Then the damage event occurs.

name: Example for Rule : 120.4d
text: The defending player controls a creature and Worship, an enchantment that says âIf you control a creature, damage that would reduce your life total to less than 1 reduces it to 1 instead.â That player is at 2 life, and is being attacked by two unblocked 5/5 creatures. The player casts Awe Strike, which says âThe next time target creature would deal damage this turn, prevent that damage. You gain life equal to the damage prevented this way,â targeting one of the attackers. The damage event starts out as [10 damage is dealt to the defending player]. Awe Strikeâs effect is applied, so the damage event becomes [5 damage is dealt to the defending player, the defending player gains 5 life]. Thatâs processed into its results, so the damage event is now [the defending player loses 5 life, the defending player gains 5 life]. Worshipâs effect sees that the damage event would not reduce the playerâs life total to less than 1, so Worshipâs effect is not applied. Then the damage event occurs.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 120. Damage : 120.5.
text: Damage dealt to a creature, planeswalker, or battle doesnât destroy it. Likewise, the source of that damage doesnât destroy it. Rather, state-based actions may destroy a creature or otherwise put a permanent into its ownerâs graveyard, due to the results of the damage dealt to that permanent. See rule 704.

name: Example for Rule : 120.5.
text: A player casts Lightning Bolt, an instant that says âLightning Bolt deals 3 damage to any target,â targeting a 2/2 creature. After Lightning Bolt deals 3 damage to that creature, the creature is destroyed as a state-based action. Neither Lightning Bolt nor the damage dealt by Lightning Bolt destroyed that creature.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 120. Damage : 120.6.
text: Damage marked on a creature remains until the cleanup step, even if that permanent stops being a creature. If the total damage marked on a creature is greater than or equal to its toughness, that creature has been dealt lethal damage and is destroyed as a state-based action (see rule 704). All damage marked on a permanent is removed when it regenerates (see rule 701.15, âRegenerateâ) and during the cleanup step (see rule 514.2).

name: Comprehensive Rules: 120. Damage : 120.7.
text: The source of damage is the object that dealt it. If an effect requires a player to choose a source of damage, they may choose a permanent; a spell on the stack (including a permanent spell); any object referred to by an object on the stack, by a prevention or replacement effect thatâs waiting to apply, or by a delayed triggered ability thatâs waiting to trigger (even if that object is no longer in the zone it used to be in); or a face-up object in the command zone. A source doesnât need to be capable of dealing damage to be a legal choice. See rule 609.7, âSources of Damage.â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 120. Damage : 120.8.
text: If a source would deal 0 damage, it does not deal damage at all. That means abilities that trigger on damage being dealt wonât trigger. It also means that replacement effects that would increase the damage dealt by that source, or would have that source deal that damage to a different object or player, have no event to replace, so they have no effect.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 120. Damage : 120.9.
text: If an ability triggers on damage being dealt by a specific source or sources, and the effect refers to the âdamage dealt,â it refers only to the damage dealt by the specified sources and not to any damage dealt at the same time by other sources.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 120. Damage : 120.10.
text: Some triggered abilities check whether a permanent has been dealt excess damage. These abilities check after the permanent has been dealt damage by one or more sources. If those sources together dealt an amount of damage to a creature greater than lethal damage, excess damage equal to the difference was dealt to that creature. If those sources together dealt an amount of damage to a planeswalker greater than that planeswalkerâs loyalty before the damage was dealt, excess damage equal to the difference was dealt to that planeswalker. If those sources together dealt an amount of damage to a battle greater than that battleâs defense before the damage was dealt, excess damage equal to the difference was dealt to that battle. If a permanent has multiple card types from among the list of creature, planeswalker, and battle, the excess damage dealt to that permanent is the greatest of the calculated amounts for each of the card types it has.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 121. Drawing a Card : 121.1.
text: A player draws a card by putting the top card of their library into their hand. This is done as a turn-based action during each playerâs draw step. It may also be done as part of a cost or effect of a spell or ability.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 121. Drawing a Card : 121.2.
text: Cards may only be drawn one at a time. If a player is instructed to draw multiple cards, that player performs that many individual card draws.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 121. Drawing a Card : 121.2a
text: An instruction to draw multiple cards can be modified by replacement effects that refer to the number of cards drawn. This modification occurs before considering any of the individual card draws. See rule 616.1g.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 121. Drawing a Card : 121.2b
text: Some effects say that a player canât draw more than one card each turn. Such an effect applies to individual card draws. Instructions to draw multiple cards may still be partially carried out. However, if an effect offers the player a choice to draw multiple cards, the affected player canât choose to do so. Similarly, the player canât pay a cost that includes drawing multiple cards.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 121. Drawing a Card : 121.2c
text: If more than one player is instructed to draw cards, the active player performs all of their draws first, then each other player in turn order does the same.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 121. Drawing a Card : 121.2d
text: If more than one player is instructed to draw cards in a game thatâs using the shared team turns option (such as a Two-Headed Giant game), first each player on the active team, in whatever order that team likes, performs their draws, then each player on each nonactive team in turn order does the same.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 121. Drawing a Card : 121.3.
text: If there are no cards in a playerâs library and an effect offers that player the choice to draw a card, that player can choose to do so. However, if an effect says that a player canât draw cards and another effect offers that player the choice to draw a card, that player canât choose to do so.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 121. Drawing a Card : 121.3a
text: The same principles apply if the player whoâs making the choice is not the player who would draw the card. If the latter player has no cards in their library, the choice can be taken. If an effect says that the latter player canât draw a card, the choice canât be taken.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 121. Drawing a Card : 121.4.
text: A player who attempts to draw a card from a library with no cards in it loses the game the next time a player would receive priority. (This is a state-based action. See rule 704.)

name: Comprehensive Rules: 121. Drawing a Card : 121.5.
text: If an effect moves cards from a playerâs library to that playerâs hand without using the word âdraw,â the player has not drawn those cards. This makes a difference for abilities that trigger on drawing cards and effects that replace card draws, as well as if the playerâs library is empty.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 121. Drawing a Card : 121.6.
text: Some effects replace card draws.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 121. Drawing a Card : 121.6a
text: An effect that replaces a card draw is applied even if no cards could be drawn because there are no cards in the affected playerâs library.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 121. Drawing a Card : 121.6b
text: If an effect replaces a draw within a sequence of card draws, the replacement effect is completed before resuming the sequence.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 121. Drawing a Card : 121.6c
text: Some effects perform additional actions on a card after itâs drawn. If the draw is replaced, the additional action is not performed on any cards that are drawn as a result of that replacement effect or any subsequent replacement effects.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 121. Drawing a Card : 121.7.
text: Some replacement effects and prevention effects result in one or more card draws. In such a case, if there are any parts of the original event that havenât been replaced, those parts occur first, then the card draws happen one at a time.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 121. Drawing a Card : 121.8.
text: If a spell or ability causes a card to be drawn while another spell is being cast, the drawn card is kept face down until that spell becomes cast (see rule 601.2i) or until the casting process is reversed (see rule 729, âHandling Illegal Actionsâ). The same is true with relation to another ability being activated. If an effect allows or instructs a player to reveal the card as itâs being drawn, itâs revealed after the spell becomes cast or the ability becomes activated. While face down, the drawn card is considered to have no characteristics and canât be used to pay any part of the cost of the spell or ability that would require the card to have specific characteristics.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 121. Drawing a Card : 121.9.
text: If an effect gives a player the option to reveal a card as they draw it, that player may look at that card as they draw it before choosing whether to reveal it.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 122. Counters : 122.1.
text: A counter is a marker placed on an object or player that modifies its characteristics and/or interacts with a rule, ability, or effect. Counters are not objects and have no characteristics. Notably, a counter is not a token, and a token is not a counter. Counters with the same name or description are interchangeable.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 122. Counters : 122.1a
text: A +X/+Y counter on a creature or on a creature card in a zone other than the battlefield, where X and Y are numbers, adds X to that objectâs power and Y to that objectâs toughness. Similarly, -X/-Y counters subtract from power and toughness. See rule 613.4c.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 122. Counters : 122.1b
text: A keyword counter on a permanent or on a card in a zone other than the battlefield causes that object to gain that keyword. The keywords that a keyword counter can be are flying, first strike, double strike, deathtouch, haste, hexproof, indestructible, lifelink, menace, reach, shadow, trample, and vigilance, as well as any variants of those keywords. See rule 613.1f.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 122. Counters : 122.1c
text: One or more shield counters on a permanent create a single replacement effect and a single prevention effect that protect the permanent. These effects are âIf this permanent would be destroyed as the result of an effect, instead remove a shield counter from itâ and âIf damage would be dealt to this permanent, prevent that damage and remove a shield counter from it.â See rule 614, âReplacement Effects,â and rule 615, âPrevention Effects.â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 122. Counters : 122.1d
text: One or more stun counters on a permanent create a single replacement effect that stops the permanent from untapping. That effect is âIf a permanent with a stun counter on it would become untapped, instead remove a stun counter from it.â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 122. Counters : 122.1e
text: The number of loyalty counters on a planeswalker on the battlefield indicates how much loyalty it has. A planeswalker with 0 loyalty is put into its ownerâs graveyard as a state-based action. See rule 704.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 122. Counters : 122.1f
text: If a player has ten or more poison counters, that player loses the game as a state-based action. See rule 704. A player is âpoisonedâ if they have one or more poison counters. (See rule 810 for additional rules for Two-Headed Giant games.)

name: Comprehensive Rules: 122. Counters : 122.1g
text: The number of defense counters on a battle on the battlefield indicates how much defense it has. A battle with 0 defense is put into its ownerâs graveyard if it isnât the source of an ability that has triggered but not yet left the stack. This state-based action doesnât use the stack. See rule 704.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 122. Counters : 122.1h
text: One or more finality counters on a permanent create a single replacement effect that stops the permanent from going to the graveyard. That effect is âIf this permanent would be put into a graveyard from the battlefield, exile it instead.â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 122. Counters : 122.2.
text: Counters on an object are not retained if that object moves from one zone to another. The counters are not âremovedâ; they simply cease to exist. See rule 400.7.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 122. Counters : 122.3.
text: If a permanent has both a +1/+1 counter and a -1/-1 counter on it, N +1/+1 and N -1/-1 counters are removed from it as a state-based action, where N is the smaller of the number of +1/+1 and -1/-1 counters on it. See rule 704.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 122. Counters : 122.4.
text: If a permanent with an ability that says it canât have more than N counters of a certain kind on it has more than N counters of that kind on it, all but N of those counters are removed from it as a state-based action. See rule 704.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 122. Counters : 122.5.
text: If an effect says to âmoveâ a counter, it means to remove that counter from the object itâs currently on and put it onto a second object. If either of these actions isnât possible, itâs not possible to move a counter, and no counter is removed from or put onto anything. This may occur if the first and second objects are the same object; if the first object doesnât have the appropriate kind of counter on it; if the second object canât have counters put onto it; or if either object is no longer in the correct zone.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 122. Counters : 122.6.
text: Some spells and abilities refer to counters being put on an object. This refers to putting counters on that object while itâs on the battlefield and also to an object thatâs given counters as it enters the battlefield.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 122. Counters : 122.6a
text: If an object enters the battlefield with counters on it, the effect causing the object to be given counters may specify which player puts those counters on it. If the effect doesnât specify a player, the objectâs controller puts those counters on it.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 122. Counters : 122.7.
text: An ability that triggers âWhen/Whenever the Nth [kind] counterâ is put on an object triggers when one or more counters of the appropriate kind are put on the object such that the object had fewer than N counters on it before the counters were put on it and N or more counters on it after.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 122. Counters : 122.8.
text: If a triggered ability instructs a player to put one objectâs counters on another object and that abilityâs trigger condition or effect checks that the object with those counters left the battlefield, the player doesnât move counters from one object to the other. Rather, the player puts the same number of each kind of counter the first object had onto the second object.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 123. Stickers : 123.1.
text: A sticker is a marker placed on an object that modifies its characteristics and/or interacts with a rule, ability, or effect. Stickers are not objects. Notably, a sticker is not a counter or a token. Changes to an object from stickers are not part of its copiable values. There are four kinds of stickers: name stickers; ability stickers; power and toughness stickers; and art stickers.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 123. Stickers : 123.2.
text: Stickers are found in boosters of the Unfinity expansion on numbered inserts. Each insert has a predetermined combination of stickers. Any rule that refers to a sticker sheet refers to the specific combination of stickers found on one of those inserts. Sticker sheets are not cards and have no characteristics. Each sticker sheet can be found at Gatherer.Wizards.com.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 123. Stickers : 123.2a
text: In constructed play, a player who chooses to play with stickers must start the game with at least ten sticker sheets selected before play begins, and each of their sticker sheets must be unique. There is no maximum number of sticker sheets a player may start the game with. Each player playing with sticker sheets reveals all of their sticker sheets and chooses three of them at random. See rule 103, âStarting the Game.â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 123. Stickers : 123.2b
text: In limited play, each player chooses up to three sticker sheets from among those in the sealed products they opened and reveals them. See rule 103, âStarting the Game.â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 123. Stickers : 123.2c
text: Each player has access to only the stickers on the chosen sheets during the game, and those sticker sheets remain revealed.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 123. Stickers : 123.3.
text: If an effect instructs a player to put a sticker on an object, that player chooses a sticker that is not currently on any objects they own from among the stickers they have access to and puts it on that object.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 123. Stickers : 123.3a
text: Each sticker a player has access to is discrete and is distinct from each other sticker they have access to. Two stickers are never considered to be the same sticker, even if they have the same text or information on them.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 123. Stickers : 123.3b
text: A player canât put a sticker on an object that they donât own. If an effect would cause them to do so, that part of the effect does nothing.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 123. Stickers : 123.3c
text: A sticker may have a ticket cost represented by a number inside a ticket symbol (see rule 107.17a). In order to put a sticker with a ticket cost on an object, the player who owns that object must pay that much {TK}. If they donât have that much {TK}, they canât put that sticker on an object.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 123. Stickers : 123.3d
text: If a sticker that is already on an object is moved to another object, that stickerâs ticket cost does not need to be paid again.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 123. Stickers : 123.4.
text: Some rules and effects refer to a âstickeredâ object. An object is âstickeredâ if it currently has any kind of sticker on it. An object without any stickers on it is not a stickered object, even if it previously had stickers on it.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 123. Stickers : 123.5.
text: Stickers on an object are not retained as that object moves to a hidden zone. Stickers are retained as that object moves to a public zone and continue to apply to the new object it becomes in that zone; this is an exception to rule 400.7.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 123. Stickers : 123.5a
text: If one or more cards with stickers on them enter the battlefield as part of a melded permanent, all of those stickers are on the permanent that object becomes on the battlefield. They maintain their relative timestamp order.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 123. Stickers : 123.5b
text: If an object with a sticker on it becomes a component of a merged permanent on the battlefield, that sticker is on that merged permanent.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 123. Stickers : 123.5c
text: If a melded or merged permanent with one or more stickers on it moves from the battlefield to another public zone, only one of the objects it becomes will retain those stickers. Its owner chooses which of the objects it becomes in its new zone retains any stickers that are on it. Effects from those stickers will continue to apply to only that object.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 123. Stickers : 123.6.
text: A name sticker consists only of one or more words. A name sticker on a permanent or on a card in a zone other than the battlefield causes the word on that sticker to be added to the text of that objectâs name. This is a text-changing effect. See rule 613.1c and rule 612, âText-Changing Effects.â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 123. Stickers : 123.6a
text: For the purposes of rules and effects related to name stickers, a âwordâ in an objectâs name is any series of non-space characters that are separated from other non-space characters by one or more spaces. Hyphenated words and words with punctuation are considered to be one word. Blank lines, such as the one in âWolf in ________ Clothing,â are not considered words in a cardâs name.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 123. Stickers : 123.6b
text: As a name sticker is placed on an object, that objectâs controller chooses a position in that objectâs name for the word in the name sticker to be added, then announces that objectâs new name. That word can be added at the beginning of the objectâs name or after any number of the other words that are currently in its name. The new name can be further modified by other name stickers. If that object has no name, its name becomes the word added by the name sticker. Name stickers never modify or remove any of the other words in that name.

name: Example for Rule : 123.6b
text: As a player puts a name sticker with the word âDarkâ printed on it onto a creature named Bear Cub, that creatureâs controller chooses whether its new name is âDark Bear Cub,â âBear Dark Cub,â or âBear Cub Dark.â They then announce the new name to all players.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 123. Stickers : 123.6c
text: The text that a name sticker is modifying may change due to other effects and/or a permanentâs face-down status (see rule 708, âFace-Down Spells and Permanentsâ). To determine the name of an object with one or more name stickers, start with the objectâs copiable values, then apply each name stickerâs effect and each other text-changing effect in timestamp order. The position of each name sticker will continue to be after the number of words that were before it in the objectâs name when it was placed. If there are fewer words in the objectâs current name, the word on that sticker is added at the end of its name instead. The position and timestamp order of each name sticker on an object is remembered as the object that sticker is on moves from one public zone to another, and it continues to apply to the new object it becomes in that zone (see rule 123.5). This is an exception to rule 400.7.

name: Example for Rule : 123.6c
text: Fae of Wishes, an adventurer card, is in exile with a name sticker on it adding the word âManaâ after its second word, so its name is âFae of Mana Wishes.â An effect allows that player to cast Granted, its Adventure, from exile. The name of that spell on the stack is âGranted Mana.â After that card is exiled as the Adventure resolves, the stickerâs position (after the second word) is remembered, so the name of the exiled card is once again âFae of Mana Wishes.â

name: Example for Rule : 123.6c
text: A player owns a creature named It That Betrays on the battlefield. Using name stickers, they add the word âEldraziâ to its name after the third word, such that its new name is âIt That Betrays Eldrazi.â Later, that creature becomes a copy of a creature named Seeker of the Way. The name sticker continues to apply after the third word, so its new name is âSeeker of the Eldrazi Way.â

name: Example for Rule : 123.6c
text: A creature with a name sticker on it becomes enchanted by Witness Protection, an Aura that changes the creatureâs name to âLegitimate Businessperson.â Since Witness Protection is also a text-changing effect, and it has a later timestamp than the name sticker, the word on that name sticker is not part of the creatureâs name. Its name is âLegitimate Businessperson.â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 123. Stickers : 123.6d
text: Some effects refer to the number of one or more specific letters on a name sticker. A lowercase letter and its uppercase equivalent are the same letter.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 123. Stickers : 123.6e
text: Some effects refer to the number of âunique vowelsâ on a name sticker. These count the number of different vowels that appear on that sticker, even if one or more of them appear more than once. The vowels are A, E, I, O, U, and Y. A lowercase letter and its uppercase equivalent are the same letter.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 123. Stickers : 123.7.
text: An ability sticker is a sticker with one or more abilities printed on it. An ability sticker on a permanent or on a card in a zone other than the battlefield causes that object to gain the ability that is printed on that sticker. See rule 613.1f.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 123. Stickers : 123.7a
text: If an effect refers to an ability of an ability sticker, it refers to the ability that sticker grants to the object it is on, even if the object it is on doesnât currently have that ability due to another effect.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 123. Stickers : 123.8.
text: A power and toughness sticker is a sticker that has two numbers and a slash printed on it, resembling the power and toughness of a creature card. A power and toughness sticker on a creature or on a creature or Vehicle card in a zone other than the battlefield sets that objectâs power and toughness to the values printed on that sticker (see rule 613.4b). If more than one power and toughness sticker is on a creature, use timestamp order to determine which one takes precedence (see rule 613.7).

name: Comprehensive Rules: 123. Stickers : 123.8a
