text: An effect that refers to the power and/or toughness of a sticker refers only to the printed power and/or toughness values on a power and toughness sticker. It does not refer to any printed value on any other stickers.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 123. Stickers : 123.9.
text:
An art sticker on a permanent has no effect on game play other than to act as a marker that other spells and abilities can identify.

2. Parts of a Card

name: Comprehensive Rules: 200. General : 200.1.
text: The parts of a card are name, mana cost, illustration, color indicator, type line, expansion symbol, text box, power and toughness, loyalty, hand modifier, life modifier, illustration credit, legal text, and collector number. Some cards may have more than one of any or all of these parts.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 200. General : 200.2.
text: Some parts of a card are also characteristics of the object that has them. See rule 109.3.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 200. General : 200.3.
text: Some objects that arenât cards (tokens, copies of cards, and copies of spells) have some of the parts of a card, but only the ones that are also characteristics. See rule 111 and rule 707.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 201. Name : 201.1.
text: The name of a card is printed on its upper left corner.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 201. Name : 201.2.
text: A cardâs name is always considered to be the English version of its name, regardless of printed language.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 201. Name : 201.2a
text: Two or more objects have the same name if they have at least one name in common, even if one or more of those objects have additional names. An object with no name doesnât have the same name as any other object, including another object with no name.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 201. Name : 201.2b
text: Some spells and abilities refer to two or more objects with different names. Those objects have different names only if each of them has at least one name and no two objects in that group have a name in common.

name: Example for Rule : 201.2b
text: A player controls Lilianaâs Contract, which says, in part, âAt the beginning of your upkeep, if you control four or more Demons with different names, you win the game.â That player controls three Demons with different names and a face-down creature with no name, with an effect making it a Demon. Because the four creatures include one with no name, those four creatures donât count as four Demons with different names. The ability of Lilianaâs Contract wonât trigger.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 201. Name : 201.2c
text: Some spells or abilities check if one object has a different name than a second object or group of objects. The first object has a different name than those objects if the first object has at least one name and has no names in common with any of the other objects, even if one or more of the other objects have no names. If the first object has no name, it does not have a different name than any of the other objects, even if those other objects themselves have names.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 201. Name : 201.3.
text: Some cards with different English names are treated as though they had the same English name. Pairs of cards with this property have names that are interchangeable.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 201. Name : 201.3a
text: For the purposes of all rules, abilities, and effects that refer to a cardâs name, objects with interchangeable names have the same name. (See rules 201.2aâb.)

name: Comprehensive Rules: 201. Name : 201.3b
text: For the purposes of deck construction and format legality, cards with interchangeable names have the same name.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 201. Name : 201.3c
text: If a card has later printings with interchangeable names, the later printings will have an interchangeable names indicator in the bottom left-hand corner referring to the original printingâs three-letter set code and collector number (see rule 213.1d).

name: Comprehensive Rules: 201. Name : 201.4.
text: If an effect instructs a player to choose a card name, the player must choose the name of a card in the Oracle card reference. (See rule 108.1.) A player may not choose the name of a token unless itâs also the name of a card.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 201. Name : 201.4a
text: If a player is instructed to choose a card name with certain characteristics, the player must choose the name of a card whose Oracle text matches those characteristics. (See rule 108.1.)

name: Example for Rule : 201.4a
text: Dispossess reads, in part, âChoose an artifact card name.â The player can choose the name of any artifact card, even one thatâs not legal in the format of the current game. The player canât choose Island, even if an Island on the battlefield has been turned into artifact by some effect.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 201. Name : 201.4b
text: If a player wants to choose the name of a split card, the player must choose the name of one of its halves, but not both. (See rule 709.) If a player is instructed to choose a card name with certain characteristics, use only that halfâs characteristics to determine if this name can be chosen.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 201. Name : 201.4c
text: If a player wants to choose a flip cardâs alternative name, the player may do so. (See rule 710.) If a player is instructed to choose a card name with certain characteristics, use the cardâs characteristics as modified by its alternative characteristics to determine if this name can be chosen.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 201. Name : 201.4d
text: If a player wants to choose the name of the back face of a double-faced card, the player may do so. (See rule 712.) If a player is instructed to choose a card name with certain characteristics, use only the characteristics of the back face to determine if this name can be chosen.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 201. Name : 201.4e
text: If a player wants to choose the name of the combined back face of a meld pair, the player may do so. (See rule 713.) If a player is instructed to choose a card name with certain characteristics, use only the characteristics of the combined back face to determine if this name can be chosen.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 201. Name : 201.4f
text: If a player wants to choose an adventurer cardâs alternative name, the player may do so. (See rule 715.) If a player is instructed to choose a card name with certain characteristics, use the cardâs characteristics as modified by its alternative characteristics to determine if this name can be chosen.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 201. Name : 201.4g
text: Some cards have interchangeable names (see rule 201.3). For all game purposes, these cards have the same name. If a player chooses the name of a card which has interchangeable names, the name of each of those cards has been chosen.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 201. Name : 201.5.
text: Text that refers to the object itâs on by name means just that particular object and not any other objects with that name, regardless of any name changes caused by game effects.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 201. Name : 201.5a
text: If an abilityâs effect grants another ability to an object, and that second ability refers to that first abilityâs source by name, the name refers only to the specific object which is that first abilityâs source. The second ability does not refer to any other object with the same name as the first abilityâs source. However, if the second ability also moved the first abilityâs source to a different public zone, the name refers to the object the source became in its new zone. This is also true if the second ability is copied onto a new object.

name: Example for Rule : 201.5a
text: Gutter Grime has an ability that reads âWhenever a nontoken creature you control dies, put a slime counter on Gutter Grime, then create a green Ooze creature token with âThis creatureâs power and toughness are each equal to the number of slime counters on Gutter Grime.ââ The ability granted to the token only looks at the Gutter Grime that created the token, not at any other Gutter Grime on the battlefield. A copy of that token would also have an ability that referred only to the Gutter Grime that created the original token.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 201. Name : 201.5b
text: If an ability of an object refers to that object by name, and an object with a different name gains that ability, each instance of the first name in the gained ability that refers to the first object by name should be treated as the second name.

name: Example for Rule : 201.5b
text: Quicksilver Elemental says, in part, â{U}: Quicksilver Elemental gains all activated abilities of target creature until end of turn.â If it gains an ability that says â{G}: Regenerate Cudgel Troll,â activating that ability will regenerate Quicksilver Elemental, not the Cudgel Troll it gained the ability from.

name: Example for Rule : 201.5b
text: Glacial Ray is an instant with splice onto Arcane that says âGlacial Ray deals 2 damage to any target.â If itâs spliced onto a Kodamaâs Reach, that Kodamaâs Reach deals 2 damage to the target.

name: Example for Rule : 201.5b
text: Dimir Doppelganger says â{1}{U}{B}: Exile target creature card from a graveyard. Dimir Doppelganger becomes a copy of that card and gains this ability.â Dimir Doppelgangerâs ability is activated targeting a Runeclaw Bear card. The Doppelganger becomes a copy of Runeclaw Bear and gains an ability that should be treated as saying â{1}{U}{B}: Exile target creature card from a graveyard. Runeclaw Bear becomes a copy of that card and gains this ability.â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 201. Name : 201.5c
text: Text printed on some legendary cards refers to that card by a shortened version of its name. Instances of a cardâs shortened name used in this manner are treated as though they used the cardâs full name.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 201. Name : 201.6.
text: Promotional or alternate-art versions of some cards feature a secondary title bar below the name line. The cardâs name as listed in the Oracle card reference is displayed in the secondary title bar, and an alternate name appears in the upper left corner. For the purposes of deck construction, game rules, and effects, these cards have only the card name specified in the secondary title bar. Rules text may also refer to a cardâs alternate name; instances of the alternate name that are present in rules text refer to the name specified in the secondary title bar. The alternate name has no effect on game play.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 202. Mana Cost and Color : 202.1.
text: A cardâs mana cost is indicated by mana symbols near the top of the card. (See rule 107.4.) On most cards, these symbols are printed in the upper right corner. Some cards from the Future Sight set have alternate frames in which the mana symbols appear to the left of the illustration.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 202. Mana Cost and Color : 202.1a
text: The mana cost of an object represents what a player must spend from their mana pool to cast that card. Unless an objectâs mana cost includes Phyrexian mana symbols (see rule 107.4f), paying that mana cost requires matching the type of any colored or colorless mana symbols as well as paying the generic mana indicated in the cost.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 202. Mana Cost and Color : 202.1b
text: Some objects have no mana cost. This normally includes all land cards, any other cards that have no mana symbols where their mana cost would appear, tokens (unless the effect that creates them specifies otherwise), and nontraditional Magic cards. Having no mana cost represents an unpayable cost (see rule 118.6). Note that lands are played without paying any costs (see rule 305, âLandsâ).

name: Comprehensive Rules: 202. Mana Cost and Color : 202.2.
text: An object is the color or colors of the mana symbols in its mana cost, regardless of the color of its frame.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 202. Mana Cost and Color : 202.2a
text: The five colors are white, blue, black, red, and green. The white mana symbol is represented by {W}, blue by {U}, black by {B}, red by {R}, and green by {G}.

name: Example for Rule : 202.2a
text: An object with a mana cost of {2}{W} is white, an object with a mana cost of {2} is colorless, and one with a mana cost of {2}{W}{B} is both white and black.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 202. Mana Cost and Color : 202.2b
text: Objects with no colored mana symbols in their mana costs are colorless.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 202. Mana Cost and Color : 202.2c
text: An object with two or more different colored mana symbols in its mana cost is each of the colors of those mana symbols. Most multicolored cards are printed with a gold frame, but this is not a requirement for a card to be multicolored.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 202. Mana Cost and Color : 202.2d
text: An object with one or more hybrid mana symbols and/or Phyrexian mana symbols in its mana cost is all of the colors of those mana symbols, in addition to any other colors the object might be. (Most cards with hybrid mana symbols in their mana costs are printed in a two-tone frame. See rule 107.4e.)

name: Comprehensive Rules: 202. Mana Cost and Color : 202.2e
text: An object may have a color indicator printed to the left of the type line. That object is each color denoted by that color indicator. (See rule 204.)

name: Comprehensive Rules: 202. Mana Cost and Color : 202.2f
text: Effects may change an objectâs color, give a color to a colorless object, or make a colored object become colorless; see rule 105.3.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 202. Mana Cost and Color : 202.3.
text: The mana value of an object is a number equal to the total amount of mana in its mana cost, regardless of color.

name: Example for Rule : 202.3.
text: A mana cost of {3}{U}{U} translates to a mana value of 5.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 202. Mana Cost and Color : 202.3a
text: The mana value of an object with no mana cost is 0, unless that object is the back face of a transforming double-faced permanent or is a melded permanent.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 202. Mana Cost and Color : 202.3b
text: The mana value of a transforming double-faced permanent or spellâs back face is calculated as though it had the mana cost of its front face. If a permanent or spell is a copy of the back face of a transforming double-faced card (even if the card representing that copy is itself a double-faced card), the mana value of the copy is 0.

name: Example for Rule : 202.3b
text: Huntmaster of the Fells is a transforming double-faced card with mana cost {2}{R}{G}. Its mana value is 4. After it transforms to its other face (Ravager of the Fells), its mana value remains 4.

name: Example for Rule : 202.3b
text: A Clone enters the battlefield as a copy of Ravager of the Fells. Its mana value is 0.

name: Example for Rule : 202.3b
text: Insectile Aberration is the back face of a transforming double-faced card whose front face has mana cost {U}. It becomes a copy of Ravager of the Fells. Its mana value becomes 0.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 202. Mana Cost and Color : 202.3c
text: The mana value of a melded permanent is calculated as though it had the combined mana cost of the front faces of each card that represents it. If a permanent is a copy of a melded permanent (even if that copy is represented by two other meld cards), the mana value of the copy is 0.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 202. Mana Cost and Color : 202.3d
text: The mana value of a split card not on the stack or of a fused split spell on the stack is determined from the combined mana costs of its halves. Otherwise, while a split card is on the stack, the mana value of the spell is determined by the mana cost of the half that was chosen to be cast. See rule 709, âSplit Cards.â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 202. Mana Cost and Color : 202.3e
text: When calculating the mana value of an object with an {X} in its mana cost, X is treated as 0 while the object is not on the stack, and X is treated as the number chosen for it while the object is on the stack.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 202. Mana Cost and Color : 202.3f
text: When calculating the mana value of an object with a hybrid mana symbol in its mana cost, use the largest component of each hybrid symbol.

name: Example for Rule : 202.3f
text: The mana value of a card with mana cost {1}{W/U}{W/U} is 3.

name: Example for Rule : 202.3f
text: The mana value of a card with mana cost {2/B}{2/B}{2/B} is 6.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 202. Mana Cost and Color : 202.3g
text: Each Phyrexian mana symbol in a cardâs mana cost contributes 1 to its mana value.

name: Example for Rule : 202.3g
text: The mana value of a card with mana cost {1}{W/P}{W/P} is 3.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 202. Mana Cost and Color : 202.4.
text: Any additional cost listed in an objectâs rules text or imposed by an effect isnât part of the mana cost. (See rule 601, âCasting Spells.â) Such costs are paid at the same time as the spellâs other costs.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 203. Illustration : 203.1.
text: The illustration is printed on the upper half of a card and has no effect on game play. For example, a creature doesnât have the flying ability unless stated in its rules text, even if itâs depicted as flying.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 204. Color Indicator : 204.1.
text: The color indicator is printed to the left of the type line directly below the illustration. It consists of a circular symbol filled in with one or more colors. A color indicator is usually found on nonland cards without a mana cost.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 204. Color Indicator : 204.2.
text: An object with a color indicator is each color denoted by that color indicator.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 205. Type Line : 205.1.
text: The type line is printed directly below the illustration. It contains the cardâs card type(s). It also contains the cardâs subtype(s) and supertype(s), if applicable.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 205. Type Line : 205.1a
text: Some effects set an objectâs card type. In most such cases, the new card type(s) replaces any existing card types. However, an object with either the instant or sorcery card type retains that type. Counters, stickers, effects, and damage marked on the object remain with it, even if they are meaningless to the new card type. Similarly, when an effect sets one or more of an objectâs subtypes, the new subtype(s) replaces any existing subtypes from the appropriate set (creature types, land types, artifact types, enchantment types, planeswalker types, or spell types). If an objectâs card type is removed, the subtypes correlated with that card type will remain if they are also the subtypes of a card type the object currently has; otherwise, they are also removed for the entire time the objectâs card type is removed. Removing an objectâs subtype doesnât affect its card types at all.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 205. Type Line : 205.1b
text: Some effects change an objectâs card type, supertype, or subtype but specify that the object retains a prior card type, supertype, or subtype. In such cases, all the objectâs prior card types, supertypes, and subtypes are retained. This rule applies to effects that use the phrase âin addition to its typesâ or that state that something is âstill a [type, supertype, or subtype].â Some effects state that an object becomes an âartifact creatureâ; these effects also allow the object to retain all of its prior card types and subtypes. Some effects state that an object becomes a â[creature type or types] artifact creatureâ; these effects also allow the object to retain all of its prior card types and subtypes other than creature types, but replace any existing creature types.

name: Example for Rule : 205.1b
text: An ability reads, âAll lands are 1/1 creatures that are still lands.â The affected lands now have two card types: creature and land. If there were any lands that were also artifacts before the abilityâs effect applied to them, those lands would become âartifact land creatures,â not just âcreatures,â or âland creatures.â The effect allows them to retain both the artifact and land card types. In addition, each land affected by the ability retains any land types and supertypes it had before the ability took effect.

name: Example for Rule : 205.1b
text: An ability reads, âAll artifacts are 1/1 artifact creatures.â If a permanent is both an artifact and an enchantment, it will become an artifact enchantment creature.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 205. Type Line Card Types: 205.2a
text: The card types are artifact, battle, conspiracy, creature, dungeon, enchantment, instant, land, phenomenon, plane, planeswalker, scheme, sorcery, tribal, and vanguard. See section 3, âCard Types.â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 205. Type Line Card Types: 205.2b
text: Some objects have more than one card type (for example, an artifact creature). Such objects satisfy the criteria for any effect that applies to any of their card types.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 205. Type Line Card Types: 205.2c
text: Tokens have card types even though they arenât cards. The same is true of copies of spells and copies of cards.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 205. Type Line Subtypes: 205.3a
text: A card can have one or more subtypes printed on its type line.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 205. Type Line Subtypes: 205.3b
text: Subtypes of each card type except creature and plane are always single words and are listed after a long dash. Each word after the dash is a separate subtype. Subtypes of creature cards are one or two words and are listed after a long dash. Each word or two-word phrase, as listed in rule 205.3m, is a separate subtype. Objects other than planes may have multiple subtypes. Subtypes of planes are also listed after a long dash, but may be multiple words; all words after the dash are, collectively, a single subtype.

name: Example for Rule Subtypes: 205.3b
text: âBasic Land â Mountainâ means the card is a land with the subtype Mountain. âCreature â Goblin Wizardâ means the card is a creature with the subtypes Goblin and Wizard. âArtifact â Equipmentâ means the card is an artifact with the subtype Equipment.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 205. Type Line Subtypes: 205.3c
text: If a card with multiple card types has one or more subtypes, each subtype is correlated to its appropriate card type.

name: Example for Rule Subtypes: 205.3c
text: Dryad Arborâs type line says âLand Creature â Forest Dryad.â Forest is a land type, and Dryad is a creature type.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 205. Type Line Subtypes: 205.3d
text: An object canât gain a subtype that doesnât correspond to one of that objectâs types.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 205. Type Line Subtypes: 205.3e
text: If an effect instructs a player to choose a subtype, that player must choose one, and only one, existing subtype, and the subtype must be for the appropriate card type. For example, the player canât choose a land type if an instruction requires choosing a creature type.

name: Example for Rule Subtypes: 205.3e

name: Comprehensive Rules: 205. Type Line Subtypes: 205.3f

name: Comprehensive Rules: 205. Type Line Subtypes: 205.3g

name: Comprehensive Rules: 205. Type Line Subtypes: 205.3h

name: Comprehensive Rules: 205. Type Line Subtypes: 205.3r

name: Comprehensive Rules: 205. Type Line Supertypes: 205.4a
text: An object can have one or more supertypes. A cardâs supertypes are printed directly before its card types. The supertypes are basic, legendary, ongoing, snow, and world.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 205. Type Line Supertypes: 205.4b
text: An objectâs supertype is independent of its card type and subtype, even though some supertypes are closely identified with specific card types. Changing an objectâs card types or subtypes wonât change its supertypes. Changing an objectâs supertypes wonât change its card types or subtypes. When an object gains or loses a supertype, it retains any other supertypes it had.

name: Example for Rule Supertypes: 205.4b
text: An ability reads, âAll lands are 1/1 creatures that are still lands.â If any of the affected lands were legendary, they are still legendary.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 205. Type Line Supertypes: 205.4c
text:
Any land with the supertype âbasicâ is a basic land. Any land that doesnât have this supertype is a nonbasic land, even if it has a basic land type.
     Cards printed in sets prior to the Eighth Edition core set didnât use the word âbasicâ to indicate a basic land. Cards from those sets with the following names are basic lands and have received errata in the Oracle card reference accordingly: Forest, Island, Mountain, Plains, Swamp, Snow-Covered Forest, Snow-Covered Island, Snow-Covered Mountain, Snow-Covered Plains, and Snow-Covered Swamp.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 205. Type Line Supertypes: 205.4d
text: Any permanent with the supertype âlegendaryâ is subject to the state-based action for legendary permanents, also called the âlegend ruleâ (see rule 704.5j).

name: Comprehensive Rules: 205. Type Line Supertypes: 205.4e
text: Any instant or sorcery spell with the supertype âlegendaryâ is subject to a casting restriction. A player canât cast a legendary instant or sorcery spell unless that player controls a legendary creature or a legendary planeswalker.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 205. Type Line Supertypes: 205.4f
text: Any permanent with the supertype âworldâ is subject to the state-based action for world permanents, also called the âworld ruleâ (see rule 704.5k).

name: Comprehensive Rules: 205. Type Line Supertypes: 205.4g
text: Any permanent with the supertype âsnowâ is a snow permanent. Any permanent that doesnât have this supertype is a nonsnow permanent, regardless of its name.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 205. Type Line Supertypes: 205.4h
text: Any scheme card with the supertype âongoingâ is exempt from the state-based action for schemes (see rule 704.6e).

name: Comprehensive Rules: 206. Expansion Symbol : 206.1.
text: The expansion symbol indicates which Magic set a card is from. Itâs a small icon normally printed below the right edge of the illustration. It has no effect on game play.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 206. Expansion Symbol : 206.2.
text: The color of the expansion symbol indicates the rarity of the card within its set. A red-orange symbol indicates the card is mythic rare. A gold symbol indicates the card is rare. A silver symbol indicates the card is uncommon. A black or white symbol indicates the card is common or is a basic land. A purple symbol signifies a special rarity; to date, only the Time Spiralâ¢ âtimeshiftedâ cards, which were rarer than that setâs rare cards, have had purple expansion symbols. (Prior to the Exodusâ¢ set, all expansion symbols were black, regardless of rarity. Also, prior to the Sixth Edition core set, with the exception of the Simplified Chinese Fifth Edition core set, Magic core sets didnât have expansion symbols at all.)

name: Comprehensive Rules: 206. Expansion Symbol : 206.4.
text: Players may include cards from any printing in their constructed decks if those cards appear in sets allowed in that format (or those cards are specifically allowed by the Magic: The Gathering Tournament Rules). See the Magic: The Gathering Tournament Rules for the current definitions of the constructed formats (WPN.Wizards.com/en/resources/rules-documents).

name: Comprehensive Rules: 206. Expansion Symbol : 206.5.
text: The full list of expansions and expansion symbols can be found in the Card Set Archive section of the Magic website (Magic.Wizards.com/en/game-info/products/card-set-archive).

name: Comprehensive Rules: 207. Text Box : 207.1.
text: The text box is printed on the lower half of the card. It usually contains rules text defining the cardâs abilities.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 207. Text Box : 207.2.
text: The text box may also contain italicized text that has no game function.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 207. Text Box : 207.2a
text: Reminder text is italicized text within parentheses that summarizes a rule that applies to that card. It usually appears on the same line as the ability itâs relevant to, but it may appear on its own line if it applies to an aspect of the card other than an ability.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 207. Text Box : 207.2b
text: Flavor text is italicized text that, like the illustration, adds artistic appeal to the game. It usually appears below the rules text.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 207. Text Box : 207.2c
text: An ability word appears in italics at the beginning of some abilities. Ability words are similar to keywords in that they tie together cards that have similar functionality, but they have no special rules meaning and no individual entries in the Comprehensive Rules. The ability words are adamant, addendum, alliance, battalion, bloodrush, celebration, channel, chroma, cohort, constellation, converge, councilâs dilemma, coven, delirium, descend 4, descend 8, domain, eminence, enrage, fateful hour, fathomless descent, ferocious, formidable, grandeur, hellbent, heroic, imprint, inspired, join forces, kinship, landfall, lieutenant, magecraft, metalcraft, morbid, pack tactics, paradox, parley, radiance, raid, rally, revolt, secret council, spell mastery, strive, sweep, tempting offer, threshold, undergrowth, and will of the council.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 207. Text Box : 207.2d
text: Similar to ability words, flavor words appear in italics at the beginning of some abilities. Flavor words provide a flavorful description of abilities, but they have no special rules meaning and are not listed in the Comprehensive Rules. While an ability word ties together several abilities with similar functionality, each flavor word is tailored to the specific ability it appears with.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 207. Text Box : 207.3.
text: Some cards have decorative icons in the background of their text boxes. For example, a guild icon appears in the text box of many cards associated with the guilds of Ravnica, and a faction icon appears in the text box of most Scars of Mirrodinâ¢ block cards. Similarly, many promotional cards include decorative icons. These icons have no effect on game play.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 207. Text Box : 207.4.
text: The chaos symbol appears in the text box of each plane card to the left of a triggered ability that triggers whenever chaos ensues. The symbol itself has no special rules meaning. See rule 901, âPlanechase.â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 207. Text Box : 207.5.
text: One card (Cryptic Spires) has a set of symbols below the text box that represent each color and an ability that instructs a player to circle two of those colors as they create their deck. To circle a color, the player circles (or otherwise clearly indicates) that colorâs symbol. The mana symbol of each circled color is considered part of that cardâs printed rules text (see rule 613.1) and affects that cardâs color identity (see rule 903.4).

name: Comprehensive Rules: 208. Power/Toughness : 208.1.
text: A creature card has two numbers separated by a slash printed in its lower right corner. The first number is its power (the amount of damage it deals in combat); the second is its toughness (the amount of damage needed to destroy it). For example, 2/3 means the object has power 2 and toughness 3. Power and toughness can be modified or set to particular values by effects.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 208. Power/Toughness : 208.2.
text: Rather than a fixed number, some creature cards have power and/or toughness that includes a star (*).

name: Comprehensive Rules: 208. Power/Toughness : 208.2a
text: The card may have a characteristic-defining ability that sets its power and/or toughness according to some stated condition. (See rule 604.3.) Such an ability is worded â[This creatureâs] [power or toughness] is equal to . . .â or â[This creatureâs] power and toughness are each equal to . . .â This ability functions everywhere, even outside the game. If the ability needs to use a number that canât be determined, including inside a calculation, use 0 instead of that number.

name: Example for Rule : 208.2a
text: Lost Order of Jarkeld has power and toughness each equal to 1+*. It has the abilities âAs Lost Order of Jarkeld enters the battlefield, choose an opponentâ and âLost Order of Jarkeldâs power and toughness are each equal to 1 plus the number of creatures the chosen player controls.â While Lost Order of Jarkeld isnât on the battlefield, there wonât be a chosen player. Its power and toughness will each be equal to 1 plus 0, so itâs 1/1.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 208. Power/Toughness : 208.2b
text: The card may have a static ability that creates a replacement effect that sets the creatureâs power and toughness to one of a number of specific values as it enters the battlefield or is turned face up. (See rule 614, âReplacement Effects.â) Such an ability is worded âAs [this creature] enters the battlefield . . . ,â âAs [this creature] is turned face up . . . ,â or â[This creature] enters the battlefield as . . .â and lists two or more specific power and toughness values (and may also list additional characteristics). The characteristics chosen or determined with these effects affect the creatureâs copiable values. (See rule 707.2.) While the card isnât on the battlefield, its power and toughness are each considered to be 0.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 208. Power/Toughness : 208.3.
text: A noncreature permanent has no power or toughness, even if itâs a card with a power and toughness printed on it (such as a Vehicle). A noncreature object not on the battlefield has power or toughness only if it has a power and toughness printed on it.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 208. Power/Toughness : 208.3a
text: If an effect would be created that sets the base power and/or toughness of a noncreature permanent, or otherwise modifies its power and/or toughness, that effect is created even though it doesnât do anything unless that permanent becomes a creature.

name: Example for Rule : 208.3a
text: Veteran Motorist has the ability âWhenever Veteran Motorist crews a Vehicle, that Vehicle gets +1/+1 until end of turn,â and itâs tapped to pay the crew cost of a Vehicle. This triggered ability resolves while the Vehicle it crewed isnât yet a creature. The continuous effect is created and will apply to the Vehicle once it becomes a creature.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 208. Power/Toughness : 208.4.
text: Some effects refer to a creatureâs âbase power,â âbase toughness,â or âbase power and toughness.â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 208. Power/Toughness : 208.4a
text: Effects that set a creatureâs power and/or toughness to specific values may refer to base power and/or toughness. Other continuous effects may further modify the creatureâs power and toughness. See rule 613, âInteraction of Continuous Effects.â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 208. Power/Toughness : 208.4b
text: Some effects check a creatureâs base power and/or toughness. These effects see that creatureâs characteristics after applying any characteristic-defining abilities and abilities that set power and/or toughness, ignoring any effects and counters that modify power and/or toughness without setting them. See rule 613, âInteraction of Continuous Effects.â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 208. Power/Toughness : 208.5.
text: If a creature somehow has no value for its power, its power is 0. The same is true for toughness.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 209. Loyalty : 209.1.
text: Each planeswalker card has a loyalty number printed in its lower right corner. This indicates its loyalty while itâs not on the battlefield, and it also indicates that the planeswalker enters the battlefield with that many loyalty counters on it (see rule 306.5b).

name: Comprehensive Rules: 209. Loyalty : 209.2.
text: An activated ability with a loyalty symbol in its cost is a loyalty ability. Loyalty abilities follow special rules: A player may activate a loyalty ability of a permanent they control any time they have priority and the stack is empty during a main phase of their turn, but only if none of that permanentâs loyalty abilities have been activated that turn. See rule 606, âLoyalty Abilities.â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 210. Defense : 210.1.
text: Each battle card has a defense number printed in its lower right corner. This indicates its defense while itâs not on the battlefield, and it also indicates that the battle enters the battlefield with that many defense counters on it (see rule 310.4b).

name: Comprehensive Rules: 211. Hand Modifier : 211.1.
text: Each vanguard card has a hand modifier printed in its lower left corner. This is a number preceded by a plus sign, a number preceded by a minus sign, or a zero. This modifier is applied as the starting hand size and the maximum hand size of the vanguard cardâs owner are determined. See rule 103.5.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 212. Life Modifier : 212.1.
text: Each vanguard card has a life modifier printed in its lower right corner. This is a number preceded by a plus sign, a number preceded by a minus sign, or a zero. This modifier is applied as the starting life total of the vanguard cardâs owner is determined. See rule 103.4.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 213. Information Below the Text Box : 213.1.
text: Each card features text printed below the text box that has no effect on game play. Not all card sets were printed with all of the information listed below on each card.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 213. Information Below the Text Box : 213.1a
text: Most card sets feature collector numbers. This information is printed in the form [card number]/[total cards in the set] or simply [card number]. Some cards, such as unique cards in Planeswalker DecksÂ®, have card numbers that exceed the listed total number of cards.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 213. Information Below the Text Box : 213.1b
text: A cardâs rarity is indicated with a single letter following the collector number.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 213. Information Below the Text Box : 213.1c
text: Some promotional cards include information to indicate the specific promotion the card is associated with.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 213. Information Below the Text Box : 213.1d
text: Some cards with interchangeable names include information about a specific version of a card with that interchangeable name. See rule 201.3.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 213. Information Below the Text Box : 213.1e
text: The three-character code representing the set in which a card is printed and the two-character code representing the language in which a card is printed are separated by a bullet point. If a card is premium, these codes are instead separated by a star.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 213. Information Below the Text Box : 213.1f
text: The illustration credit for a card follows the paintbrush icon or, on older cards, the abbreviation âIllus.â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 213. Information Below the Text Box : 213.1g
text:
Legal text (the fine print at the bottom or bottom-right of the card) lists the trademark and copyright information.

3. Card Types

name: Comprehensive Rules: 300. General : 300.1.
text: The card types are artifact, battle, conspiracy, creature, dungeon, enchantment, instant, land, phenomenon, plane, planeswalker, scheme, sorcery, tribal, and vanguard.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 300. General : 300.2.
text: Some objects have more than one card type (for example, an artifact creature). Such objects combine the aspects of each of those card types, and are subject to spells and abilities that affect either or all of those card types.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 300. General : 300.2a
text: An object thatâs both a land and another card type (for example, an artifact land) can only be played as a land. It canât be cast as a spell.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 300. General : 300.2b
text: Each tribal card has another card type. Casting and resolving a tribal card follow the rules for casting and resolving a card of the other card type.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 301. Artifacts : 301.1.
text: A player who has priority may cast an artifact card from their hand during a main phase of their turn when the stack is empty. Casting an artifact as a spell uses the stack. (See rule 601, âCasting Spells.â)

name: Comprehensive Rules: 301. Artifacts : 301.2.
text: When an artifact spell resolves, its controller puts it onto the battlefield under their control.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 301. Artifacts : 301.3.
text: Artifact subtypes are always a single word and are listed after a long dash: âArtifact â Equipment.â Artifact subtypes are also called artifact types. Artifacts may have multiple subtypes. See rule 205.3g for the complete list of artifact types.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 301. Artifacts : 301.4.
text: Artifacts have no characteristics specific to their card type. Most artifacts have no colored mana symbols in their mana costs, and are therefore colorless. However, there is no correlation between being colorless and being an artifact: artifacts may be colored, and colorless objects may be card types other than artifact.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 301. Artifacts : 301.5.
text: Some artifacts have the subtype âEquipment.â An Equipment can be attached to a creature. It canât legally be attached to anything that isnât a creature.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 301. Artifacts : 301.5a
text: The creature an Equipment is attached to is called the âequipped creature.â The Equipment is attached to, or âequips,â that creature.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 301. Artifacts : 301.5b
text: Equipment spells are cast like other artifact spells. Equipment enter the battlefield like other artifacts. They donât enter the battlefield attached to a creature. The equip keyword ability attaches the Equipment to a creature you control (see rule 702.6, âEquipâ). Control of the creature matters only when the equip ability is activated and when it resolves. Spells and other abilities may also attach an Equipment to a creature. If an effect attempts to attach an Equipment to an object that canât be equipped by it, the Equipment doesnât move.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 301. Artifacts : 301.5c
text: An Equipment thatâs also a creature canât equip a creature unless that Equipment has reconfigure (see rule 702.151, âReconfigureâ). An Equipment that loses the subtype âEquipmentâ canât equip a creature. An Equipment canât equip itself. An Equipment that equips an illegal or nonexistent permanent becomes unattached from that permanent but remains on the battlefield. (This is a state-based action. See rule 704.) An Equipment canât equip more than one creature. If a spell or ability would cause an Equipment to equip more than one creature, the Equipmentâs controller chooses which creature it equips.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 301. Artifacts : 301.5d
text: An Equipmentâs controller is separate from the equipped creatureâs controller; the two need not be the same. Changing control of the creature doesnât change control of the Equipment, and vice versa. Only the Equipmentâs controller can activate its abilities. However, if the Equipment grants an ability to the equipped creature (with âgainsâ or âhasâ), the equipped creatureâs controller is the only one who can activate that ability.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 301. Artifacts : 301.5e
text: If an effect attempts to put an Equipment that isnât also an Aura (see rule 303.4i) onto the battlefield attached to either an object it canât legally equip or an object that is undefined, the Equipment enters the battlefield unattached. If the Equipment is a token, itâs created and enters the battlefield unattached.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 301. Artifacts : 301.5f
text: An ability of a permanent that refers to the âequipped creatureâ refers to whatever creature that permanent is attached to, even if the permanent with the ability isnât an Equipment.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 301. Artifacts : 301.6.
text: Some artifacts have the subtype âFortification.â A Fortification can be attached to a land. It canât legally be attached to an object that isnât a land. Fortificationâs analog to the equip keyword ability is the fortify keyword ability. Rules 301.5aâf apply to Fortifications in relation to lands just as they apply to Equipment in relation to creatures, with one clarification relating to rule 301.5c: a Fortification thatâs also a creature (not a land) canât fortify a land. (See rule 702.67, âFortify.â)

name: Comprehensive Rules: 301. Artifacts : 301.7.
text: Some artifacts have the subtype âVehicle.â Most Vehicles have a crew ability which allows them to become artifact creatures. See rule 702.122, âCrew.â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 301. Artifacts : 301.7a
text: Each Vehicle has a printed power and toughness, but it has these characteristics only if itâs also a creature. See rule 208.3.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 301. Artifacts : 301.7b
text: If a Vehicle becomes a creature, it immediately has its printed power and toughness. Other effects, including the effect that makes it a creature, may modify these values or set them to different values.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 302. Creatures : 302.1.
text: A player who has priority may cast a creature card from their hand during a main phase of their turn when the stack is empty. Casting a creature as a spell uses the stack. (See rule 601, âCasting Spells.â)

name: Comprehensive Rules: 302. Creatures : 302.2.
text: When a creature spell resolves, its controller puts it onto the battlefield under their control.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 302. Creatures : 302.3.
text: Creature subtypes are always a single word and are listed after a long dash: âCreature â Human Soldier,â âArtifact Creature â Golem,â and so on. Creature subtypes are also called creature types. Creatures may have multiple subtypes. See rule 205.3m for the complete list of creature types.

name: Example for Rule : 302.3.
text: âCreature â Goblin Wizardâ means the card is a creature with the subtypes Goblin and Wizard.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 302. Creatures : 302.4.
text: Power and toughness are characteristics only creatures have.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 302. Creatures : 302.4a
text: A creatureâs power is the amount of damage it deals in combat.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 302. Creatures : 302.4b
text: A creatureâs toughness is the amount of damage needed to destroy it.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 302. Creatures : 302.4c
text: To determine a creatureâs power and toughness, start with the numbers printed in its lower right corner, then apply any applicable continuous effects. (See rule 613, âInteraction of Continuous Effects.â)

name: Comprehensive Rules: 302. Creatures : 302.5.
text: Creatures can attack and block. (See rule 508, âDeclare Attackers Step,â and rule 509, âDeclare Blockers Step.â)

name: Comprehensive Rules: 302. Creatures : 302.6.
text: A creatureâs activated ability with the tap symbol or the untap symbol in its activation cost canât be activated unless the creature has been under its controllerâs control continuously since their most recent turn began. A creature canât attack unless it has been under its controllerâs control continuously since their most recent turn began. This rule is informally called the âsummoning sicknessâ rule.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 302. Creatures : 302.7.
text: Damage dealt to a creature by a source with neither wither nor infect is marked on that creature (see rule 120.3). If the total damage marked on that creature is greater than or equal to its toughness, that creature has been dealt lethal damage and is destroyed as a state-based action (see rule 704). All damage marked on a creature is removed when it regenerates (see rule 701.15, âRegenerateâ) and during the cleanup step (see rule 514.2).

name: Comprehensive Rules: 303. Enchantments : 303.1.
text: A player who has priority may cast an enchantment card from their hand during a main phase of their turn when the stack is empty. Casting an enchantment as a spell uses the stack. (See rule 601, âCasting Spells.â)

name: Comprehensive Rules: 303. Enchantments : 303.2.
text: When an enchantment spell resolves, its controller puts it onto the battlefield under their control.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 303. Enchantments : 303.3.
text: Enchantment subtypes are always a single word and are listed after a long dash: âEnchantment â Shrine.â Each word after the dash is a separate subtype. Enchantment subtypes are also called enchantment types. Enchantments may have multiple subtypes. See rule 205.3h for the complete list of enchantment types.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 303. Enchantments : 303.4.
text: Some enchantments have the subtype âAura.â An Aura enters the battlefield attached to an object or player. What an Aura can be attached to is defined by its enchant keyword ability (see rule 702.5, âEnchantâ). Other effects can limit what a permanent can be enchanted by.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 303. Enchantments : 303.4a
text: An Aura spell requires a target, which is defined by its enchant ability.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 303. Enchantments : 303.4b
text: The object or player an Aura is attached to is called enchanted. The Aura is attached to, or âenchants,â that object or player.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 303. Enchantments : 303.4c
text: If an Aura is enchanting an illegal object or player as defined by its enchant ability and other applicable effects, the object it was attached to no longer exists, or the player it was attached to has left the game, the Aura is put into its ownerâs graveyard. (This is a state-based action. See rule 704.)

name: Comprehensive Rules: 303. Enchantments : 303.4d
text: An Aura canât enchant itself. If this occurs somehow, the Aura is put into its ownerâs graveyard. An Aura thatâs also a creature canât enchant anything. If this occurs somehow, the Aura becomes unattached, then is put into its ownerâs graveyard. (These are state-based actions. See rule 704.) An Aura canât enchant more than one object or player. If a spell or ability would cause an Aura to become attached to more than one object or player, the Auraâs controller chooses which object or player it becomes attached to.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 303. Enchantments : 303.4e
text: An Auraâs controller is separate from the enchanted objectâs controller or the enchanted player; the two need not be the same. If an Aura enchants an object, changing control of the object doesnât change control of the Aura, and vice versa. Only the Auraâs controller can activate its abilities. However, if the Aura grants an ability to the enchanted object (with âgainsâ or âhasâ), the enchanted objectâs controller is the only one who can activate that ability.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 303. Enchantments : 303.4f
text: If an Aura is entering the battlefield under a playerâs control by any means other than by resolving as an Aura spell, and the effect putting it onto the battlefield doesnât specify the object or player the Aura will enchant, that player chooses what it will enchant as the Aura enters the battlefield. The player must choose a legal object or player according to the Auraâs enchant ability and any other applicable effects.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 303. Enchantments : 303.4g
text: If an Aura is entering the battlefield and there is no legal object or player for it to enchant, the Aura remains in its current zone, unless that zone is the stack. In that case, the Aura is put into its ownerâs graveyard instead of entering the battlefield. If the Aura is a token, it isnât created.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 303. Enchantments : 303.4h
text: If an effect attempts to put a permanent that isnât an Aura, Equipment, or Fortification onto the battlefield attached to an object or player, it enters the battlefield unattached.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 303. Enchantments : 303.4i
text: If an effect attempts to put an Aura onto the battlefield attached to either an object or player it canât legally enchant or an object or player that is undefined, the Aura remains in its current zone, unless that zone is the stack. In that case, the Aura is put into its ownerâs graveyard instead of entering the battlefield. If the Aura is a token, it isnât created.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 303. Enchantments : 303.4j
text: If an effect attempts to attach an Aura on the battlefield to an object or player it canât legally enchant, the Aura doesnât move.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 303. Enchantments : 303.4k
text: If an effect allows an Aura thatâs being turned face up to become attached to an object or player, the Auraâs controller considers the characteristics of that Aura as it would exist if it were face up to determine what it may be attached to, and they must choose a legal object or player according to the Auraâs enchant ability and any other applicable effects.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 303. Enchantments : 303.4m
text: An ability of a permanent that refers to the âenchanted [object or player]â refers to whatever object or player that permanent is attached to, even if the permanent with the ability isnât an Aura.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 303. Enchantments : 303.5.
text: Some enchantments have the subtype âSaga.â See rule 714 for more information about Saga cards.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 303. Enchantments : 303.6.
text: Some enchantments have the subtype âClass.â See rule 716 for more information about Class cards.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 303. Enchantments : 303.7.
text: Some Aura enchantments also have the subtype âRole.â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 303. Enchantments : 303.7a
text: If a permanent has more than one Role controlled by the same player attached to it, each of those Roles except the one with the most recent timestamp is put into its ownerâs graveyard. This is a state-based action. See rule 704.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 304. Instants : 304.1.
text: A player who has priority may cast an instant card from their hand. Casting an instant as a spell uses the stack. (See rule 601, âCasting Spells.â)

name: Comprehensive Rules: 304. Instants : 304.2.
text: When an instant spell resolves, the actions stated in its rules text are followed. Then itâs put into its ownerâs graveyard.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 304. Instants : 304.3.
text: Instant subtypes are always a single word and are listed after a long dash: âInstant â Arcane.â Each word after the dash is a separate subtype. The set of instant subtypes is the same as the set of sorcery subtypes; these subtypes are called spell types. Instants may have multiple subtypes. See rule 205.3k for the complete list of spell types.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 304. Instants : 304.4.
text: Instants canât enter the battlefield. If an instant would enter the battlefield, it remains in its previous zone instead.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 304. Instants : 304.5.
text: If text states that a player may do something âany time they could cast an instantâ or âonly as an instant,â it means only that the player must have priority. The player doesnât need to have an instant card they could cast. Effects that would preclude that player from casting an instant spell donât affect the playerâs capability to perform that action (unless the action is actually casting an instant spell).

name: Comprehensive Rules: 305. Lands : 305.1.
text: A player who has priority may play a land card from their hand during a main phase of their turn when the stack is empty. Playing a land is a special action; it doesnât use the stack (see rule 116). Rather, the player simply puts the land onto the battlefield. Since the land doesnât go on the stack, it is never a spell, and players canât respond to it with instants or activated abilities.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 305. Lands : 305.2.
text: A player can normally play one land during their turn; however, continuous effects may increase this number.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 305. Lands : 305.2a
text: To determine whether a player can play a land, compare the number of lands the player can play this turn with the number of lands they have already played this turn (including lands played as special actions and lands played during the resolution of spells and abilities). If the number of lands the player can play is greater, the play is legal.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 305. Lands : 305.2b
text: A player canât play a land, for any reason, if the number of lands the player can play this turn is equal to or less than the number of lands they have already played this turn. Ignore any part of an effect that instructs a player to do so.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 305. Lands : 305.3.
text: A player canât play a land, for any reason, if it isnât their turn. Ignore any part of an effect that instructs a player to do so.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 305. Lands : 305.4.
text: Effects may also allow players to âputâ lands onto the battlefield. This isnât the same as âplaying a landâ and doesnât count as a land played during the current turn.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 305. Lands : 305.5.
text: Land subtypes are always a single word and are listed after a long dash. Land subtypes are also called land types. Lands may have multiple subtypes. See rule 205.3i for the complete list of land types.

name: Example for Rule : 305.5.
text: âBasic Land â Mountainâ means the card is a land with the subtype Mountain.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 305. Lands : 305.6.
text: The basic land types are Plains, Island, Swamp, Mountain, and Forest. If an object uses the words âbasic land type,â itâs referring to one of these subtypes. An object with the land card type and a basic land type has the intrinsic ability â{T}: Add [mana symbol],â even if the text box doesnât actually contain that text or the object has no text box. For Plains, [mana symbol] is {W}; for Islands, {U}; for Swamps, {B}; for Mountains, {R}; and for Forests, {G}. See rule 107.4a. See also rule 605, âMana Abilities.â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 305. Lands : 305.7.
text: If an effect sets a landâs subtype to one or more of the basic land types, the land no longer has its old land type. It loses all abilities generated from its rules text, its old land types, and any copiable effects affecting that land, and it gains the appropriate mana ability for each new basic land type. Note that this doesnât remove any abilities that were granted to the land by other effects. Setting a landâs subtype doesnât add or remove any card types (such as creature) or supertypes (such as basic, legendary, and snow) the land may have. If a land gains one or more land types in addition to its own, it keeps its land types and rules text, and it gains the new land types and mana abilities.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 305. Lands : 305.8.
text: Any land with the supertype âbasicâ is a basic land. Any land that doesnât have this supertype is a nonbasic land, even if it has a basic land type.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 305. Lands : 305.9.
text: If an object is both a land and another card type, it can be played only as a land. It canât be cast as a spell.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 306. Planeswalkers : 306.1.
text: A player who has priority may cast a planeswalker card from their hand during a main phase of their turn when the stack is empty. Casting a planeswalker as a spell uses the stack. (See rule 601, âCasting Spells.â)

name: Comprehensive Rules: 306. Planeswalkers : 306.2.
text: When a planeswalker spell resolves, its controller puts it onto the battlefield under their control.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 306. Planeswalkers : 306.3.
text: Planeswalker subtypes are always a single word and are listed after a long dash: âPlaneswalker â Jace.â Each word after the dash is a separate subtype. Planeswalker subtypes are also called planeswalker types. Planeswalkers may have multiple subtypes. See rule 205.3j for the complete list of planeswalker types.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 306. Planeswalkers : 306.4.
text: Previously, planeswalkers were subject to a âplaneswalker uniqueness ruleâ that stopped a player from controlling two planeswalkers of the same planeswalker type. This rule has been removed and planeswalker cards printed before this change have received errata in the Oracle card reference to have the legendary supertype. Like other legendary permanents, they are subject to the âlegend ruleâ (see rule 704.5j).

name: Comprehensive Rules: 306. Planeswalkers : 306.5.
text: Loyalty is a characteristic only planeswalkers have.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 306. Planeswalkers : 306.5a
text: The loyalty of a planeswalker card not on the battlefield is equal to the number printed in its lower right corner.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 306. Planeswalkers : 306.5b
text: A planeswalker has the intrinsic ability âThis permanent enters the battlefield with a number of loyalty counters on it equal to its printed loyalty number.â This ability creates a replacement effect (see rule 614.1c).

name: Comprehensive Rules: 306. Planeswalkers : 306.5c
text: The loyalty of a planeswalker on the battlefield is equal to the number of loyalty counters on it.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 306. Planeswalkers : 306.5d
text: Each planeswalker has a number of loyalty abilities, which are activated abilities with loyalty symbols in their costs. Loyalty abilities follow special rules: A player may activate a loyalty ability of a permanent they control any time they have priority and the stack is empty during a main phase of their turn, but only if none of that permanentâs loyalty abilities have been activated that turn. See rule 606, âLoyalty Abilities.â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 306. Planeswalkers : 306.6.
text: Planeswalkers can be attacked. (See rule 508, âDeclare Attackers Step.â)

name: Comprehensive Rules: 306. Planeswalkers : 306.7.
text: Previously, planeswalkers were subject to a redirection effect that allowed a player to have noncombat damage that would be dealt to an opponent be dealt to a planeswalker under that opponentâs control instead. This rule has been removed and certain cards have received errata in the Oracle card reference to deal damage directly to planeswalkers.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 306. Planeswalkers : 306.8.
text: Damage dealt to a planeswalker results in that many loyalty counters being removed from it.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 306. Planeswalkers : 306.9.
text: If a planeswalkerâs loyalty is 0, itâs put into its ownerâs graveyard. (This is a state-based action. See rule 704.)

name: Comprehensive Rules: 307. Sorceries : 307.1.
text: A player who has priority may cast a sorcery card from their hand during a main phase of their turn when the stack is empty. Casting a sorcery as a spell uses the stack. (See rule 601, âCasting Spells.â)

name: Comprehensive Rules: 307. Sorceries : 307.2.
text: When a sorcery spell resolves, the actions stated in its rules text are followed. Then itâs put into its ownerâs graveyard.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 307. Sorceries : 307.3.
text: Sorcery subtypes are always a single word and are listed after a long dash: âSorcery â Arcane.â Each word after the dash is a separate subtype. The set of sorcery subtypes is the same as the set of instant subtypes; these subtypes are called spell types. Sorceries may have multiple subtypes. See rule 205.3k for the complete list of spell types.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 307. Sorceries : 307.4.
text: Sorceries canât enter the battlefield. If a sorcery would enter the battlefield, it remains in its previous zone instead.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 307. Sorceries : 307.5.
text: If a spell, ability, or effect states that a player can do something only âany time they could cast a sorceryâ or âonly as a sorcery,â it means only that the player must have priority, it must be during the main phase of their turn, and the stack must be empty. The player doesnât need to have a sorcery card they could cast. Effects that would preclude that player from casting a sorcery spell donât affect the playerâs capability to perform that action (unless the action is actually casting a sorcery spell).

name: Comprehensive Rules: 307. Sorceries : 307.5a
text: Similarly, if an effect checks to see if a spell was cast âany time a sorcery couldnât have been cast,â itâs checking only whether the spellâs controller cast it without having priority, during a phase other than their main phase, or while another object was on the stack.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 308. Tribals : 308.1.
text: Each tribal card has another card type. Casting and resolving a tribal card follows the rules for casting and resolving a card of the other card type.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 308. Tribals : 308.2.
text: Tribal subtypes are always a single word and are listed after a long dash: âTribal Enchantment â Merfolk.â The set of tribal subtypes is the same as the set of creature subtypes; these subtypes are called creature types. Tribals may have multiple subtypes. See rule 205.3m for the complete list of creature types.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 309. Dungeons : 309.1.
text: Dungeon is a card type seen only on nontraditional Magic cards.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 309. Dungeons : 309.2.
text: Dungeon cards begin outside the game. Dungeon cards arenât part of a playerâs deck or sideboard. They are brought into the game using the venture into the dungeon keyword action. See rule 701.46, âVenture into the Dungeon.â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 309. Dungeons : 309.2a
text: If a player ventures into the dungeon while they donât own a dungeon card in the command zone, they choose a dungeon card they own from outside the game and put it into the command zone.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 309. Dungeons : 309.2b
text: A dungeon card thatâs brought into the game is put into the command zone until it leaves the game.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 309. Dungeons : 309.2c
text: Dungeon cards are not permanents. They canât be cast. Dungeon cards canât leave the command zone except as they leave the game.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 309. Dungeons : 309.2d
text: If an effect other than a venture into the dungeon keyword action would bring a dungeon card into the game from outside the game, it doesnât; that card remains outside the game.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 309. Dungeons : 309.3.
text: A player can own only one dungeon card in the command zone at a time, and they canât bring a dungeon card into the game if a dungeon card they own is in the command zone.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 309. Dungeons : 309.4.
text: Each dungeon card has a series of rooms connected to one another with arrows. A player uses a venture marker placed on the dungeon card they own to indicate which room they are currently in.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 309. Dungeons : 309.4a
text: As a player puts a dungeon they own into the command zone, they put their venture marker on the topmost room.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 309. Dungeons : 309.4b
text: Each room has a name. These names are considered flavor text and do not affect game play.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 309. Dungeons : 309.4c
text: Each room has a triggered ability called a room ability whose effect is printed on the card. They all have the same trigger condition not printed on the card. The full text of each room ability is âWhen you move your venture marker into this room, [effect.]â As long as a dungeon card is in the command zone, its abilities may trigger. Each room ability is controlled by the player who owns the dungeon card that is that abilityâs source.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 309. Dungeons : 309.5.
text: The venture into the dungeon keyword action allows players to move their venture marker down the rooms of a dungeon card.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 309. Dungeons : 309.5a
text: If a player ventures into the dungeon while they own a dungeon card in the command zone and their venture marker isnât on that dungeonâs bottommost room, they move their venture marker from the room it is on to the next room, following the direction of an arrow pointing away from the room their venture marker is on. If there are multiple arrows pointing away from the room the playerâs venture marker is on, they choose one of them to follow.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 309. Dungeons : 309.5b
text: If a player ventures into the dungeon while they own a dungeon card in the command zone and their venture marker is on that dungeon cardâs bottommost room, they remove that dungeon card from the game. They then choose a dungeon card they own from outside the game and put it into the command zone. They put their venture marker on the topmost room.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 309. Dungeons : 309.6.
text: If a playerâs venture marker is on the bottommost room of a dungeon card, and that dungeon card isnât the source of a room ability that has triggered but not yet left the stack, the dungeon cardâs owner removes it from the game. (This is a state-based action. See rule 704.)

name: Comprehensive Rules: 309. Dungeons : 309.7.
text: A player completes a dungeon as that dungeon card is removed from the game.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 310. Battles : 310.1.
text: A player who has priority may cast a battle card from their hand during a main phase of their turn when the stack is empty. Casting a battle as a spell uses the stack. (See rule 601, âCasting Spells.â)

name: Comprehensive Rules: 310. Battles : 310.2.
text: When a battle spell resolves, its controller puts it onto the battlefield under their control.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 310. Battles : 310.3.
text: Battle subtypes are always a single word and are listed after a long dash: âBattle â Siege.â Battle subtypes are also called battle types. See rule 205.3q for the complete list of battle types.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 310. Battles : 310.4.
text: Defense is a characteristic that battles have.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 310. Battles : 310.4a
text: The defense of a battle card not on the battlefield is equal to the number printed in its lower right corner.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 310. Battles : 310.4b
text: A battle has the intrinsic ability âThis permanent enters the battlefield with a number of defense counters on it equal to its printed defense number.â This ability creates a replacement effect (see rule 614.1c).

name: Comprehensive Rules: 310. Battles : 310.4c
text: The defense of a battle on the battlefield is equal to the number of defense counters on it.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 310. Battles : 310.5.
text: Battles can be attacked. (See rule 508, âDeclare Attackers Step.â)

name: Comprehensive Rules: 310. Battles : 310.6.
text: Damage dealt to a battle results in that many defense counters being removed from it.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 310. Battles : 310.7.
text: If a battleâs defense is 0 and it isnât the source of an ability which has triggered but not yet left the stack, itâs put into its ownerâs graveyard. (This is a state-based action. See rule 704.)

name: Comprehensive Rules: 310. Battles : 310.8.
text: Each battle has a player designated as its protector.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 310. Battles : 310.8a
text: As a battle enters the battlefield, its controller chooses a player to be its protector. Which players may be chosen as its protector are determined by its battle type (see rule 310.11). If it has no battle types, its controller becomes its protector.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 310. Battles : 310.8b
text: A battleâs protector can never attack it. A battle can be attacked by any attacking player for whom its protector is a defending player. Notably, a Siege battle can be attacked by its own controller.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 310. Battles : 310.8c
text: A battleâs protector may block creatures attacking that battle with creatures they control. Creatures controlled by other players canât block those attackers.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 310. Battles : 310.8d
text: If a battleâs protector is a different player than its controller, all rules and effects that refer to the âdefending playerâ relative to a battle that is being attacked refer to that battleâs protector rather than its controller. See rule 508.5.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 310. Battles : 310.8e
text: If a rule or effect refers to the player who protects a battle, it means the player who is that battleâs protector.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 310. Battles : 310.8f
text: A battle can have only one protector at a time. A battleâs protector stops being its protector if another player becomes its protector.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 310. Battles : 310.8g
text: A battleâs protector doesnât change if it stops being a battle or it becomes a copy of another battle.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 310. Battles : 310.9.
text: A battle canât be attached to players or permanents, even if it is also an Aura, Equipment, or Fortification. If a battle is somehow attached to a permanent, it becomes unattached. This is a state-based action (see rule 704).

name: Comprehensive Rules: 310. Battles : 310.10.
text: If a battle that isnât being attacked has no player designated as its protector, or its protector is a player who canât be its protector based on its battle type, its controller chooses an appropriate player to be its protector. If no player can be chosen this way, the battle is put into its ownerâs graveyard. This is a state-based action (see rule 704).

name: Comprehensive Rules: 310. Battles : 310.11.
text: All currently existing battles have the subtype Siege. Sieges are subject to special rules.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 310. Battles : 310.11a
text: As a Siege enters the battlefield, its controller must choose its protector from among their opponents. Only an opponent of a Siegeâs controller can be its protector.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 310. Battles : 310.11b
text: Sieges have the intrinsic ability âWhen the last defense counter is removed from this permanent, exile it, then you may cast it transformed without paying its mana cost.â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 311. Planes : 311.1.
text: Plane is a card type seen only on nontraditional Magic cards. Only the Planechase casual variant uses plane cards. See rule 901, âPlanechase.â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 311. Planes : 311.2.
text: Plane cards remain in the command zone throughout the game, both while theyâre part of a planar deck and while theyâre face up. Theyâre not permanents. They canât be cast. If a plane card would leave the command zone, it remains in the command zone.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 311. Planes : 311.3.
text: Plane subtypes are listed after a long dash, and may be multiple words: âPlane â Serraâs Realm.â All words after the dash are, collectively, a single subtype. Planar subtypes are called planar types. A plane can have only one subtype. See rule 205.3n for the complete list of planar types.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 311. Planes : 311.4.
text: A plane card may have any number of static, triggered, and/or activated abilities. As long as a plane card is face up in the command zone, its static abilities affect the game, its triggered abilities may trigger, and its activated abilities may be activated.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 311. Planes : 311.5.
text: The controller of a face-up plane card is the player designated as the planar controller. Normally, the planar controller is whoever the active player is. However, if the current planar controller would leave the game, instead the next player in turn order that wouldnât leave the game becomes the planar controller, then the old planar controller leaves the game. The new planar controller retains that designation until they leave the game or a different player becomes the active player, whichever comes first.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 311. Planes : 311.6.
text: A face-up plane card thatâs turned face down becomes a new object.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 311. Planes : 311.7.
text: Each plane card has a triggered ability that triggers âWhenever chaos ensues.â These are called chaos abilities. Each one is indicated by a chaos symbol to the left of the ability, though the symbol itself has no special rules meaning. This ability triggers if the chaos symbol is rolled on the planar die (see rule 901.9b), if a resolving spell or ability says that chaos ensues, or if a resolving spell or ability states that chaos ensues for a particular object. In the last case, the chaos ability can trigger even if that plane card is still in the planar deck but revealed. A chaos ability is controlled by the current planar controller.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 312. Phenomena : 312.1.
text: Phenomenon is a card type seen only on nontraditional Magic cards. Only the Planechase casual variant uses phenomenon cards. See rule 901, âPlanechase.â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 312. Phenomena : 312.2.
text: Phenomenon cards remain in the command zone throughout the game, both while theyâre part of a planar deck and while theyâre face up. Theyâre not permanents. They canât be cast. If a phenomenon card would leave the command zone, it remains in the command zone.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 312. Phenomena : 312.3.
text: Phenomenon cards have no subtypes.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 312. Phenomena : 312.4.
text: The controller of a face-up phenomenon card is the player designated as the planar controller. Normally, the planar controller is whoever the active player is. However, if the current planar controller would leave the game, instead the next player in turn order that wouldnât leave the game becomes the planar controller, then the old planar controller leaves the game. The new planar controller retains that designation until they leave the game or a different player becomes the active player, whichever comes first.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 312. Phenomena : 312.5.
text: Each phenomenon card has a triggered ability that triggers when you encounter it. âWhen you encounter [this phenomenon]â means âWhen you move this card off a planar deck and turn it face up.â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 312. Phenomena : 312.6.
text: A face-up phenomenon card thatâs turned face down becomes a new object.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 312. Phenomena : 312.7.
text: If a phenomenon card is face up in the command zone, and it isnât the source of a triggered ability that has triggered but not yet left the stack, the planar controller planeswalks the next time a player would receive priority. (This is a state-based action; see rule 704. See also rule 701.24, âPlaneswalk.â)

name: Comprehensive Rules: 313. Vanguards : 313.1.
text: Vanguard is a card type seen only on nontraditional Magic cards. Only the Vanguard casual variant uses vanguard cards. See rule 902, âVanguard.â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 313. Vanguards : 313.2.
text: Vanguard cards remain in the command zone throughout the game. Theyâre not permanents. They canât be cast. If a vanguard card would leave the command zone, it remains in the command zone.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 313. Vanguards : 313.3.
text: Vanguard cards have no subtypes.
