name: Comprehensive Rules: 313. Vanguards : 313.4.
text: A vanguard card may have any number of static, triggered, and/or activated abilities. As long as a vanguard card is in the command zone, its static abilities affect the game, its triggered abilities may trigger, and its activated abilities may be activated.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 313. Vanguards : 313.5.
text: The owner of a vanguard card is the player who started the game with it in the command zone. The controller of a face-up vanguard card is its owner.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 313. Vanguards : 313.6.
text: Each vanguard card has a hand modifier printed in its lower left corner. This is a number preceded by a plus sign, a number preceded by a minus sign, or a zero. This modifier is applied to the starting hand size and maximum hand size of the vanguard cardâs owner (normally seven). The resulting number is both how many cards that player draws at the beginning of the game and their maximum hand size. See rule 103.5.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 313. Vanguards : 313.7.
text: Each vanguard card has a life modifier printed in its lower right corner. This is a number preceded by a plus sign, a number preceded by a minus sign, or a zero. This modifier is applied as the starting life total of the vanguard cardâs owner (normally 20) to is determined. See rule 103.4.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 314. Schemes : 314.1.
text: Scheme is a card type seen only on nontraditional Magic cards. Only the Archenemy casual variant uses scheme cards. See rule 904, âArchenemy.â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 314. Schemes : 314.2.
text: Scheme cards remain in the command zone throughout the game, both while theyâre part of a scheme deck and while theyâre face up. Theyâre not permanents. They canât be cast. If a scheme card would leave the command zone, it remains in the command zone.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 314. Schemes : 314.3.
text: Scheme cards have no subtypes.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 314. Schemes : 314.4.
text: A scheme card may have any number of static, triggered, and/or activated abilities. As long as a scheme card is face up in the command zone, its static abilities affect the game, its triggered abilities may trigger, and its activated abilities may be activated.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 314. Schemes : 314.5.
text: The owner of a scheme card is the player who started the game with it in the command zone. The controller of a face-up scheme card is its owner.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 314. Schemes : 314.6.
text: If a non-ongoing scheme card is face up in the command zone, and no triggered abilities of any scheme are on the stack or waiting to be put on the stack, that scheme card is turned face down and put on the bottom of its ownerâs scheme deck the next time a player would receive priority. (This is a state-based action. See rule 704.)

name: Comprehensive Rules: 314. Schemes : 314.7.
text: If an ability of a scheme card includes the text âthis scheme,â it means the scheme card in the command zone thatâs the source of that ability. This is an exception to rule 109.2.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 315. Conspiracies : 315.1.
text: Conspiracy cards are used only in limited play, particularly in the Conspiracy Draft variant (see rule 905). Conspiracy cards arenât used in constructed play.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 315. Conspiracies : 315.2.
text: At the start of a game, before decks are shuffled, each player may put any number of conspiracy cards from their sideboard into the command zone. Conspiracy cards with hidden agenda are put into the command zone face down. (See rule 702.106, âHidden Agenda.â)

name: Comprehensive Rules: 315. Conspiracies : 315.3.
text: Conspiracy cards remain in the command zone throughout the game. Theyâre not permanents. They canât be cast or included in a deck. If a conspiracy card would leave the command zone, it remains in the command zone. Conspiracy cards that arenât in the game canât be brought into the game.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 315. Conspiracies : 315.4.
text: Conspiracy cards have no subtypes.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 315. Conspiracies : 315.5.
text: Conspiracy cards may have any number of static or triggered abilities. As long as a conspiracy card is face up in the command zone, its static abilities affect the game, and its triggered abilities may trigger.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 315. Conspiracies : 315.5a
text: Abilities of conspiracy cards may affect the start-of-game procedure.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 315. Conspiracies : 315.5b
text: Face-down conspiracy cards have no characteristics.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 315. Conspiracies : 315.6.
text: The owner of a conspiracy card is the player who put it into the command zone at the start of the game. The controller of a conspiracy card is its owner.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 315. Conspiracies : 315.7.
text:
At any time, you may look at a face-down conspiracy card you control. You canât look at face-down conspiracy cards controlled by other players.

4. Zones

name: Comprehensive Rules: 400. General : 400.1.
text: A zone is a place where objects can be during a game. There are normally seven zones: library, hand, battlefield, graveyard, stack, exile, and command. Some older cards also use the ante zone. Each player has their own library, hand, and graveyard. The other zones are shared by all players.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 400. General : 400.2.
text: Public zones are zones in which all players can see the cardsâ faces, except for those cards that some rule or effect specifically allow to be face down. Graveyard, battlefield, stack, exile, ante, and command are public zones. Hidden zones are zones in which not all players can be expected to see the cardsâ faces. Library and hand are hidden zones, even if all the cards in one such zone happen to be revealed.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 400. General : 400.3.
text: If an object would go to any library, graveyard, or hand other than its ownerâs, it goes to its ownerâs corresponding zone.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 400. General : 400.4.
text: Cards with certain card types canât enter certain zones.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 400. General : 400.4a
text: If an instant or sorcery card would enter the battlefield, it remains in its previous zone.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 400. General : 400.4b
text: If a conspiracy, phenomenon, plane, scheme, or vanguard card would leave the command zone, it remains in the command zone.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 400. General : 400.5.
text: The order of objects in a library, in a graveyard, or on the stack canât be changed except when effects or rules allow it. The same is true for objects arranged in face-down piles in other zones. Other objects in other zones can be arranged however their owners wish, although who controls those objects, whether theyâre tapped or flipped, and what other objects are attached to them must remain clear to all players.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 400. General : 400.6.
text: If an object would move from one zone to another, determine what event is moving the object. If the object is moving to a public zone and its owner will be able to look at it in that zone, its owner looks at it to see if it has any abilities that would affect the move. If the object is moving to the battlefield, each other player who will be able to look at it in that zone does so. Then any appropriate replacement effects, whether they come from that object or from elsewhere, are applied to that event. If any effects or rules try to do two or more contradictory or mutually exclusive things to a particular object, that objectâs controllerâor its owner if it has no controllerâchooses which effect to apply, and what that effect does. (Note that multiple instances of the same thing may be mutually exclusive; for example, two simultaneous âdestroyâ effects.) Then the event moves the object.

name: Example for Rule : 400.6.
text: Exquisite Archangel has an ability which reads âIf you would lose the game, instead exile Exquisite Archangel and your life total becomes equal to your starting life total.â A spell deals 5 damage to a player with 5 life and 5 damage to an Exquisite Archangel under that playerâs control. As state-based actions are performed, that playerâs life total becomes equal to their starting life total, and that player chooses whether Exquisite Archangel moves to its ownerâs graveyard or to exile.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 400. General : 400.7.
text: An object that moves from one zone to another becomes a new object with no memory of, or relation to, its previous existence. This rule has the following exceptions.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 400. General : 400.7a
text: Effects from spells, activated abilities, and triggered abilities that change the characteristics or controller of a permanent spell on the stack continue to apply to the permanent that spell becomes.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 400. General : 400.7b
text: Effects from static abilities that grant an ability to a permanent spell that functions on the battlefield continue to apply to the permanent that spell becomes (see rule 611.3d).

name: Comprehensive Rules: 400. General : 400.7c
text: Prevention effects that apply to damage from a permanent spell on the stack continue to apply to damage from the permanent that spell becomes.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 400. General : 400.7d
text: An ability of a permanent can reference information about the spell that became that permanent as it resolved, including what costs were paid to cast that spell or what mana was spent to pay those costs.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 400. General : 400.7e
text: Abilities that trigger when an object moves from one zone to another (for example, âWhen Rancor is put into a graveyard from the battlefieldâ) can find the new object that it became in the zone it moved to when the ability triggered, if that zone is a public zone.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 400. General : 400.7f
text: Abilities that trigger when an enchanted permanent leaves the battlefield can find the new object that each Aura enchanting that permanent became in its ownerâs graveyard if it was put into that graveyard at the same time the enchanted permanent left the battlefield. It can also find the new object that each Aura enchanting it became in its ownerâs graveyard as a result of being put there as a state-based action for not being attached to a permanent. (See rule 704.5m.)

name: Comprehensive Rules: 400. General : 400.7g
text: If an effect grants a nonland card an ability that allows it to be cast, that ability will continue to apply to the new object that card became after it moved to the stack as a result of being cast this way.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 400. General : 400.7h
text: If an effect allows a nonland card to be cast, other parts of that effect can find the new object that card becomes after it moves to the stack as a result of being cast this way.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 400. General : 400.7i
text: If an effect allows a land card to be played, other parts of that effect can find the new object that land card becomes after it moves to the battlefield as a result of being played this way.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 400. General : 400.7j
text: If an effect causes an object to move to a public zone, other parts of that effect can find that object. If the cost of a spell or ability causes an object to move to a public zone, that spell or abilityâs effects can find that object.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 400. General : 400.7k
text: After resolving a madness triggered ability (see rule 702.35), if the exiled card wasnât cast and was moved to a public zone, effects referencing the discarded card can find that object.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 400. General : 400.7m
text: Stickers on an object in a public zone are retained as it moves to another public zone (see rule 123.5). Any effects from stickers continue to apply to the new object it becomes in that zone.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 400. General : 400.8.
text: If an object in the exile zone is exiled, it doesnât change zones, but it becomes a new object that has just been exiled.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 400. General : 400.9.
text: If a face-up object in the command zone is turned face down, it becomes a new object.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 400. General : 400.10.
text: If an object in the command zone is put into the command zone, it doesnât change zones, but it becomes a new object that has just entered the command zone.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 400. General : 400.11.
text: An object is outside the game if it isnât in any of the gameâs zones. Outside the game is not a zone.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 400. General : 400.11a
text: Cards in a playerâs sideboard are outside the game. See rule 100.4.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 400. General : 400.11b
text: Some effects bring cards into a game from outside the game. Those cards remain in the game until the game ends, their owner leaves the game, or a rule or effect removes them from the game, whichever comes first.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 400. General : 400.11c
text: Cards outside the game canât be affected by spells or abilities, except for characteristic-defining abilities printed on them (see rule 604.3) and spells and abilities that allow those cards to be brought into the game.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 400. General : 400.12.
text: Some effects instruct a player to do something to a zone (such as âShuffle your hand into your libraryâ). That action is performed on all cards in that zone. The zone itself is not affected.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 401. Library : 401.1.
text: When a game begins, each playerâs deck becomes their library.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 401. Library : 401.2.
text: Each library must be kept in a single face-down pile. Players canât look at or change the order of cards in a library.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 401. Library : 401.3.
text: Any player may count the number of cards remaining in any playerâs library at any time.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 401. Library : 401.4.
text: If an effect puts two or more cards in a specific position in a library at the same time, the owner of those cards may arrange them in any order. That libraryâs owner doesnât reveal the order in which the cards go into the library.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 401. Library : 401.5.
text: Some effects tell a player to play with the top card of their library revealed, or say that a player may look at the top card of their library. If the top card of the playerâs library changes while a spell is being cast, the new top card wonât be revealed and canât be looked at until the spell becomes cast (see rule 601.2i). The same is true with relation to an ability being activated.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 401. Library : 401.6.
text: If an effect causes a player to play with the top card of their library revealed, and that particular card stops being revealed for any length of time before being revealed again, it becomes a new object.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 401. Library : 401.7.
text: If an effect causes a player to put a card into a library âNth from the top,â and that library has fewer than N cards in it, the player puts that card on the bottom of that library.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 402. Hand : 402.1.
text: The hand is where a player holds cards that have been drawn. Cards can be put into a playerâs hand by other effects as well. At the beginning of the game, each player draws a number of cards equal to that playerâs starting hand size, normally seven. (See rule 103, âStarting the Game.â)

name: Comprehensive Rules: 402. Hand : 402.2.
text: Each player has a maximum hand size, which is normally seven cards. A player may have any number of cards in their hand, but as part of their cleanup step, the player must discard excess cards down to the maximum hand size.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 402. Hand : 402.3.
text: A player may arrange their hand in any convenient fashion and look at it at any time. A player canât look at the cards in another playerâs hand but may count those cards at any time.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 403. Battlefield : 403.1.
text: Most of the area between the players represents the battlefield. The battlefield starts out empty. Permanents a player controls are normally kept in front of them on the battlefield, though there are some cases (such as an Aura attached to another playerâs permanent) when a permanent one player controls is kept closer to a different player.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 403. Battlefield : 403.2.
text: A spell or ability affects and checks only the battlefield unless it specifically mentions a player or another zone.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 403. Battlefield : 403.3.
text: Permanents exist only on the battlefield. Every object on the battlefield is a permanent. See rule 110, âPermanents.â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 403. Battlefield : 403.4.
text: Whenever a permanent enters the battlefield, it becomes a new object and has no relationship to any previous permanent represented by the same card, except for the cases listed in rule 400.7. (This is also true for any objects entering any zone.)

name: Comprehensive Rules: 403. Battlefield : 403.5.
text: Previously, the battlefield was called the âin-play zone.â Cards that were printed with text that contains the phrases âin play,â âfrom play,â âinto play,â or the like are referring to the battlefield. Cards that were printed with that text have received errata in the Oracle card reference.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 404. Graveyard : 404.1.
text: A playerâs graveyard is their discard pile. Any object thatâs countered, discarded, destroyed, or sacrificed is put on top of its ownerâs graveyard, as is any instant or sorcery spell thatâs finished resolving. Each playerâs graveyard starts out empty.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 404. Graveyard : 404.2.
text: Each graveyard is kept in a single face-up pile. A player can examine the cards in any graveyard at any time but normally canât change their order. Additional rules applying to sanctioned tournaments may allow a player to change the order of cards in their graveyard.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 404. Graveyard : 404.3.
text: If an effect or rule puts two or more cards into the same graveyard at the same time, the owner of those cards may arrange them in any order.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 405. Stack : 405.1.
text: When a spell is cast, the physical card is put on the stack (see rule 601.2a). When an ability is activated or triggers, it goes on top of the stack without any card associated with it (see rules 602.2a and 603.3).

name: Comprehensive Rules: 405. Stack : 405.2.
text: The stack keeps track of the order that spells and/or abilities were added to it. Each time an object is put on the stack, itâs put on top of all objects already there.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 405. Stack : 405.3.
text: If an effect puts two or more objects on the stack at the same time, those controlled by the active player are put on lowest, followed by each other playerâs objects in APNAP order (see rule 101.4). If a player controls more than one of these objects, that player chooses their relative order on the stack.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 405. Stack : 405.4.
text: Each spell has all the characteristics of the card associated with it. Each activated or triggered ability thatâs on the stack has the text of the ability that created it and no other characteristics. The controller of a spell is the person who cast it. The controller of an activated ability is the player who activated it. The controller of a triggered ability is the player who controlled the abilityâs source when it triggered, unless itâs a delayed triggered ability. To determine the controller of a delayed triggered ability, see rules 603.7dâf.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 405. Stack : 405.5.
text: When all players pass in succession, the top (last-added) spell or ability on the stack resolves. If the stack is empty when all players pass, the current step or phase ends and the next begins.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 405. Stack : 405.6.
text: Some things that happen during the game donât use the stack.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 405. Stack : 405.6a
text: Effects donât go on the stack; theyâre the result of spells and abilities resolving. Effects may create delayed triggered abilities, however, and these may go on the stack when they trigger (see rule 603.7).

name: Comprehensive Rules: 405. Stack : 405.6b
text: Static abilities continuously generate effects and donât go on the stack. (See rule 604, âHandling Static Abilities.â) This includes characteristic-defining abilities such as â[This object] is redâ (see rule 604.3).

name: Comprehensive Rules: 405. Stack : 405.6c
text: Mana abilities resolve immediately. If a mana ability both produces mana and has another effect, the mana is produced and the other effect happens immediately. If a player had priority before a mana ability was activated, that player gets priority after it resolves. (See rule 605, âMana Abilities.â)

name: Comprehensive Rules: 405. Stack : 405.6d
text: Special actions donât use the stack; they happen immediately. See rule 116, âSpecial Actions.â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 405. Stack : 405.6e
text: Turn-based actions donât use the stack; they happen automatically when certain steps or phases begin. Theyâre dealt with before a player would receive priority (see rule 117.3a). Turn-based actions also happen automatically when each step and phase ends; no player receives priority afterward. See rule 703.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 405. Stack : 405.6f
text: State-based actions donât use the stack; they happen automatically when certain conditions are met. See rule 704. They are dealt with before a player would receive priority. See rule 117.5.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 405. Stack : 405.6g
text: A player may concede the game at any time. That player leaves the game immediately. See rule 104.3a.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 405. Stack : 405.6h
text: If a player leaves a multiplayer game, objects may leave the game, cease to exist, change control, or be exiled as a result. These actions happen immediately. See rule 800.4a.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 406. Exile : 406.1.
text: The exile zone is essentially a holding area for objects. Some spells and abilities exile an object without any way to return that object to another zone. Other spells and abilities exile an object only temporarily.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 406. Exile : 406.2.
text: To exile an object is to put it into the exile zone from whatever zone itâs currently in. An exiled card is a card thatâs been put into the exile zone.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 406. Exile : 406.3.
text: Exiled cards are, by default, kept face up and may be examined by any player at any time. Cards âexiled face downâ canât be examined by any player except when instructions allow it. However, if a player is instructed to look at a card and then exile it face down, or once a player is allowed to look at a card exiled face down, that player may continue to look at that card until it leaves the exile zone or is part of a pile of cards that are shuffled, even if the instruction allowing the player to do so no longer applies.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 406. Exile : 406.3a
text: A card exiled face down has no characteristics, but the spell or ability that exiled it may allow it to be played from exile. Unless that card is being cast face down (see rule 708.4), the card is turned face up just before the player announces that they are playing the card (see rule 601.2).

name: Comprehensive Rules: 406. Exile : 406.3b
text: Some spells and abilities allow a player to cast spells with certain qualities from among face-down cards in exile. A player may cast such a spell only if they are allowed to look at the face-down card in exile and if the resulting spell has the specified qualities.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 406. Exile : 406.4.
text: Face-down cards in exile should be kept in separate piles based on when they were exiled and how they were exiled. If a player is instructed to choose an exiled card, the player may choose a specific face-down card only if the player is allowed to look at that card. Otherwise, they may choose a pile of face-down exiled cards, and then a card is chosen at random from within that pile. If choosing such a card is part of casting a spell or activating an ability, the chosen card isnât revealed until after that cost is fully paid. (See rule 601.2i.)

name: Comprehensive Rules: 406. Exile : 406.5.
text: Exiled cards that might return to the battlefield or any other zone should be kept in separate piles to keep track of their respective ways of returning. Exiled cards that may have an impact on the game due to their own abilities (such as cards with haunt) or the abilities of the cards that exiled them should likewise be kept in separate piles.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 406. Exile : 406.6.
text: An object may have one ability printed on it that causes one or more cards to be exiled, and another ability that refers either to âthe exiled cardsâ or to cards âexiled with [this object].â These abilities are linked: the second refers only to cards that have been exiled due to the first. See rule 607, âLinked Abilities.â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 406. Exile : 406.7.
text: If an object in the exile zone becomes exiled, it doesnât change zones, but it becomes a new object that has just been exiled.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 406. Exile : 406.8.
text: Previously, the exile zone was called the âremoved-from-the-game zone.â Cards that were printed with text that âremoves [an object] from the gameâ exiles that object. The same is true for cards printed with text that âsets [an object] aside.â Cards that were printed with that text have received errata in the Oracle card reference.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 407. Ante : 407.1.
text: Earlier versions of the Magic rules included an ante rule as a way of playing âfor keeps.â Playing Magic games for ante is now considered an optional variation on the game, and itâs allowed only where itâs not forbidden by law or by other rules. Playing for ante is strictly forbidden under the Magic: The Gathering Tournament Rules (WPN.Wizards.com/en/resources/rules-documents).

name: Comprehensive Rules: 407. Ante : 407.2.
text: When playing for ante, each player puts one random card from their deck into the ante zone after determining which player goes first but before players draw any cards. Cards in the ante zone may be examined by any player at any time. At the end of the game, the winner becomes the owner of all the cards in the ante zone.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 407. Ante : 407.3.
text: A few cards have the text âRemove [this card] from your deck before playing if youâre not playing for ante.â These are the only cards that can add or remove cards from the ante zone or change a cardâs owner. When not playing for ante, players canât include these cards in their decks or sideboards, and these cards canât be brought into the game from outside the game.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 407. Ante : 407.4.
text: To ante an object is to put that object into the ante zone from whichever zone itâs currently in. The owner of an object is the only person who can ante that object.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 408. Command : 408.1.
text: The command zone is a game area reserved for certain specialized objects that have an overarching effect on the game, yet are not permanents and cannot be destroyed.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 408. Command : 408.2.
text: Emblems may be created in the command zone. See rule 114, âEmblems.â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 408. Command : 408.3.
text:
In the Planechase, Vanguard, Commander, Archenemy, and Conspiracy Draft casual variants, nontraditional Magic cards and/or specially designated cards start the game in the command zone. Each variant has its own rules regarding such cards. See section 9, âCasual Variants.â


5. Turn Structure

name: Comprehensive Rules: 500. General : 500.1.
text: A turn consists of five phases, in this order: beginning, precombat main, combat, postcombat main, and ending. Each of these phases takes place every turn, even if nothing happens during the phase. The beginning, combat, and ending phases are further broken down into steps, which proceed in order.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 500. General : 500.2.
text: A phase or step in which players receive priority ends when the stack is empty and all players pass in succession. Simply having the stack become empty doesnât cause such a phase or step to end; all players have to pass in succession with the stack empty. Because of this, each player gets a chance to add new things to the stack before that phase or step ends.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 500. General : 500.3.
text: A step in which no players receive priority ends when all specified actions that take place during that step are completed. The only such steps are the untap step (see rule 502) and certain cleanup steps (see rule 514).

name: Comprehensive Rules: 500. General : 500.4.
text: When a step or phase ends, any unused mana left in a playerâs mana pool empties. This turn-based action doesnât use the stack.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 500. General : 500.5.
text: When a phase or step ends, any effects scheduled to last âuntil end ofâ that phase or step expire. When a phase or step begins, any effects scheduled to last âuntilâ that phase or step expire. Effects that last âuntil end of combatâ expire at the end of the combat phase, not at the beginning of the end of combat step. Effects that last âuntil end of turnâ are subject to special rules; see rule 514.2.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 500. General : 500.6.
text: When a phase or step begins, any abilities that trigger âat the beginning ofâ that phase or step trigger. They are put on the stack the next time a player would receive priority. (See rule 117, âTiming and Priority.â)

name: Comprehensive Rules: 500. General : 500.7.
text: Some effects can give a player extra turns. They do this by adding the turns directly after the specified turn. If a player is given multiple extra turns, the extra turns are added one at a time. If multiple players are given extra turns, the extra turns are added one at a time, in APNAP order (see rule 101.4). The most recently created turn will be taken first.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 500. General : 500.8.
text: Some effects can add phases to a turn. They do this by adding the phases directly after the specified phase. If multiple extra phases are created after the same phase, the most recently created phase will occur first.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 500. General : 500.9.
text: Some effects can add steps to a phase. They do this by adding the steps directly after a specified step or directly before a specified step. If multiple extra steps are created after the same step, the most recently created step will occur first.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 500. General : 500.10.
text: Some effects can cause a step, phase, or turn to be skipped. To skip a step, phase, or turn is to proceed past it as though it didnât exist. See rule 614.10.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 500. General : 500.11.
text: No game events can occur between turns, phases, or steps.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 501. Beginning Phase : 501.1.
text: The beginning phase consists of three steps, in this order: untap, upkeep, and draw.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 502. Untap Step : 502.1.
text: First, all phased-in permanents with phasing that the active player controls phase out, and all phased-out permanents that the active player controlled when they phased out phase in. This all happens simultaneously. This turn-based action doesnât use the stack. See rule 702.26, âPhasing.â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 502. Untap Step : 502.2.
text: Second, if itâs day and the previous turnâs active player didnât cast any spells during that turn, it becomes night. If itâs night and the previous turnâs active player cast two or more spells during that turn, it becomes day. If itâs neither day nor night, this check doesnât happen and it remains neither. This turn-based action doesnât use the stack. See rule 727, âDay and Night.â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 502. Untap Step : 502.2a
text: Multiplayer games using the shared team turns option use a modified rule. If itâs day and no player on the previous turnâs active team cast a spell during that turn, it becomes night. If itâs night and any player on the previous turnâs active team cast two or more spells during the previous turn, it becomes day. If itâs neither day nor night, this check doesnât happen and it remains neither. This turn-based action doesnât use the stack.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 502. Untap Step : 502.3.
text: Third, the active player determines which permanents they control will untap. Then they untap them all simultaneously. This turn-based action doesnât use the stack. Normally, all of a playerâs permanents untap, but effects can keep one or more of a playerâs permanents from untapping.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 502. Untap Step : 502.4.
text: No player receives priority during the untap step, so no spells can be cast or resolve and no abilities can be activated or resolve. Any ability that triggers during this step will be held until the next time a player would receive priority, which is usually during the upkeep step. (See rule 503, âUpkeep Step.â)

name: Comprehensive Rules: 503. Upkeep Step : 503.1.
text: The upkeep step has no turn-based actions. Once it begins, the active player gets priority. (See rule 117, âTiming and Priority.â)

name: Comprehensive Rules: 503. Upkeep Step : 503.1a
text: Any abilities that triggered during the untap step and any abilities that triggered at the beginning of the upkeep are put onto the stack before the active player gets priority; the order in which they triggered doesnât matter. (See rule 603, âHandling Triggered Abilities.â)

name: Comprehensive Rules: 503. Upkeep Step : 503.2.
text: If a spell states that it may be cast only âafter [a playerâs] upkeep step,â and the turn has multiple upkeep steps, that spell may be cast any time after the first upkeep step ends.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 504. Draw Step : 504.1.
text: First, the active player draws a card. This turn-based action doesnât use the stack.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 504. Draw Step : 504.2.
text: Second, the active player gets priority. (See rule 117, âTiming and Priority.â)

name: Comprehensive Rules: 505. Main Phase : 505.1.
text: There are two main phases in a turn. In each turn, the first main phase (also known as the precombat main phase) and the second main phase (also known as the postcombat main phase) are separated by the combat phase (see rule 506, âCombat Phaseâ). The precombat and postcombat main phases are individually and collectively known as the main phase.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 505. Main Phase : 505.1a
text: Only the first main phase of the turn is a precombat main phase. All other main phases are postcombat main phases. This includes the second main phase of a turn in which the combat phase has been skipped. It is also true of a turn in which an effect has caused an additional combat phase and an additional main phase to be created.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 505. Main Phase : 505.2.
text: The main phase has no steps, so a main phase ends when all players pass in succession while the stack is empty. (See rule 500.2.)

name: Comprehensive Rules: 505. Main Phase : 505.3.
text: First, but only if the players are playing an Archenemy game (see rule 904), the active player is the archenemy, and itâs the active playerâs precombat main phase, the active player sets the top card of their scheme deck in motion (see rule 701.25). This turn-based action doesnât use the stack.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 505. Main Phase : 505.4.
text: Second, if the active player controls one or more Saga enchantments and itâs the active playerâs precombat main phase, the active player puts a lore counter on each Saga they control. (See rule 714, âSaga Cards.â) This turn-based action doesnât use the stack.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 505. Main Phase : 505.5.
text: Third, if the active player controls one or more Attractions and itâs the active playerâs precombat main phase, the active player rolls to visit their Attractions. (See rule 701.49, âRoll to Visit Your Attractions.â) This turn-based action doesnât use the stack.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 505. Main Phase : 505.6.
text: Fourth, the active player gets priority. (See rule 117, âTiming and Priority.â)

name: Comprehensive Rules: 505. Main Phase : 505.6a
text: The main phase is the only phase in which a player can normally cast artifact, creature, enchantment, planeswalker, and sorcery spells. The active player may cast these spells.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 505. Main Phase : 505.6b
text: During either main phase, the active player may play one land card from their hand if the stack is empty, if the player has priority, and if they havenât played a land this turn (unless an effect states the player may play additional lands). This action doesnât use the stack. Neither the land nor the action of playing the land is a spell or ability, so it canât be countered, and players canât respond to it with instants or activated abilities. (See rule 305, âLands.â)

name: Comprehensive Rules: 506. Combat Phase : 506.1.
text: The combat phase has five steps, which proceed in order: beginning of combat, declare attackers, declare blockers, combat damage, and end of combat. The declare blockers and combat damage steps are skipped if no creatures are declared as attackers or put onto the battlefield attacking (see rule 508.8). There are two combat damage steps if any attacking or blocking creature has first strike (see rule 702.7) or double strike (see rule 702.4).

name: Comprehensive Rules: 506. Combat Phase : 506.2.
text: During the combat phase, the active player is the attacking player; creatures that player controls may attack. During the combat phase of a two-player game, the nonactive player is the defending player; that player, planeswalkers they control, and battles they protect may be attacked.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 506. Combat Phase : 506.2a
text: During the combat phase of a multiplayer game, there may be one or more defending players, depending on the variant being played and the options chosen for it. Unless all the attacking playerâs opponents automatically become defending players during the combat phase, the attacking player chooses one of their opponents as a turn-based action during the beginning of combat step. (Note that the choice may be dictated by the variant being played or the options chosen for it.) That player becomes the defending player. See rule 802, âAttack Multiple Players Option,â rule 803, âAttack Left and Attack Right Options,â and rule 809, âEmperor Variant.â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 506. Combat Phase : 506.2b
text: In multiplayer games using the shared team turns option, the active team is the attacking team and the nonactive team is the defending team. See rule 805, âShared Team Turns Option.â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 506. Combat Phase : 506.3.
text: Only a creature can attack or block. Only a player, a planeswalker, or a battle can be attacked.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 506. Combat Phase : 506.3a
text: If an effect would put a noncreature permanent onto the battlefield attacking or blocking, the permanent does enter the battlefield but itâs never considered to be an attacking or blocking permanent.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 506. Combat Phase : 506.3b
text: If an effect would put a creature onto the battlefield attacking under the control of any player except an attacking player, that creature does enter the battlefield, but itâs never considered to be an attacking creature.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 506. Combat Phase : 506.3c
text: If an effect would put a creature onto the battlefield attacking either a player not in the game or a permanent thatâs no longer on the battlefield or isnât either a planeswalker or a battle, that creature does enter the battlefield, but itâs never considered to be an attacking creature.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 506. Combat Phase : 506.3d
text: If an effect would put a creature onto the battlefield blocking but the creature it would block isnât attacking the entering creatureâs controller, a planeswalker that player controls, or a battle that player protects, that creature does enter the battlefield, but itâs never considered to be a blocking creature.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 506. Combat Phase : 506.3e
text: If an effect would put a creature thatâs also a battle onto the battlefield attacking or blocking, that permanent enters the battlefield but itâs never considered to be an attacking or blocking creature.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 506. Combat Phase : 506.3f
text: If a resolving spell or ability would cause a battle to become an attacking or blocking creature, that part of the effect does nothing.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 506. Combat Phase : 506.4.
text: A permanent is removed from combat if it leaves the battlefield, if its controller changes, if it phases out, if an effect specifically removes it from combat, if itâs a planeswalker thatâs being attacked and stops being a planeswalker, if itâs a battle thatâs being attacked and stops being a battle, or if itâs an attacking or blocking creature that regenerates (see rule 701.15), stops being a creature, or becomes a battle. A creature thatâs removed from combat stops being an attacking, blocking, blocked, and/or unblocked creature. A planeswalker or battle thatâs removed from combat stops being attacked.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 506. Combat Phase : 506.4a
text: Once a creature has been declared as an attacking or blocking creature, spells or abilities that would have kept that creature from attacking or blocking donât remove the creature from combat.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 506. Combat Phase : 506.4b
text: Tapping or untapping a creature thatâs already been declared as an attacker or blocker doesnât remove it from combat and doesnât prevent its combat damage.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 506. Combat Phase : 506.4c
text: If a creature is attacking a planeswalker or battle, removing that planeswalker or battle from combat doesnât remove that creature from combat. It continues to be an attacking creature, although it is not attacking any player, planeswalker, or battle. It may be blocked. If it is unblocked, it will deal no combat damage.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 506. Combat Phase : 506.4d
text: A permanent thatâs both a blocking creature and a planeswalker thatâs being attacked is removed from combat if it stops being both a creature and a planeswalker. If it stops being one of those card types but continues to be the other, it continues to be either a blocking creature or a planeswalker thatâs being attacked, whichever is appropriate.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 506. Combat Phase : 506.4e
text: A permanent thatâs being attacked that is both a planeswalker and a battle is removed from combat if it stops being both a planeswalker and a battle. If it stops being a battle but is still a planeswalker, it is removed from combat only if it is not controlled by its protector. If it stops being a planeswalker but is still a battle, it is not removed from combat. It continues to be a battle thatâs being attacked.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 506. Combat Phase : 506.5.
text: A creature attacks alone if itâs the only creature declared as an attacker during the declare attackers step. A creature is attacking alone if itâs attacking but no other creatures are. A creature blocks alone if itâs the only creature declared as a blocker during the declare blockers step. A creature is blocking alone if itâs blocking but no other creatures are.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 506. Combat Phase : 506.6.
text: Some abilities check to see whether or not a creature âhad to attackâ during a particular combat phase. A creature had to attack if one or more effects were requiring that creature to attack at the time attackers were declared in that combat. A creature did not âhave to attackâ if there were no such effects that required it to attack, even if there were no other legal attacks that could have been declared. (See rule 508.)

name: Comprehensive Rules: 506. Combat Phase : 506.7.
text: Some spells state that they may be cast âonly [before/after] [a particular point in the combat phase],â in which that point may be âattackers are declared,â âblockers are declared,â âthe combat damage step,â âthe end of combat step,â âthe combat phase,â or âcombat.â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 506. Combat Phase : 506.7a
text: A spell that states it may be cast âonly before (or after) attackers are declaredâ is referring to the turn-based action of declaring attackers. It may be cast only before (or after) the declare attackers step begins, regardless of whether any attackers are actually declared. (See rule 508.)

name: Comprehensive Rules: 506. Combat Phase : 506.7b
text: A spell that states it may be cast âonly before (or after) blockers are declaredâ is referring to the turn-based action of declaring blockers. It may be cast only before (or after) the declare blockers step begins, regardless of whether any blockers are actually declared. (See rule 509.)

name: Comprehensive Rules: 506. Combat Phase : 506.7c
text: Some spells state that they may be cast only âduring combatâ or âduring a certain playerâs combat phaseâ in addition to the criteria described in rule 506.7. If a turn has multiple combat phases, such spells may be cast at an appropriate time during any of them.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 506. Combat Phase : 506.7d
text: Some spells state that they may be cast âonly before (or after) [a particular point in the combat phase],â but donât meet the additional criteria described in rule 506.7c. If a turn has multiple combat phases, such spells may be cast that turn only before (or after) the stated point of the first combat phase.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 506. Combat Phase : 506.7e
text: If a spell states that it may be cast âonly before [a particular point in the combat phase],â but the stated point doesnât exist within the relevant combat phase because the declare blockers step and the combat damage step are skipped (see rule 508.8), then the spell may be cast only before the declare attackers step ends. If the stated point doesnât exist because the relevant combat phase has been skipped, then the spell may be cast only before the precombat main phase ends.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 506. Combat Phase : 506.7f
text: If a spell states that it may be cast âonly during combat after blockers are declared,â but the declare blockers step is skipped that combat phase (see rule 508.8), then the spell may not be cast during that combat phase.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 506. Combat Phase : 506.7g
text: Rules 506.7 and 506.7aâf apply to abilities that state that they may be activated only at certain times with respect to combat just as they apply to spells that state that they may be cast only at certain times with respect to combat.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 507. Beginning of Combat Step : 507.1.
text: First, if the game being played is a multiplayer game in which the active playerâs opponents donât all automatically become defending players, the active player chooses one of their opponents. That player becomes the defending player. This turn-based action doesnât use the stack. (See rule 506.2.)

name: Comprehensive Rules: 507. Beginning of Combat Step : 507.2.
text: Second, the active player gets priority. (See rule 117, âTiming and Priority.â)

name: Comprehensive Rules: 508. Declare Attackers Step : 508.1.
text: First, the active player declares attackers. This turn-based action doesnât use the stack. To declare attackers, the active player follows the steps below, in order. If at any point during the declaration of attackers, the active player is unable to comply with any of the steps listed below, the declaration is illegal; the game returns to the moment before the declaration (see rule 729, âHandling Illegal Actionsâ).

name: Comprehensive Rules: 508. Declare Attackers Step : 508.1a
text: The active player chooses which creatures that they control, if any, will attack. The chosen creatures must be untapped, they canât also be battles, and each one must either have haste or have been controlled by the active player continuously since the turn began.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 508. Declare Attackers Step : 508.1b
text: If the defending player controls any planeswalkers, is the protector of any battles, or the game allows the active player to attack multiple other players, the active player announces which player, planeswalker, or battle each of the chosen creatures is attacking.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 508. Declare Attackers Step : 508.1c
text: The active player checks each creature they control to see whether itâs affected by any restrictions (effects that say a creature canât attack, or that it canât attack unless some condition is met). If any restrictions are being disobeyed, the declaration of attackers is illegal.

name: Example for Rule : 508.1c
text: A player controls two creatures, each with a restriction that states â[This creature] canât attack alone.â Itâs legal to declare both as attackers.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 508. Declare Attackers Step : 508.1d
text: The active player checks each creature they control to see whether itâs affected by any requirements (effects that say a creature attacks if able, or that it attacks if some condition is met). If the number of requirements that are being obeyed is fewer than the maximum possible number of requirements that could be obeyed without disobeying any restrictions, the declaration of attackers is illegal. If a creature canât attack unless a player pays a cost, that player is not required to pay that cost, even if attacking with that creature would increase the number of requirements being obeyed. If a requirement that says a creature attacks if able during a certain turn refers to a turn with multiple combat phases, the creature attacks if able during each declare attackers step in that turn.

name: Example for Rule : 508.1d
text: A player controls two creatures: one that âattacks if ableâ and one with no abilities. An effect states âNo more than one creature can attack each turn.â The only legal attack is for just the creature that âattacks if ableâ to attack. Itâs illegal to attack with the other creature, attack with both, or attack with neither.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 508. Declare Attackers Step : 508.1e
text: If any of the chosen creatures have banding or a âbands with otherâ ability, the active player announces which creatures, if any, are banded with which. (See rule 702.22, âBanding.â)

name: Comprehensive Rules: 508. Declare Attackers Step : 508.1f
text: The active player taps the chosen creatures. Tapping a creature when itâs declared as an attacker isnât a cost; attacking simply causes creatures to become tapped.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 508. Declare Attackers Step : 508.1g
text: If there are any optional costs to attack with the chosen creatures (expressed as costs a player may pay âasâ a creature attacks), the active player chooses which, if any, they will pay.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 508. Declare Attackers Step : 508.1h
text: If any of the chosen creatures require paying costs to attack, or if any optional costs to attack were chosen, the active player determines the total cost to attack. Costs may include paying mana, tapping permanents, sacrificing permanents, discarding cards, and so on. Once the total cost is determined, it becomes âlocked in.â If effects would change the total cost after this time, ignore this change.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 508. Declare Attackers Step : 508.1i
text: If any of the costs require mana, the active player then has a chance to activate mana abilities (see rule 605, âMana Abilitiesâ).

name: Comprehensive Rules: 508. Declare Attackers Step : 508.1j
text: Once the player has enough mana in their mana pool, they pay all costs in any order. Partial payments are not allowed.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 508. Declare Attackers Step : 508.1k
text: Each chosen creature still controlled by the active player becomes an attacking creature. It remains an attacking creature until itâs removed from combat or the combat phase ends, whichever comes first. See rule 506.4.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 508. Declare Attackers Step : 508.1m
text: Any abilities that trigger on attackers being declared trigger.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 508. Declare Attackers Step : 508.2.
text: Second, the active player gets priority. (See rule 117, âTiming and Priority.â)

name: Comprehensive Rules: 508. Declare Attackers Step : 508.2a
text: Abilities that trigger on a creature attacking trigger only at the point the creature is declared as an attacker. They will not trigger if a creature attacks and then that creatureâs characteristics change to match the abilityâs trigger condition.

name: Example for Rule : 508.2a
text: A permanent has the ability âWhenever a green creature attacks, destroy that creature at end of combat.â If a blue creature attacks and is later turned green, the ability will not trigger.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 508. Declare Attackers Step : 508.2b
text: Any abilities that triggered on attackers being declared or that triggered during the process described in rules 508.1 are put onto the stack before the active player gets priority; the order in which they triggered doesnât matter. (See rule 603, âHandling Triggered Abilities.â)

name: Comprehensive Rules: 508. Declare Attackers Step : 508.3.
text: Triggered abilities that trigger on attackers being declared may have different trigger conditions.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 508. Declare Attackers Step : 508.3a
text: An ability that reads âWhenever [a creature] attacks, . . .â triggers if that creature is declared as an attacker. Similarly, âWhenever [a creature] attacks [a player, planeswalker, or battle], . . .â triggers if that creature is declared as an attacker attacking that player or permanent. Such abilities wonât trigger if a creature is put onto the battlefield attacking.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 508. Declare Attackers Step : 508.3b
text: An ability that reads âWhenever [a player, planeswalker, or battle] is attacked, . . .â triggers if one or more creatures are declared as attackers attacking that player or permanent. It wonât trigger if a creature is put onto the battlefield attacking that player or permanent.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 508. Declare Attackers Step : 508.3c
text: An ability that reads âWhenever [a player] attacks with [a creature], . . .â triggers if a creature that player controls is declared as an attacker.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 508. Declare Attackers Step : 508.3d
text: An ability that reads âWhenever [a player] attacks, . . .â triggers if one or more creatures that player controls are declared as attackers.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 508. Declare Attackers Step : 508.3e
text: An ability that reads âWhenever [a player] attacks [another player], . . .â triggers if one or more creatures the first player controls are declared as attackers attacking the second player. It wonât trigger if a creature is put onto the battlefield attacking or if a creature attacks a planeswalker or a battle.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 508. Declare Attackers Step : 508.3f
text: An ability that reads âWhenever [a creature] attacks and isnât blocked, . . .â triggers during the declare blockers step, not the declare attackers step. See rule 509.5g.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 508. Declare Attackers Step : 508.4.
text: If a creature is put onto the battlefield attacking, its controller chooses which defending player, planeswalker a defending player controls, or battle a defending player protects itâs attacking as it enters the battlefield (unless the effect that put it onto the battlefield specifies what itâs attacking). Similarly, if an effect states that a creature is attacking, its controller chooses which defending player, planeswalker a defending player controls, or battle a defending player protects itâs attacking (unless the effect has already specified). Such creatures are âattackingâ but, for the purposes of trigger events and effects, they never âattacked.â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 508. Declare Attackers Step : 508.4a
text: If the effect that puts a creature onto the battlefield attacking specifies itâs attacking a certain player, and that player is no longer in the game when the effect resolves, the creature is put onto the battlefield but is never considered an attacking creature. The same is true if the effect specifies a creature is put onto the battlefield attacking a planeswalker or battle and that permanent is no longer on the battlefield or is no longer a planeswalker or battle when the effect resolves.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 508. Declare Attackers Step : 508.4b
text: If the effect that states a creature is attacking specifies itâs attacking a certain player, and that player is no longer in the game when the effect resolves, the creature doesnât become an attacking creature. The same is true if the effect specifies a creature is attacking a planeswalker or battle and that permanent is no longer on the battlefield or is no longer a planeswalker or battle when the effect resolves.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 508. Declare Attackers Step : 508.4c
text: A creature thatâs put onto the battlefield attacking or that is stated to be attacking isnât affected by requirements or restrictions that apply to the declaration of attackers.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 508. Declare Attackers Step : 508.5.
text: If an ability of an attacking creature refers to a defending player, or a spell or ability refers to both an attacking creature and a defending player, then unless otherwise specified, the defending player itâs referring to is the player that creature is attacking, the controller of the planeswalker that creature is attacking, or the protector of the battle that creature is attacking. If that creature is no longer attacking, the defending player itâs referring to is the player that creature was attacking before it was removed from combat, the controller of the planeswalker that creature was attacking before it was removed from combat, or the protector of the battle that creature was attacking before it was removed from combat.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 508. Declare Attackers Step : 508.5a
text: In a multiplayer game, any rule, object, or effect that refers to a âdefending playerâ refers to one specific defending player, not to all of the defending players. If a spell or ability could apply to multiple attacking creatures, the appropriate defending player is individually determined for each of those attacking creatures. If there are multiple defending players that could be chosen, the controller of the spell or ability chooses one.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 508. Declare Attackers Step : 508.6.
text: A player is âattacking [a player]â if the first player controls a creature that is attacking the second player. A player has âattacked [a player]â if the first player declared one or more creatures as attackers attacking the second player.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 508. Declare Attackers Step : 508.7.
text: Some cards allow a player to reselect which player, planeswalker, or battle a creature is attacking.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 508. Declare Attackers Step : 508.7a
text: The attacking creature isnât removed from combat and it isnât considered to have attacked a second time. That creature is attacking the reselected player or permanent, but itâs still considered to have attacked the player or permanent chosen as it was declared as an attacker.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 508. Declare Attackers Step : 508.7b
text: While reselecting which player, planeswalker, or battle a creature is attacking, that creature isnât affected by requirements or restrictions that apply to the declaration of attackers.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 508. Declare Attackers Step : 508.7c
text: The reselected player, planeswalker, or battle must be an opponent of the attacking creatureâs controller, a planeswalker controlled by an opponent of the attacking creatureâs controller, or a battle protected by an opponent of the attacking creatureâs controller.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 508. Declare Attackers Step : 508.7d
text: In a multiplayer game not using the attack multiple players option (see rule 802), the reselected player, planeswalker, or battle must be the chosen defending player, a planeswalker controlled by that player, or a battle protected by that player.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 508. Declare Attackers Step : 508.7e
text: In a multiplayer game using the limited range of influence option (see rule 801), the reselected player, planeswalker, or battle must be within the range of influence of the attacking creatureâs controller. In the case of a battle, the battleâs protector must also be within the range of influence of the attacking creatureâs controller.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 508. Declare Attackers Step : 508.8.
text: If no creatures are declared as attackers or put onto the battlefield attacking, skip the declare blockers and combat damage steps.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 509. Declare Blockers Step : 509.1.
text: First, the defending player declares blockers. This turn-based action doesnât use the stack. To declare blockers, the defending player follows the steps below, in order. If at any point during the declaration of blockers, the defending player is unable to comply with any of the steps listed below, the declaration is illegal; the game returns to the moment before the declaration (see rule 729, âHandling Illegal Actionsâ).

name: Comprehensive Rules: 509. Declare Blockers Step : 509.1a
text: The defending player chooses which creatures they control, if any, will block. The chosen creatures must be untapped and they canât also be battles. For each of the chosen creatures, the defending player chooses one creature for it to block thatâs attacking that player, a planeswalker they control, or a battle they protect.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 509. Declare Blockers Step : 509.1b
text:
The defending player checks each creature they control to see whether itâs affected by any restrictions (effects that say a creature canât block, or that it canât block unless some condition is met). If any restrictions are being disobeyed, the declaration of blockers is illegal.
     A restriction may be created by an evasion ability (a static ability an attacking creature has that restricts what can block it). If an attacking creature gains or loses an evasion ability after a legal block has been declared, it doesnât affect that block. Different evasion abilities are cumulative.

name: Example for Rule : 509.1b
text: An attacking creature with flying and shadow canât be blocked by a creature with flying but without shadow.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 509. Declare Blockers Step : 509.1c
text: The defending player checks each creature they control to see whether itâs affected by any requirements (effects that say a creature must block, or that it must block if some condition is met). If the number of requirements that are being obeyed is fewer than the maximum possible number of requirements that could be obeyed without disobeying any restrictions, the declaration of blockers is illegal. If a creature canât block unless a player pays a cost, that player is not required to pay that cost, even if blocking with that creature would increase the number of requirements being obeyed. If a requirement that says a creature blocks if able during a certain turn refers to a turn with multiple combat phases, the creature blocks if able during each declare blockers step in that turn.

name: Example for Rule : 509.1c
text: A player controls one creature that âblocks if ableâ and another creature with no abilities. If a creature with menace attacks that player, the player must block with both creatures. Having only the first creature block violates the restriction created by menace (the attacking creature canât be blocked except by two or more creatures). Having only the second creature block violates both the menace restriction and the first creatureâs blocking requirement. Having neither creature block fulfills the restriction but not the requirement.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 509. Declare Blockers Step : 509.1d
text: If any of the chosen creatures require paying costs to block, the defending player determines the total cost to block. Costs may include paying mana, tapping permanents, sacrificing permanents, discarding cards, and so on. Once the total cost is determined, it becomes âlocked in.â If effects would change the total cost after this time, ignore this change.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 509. Declare Blockers Step : 509.1e
text: If any of the costs require mana, the defending player then has a chance to activate mana abilities (see rule 605, âMana Abilitiesâ).

name: Comprehensive Rules: 509. Declare Blockers Step : 509.1f
text: Once the player has enough mana in their mana pool, they pay all costs in any order. Partial payments are not allowed.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 509. Declare Blockers Step : 509.1g
text: Each chosen creature still controlled by the defending player becomes a blocking creature. Each one is blocking the attacking creatures chosen for it. It remains a blocking creature until itâs removed from combat or the combat phase ends, whichever comes first. See rule 506.4.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 509. Declare Blockers Step : 509.1h
text: An attacking creature with one or more creatures declared as blockers for it becomes a blocked creature; one with no creatures declared as blockers for it becomes an unblocked creature. This remains unchanged until the creature is removed from combat, an effect says that it becomes blocked or unblocked, or the combat phase ends, whichever comes first. A creature remains blocked even if all the creatures blocking it are removed from combat.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 509. Declare Blockers Step : 509.1i
text: Any abilities that trigger on blockers being declared trigger. See rule 509.4 for more information.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 509. Declare Blockers Step : 509.2.
text: Second, for each attacking creature thatâs become blocked, the active player announces that creatureâs damage assignment order, which consists of the creatures blocking it in an order of that playerâs choice. (During the combat damage step, an attacking creature canât assign combat damage to a creature thatâs blocking it unless each creature ahead of that blocking creature in its order is assigned lethal damage.) This turn-based action doesnât use the stack.

name: Example for Rule : 509.2.
text: Vastwood Gorger is blocked by Llanowar Elves, Runeclaw Bear, and Serra Angel. Vastwood Gorgerâs controller announces the Vastwood Gorgerâs damage assignment order as Serra Angel, then Llanowar Elves, then Runeclaw Bear.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 509. Declare Blockers Step : 509.2a
text: During the declare blockers step, if a blocking creature is removed from combat or a spell or ability causes it to stop blocking an attacking creature, the blocking creature is removed from all relevant damage assignment orders. The relative order among the remaining blocking creatures is unchanged.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 509. Declare Blockers Step : 509.3.
text: Third, for each blocking creature, the defending player announces that creatureâs damage assignment order, which consists of the creatures itâs blocking in an order of that playerâs choice. (During the combat damage step, a blocking creature canât assign combat damage to a creature itâs blocking unless each creature ahead of that blocked creature in its order is assigned lethal damage.) This turn-based action doesnât use the stack.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 509. Declare Blockers Step : 509.3a
text: During the declare blockers step, if an attacking creature is removed from combat or a spell or ability causes it to stop being blocked by a blocking creature, the attacking creature is removed from all relevant damage assignment orders. The relative order among the remaining attacking creatures is unchanged.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 509. Declare Blockers Step : 509.4.
text: Fourth, the active player gets priority. (See rule 117, âTiming and Priority.â)

name: Comprehensive Rules: 509. Declare Blockers Step : 509.4a
text: Any abilities that triggered on blockers being declared or that triggered during the process described in rules 509.1â3 are put onto the stack before the active player gets priority; the order in which they triggered doesnât matter. (See rule 603, âHandling Triggered Abilities.â)

name: Comprehensive Rules: 509. Declare Blockers Step : 509.5.
text: Triggered abilities that trigger on blockers being declared may have different trigger conditions.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 509. Declare Blockers Step : 509.5a
text: An ability that reads âWhenever [a creature] blocks, . . .â generally triggers only once each combat for that creature, even if it blocks multiple creatures. It triggers if the creature is declared as a blocker. It will also trigger if that creature becomes a blocker as the result of an effect, but only if it wasnât a blocking creature at that time. (See rule 509.1g.) It wonât trigger if the creature is put onto the battlefield blocking.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 509. Declare Blockers Step : 509.5b
text: An ability that reads âWhenever [a creature] blocks a creature, . . .â triggers once for each attacking creature the creature with the ability blocks. It triggers if the creature is declared as a blocker. It will also trigger if an effect causes that creature to block an attacking creature, but only if it wasnât already blocking that attacking creature at that time. It wonât trigger if the creature is put onto the battlefield blocking.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 509. Declare Blockers Step : 509.5c
text: An ability that reads âWhenever [a creature] becomes blocked, . . .â generally triggers only once each combat for that creature, even if itâs blocked by multiple creatures. It will trigger if that creature becomes blocked by at least one creature declared as a blocker. It will also trigger if that creature becomes blocked by an effect or by a creature thatâs put onto the battlefield as a blocker, but only if the attacking creature was an unblocked creature at that time. (See rule 509.1h.)

name: Comprehensive Rules: 509. Declare Blockers Step : 509.5d
text: An ability that reads âWhenever [a creature] becomes blocked by a creature, . . .â triggers once for each creature that blocks the specified creature. It triggers if a creature is declared as a blocker for the attacking creature. It will also trigger if an effect causes a creature to block the attacking creature, but only if it wasnât already blocking that attacking creature at that time. In addition, it will trigger if a creature is put onto the battlefield blocking that creature. It wonât trigger if the creature becomes blocked by an effect rather than a creature.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 509. Declare Blockers Step : 509.5e
text: If an ability triggers when a creature blocks or becomes blocked by a particular number of creatures, the ability triggers if the creature blocks or is blocked by that many creatures when blockers are declared. Effects that add or remove blockers can also cause such abilities to trigger. This applies to abilities that trigger on a creature blocking or being blocked by at least a certain number of creatures as well.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 509. Declare Blockers Step : 509.5f
text: If an ability triggers when a creature with certain characteristics blocks, it will trigger only if the creature has those characteristics at the point blockers are declared, or at the point an effect causes it to block. If an ability triggers when a creature with certain characteristics becomes blocked, it will trigger only if the creature has those characteristics at the point it becomes a blocked creature. If an ability triggers when a creature becomes blocked by a creature with certain characteristics, it will trigger only if the latter creature has those characteristics at the point it becomes a blocking creature. None of those abilities will trigger if the relevant creatureâs characteristics change to match the abilityâs trigger condition later on.

name: Example for Rule : 509.5f
text: A creature has the ability âWhenever this creature becomes blocked by a white creature, destroy that creature at end of combat.â If the creature becomes blocked by a black creature that is later turned white, the ability will not trigger.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 509. Declare Blockers Step : 509.5g
text: An ability that reads âWhenever [a creature] attacks and isnât blocked, . . .â triggers if no creatures are declared as blockers for that creature. It will trigger even if the creature was never declared as an attacker (for example, if it entered the battlefield attacking). It wonât trigger if the attacking creature is blocked and then all its blockers are removed from combat.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 509. Declare Blockers Step : 509.6.
text: If a spell or ability causes a creature on the battlefield to block an attacking creature, the active player announces the blocking creatureâs placement in the attacking creatureâs damage assignment order. The relative order among the remaining blocking creatures is unchanged. Then the defending player announces the attacking creatureâs placement in the blocking creatureâs damage assignment order. The relative order among the remaining attacking creatures is unchanged. This is done as part of the blocking effect.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 509. Declare Blockers Step : 509.7.
text: If a creature is put onto the battlefield blocking, its controller chooses which attacking creature itâs blocking as it enters the battlefield (unless the effect that put it onto the battlefield specifies what itâs blocking), then the active player announces the new creatureâs placement in the blocked creatureâs damage assignment order. The relative order among the remaining blocking creatures is unchanged. A creature put onto the battlefield this way is âblockingâ but, for the purposes of trigger events and effects, it never âblocked.â

name: Example for Rule : 509.7.
text: Giant Spider is blocked by Canyon Minotaur. The defending player casts Flash Foliage, which creates a Saproling creature token blocking the Giant Spider. Giant Spiderâs controller announces the Giant Spiderâs damage assignment order as the Saproling token, then Canyon Minotaur.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 509. Declare Blockers Step : 509.7a
text: If the effect that puts a creature onto the battlefield blocking specifies itâs blocking a certain creature and that creature is no longer attacking, the creature is put onto the battlefield but is never considered a blocking creature. The same is true if the controller of the creature thatâs put onto the battlefield blocking isnât a defending player for the specified attacking creature.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 509. Declare Blockers Step : 509.7b
text: A creature thatâs put onto the battlefield blocking isnât affected by requirements or restrictions that apply to the declaration of blockers.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 510. Combat Damage Step : 510.1.
text: First, the active player announces how each attacking creature assigns its combat damage, then the defending player announces how each blocking creature assigns its combat damage. This turn-based action doesnât use the stack. A player assigns a creatureâs combat damage according to the following rules:

name: Comprehensive Rules: 510. Combat Damage Step : 510.1a
text: Each attacking creature and each blocking creature assigns combat damage equal to its power. Creatures that would assign 0 or less damage this way donât assign combat damage at all.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 510. Combat Damage Step : 510.1b
text: An unblocked creature assigns its combat damage to the player, planeswalker, or battle itâs attacking. If it isnât currently attacking anything (if, for example, it was attacking a planeswalker that has left the battlefield), it assigns no combat damage.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 510. Combat Damage Step : 510.1c
text: A blocked creature assigns its combat damage to the creatures blocking it. If no creatures are currently blocking it (if, for example, they were destroyed or removed from combat), it assigns no combat damage. If exactly one creature is blocking it, it assigns all its combat damage to that creature. If two or more creatures are blocking it, it assigns its combat damage to those creatures according to the damage assignment order announced for it. This may allow the blocked creature to divide its combat damage. However, it canât assign combat damage to a creature thatâs blocking it unless, when combat damage assignments are complete, each creature that precedes that blocking creature in its order is assigned lethal damage. When checking for assigned lethal damage, take into account damage already marked on the creature and damage from other creatures thatâs being assigned during the same combat damage step, but not any abilities or effects that might change the amount of damage thatâs actually dealt. An amount of damage thatâs greater than a creatureâs lethal damage may be assigned to it.

name: Example for Rule : 510.1c
text: The damage assignment order of an attacking Vastwood Gorger (a 5/6 creature) is Pride Guardian (a 0/3 creature) then Llanowar Elves (a 1/1 creature). Vastwood Gorger can assign 3 damage to the Guardian and 2 damage to the Elves, 4 damage to the Guardian and 1 damage to the Elves, or 5 damage to the Guardian.

name: Example for Rule : 510.1c
text: The damage assignment order of an attacking Vastwood Gorger (a 5/6 creature) is Pride Guardian (a 0/3 creature) then Llanowar Elves (a 1/1 creature). During the declare blockers step, the defending player casts Giant Growth targeting Pride Guardian, which gives it +3/+3 until end of turn. Vastwood Gorger must assign its 5 damage to the Guardian.

name: Example for Rule : 510.1c
text: The damage assignment order of an attacking Vastwood Gorger (a 5/6 creature) is Pride Guardian (a 0/3 creature) then Llanowar Elves (a 1/1 creature). During the declare blockers step, the defending player casts Mending Hands targeting Pride Guardian, which prevents the next 4 damage that would be dealt to it.
