Vastwood Gorger can assign 3 damage to the Guardian and 2 damage to the Elves, 4 damage to the Guardian and 1 damage to the Elves, or 5 damage to the Guardian.

name: Example for Rule : 510.1c
text: The damage assignment order of an attacking Enormous Baloth (a 7/7 creature) is Trained Armodon (a 3/3 creature) that already has 2 damage marked on it, then Foriysian Brigade (a 2/4 creature that can block an additional creature), then Silverback Ape (a 5/5 creature). The damage assignment order of an attacking Durkwood Boars (a 4/4 creature) is the same Foriysian Brigade, then Goblin Piker (a 2/1 creature). Among other possibilities, the active player may have the Baloth assign 1 damage to the Armodon, 1 damage to the Brigade, and 5 damage to the Ape, and have the Boars assign 3 damage to the Brigade and 1 damage to the Piker.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 510. Combat Damage Step : 510.1d
text: A blocking creature assigns combat damage to the creatures itâs blocking. If it isnât currently blocking any creatures (if, for example, they were destroyed or removed from combat), it assigns no combat damage. If itâs blocking exactly one creature, it assigns all its combat damage to that creature. If itâs blocking two or more creatures, it assigns its combat damage to those creatures according to the damage assignment order announced for it. This may allow the blocking creature to divide its combat damage. However, it canât assign combat damage to a creature that itâs blocking unless, when combat damage assignments are complete, each creature that precedes that blocked creature is assigned lethal damage. When checking for assigned lethal damage, take into account damage already marked on the creature and damage from other creatures thatâs being assigned during the same combat damage step, but not any abilities or effects that might change the amount of damage thatâs actually dealt. An amount of damage thatâs greater than a creatureâs lethal damage may be assigned to it.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 510. Combat Damage Step : 510.1e
text: Once a player has assigned combat damage from each attacking or blocking creature they control, the total damage assignment (not solely the damage assignment of any individual attacking or blocking creature) is checked to see if it complies with the above rules. If it doesnât, the combat damage assignment is illegal; the game returns to the moment before that player began to assign combat damage. (See rule 729, âHandling Illegal Actions.â)

name: Comprehensive Rules: 510. Combat Damage Step : 510.2.
text: Second, all combat damage thatâs been assigned is dealt simultaneously. This turn-based action doesnât use the stack. No player has the chance to cast spells or activate abilities between the time combat damage is assigned and the time itâs dealt.

name: Example for Rule : 510.2.
text: Squadron Hawk (a 1/1 creature with flying) and Goblin Piker (a 2/1 creature) are attacking. Mogg Fanatic (a 1/1 creature with the ability âSacrifice Mogg Fanatic: Mogg Fanatic deals 1 damage to any target.â) blocks the Goblin Piker. The defending player sacrifices Mogg Fanatic during the declare blockers step to deal 1 damage to the Squadron Hawk. The Hawk is destroyed. The Piker deals and is dealt no combat damage this turn. If the defending player instead left Mogg Fanatic on the battlefield, the Fanatic and the Piker would have dealt lethal damage to one another, but the Squadron Hawk couldnât have been dealt damage.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 510. Combat Damage Step : 510.3.
text: Third, the active player gets priority. (See rule 117, âTiming and Priority.â)

name: Comprehensive Rules: 510. Combat Damage Step : 510.3a
text: Any abilities that triggered on damage being dealt or while state-based actions are performed afterward are put onto the stack before the active player gets priority; the order in which they triggered doesnât matter. (See rule 603, âHandling Triggered Abilities.â)

name: Comprehensive Rules: 510. Combat Damage Step : 510.4.
text: If at least one attacking or blocking creature has first strike (see rule 702.7) or double strike (see rule 702.4) as the combat damage step begins, the only creatures that assign combat damage in that step are those with first strike or double strike. After that step, instead of proceeding to the end of combat step, the phase gets a second combat damage step. The only creatures that assign combat damage in that step are the remaining attackers and blockers that had neither first strike nor double strike as the first combat damage step began, as well as the remaining attackers and blockers that currently have double strike. After that step, the phase proceeds to the end of combat step.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 511. End of Combat Step : 511.1.
text: The end of combat step has no turn-based actions. Once it begins, the active player gets priority. (See rule 117, âTiming and Priority.â)

name: Comprehensive Rules: 511. End of Combat Step : 511.2.
text: Abilities that trigger âat end of combatâ trigger as the end of combat step begins. Effects that last âuntil end of combatâ expire at the end of the combat phase.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 511. End of Combat Step : 511.3.
text: As soon as the end of combat step ends, all creatures, battles, and planeswalkers are removed from combat. After the end of combat step ends, the combat phase is over and the postcombat main phase begins (see rule 505).

name: Comprehensive Rules: 512. Ending Phase : 512.1.
text: The ending phase consists of two steps: end and cleanup.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 513. End Step : 513.1.
text: The end step has no turn-based actions. Once it begins, the active player gets priority. (See rule 117, âTiming and Priority.â)

name: Comprehensive Rules: 513. End Step : 513.1a
text: Previously, abilities that triggered at the beginning of the end step were printed with the trigger condition âat end of turn.â Cards that were printed with that text have received errata in the Oracle card reference to say âat the beginning of the end stepâ or âat the beginning of the next end step.â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 513. End Step : 513.2.
text: If a permanent with an ability that triggers âat the beginning of the end stepâ enters the battlefield during this step, that ability wonât trigger until the next turnâs end step. Likewise, if a delayed triggered ability that triggers âat the beginning of the next end stepâ is created during this step, that ability wonât trigger until the next turnâs end step. In other words, the step doesnât âback upâ so those abilities can go on the stack. This rule applies only to triggered abilities; it doesnât apply to continuous effects whose durations say âuntil end of turnâ or âthis turn.â (See rule 514, âCleanup Step.â)

name: Comprehensive Rules: 514. Cleanup Step : 514.1.
text: First, if the active playerâs hand contains more cards than their maximum hand size (normally seven), they discard enough cards to reduce their hand size to that number. This turn-based action doesnât use the stack.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 514. Cleanup Step : 514.2.
text: Second, the following actions happen simultaneously: all damage marked on permanents (including phased-out permanents) is removed and all âuntil end of turnâ and âthis turnâ effects end. This turn-based action doesnât use the stack.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 514. Cleanup Step : 514.3.
text: Normally, no player receives priority during the cleanup step, so no spells can be cast and no abilities can be activated. However, this rule is subject to the following exception:

name: Comprehensive Rules: 514. Cleanup Step : 514.3a
text:
At this point, the game checks to see if any state-based actions would be performed and/or any triggered abilities are waiting to be put onto the stack (including those that trigger âat the beginning of the next cleanup stepâ). If so, those state-based actions are performed, then those triggered abilities are put on the stack, then the active player gets priority. Players may cast spells and activate abilities. Once the stack is empty and all players pass in succession, another cleanup step begins.


6. Spells, Abilities, and Effects

name: Comprehensive Rules: 601. Casting Spells : 601.1.
text: Previously, the action of casting a spell, or casting a card as a spell, was referred to on cards as âplayingâ that spell or that card. Cards that were printed with that text have received errata in the Oracle card reference so they now refer to âcastingâ that spell or that card.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 601. Casting Spells : 601.1a
text: Some effects still refer to âplayingâ a card. âPlaying a cardâ means playing that card as a land or casting that card as a spell, whichever is appropriate.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 601. Casting Spells : 601.2.
text: To cast a spell is to take it from where it is (usually the hand), put it on the stack, and pay its costs, so that it will eventually resolve and have its effect. Casting a spell includes proposal of the spell (rules 601.2aâd) and determination and payment of costs (rules 601.2fâh). To cast a spell, a player follows the steps listed below, in order. A player must be legally allowed to cast the spell to begin this process (see rule 601.3). If a player is unable to comply with the requirements of a step listed below while performing that step, the casting of the spell is illegal; the game returns to the moment before the casting of that spell was proposed (see rule 729, âHandling Illegal Actionsâ).

name: Comprehensive Rules: 601. Casting Spells : 601.2a
text: To propose the casting of a spell, a player first moves that card (or that copy of a card) from where it is to the stack. It becomes the topmost object on the stack. It has all the characteristics of the card (or the copy of a card) associated with it, and that player becomes its controller. Any continuous effects that modify the characteristics of the spell as you start casting it begin as it is put on the stack (see rule 611.2f). The spell remains on the stack until it resolves, itâs countered, or a rule or effect moves it elsewhere.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 601. Casting Spells : 601.2b
text: If the spell is modal, the player announces the mode choice (see rule 700.2). If the player wishes to splice any cards onto the spell (see rule 702.47), they reveal those cards in their hand. If the spell has alternative or additional costs that will be paid as itâs being cast such as buyback or kicker costs (see rules 118.8 and 118.9), the player announces their intentions to pay any or all of those costs (see rule 601.2f). A player canât apply two alternative methods of casting or two alternative costs to a single spell. If the spell has a variable cost that will be paid as itâs being cast (such as an {X} in its mana cost; see rule 107.3), the player announces the value of that variable. If the value of that variable is defined in the text of the spell by a choice that player would make later in the announcement or resolution of the spell, that player makes that choice at this time instead of that later time. If a cost that will be paid as the spell is being cast includes hybrid mana symbols, the player announces the nonhybrid equivalent cost they intend to pay. If a cost that will be paid as the spell is being cast includes Phyrexian mana symbols, the player announces whether they intend to pay 2 life or a corresponding colored mana cost for each of those symbols. Previously made choices (such as choosing to cast a spell with flashback from a graveyard or choosing to cast a creature with morph face down) may restrict the playerâs options when making these choices.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 601. Casting Spells : 601.2c
text: The player announces their choice of an appropriate object or player for each target the spell requires. A spell may require some targets only if an alternative or additional cost (such as a kicker cost) or a particular mode was chosen for it; otherwise, the spell is cast as though it did not require those targets. Similarly, a spell may require alternative targets only if an alternative or additional cost was chosen for it. If the spell has a variable number of targets, the player announces how many targets they will choose before they announce those targets. In some cases, the number of targets will be defined by the spellâs text. Once the number of targets the spell has is determined, that number doesnât change, even if the information used to determine the number of targets does. The same target canât be chosen multiple times for any one instance of the word âtargetâ on the spell. However, if the spell uses the word âtargetâ in multiple places, the same object or player can be chosen once for each instance of the word âtargetâ (as long as it fits the targeting criteria). If any effects say that an object or player must be chosen as a target, the player chooses targets so that they obey the maximum possible number of such effects without violating any rules or effects that say that an object or player canât be chosen as a target. The chosen objects and/or players each become a target of that spell. (Any abilities that trigger when those objects and/or players become the target of a spell trigger at this point; theyâll wait to be put on the stack until the spell has finished being cast.)

name: Example for Rule : 601.2c
text: If a spell says âTap two target creatures,â then the same creature canât be chosen twice; the spell requires two different legal targets. A spell that says âDestroy target artifact and target land,â however, can target the same artifact land twice because it uses the word âtargetâ in multiple places.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 601. Casting Spells : 601.2d
text: If the spell requires the player to divide or distribute an effect (such as damage or counters) among one or more targets, the player announces the division. Each of these targets must receive at least one of whatever is being divided.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 601. Casting Spells : 601.2e
text: The game checks to see if the proposed spell can legally be cast. If the proposed spell is illegal, the game returns to the moment before the casting of that spell was proposed (see rule 729, âHandling Illegal Actionsâ).

name: Comprehensive Rules: 601. Casting Spells : 601.2f
text: The player determines the total cost of the spell. Usually this is just the mana cost. Some spells have additional or alternative costs. Some effects may increase or reduce the cost to pay, or may provide other alternative costs. Costs may include paying mana, tapping permanents, sacrificing permanents, discarding cards, and so on. The total cost is the mana cost or alternative cost (as determined in rule 601.2b), plus all additional costs and cost increases, and minus all cost reductions. If multiple cost reductions apply, the player may apply them in any order. If the mana component of the total cost is reduced to nothing by cost reduction effects, it is considered to be {0}. It canât be reduced to less than {0}. Once the total cost is determined, any effects that directly affect the total cost are applied. Then the resulting total cost becomes âlocked in.â If effects would change the total cost after this time, they have no effect.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 601. Casting Spells : 601.2g
text: If the total cost includes a mana payment, the player then has a chance to activate mana abilities (see rule 605, âMana Abilitiesâ). Mana abilities must be activated before costs are paid.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 601. Casting Spells : 601.2h
text: The player pays the total cost. First, they pay all costs that donât involve random elements or moving objects from the library to a public zone, in any order. Then they pay all remaining costs in any order. Partial payments are not allowed. Unpayable costs canât be paid.

name: Example for Rule : 601.2h
text: You cast Altarâs Reap, which costs {1}{B} and has an additional cost of sacrificing a creature. You sacrifice Thunderscape Familiar, whose effect makes your black spells cost {1} less to cast. Because a spellâs total cost is âlocked inâ before payments are actually made, you pay {B}, not {1}{B}, even though youâre sacrificing the Familiar.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 601. Casting Spells : 601.2i
text: Once the steps described in 601.2aâh are completed, effects that modify the characteristics of the spell as itâs cast are applied, then the spell becomes cast. Any abilities that trigger when a spell is cast or put onto the stack trigger at this time. If the spellâs controller had priority before casting it, they get priority.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 601. Casting Spells : 601.3.
text: A player can begin to cast a spell only if a rule or effect allows that player to cast it and no rule or effect prohibits that player from casting it.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 601. Casting Spells : 601.3a
text: If an effect prohibits a player from casting a spell with certain qualities, that player may consider any choices to be made during that spellâs proposal that may cause those qualities to change. If any such choices could cause that effect to no longer prohibit that player from casting that spell, the player may begin to cast the spell, ignoring the effect.

name: Example for Rule : 601.3a
text: A player controls Void Winnower, which reads, in part, âYour opponents canât cast spells with even mana values.â That playerâs opponent may begin to cast Rolling Thunder, a card whose mana cost is {X}{R}{R}, because the chosen value of X may cause the spellâs mana value to become odd.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 601. Casting Spells : 601.3b
text: If an effect allows a player to cast a spell with certain qualities as though it had flash, that player may consider any choices to be made during that spellâs proposal that may cause that spellâs qualities to change. If any such choices could cause that effect to apply, that player may begin to cast that spell as though it had flash.

name: Example for Rule : 601.3b
text: An effect says that you may cast Aura spells as though they had flash, and you have a creature card with bestow in your hand. Because choosing the bestow abilityâs alternative cost causes that spell to become an Aura spell, you may legally begin to cast that spell as though it had flash.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 601. Casting Spells : 601.3c
text: If an effect allows a player to cast a spell as though it had flash only if an alternative or additional cost is paid, that player may begin to cast that spell as though it had flash.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 601. Casting Spells : 601.3d
text: If a spell would have flash only if certain conditions are met, its controller may begin to cast that spell as though it had flash if those conditions are met.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 601. Casting Spells : 601.3e
text: Some rules and effects state that an alternative set of characteristics or a subset of characteristics are considered to determine if a card or copy of a card is legal to cast. These alternative characteristics replace the objectâs characteristics for this determination. Continuous effects that would apply to that object once it has those characteristics are also considered.

name: Example for Rule : 601.3e
text: Garrukâs Horde says, in part, âYou may cast creature spells from the top of your library.â If you control Garrukâs Horde and the top card of your library is a noncreature card with morph, you may cast it using its morph ability.

name: Example for Rule : 601.3e
text: Melek, Izzet Paragon says, in part, âYou may cast instant and sorcery spells from the top of your library.â If you control Melek, Izzet Paragon and the top card of your library is Giant Killer, an adventurer creature card whose Adventure is an instant named Chop Down, you may cast Chop Down but not Giant Killer. If instead you control Garrukâs Horde and the top card of your library is Giant Killer, you may cast Giant Killer but not Chop Down.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 601. Casting Spells : 601.3f
text: Some effects allow a player to cast a spell with certain qualities from among face-down cards in exile. A player may begin to cast such a spell only if they can look at the face-down card in exile.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 601. Casting Spells : 601.4.
text: While announcing the choices of any modes, alternative costs, and/or additional costs as described in rule 601.2b, some options may be available to a player only if other choices are made that would normally be made later in that ruleâs instructions. In that case, the spellâs controller may consider any other choices to be made in that step. If any such choices could allow them to choose a particular mode, alternative cost, or additional cost, they may do so.

name: Example for Rule : 601.4.
text: Inscription of Abundance is a modal spell with kicker and the text âChoose one. If this spell was kicked, choose any number instead.â When announcing the chosen modes for the spell, its controller may choose any number of modes, even though choosing to pay the kicker cost is normally done later in the announcement process.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 601. Casting Spells : 601.5.
text: If a player is no longer allowed to cast a spell after completing its proposal (see rules 601.2aâd), the casting of the spell is illegal and the game returns to the moment before the casting of that spell was proposed (see rule 729, âHandling Illegal Actionsâ). It doesnât matter if a rule or effect would make the casting of the spell illegal while determining and paying that spellâs costs (see rules 601.2fâh) or any time after the spell has been cast.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 601. Casting Spells : 601.5a
text: Once a player has begun casting a spell that had flash because certain conditions were met or that could be cast as though it had flash because certain conditions were met (see 601.3d), they may continue to cast that spell as though it had flash even if those conditions stop being met.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 601. Casting Spells : 601.6.
text: Some spells specify that one of their controllerâs opponents does something the controller would normally do while itâs being cast, such as choose a mode or choose targets. In these cases, the opponent does so when the spellâs controller normally would do so.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 601. Casting Spells : 601.6a
text: If there is more than one opponent who could make such a choice, the spellâs controller decides which of those opponents will make the choice.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 601. Casting Spells : 601.6b
text: If the spell instructs its controller and another player to do something at the same time as the spell is being cast, the spellâs controller goes first, then the other player. This is an exception to rule 101.4.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 601. Casting Spells : 601.7.
text: Casting a spell that alters costs wonât affect spells and abilities that are already on the stack.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 602. Activating Activated Abilities : 602.1.
text: Activated abilities have a cost and an effect. They are written as â[Cost]: [Effect.] [Activation instructions (if any).]â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 602. Activating Activated Abilities : 602.1a
text: The activation cost is everything before the colon (:). An abilityâs activation cost must be paid by the player who is activating it.

name: Example for Rule : 602.1a
text: The activation cost of an ability that reads â{2}, {T}: You gain 1 lifeâ is two mana of any type plus tapping the permanent that has the ability.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 602. Activating Activated Abilities : 602.1b
text: Some text after the colon of an activated ability states instructions that must be followed while activating that ability. Such text may state which players can activate that ability, may restrict when a player can activate the ability, or may define some aspect of the activation cost. This text is not part of the abilityâs effect. It functions at all times. If an activated ability has any activation instructions, they appear last, after the abilityâs effect.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 602. Activating Activated Abilities : 602.1c
text: An activated ability is the only kind of ability that can be activated. If an object or rule refers to activating an ability without specifying what kind, it must be referring to an activated ability.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 602. Activating Activated Abilities : 602.1d
text: Previously, the action of using an activated ability was referred to on cards as âplayingâ that ability. Cards that were printed with that text have received errata in the Oracle card reference so they now refer to âactivatingâ that ability.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 602. Activating Activated Abilities : 602.2.
text: To activate an ability is to put it onto the stack and pay its costs, so that it will eventually resolve and have its effect. Only an objectâs controller (or its owner, if it doesnât have a controller) can activate its activated ability unless the object specifically says otherwise. Activating an ability follows the steps listed below, in order. If, at any point during the activation of an ability, a player is unable to comply with any of those steps, the activation is illegal; the game returns to the moment before that ability started to be activated (see rule 729, âHandling Illegal Actionsâ). Announcements and payments canât be altered after theyâve been made.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 602. Activating Activated Abilities : 602.2a
text: The player announces that they are activating the ability. If an activated ability is being activated from a hidden zone, the card that has that ability is revealed. That ability is created on the stack as an object thatâs not a card. It becomes the topmost object on the stack. It has the text of the ability that created it, and no other characteristics. Its controller is the player who activated the ability. The ability remains on the stack until itâs countered, it resolves, or an effect moves it elsewhere.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 602. Activating Activated Abilities : 602.2b
text: The remainder of the process for activating an ability is identical to the process for casting a spell listed in rules 601.2bâi. Those rules apply to activating an ability just as they apply to casting a spell. An activated abilityâs analog to a spellâs mana cost (as referenced in rule 601.2f) is its activation cost.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 602. Activating Activated Abilities : 602.3.
text: Some abilities specify that one of their controllerâs opponents does something the controller would normally do while itâs being activated, such as choose a mode or choose targets. In these cases, the opponent does so when the abilityâs controller normally would do so.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 602. Activating Activated Abilities : 602.3a
text: If there is more than one opponent who could make such a choice, the abilityâs controller decides which of those opponents will make the choice.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 602. Activating Activated Abilities : 602.3b
text: If the ability instructs its controller and another player to do something at the same time as the ability is being activated, the abilityâs controller goes first, then the other player. This is an exception to rule 101.4.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 602. Activating Activated Abilities : 602.4.
text: Activating an ability that alters costs wonât affect spells and abilities that are already on the stack.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 602. Activating Activated Abilities : 602.5.
text: A player canât begin to activate an ability thatâs prohibited from being activated.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 602. Activating Activated Abilities : 602.5a
text: A creatureâs activated ability with the tap symbol ({T}) or the untap symbol ({Q}) in its activation cost canât be activated unless the creature has been under its controllerâs control since the start of their most recent turn. Ignore this rule for creatures with haste (see rule 702.10).

name: Comprehensive Rules: 602. Activating Activated Abilities : 602.5b
text: If an activated ability has a restriction on its use (for example, âActivate only once each turnâ), the restriction continues to apply to that object even if its controller changes.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 602. Activating Activated Abilities : 602.5c
text: If an object acquires an activated ability with a restriction on its use from another object, that restriction applies only to that ability as acquired from that object. It doesnât apply to other, identically worded abilities.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 602. Activating Activated Abilities : 602.5d
text: Activated abilities that read âActivate only as a sorceryâ mean the player must follow the timing rules for casting a sorcery spell, though the ability isnât actually a sorcery. The player doesnât actually need to have a sorcery card that they could cast.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 602. Activating Activated Abilities : 602.5e
text: Activated abilities that read âActivate only as an instantâ mean the player must follow the timing rules for casting an instant spell, though the ability isnât actually an instant. The player doesnât actually need to have an instant card that they could cast.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 603. Handling Triggered Abilities : 603.1.
text: Triggered abilities have a trigger condition and an effect. They are written as â[When/Whenever/At] [trigger condition or event], [effect]. [Instructions (if any).]â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 603. Handling Triggered Abilities : 603.1a
text: A triggered ability may include instructions after its effects that limit what the ability may target or state that it canât be countered. This text is not part of the abilityâs effect. It functions while the ability is on the stack.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 603. Handling Triggered Abilities : 603.2.
text: Whenever a game event or game state matches a triggered abilityâs trigger event, that ability automatically triggers. The ability doesnât do anything at this point.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 603. Handling Triggered Abilities : 603.2a
text: Because they arenât cast or activated, triggered abilities can trigger even when it isnât legal to cast spells and activate abilities. Effects that preclude abilities from being activated donât affect them.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 603. Handling Triggered Abilities : 603.2b
text: When a phase or step begins, all abilities that trigger âat the beginning ofâ that phase or step trigger.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 603. Handling Triggered Abilities : 603.2c
text: An ability triggers only once each time its trigger event occurs. However, it can trigger repeatedly if one event contains multiple occurrences.

name: Example for Rule : 603.2c
text: A permanent has an ability whose trigger condition reads, âWhenever a land is put into a graveyard from the battlefield, . . . .â If someone casts a spell that destroys all lands, the ability will trigger once for each land put into the graveyard during the spellâs resolution.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 603. Handling Triggered Abilities : 603.2d
text: An ability may state that a triggered ability triggers additional times. In this case, rather than simply determining that such an ability has triggered, determine how many times it should trigger, then that ability triggers that many times. An effect that states that an ability triggers additional times doesnât invoke itself repeatedly and doesnât apply to other effects that affect how many times an ability triggers.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 603. Handling Triggered Abilities : 603.2e
text: Some effects refer to a triggered ability of an object. Such effects refer only to triggered abilities the object has, not any delayed triggered abilities (see rule 603.7) that may be created by abilities the object has.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 603. Handling Triggered Abilities : 603.2f
text: Some trigger events use the word âbecomesâ (for example, âbecomes attachedâ or âbecomes blockedâ). These trigger only at the time the named event happensâthey donât trigger if that state already exists or retrigger if it persists. An ability that triggers when a permanent âbecomes tappedâ or âbecomes untappedâ doesnât trigger if the permanent enters the battlefield in that state.

name: Example for Rule : 603.2f
text: An ability that triggers when a permanent âbecomes tappedâ triggers only when the status of a permanent thatâs already on the battlefield changes from untapped to tapped.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 603. Handling Triggered Abilities : 603.2g
text: If a triggered abilityâs trigger condition is met, but the object with that triggered ability is at no time visible to all players, the ability does not trigger.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 603. Handling Triggered Abilities : 603.2h
text: An ability triggers only if its trigger event actually occurs. An event thatâs prevented or replaced wonât trigger anything.

name: Example for Rule : 603.2h
text: An ability that triggers on damage being dealt wonât trigger if all the damage is prevented.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 603. Handling Triggered Abilities : 603.2i
text: A triggered ability may have an instruction followed by âDo this only once each turn.â This ability triggers only if its sourceâs controller has not yet taken the indicated action that turn.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 603. Handling Triggered Abilities : 603.3.
text: Once an ability has triggered, its controller puts it on the stack as an object thatâs not a card the next time a player would receive priority. See rule 117, âTiming and Priority.â The ability becomes the topmost object on the stack. It has the text of the ability that created it, and no other characteristics. It remains on the stack until itâs countered, it resolves, a rule causes it to be removed from the stack, or an effect moves it elsewhere.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 603. Handling Triggered Abilities : 603.3a
text: A triggered ability is controlled by the player who controlled its source at the time it triggered, unless itâs a delayed triggered ability. To determine the controller of a delayed triggered ability, see rules 603.7dâf.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 603. Handling Triggered Abilities : 603.3b
text: If multiple abilities have triggered since the last time a player received priority, the abilities are placed on the stack in a two-part process. First, each player, in APNAP order, puts each triggered ability they control with a trigger condition that isnât another ability triggering on the stack in any order they choose. (See rule 101.4.) Second, each player, in APNAP order, puts all remaining triggered abilities they control on the stack in any order they choose. Then the game once again checks for and performs state-based actions until none are performed, then abilities that triggered during this process go on the stack. This process repeats until no new state-based actions are performed and no abilities trigger. Then the appropriate player gets priority.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 603. Handling Triggered Abilities : 603.3c
text: If a triggered ability is modal, its controller announces the mode choice when putting the ability on the stack. If one of the modes would be illegal (due to an inability to choose legal targets, for example), that mode canât be chosen. If no mode is chosen, the ability is removed from the stack. (See rule 700.2.)

name: Comprehensive Rules: 603. Handling Triggered Abilities : 603.3d
text: The remainder of the process for putting a triggered ability on the stack is identical to the process for casting a spell listed in rules 601.2câd. If a choice is required when the triggered ability goes on the stack but no legal choices can be made for it, or if a rule or a continuous effect otherwise makes the ability illegal, the ability is simply removed from the stack.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 603. Handling Triggered Abilities : 603.4.
text: A triggered ability may read âWhen/Whenever/At [trigger event], if [condition], [effect].â When the trigger event occurs, the ability checks whether the stated condition is true. The ability triggers only if it is; otherwise it does nothing. If the ability triggers, it checks the stated condition again as it resolves. If the condition isnât true at that time, the ability is removed from the stack and does nothing. Note that this mirrors the check for legal targets. This rule is referred to as the âintervening âifâ clauseâ rule. (The word âifâ has only its normal English meaning anywhere else in the text of a card; this rule only applies to an âifâ that immediately follows a trigger condition.)

name: Example for Rule : 603.4.
text: Felidar Sovereign reads, âAt the beginning of your upkeep, if you have 40 or more life, you win the game.â Its controllerâs life total is checked as that playerâs upkeep begins. If that player has 39 or less life, the ability doesnât trigger at all. If that player has 40 or more life, the ability triggers and goes on the stack. As the ability resolves, that playerâs life total is checked again. If that player has 39 or less life at this time, the ability is removed from the stack and has no effect. If that player has 40 or more life at this time, the ability resolves and that player wins the game.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 603. Handling Triggered Abilities : 603.5.
text: Some triggered abilitiesâ effects are optional (they contain âmay,â as in âAt the beginning of your upkeep, you may draw a cardâ). These abilities go on the stack when they trigger, regardless of whether their controller intends to exercise the abilityâs option or not. The choice is made when the ability resolves. Likewise, triggered abilities that have an effect âunlessâ something is true or a player chooses to do something will go on the stack normally; the âunlessâ part of the ability is dealt with when the ability resolves.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 603. Handling Triggered Abilities : 603.6.
text: Trigger events that involve objects changing zones are called âzone-change triggers.â Many abilities with zone-change triggers attempt to do something to that object after it changes zones. During resolution, these abilities look for the object in the zone that it moved to. If the object is unable to be found in the zone it went to, the part of the ability attempting to do something to the object will fail to do anything. The ability could be unable to find the object because the object never entered the specified zone, because it left the zone before the ability resolved, or because it is in a zone that is hidden from a player, such as a library or an opponentâs hand. (This rule applies even if the object leaves the zone and returns again before the ability resolves.) The most common zone-change triggers are enters-the-battlefield triggers and leaves-the-battlefield triggers.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 603. Handling Triggered Abilities : 603.6a
text: Enters-the-battlefield abilities trigger when a permanent enters the battlefield. These are written, âWhen [this object] enters the battlefield, . . . â or âWhenever a [type] enters the battlefield, . . .â Each time an event puts one or more permanents onto the battlefield, all permanents on the battlefield (including the newcomers) are checked for any enters-the-battlefield triggers that match the event.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 603. Handling Triggered Abilities : 603.6b
text: Continuous effects that modify characteristics of a permanent do so the moment the permanent is on the battlefield (and not before then). The permanent is never on the battlefield with its unmodified characteristics. Continuous effects donât apply before the permanent is on the battlefield, however (see rule 603.6d).

name: Example for Rule : 603.6b
text: If an effect reads âAll lands are creaturesâ and a land card is played, the effect makes the land card into a creature the moment it enters the battlefield, so it would trigger abilities that trigger when a creature enters the battlefield. Conversely, if an effect reads âAll creatures lose all abilitiesâ and a creature card with an enters-the-battlefield triggered ability enters the battlefield, that effect will cause it to lose its abilities the moment it enters the battlefield, so the enters-the-battlefield ability wonât trigger.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 603. Handling Triggered Abilities : 603.6c
text: Leaves-the-battlefield abilities trigger when a permanent moves from the battlefield to another zone, or when a phased-in permanent leaves the game because its owner leaves the game. These are written as, but arenât limited to, âWhen [this object] leaves the battlefield, . . .â or âWhenever [something] is put into a graveyard from the battlefield, . . . .â (See also rule 603.10.) An ability that attempts to do something to the card that left the battlefield checks for it only in the first zone that it went to. An ability that triggers when a card is put into a certain zone âfrom anywhereâ is never treated as a leaves-the-battlefield ability, even if an object is put into that zone from the battlefield.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 603. Handling Triggered Abilities : 603.6d
text: Some permanents have text that reads â[This permanent] enters the battlefield with . . . ,â âAs [this permanent] enters the battlefield . . . ,â â[This permanent] enters the battlefield as . . . ,â or â[This permanent] enters the battlefield tapped.â Such text is a static abilityânot a triggered abilityâwhose effect occurs as part of the event that puts the permanent onto the battlefield.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 603. Handling Triggered Abilities : 603.6e
text: Some Auras have triggered abilities that trigger on the enchanted permanent leaving the battlefield. These triggered abilities can find the new object that permanent card became in the zone it moved to; they can also find the new object the Aura card became in its ownerâs graveyard after state-based actions have been checked. See rule 400.7.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 603. Handling Triggered Abilities : 603.7.
text: An effect may create a delayed triggered ability that can do something at a later time. A delayed triggered ability will contain âwhen,â âwhenever,â or âat,â although that word wonât usually begin the ability.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 603. Handling Triggered Abilities : 603.7a
text: Delayed triggered abilities are created during the resolution of spells or abilities, as the result of a replacement effect being applied, or as a result of a static ability that allows a player to take an action. A delayed triggered ability wonât trigger until it has actually been created, even if its trigger event occurred just beforehand. Other events that happen earlier may make the trigger event impossible.

name: Example for Rule : 603.7a
text: Part of an effect reads âWhen this creature leaves the battlefield,â but the creature in question leaves the battlefield before the spell or ability creating the effect resolves. In this case, the delayed ability never triggers.

name: Example for Rule : 603.7a
text: If an effect reads âWhen this creature becomes untappedâ and the named creature becomes untapped before the effect resolves, the ability waits for the next time that creature untaps.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 603. Handling Triggered Abilities : 603.7b
text: A delayed triggered ability will trigger only onceâthe next time its trigger event occursâunless it has a stated duration, such as âthis turn.â If its trigger event occurs more than once simultaneously and the ability doesnât have a stated duration, the controller of the delayed triggered ability chooses which event causes the ability to trigger.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 603. Handling Triggered Abilities : 603.7c
text: A delayed triggered ability that refers to a particular object still affects it even if the object changes characteristics. However, if that object is no longer in the zone itâs expected to be in at the time the delayed triggered ability resolves, the ability wonât affect it. (Note that if that object left that zone and then returned, itâs a new object and thus wonât be affected. See rule 400.7.)

name: Example for Rule : 603.7c
text: An ability that reads âExile this creature at the beginning of the next end stepâ will exile the permanent even if itâs no longer a creature during the next end step. However, it wonât do anything if the permanent left the battlefield before then.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 603. Handling Triggered Abilities : 603.7d
text: If a spell creates a delayed triggered ability, the source of that delayed triggered ability is that spell. The controller of that delayed triggered ability is the player who controlled that spell as it resolved.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 603. Handling Triggered Abilities : 603.7e
text: If an activated or triggered ability creates a delayed triggered ability, the source of that delayed triggered ability is the same as the source of that other ability. The controller of that delayed triggered ability is the player who controlled that other ability as it resolved.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 603. Handling Triggered Abilities : 603.7f
text: If a static ability generates a replacement effect which causes a delayed triggered ability to be created, the source of that delayed triggered ability is the object with that static ability. The controller of that delayed triggered ability is the same as the controller of that object at the time the replacement effect was applied.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 603. Handling Triggered Abilities : 603.7g
text: If a static ability allows a player to take an action and creates a delayed triggered ability if that player does so, the source of that delayed triggered ability is the object with that static ability. The controller of that delayed triggered ability is the same as the controller of that object at the time the action was taken.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 603. Handling Triggered Abilities : 603.7h
text: An activated or triggered ability may create a delayed triggered ability that triggers when the ability that created it has resolved a certain number of times in a turn. In that case, that delayed triggered ability is created only once, during the appropriate resolution of that ability.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 603. Handling Triggered Abilities : 603.8.
text: Some triggered abilities trigger when a game state (such as a player controlling no permanents of a particular card type) is true, rather than triggering when an event occurs. These abilities trigger as soon as the game state matches the condition. Theyâll go onto the stack at the next available opportunity. These are called state triggers. (Note that state triggers arenât the same as state-based actions.) A state-triggered ability doesnât trigger again until the ability has resolved, has been countered, or has otherwise left the stack. Then, if the object with the ability is still in the same zone and the game state still matches its trigger condition, the ability will trigger again.

name: Example for Rule : 603.8.
text: A permanentâs ability reads, âWhenever you have no cards in hand, draw a card.â If its controller plays the last card from their hand, the ability will trigger once and wonât trigger again until it has left the stack. If its controller casts a spell that reads âDiscard your hand, then draw that many cards,â the ability will trigger during the spellâs resolution because the playerâs hand was momentarily empty.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 603. Handling Triggered Abilities : 603.9.
text: Some triggered abilities trigger specifically when a player loses the game. These abilities trigger when a player loses or leaves the game, regardless of the reason, unless that player leaves the game as the result of a draw. See rule 104.3.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 603. Handling Triggered Abilities : 603.10.
text: Normally, objects that exist immediately after an event are checked to see if the event matched any trigger conditions, and continuous effects that exist at that time are used to determine what the trigger conditions are and what the objects involved in the event look like. However, some triggered abilities are exceptions to this rule; the game âlooks back in timeâ to determine if those abilities trigger, using the existence of those abilities and the appearance of objects immediately prior to the event. The list of exceptions is as follows:

name: Comprehensive Rules: 603. Handling Triggered Abilities : 603.10a
text: Some zone-change triggers look back in time. These are leaves-the-battlefield abilities, abilities that trigger when a card leaves a graveyard, and abilities that trigger when an object that all players can see is put into a hand or library.

name: Example for Rule : 603.10a
text: Two creatures are on the battlefield along with an artifact that has the ability âWhenever a creature dies, you gain 1 life.â Someone casts a spell that destroys all artifacts, creatures, and enchantments. The artifactâs ability triggers twice, even though the artifact goes to its ownerâs graveyard at the same time as the creatures.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 603. Handling Triggered Abilities : 603.10b
text: Abilities that trigger when a permanent phases out look back in time.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 603. Handling Triggered Abilities : 603.10c
text: Abilities that trigger specifically when an object becomes unattached look back in time.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 603. Handling Triggered Abilities : 603.10d
text: Abilities that trigger when a player loses control of an object look back in time.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 603. Handling Triggered Abilities : 603.10e
text: Abilities that trigger when a spell is countered look back in time.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 603. Handling Triggered Abilities : 603.10f
text: Abilities that trigger when a player loses the game look back in time.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 603. Handling Triggered Abilities : 603.10g
text: Abilities that trigger when a player planeswalks away from a plane look back in time.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 603. Handling Triggered Abilities : 603.11.
text: Some objects have a static ability thatâs linked to one or more triggered abilities. (See rule 607, âLinked Abilities.â) These objects combine the abilities into one paragraph, with the static ability first, followed by each triggered ability thatâs linked to it. A very few objects have triggered abilities which are written with the trigger condition in the middle of the ability, rather than at the beginning.

name: Example for Rule : 603.11.
text: An ability that reads âReveal the first card you draw each turn. Whenever you reveal a basic land card this way, draw a cardâ is a static ability linked to a triggered ability.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 603. Handling Triggered Abilities : 603.12.
text: A resolving spell or ability may allow or instruct a player to take an action and create a triggered ability that triggers âwhen [a player] [does or doesnât]â take that action or âwhen [something happens] this way.â These reflexive triggered abilities follow the rules for delayed triggered abilities (see rule 603.7), except that theyâre checked immediately after being created and trigger based on whether the trigger event or events occurred earlier during the resolution of the spell or ability that created them.

name: Example for Rule : 603.12.
text: Heart-Piercer Manticore has an ability that reads âWhen Heart-Piercer Manticore enters the battlefield, you may sacrifice another creature. When you do, Heart-Piercer Manticore deals damage equal to that creatureâs power to any target.â The reflexive triggered ability triggers only when you sacrifice another creature due to the original triggered ability, and not if you sacrifice a creature for any other reason.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 603. Handling Triggered Abilities : 603.12a
text: Normally, if the trigger event or events occur multiple times during the resolution of the spell or ability that created it, the reflexive triggered ability will trigger once for each of those times. However, if a resolving spell or ability includes a choice to pay a cost âany number of timesâ and creates a triggered ability that triggers âwhen [a player] pays [that cost] one or more times,â paying that cost one or more times causes the reflexive triggered ability to trigger only once.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 604. Handling Static Abilities : 604.1.
text: Static abilities do something all the time rather than being activated or triggered. They are written as statements, and theyâre simply true.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 604. Handling Static Abilities : 604.2.
text: Static abilities create continuous effects, some of which are prevention effects or replacement effects. These effects are active as long as the permanent with the ability remains on the battlefield and has the ability, or as long as the object with the ability remains in the appropriate zone, as described in rule 113.6.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 604. Handling Static Abilities : 604.3.
text: Some static abilities are characteristic-defining abilities. A characteristic-defining ability conveys information about an objectâs characteristics that would normally be found elsewhere on that object (such as in its mana cost, type line, or power/toughness box). Characteristic-defining abilities can add to or override information found elsewhere on that object. Characteristic-defining abilities function in all zones. They also function outside the game and before the game begins.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 604. Handling Static Abilities : 604.3a
text: A static ability is a characteristic-defining ability if it meets the following criteria: (1) It defines an objectâs colors, subtypes, power, or toughness; (2) it is printed on the card it affects, it was granted to the token it affects by the effect that created the token, or it was acquired by the object it affects as the result of a copy effect or text-changing effect; (3) it does not directly affect the characteristics of any other objects; (4) it is not an ability that an object grants to itself; and (5) it does not set the values of such characteristics only if certain conditions are met.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 604. Handling Static Abilities : 604.4.
text: Many Auras, Equipment, and Fortifications have static abilities that modify the object theyâre attached to, but those abilities donât target that object. If an Aura, Equipment, or Fortification is moved to a different object, the ability stops applying to the original object and starts modifying the new one.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 604. Handling Static Abilities : 604.5.
text: Some static abilities apply while a spell is on the stack. These are often abilities that refer to countering the spell. Also, abilities that say âAs an additional cost to cast . . . ,â âYou may pay [cost] rather than pay [this object]âs mana cost,â and âYou may cast [this object] without paying its mana costâ work while a spell is on the stack.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 604. Handling Static Abilities : 604.6.
text: Some static abilities apply while a card is in any zone that you could cast or play it from (usually your hand). These are limited to those that read, âYou may [cast/play] [this card] . . . ,â âYou canât [cast/play] [this card] . . . ,â and â[Cast/Play] [this card] only . . . .â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 604. Handling Static Abilities : 604.7.
text: Unlike spells and other kinds of abilities, static abilities canât use an objectâs last known information for purposes of determining how their effects are applied.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 605. Mana Abilities : 605.1.
text: Some activated abilities and some triggered abilities are mana abilities, which are subject to special rules. Only abilities that meet either of the following two sets of criteria are mana abilities, regardless of what other effects they may generate or what timing restrictions (such as âActivate only as an instantâ) they may have.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 605. Mana Abilities : 605.1a
text: An activated ability is a mana ability if it meets all of the following criteria: it doesnât require a target (see rule 115.6), it could add mana to a playerâs mana pool when it resolves, and itâs not a loyalty ability. (See rule 606, âLoyalty Abilities.â)

name: Comprehensive Rules: 605. Mana Abilities : 605.1b
text: A triggered ability is a mana ability if it meets all of the following criteria: it doesnât require a target (see rule 115.6), it triggers from the activation or resolution of an activated mana ability (see rule 605.1a) or from mana being added to a playerâs mana pool, and it could add mana to a playerâs mana pool when it resolves.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 605. Mana Abilities : 605.2.
text: A mana ability remains a mana ability even if the game state doesnât allow it to produce mana.

name: Example for Rule : 605.2.
text: A permanent has an ability that reads â{T}: Add {G} for each creature you control.â The ability is still a mana ability even if you control no creatures or if the permanent is already tapped.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 605. Mana Abilities : 605.3.
text: Activating an activated mana ability follows the rules for activating any other activated ability (see rule 602.2), with the following exceptions:

name: Comprehensive Rules: 605. Mana Abilities : 605.3a
text: A player may activate an activated mana ability whenever they have priority, whenever they are casting a spell or activating an ability that requires a mana payment, or whenever a rule or effect asks for a mana payment, even if itâs in the middle of casting or resolving a spell or activating or resolving an ability.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 605. Mana Abilities : 605.3b
text: An activated mana ability doesnât go on the stack, so it canât be targeted, countered, or otherwise responded to. Rather, it resolves immediately after it is activated. (See rule 405.6c.)

name: Comprehensive Rules: 605. Mana Abilities : 605.3c
text: Once a player begins to activate a mana ability, that ability canât be activated again until it has resolved.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 605. Mana Abilities : 605.4.
text: Triggered mana abilities follow all the rules for other triggered abilities (see rule 603, âHandling Triggered Abilitiesâ), with the following exception:

name: Comprehensive Rules: 605. Mana Abilities : 605.4a
text: A triggered mana ability doesnât go on the stack, so it canât be targeted, countered, or otherwise responded to. Rather, it resolves immediately after the mana ability that triggered it, without waiting for priority.

name: Example for Rule : 605.4a
text: An enchantment reads, âWhenever a player taps a land for mana, that player adds one mana of any type that land produced.â If a player taps lands for mana while casting a spell, the additional mana is added immediately and can be used to pay for the spell.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 605. Mana Abilities : 605.5.
text: Abilities that donât meet the criteria specified in rules 605.1aâb and spells arenât mana abilities.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 605. Mana Abilities : 605.5a
text: An ability with a target is not a mana ability, even if it could put mana into a playerâs mana pool when it resolves. The same is true for a triggered ability that could produce mana but triggers from an event other than activating a mana ability, or a triggered ability that triggers from activating a mana ability but couldnât produce mana. These follow the normal rules for activated or triggered abilities, as appropriate.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 605. Mana Abilities : 605.5b
text: A spell can never be a mana ability, even if it could put mana into a playerâs mana pool when it resolves. Itâs cast and resolves just like any other spell. Some older cards were printed with the card type âmana sourceâ; these cards have received errata in the Oracle card reference and are now instants.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 606. Loyalty Abilities : 606.1.
text: Some activated abilities are loyalty abilities, which are subject to special rules.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 606. Loyalty Abilities : 606.2.
text: An activated ability with a loyalty symbol in its cost is a loyalty ability. Normally, only planeswalkers have loyalty abilities.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 606. Loyalty Abilities : 606.3.
text: A player may activate a loyalty ability of a permanent they control any time they have priority and the stack is empty during a main phase of their turn, but only if no player has previously activated a loyalty ability of that permanent that turn.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 606. Loyalty Abilities : 606.4.
text: The cost to activate a loyalty ability of a permanent is to put on or remove from that permanent a certain number of loyalty counters, as shown by the loyalty symbol in the abilityâs cost. This cost may be modified by other effects.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 606. Loyalty Abilities : 606.5
text: If the total cost to activate a loyalty ability contains multiple costs to add or remove loyalty counters, those costs are combined into a single cost to add or remove loyalty counters, as appropriate.

name: Example for Rule : 606.5
text: A player controls Carth the Lion, which says, in part, âPlaneswalkersâ loyalty abilities you control cost an additional [+1] to activate. That player also controls a planeswalker with three loyalty counters. To activate one of that planeswalkerâs abilities that normally costs [+1], they put two loyalty counters on it. To activate one of its abilities that normally costs [â4], they remove three loyalty counters from it.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 606. Loyalty Abilities : 606.6.
text: A loyalty ability with a negative loyalty cost, taking into account any additional costs, canât be activated unless the permanent has at least that many loyalty counters on it.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 607. Linked Abilities : 607.1.
text: An object may have two abilities printed on it such that one of them causes actions to be taken or objects or players to be affected and the other one directly refers to those actions, objects, or players. If so, these two abilities are linked: the second refers only to actions that were taken or objects or players that were affected by the first, and not by any other ability.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 607. Linked Abilities : 607.1a
text: An ability printed on an object within another ability that grants that ability to that object is considered to be âprinted onâ that object for these purposes.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 607. Linked Abilities : 607.1b
text: An ability printed on either face of a transforming double-faced card (see rule 712) is considered to be âprinted onâ that object for these purposes, regardless of which face is up.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 607. Linked Abilities : 607.1c
text: An ability printed on an object that fulfills both criteria described in rule 607.1 is linked to itself.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 607. Linked Abilities : 607.1d
text: Abilities printed on two objects can be linked if one object is a token, emblem, or nontoken permanent and the second object was the source of the ability that either created the token or emblem or put that nontoken permanent onto the battlefield. In these cases, the abilities fit the criteria listed for one of the different kinds of linked abilities in rule 607.2 except they are printed on two objects rather than one.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 607. Linked Abilities : 607.2.
text: There are different kinds of linked abilities.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 607. Linked Abilities : 607.2a
text: If an object has an activated or triggered ability printed on it that instructs a player to exile one or more cards and an ability printed on it that refers either to âthe exiled cardsâ or to cards âexiled with [this object],â these abilities are linked. The second ability refers only to cards in the exile zone that were put there as a result of an instruction to exile them in the first ability.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 607. Linked Abilities : 607.2b
text: If an object has an ability printed on it that generates a replacement effect which causes one or more cards to be exiled and an ability printed on it that refers either to âthe exiled cardsâ or to cards âexiled with [this object],â these abilities are linked. The second ability refers only to cards in the exile zone that were put there as a direct result of a replacement event caused by the first ability. See rule 614, âReplacement Effects.â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 607. Linked Abilities : 607.2c
text: If an object has an activated or triggered ability printed on it that puts one or more objects onto the battlefield and an ability printed on it that refers to objects âput onto the battlefield with [this object]â or âcreated with [this object],â those abilities are linked. The second can refer only to objects put onto the battlefield as a result of the first.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 607. Linked Abilities : 607.2d
text: If an object has an ability printed on it that causes a player to âchoose a [value]â and an ability printed on it that refers to âthe chosen [value],â âthe last chosen [value],â or similar, those abilities are linked. The second ability refers only to a choice made as a result of the first ability.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 607. Linked Abilities : 607.2e
text: If an object has an ability printed on it that allows some information to be noted and another ability which refers to information noted for that object, those abilities are linked. The second ability refers only to information noted as a result of the first ability.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 607. Linked Abilities : 607.2f
text: If an object has an ability printed on it that causes a player to choose from between two or more words that otherwise have no rules meaning and an ability printed on it that refers to a choice involving one or more of those words, those abilities are linked. The second can refer only to a choice made as a result of the first ability.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 607. Linked Abilities : 607.2g
text: If an object has an ability printed on it that causes a player to pay a cost as it enters the battlefield and an ability printed on it that refers to the cost paid âas [this object] entered the battlefield,â these abilities are linked. The second ability refers only to a cost paid as a result of the first ability.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 607. Linked Abilities : 607.2h
text: If an object has both a static ability and one or more triggered abilities printed on it in the same paragraph, each of those triggered abilities is linked to the static ability. Each triggered ability refers only to actions taken as a result of the static ability. See rule 603.11.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 607. Linked Abilities : 607.2i
text: If an object has an ability printed on it that allows an additional cost to be paid and an ability printed on it that refers to whether that cost was paid, those abilities are linked. The second refers only to whether the intent to pay the additional cost listed in the first was declared as the object was cast as a spell. If an ability lists multiple such costs, it may have multiple abilities linked to it. Each of those abilities will specify which cost it refers to.

name: Example for Rule : 607.2i
text: Stormscape Battlemage has âKicker {W} and/or {2}{B}â and two abilities that may trigger when it enters the battlefield. The first triggers if it was kicked with its {W} kicker, and the second triggers if it was kicked with its {2}{B} kicker. Each of those triggered abilities is linked to its kicker ability.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 607. Linked Abilities : 607.2j
text: If an object has an ability printed on it that causes a player to pay a variable additional cost as itâs cast and an ability printed on it that refers to the cost paid âas [this object] was cast,â these abilities are linked. The second refers only to the value chosen for the cost listed in the first as the object was cast as a spell. See rule 601.2b.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 607. Linked Abilities : 607.2k
text: The two abilities represented by the champion keyword are linked abilities. See rule 702.72, âChampion.â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 607. Linked Abilities : 607.2m
text: Abilities preceded by an anchor word are linked to the ability that allows a player to choose that anchor word. See rule 614.12b.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 607. Linked Abilities : 607.2n
text: If an object has a static ability printed on it that allows a player to exile one or more cards âbefore you shuffle your deck to start the gameâ and an ability printed on it that refers to cards âexiled with cards named [this objectâs name],â the second ability is linked to the first ability of any objects that had the specified name before the game began.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 607. Linked Abilities : 607.2p
text: If an object has both a static ability that causes a player to make a choice for a characteristic-defining ability before the game begins and that characteristic-defining ability printed on it in the same paragraph, those abilities are linked. The second ability refers only to the choice made as a result of the first ability and continues to refer to that choice as the object changes zones during the game.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 607. Linked Abilities : 607.2q
text: If a permanent spell has an ability printed on it that allows one or more cards to be exiled while paying a cost to cast it and the permanent that spell becomes has an ability that refers to cards âexiled with [this object],â those abilities are linked. The second ability refers only to cards exiled to pay the cost of the spell that became that permanent.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 607. Linked Abilities : 607.3.
text: If, within a pair of linked abilities, one ability refers to a single object as âthe exiled card,â âa card exiled with [this card],â or a similar phrase, and the other ability has exiled multiple cards (usually because it was copied), the ability refers to each of the exiled cards. If that ability asks for any information about the exiled card, such as a characteristic or mana value, it gets multiple answers. If these answers are used to determine the value of a variable, the sum of the answers is used. If that ability performs any actions on âtheâ card, it performs that action on each exiled card. If that ability creates a token that is a copy of âtheâ card, then for each exiled card, it creates a token that is a copy of that card. If that ability performs any actions on âaâ card, the controller of the ability chooses which card is affected.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 607. Linked Abilities : 607.4.
text: An ability may be part of more than one pair of linked abilities.

name: Example for Rule : 607.4.
text: Paradise Plume has the following three abilities: âAs Paradise Plume enters the battlefield, choose a color,â âWhenever a player casts a spell of the chosen color, you may gain 1 life,â and â{T}: Add one mana of the chosen color.â The first and second abilities are linked. The first and third abilities are linked.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 607. Linked Abilities : 607.5.
text: If an object acquires a pair of linked abilities as part of the same effect, the abilities will be similarly linked to one another on that object even though they werenât printed on that object. They canât be linked to any other ability, regardless of what other abilities the object may currently have or may have had in the past.

name: Example for Rule : 607.5.
text: Arc-Slogger has the ability â{R}, Exile the top ten cards of your library: Arc-Slogger deals 2 damage to any target.â Sisters of Stone Death has the ability â{B}{G}: Exile target creature blocking or blocked by Sisters of Stone Deathâ and the ability â{2}{B}: Put a creature card exiled with Sisters of Stone Death onto the battlefield under your control.â Quicksilver Elemental has the ability â{U}: Quicksilver Elemental gains all activated abilities of target creature until end of turn.â If a player has Quicksilver Elemental gain Arc-Sloggerâs ability, activates it, then has Quicksilver Elemental gain Sisters of Stone Deathâs abilities, activates the exile ability, and then activates the return-to-the-battlefield ability, only the creature card Quicksilver Elemental exiled with Sisters of Stone Deathâs ability can be returned to the battlefield. Creature cards Quicksilver Elemental exiled with Arc-Sloggerâs ability canât be returned.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 607. Linked Abilities : 607.5a
text: If an object gains an ability that refers to a choice, but either (a) doesnât copy that abilityâs linked ability or (b) does copy the linked ability but no choice is made for it, then the choice is considered to be âundefined.â If an ability refers to an undefined choice, that part of the ability wonât do anything.

name: Example for Rule : 607.5a
text: Voice of All enters the battlefield and Unstable Shapeshifter copies it. Voice of All reads, in part, âAs Voice of All enters the battlefield, choose a color.â and âVoice of All has protection from the chosen color.â Unstable Shapeshifter never had a chance for a color to be chosen for it, because it didnât enter the battlefield as Voice of All so it doesnât gain a protection ability.

name: Example for Rule : 607.5a
text: A Vesuvan Doppelganger enters the battlefield as a copy of Voice of All, and the Doppelgangerâs controller chooses blue. Later, the Doppelganger copies Quirion Elves, which has the ability, â{T}: Add one mana of the chosen color.â Even though a color was chosen for the Doppelganger, it wasnât chosen for the ability linked to the mana ability copied from the Elves. If that mana ability of the Doppelganger is activated, it will not produce mana.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 608. Resolving Spells and Abilities : 608.1.
text: Each time all players pass in succession, the spell or ability on top of the stack resolves. (See rule 609, âEffects.â)

name: Comprehensive Rules: 608. Resolving Spells and Abilities : 608.2.
text: If the object thatâs resolving is an instant spell, a sorcery spell, or an ability, its resolution may involve several steps. The steps described in rules 608.2a and 608.2b are followed first. The steps described in rules 608.2câk are then followed as appropriate, in no specific order. The steps described in rule 608.2m and 608.2n are followed last.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 608. Resolving Spells and Abilities : 608.2a
text: If a triggered ability has an intervening âifâ clause, it checks whether the clauseâs condition is true. If it isnât, the ability is removed from the stack and does nothing. Otherwise, it continues to resolve. See rule 603.4.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 608. Resolving Spells and Abilities : 608.2b
text: If the spell or ability specifies targets, it checks whether the targets are still legal. A target thatâs no longer in the zone it was in when it was targeted is illegal. Other changes to the game state may cause a target to no longer be legal; for example, its characteristics may have changed or an effect may have changed the text of the spell. If the source of an ability has left the zone it was in, its last known information is used during this process. If all its targets, for every instance of the word âtarget,â are now illegal, the spell or ability doesnât resolve. Itâs removed from the stack and, if itâs a spell, put into its ownerâs graveyard. Otherwise, the spell or ability will resolve normally. Illegal targets, if any, wonât be affected by parts of a resolving spellâs effect for which theyâre illegal. Other parts of the effect for which those targets are not illegal may still affect them. If the spell or ability creates any continuous effects that affect game rules (see rule 613.11), those effects donât apply to illegal targets. If part of the effect requires information about an illegal target, it fails to determine any such information. Any part of the effect that requires that information wonât happen.

name: Example for Rule : 608.2b
text: Sorinâs Thirst is a black instant that reads, âSorinâs Thirst deals 2 damage to target creature and you gain 2 life.â If the creature isnât a legal target during the resolution of Sorinâs Thirst (say, if the creature has gained protection from black or left the battlefield), then Sorinâs Thirst doesnât resolve. Its controller doesnât gain any life.

name: Example for Rule : 608.2b
text: Plague Spores reads, âDestroy target nonblack creature and target land. They canât be regenerated.â Suppose the same creature land is chosen both as the nonblack creature and as the land, and the color of the creature land is changed to black before Plague Spores resolves. Plague Spores still resolves because the black creature land is still a legal target for the âtarget landâ part of the spell. The âdestroy target nonblack creatureâ part of the spell wonât affect that permanent, but the âdestroy target landâ part of the spell will still destroy it. It canât be regenerated.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 608. Resolving Spells and Abilities : 608.2c
text: The controller of the spell or ability follows its instructions in the order written. However, replacement effects may modify these actions. In some cases, later text on the card may modify the meaning of earlier text (for example, âDestroy target creature. It canât be regeneratedâ or âCounter target spell. If that spell is countered this way, put it on top of its ownerâs library instead of into its ownerâs graveyard.â) Donât just apply effects step by step without thinking in these casesâread the whole text and apply the rules of English to the text.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 608. Resolving Spells and Abilities : 608.2d
text: If an effect of a spell or ability offers any choices other than choices already made as part of casting the spell, activating the ability, or otherwise putting the spell or ability on the stack, the player announces these while applying the effect. The player canât choose an option thatâs illegal or impossible, with the exception that having a library with no cards in it doesnât make drawing a card an impossible action (see rule 121.3). If an effect divides or distributes something, such as damage or counters, as a player chooses among any number of untargeted players and/or objects, the player chooses the amount and division such that each chosen player or object receives at least one of whatever is being divided.
