(Note that if an effect divides or distributes something, such as damage or counters, as a player chooses among some number of target objects and/or players, the amount and division were determined as the spell or ability was put onto the stack rather than at this time; see rule 601.2d.)

name: Example for Rule : 608.2d
text: A spellâs instruction reads, âYou may sacrifice a creature. If you donât, you lose 4 life.â A player who controls no creatures canât choose the sacrifice option.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 608. Resolving Spells and Abilities : 608.2e
text: Some spells and abilities have multiple steps or actions, denoted by separate sentences or clauses, that involve multiple players. In these cases, the choices for the first action are made in APNAP order, and then the first action is processed simultaneously. Then the choices for the second action are made in APNAP order, and then that action is processed simultaneously, and so on. See rule 101.4.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 608. Resolving Spells and Abilities : 608.2f
text: Some spells and abilities include actions taken on multiple players and/or objects. In most cases, each such action is processed simultaneously. If the action canât be processed simultaneously, itâs instead processed considering each affected player or object individually. APNAP order is used to make the primary determination of the order of those actions. Secondarily, if the action is to be taken on both a player and an object they control or on multiple objects controlled by the same player, the player who controls the resolving spell or ability chooses the relative order of those actions.

name: Example for Rule : 608.2f
text: Blatant Thievery says âFor each opponent, gain control of target permanent that player controls.â As Blatant Thievery resolves, its controller gains control of all permanents chosen as targets simultaneously.

name: Example for Rule : 608.2f
text: Soulfire Eruption says, in part, âChoose any number of target creatures, planeswalkers, and/or players. For each of them, exile the top card of your library, then Soulfire Eruption deals damage equal to that cardâs mana value to that permanent or player.â A player casts Soulfire Eruption targeting an opponent and a creature that opponent controls. As Soulfire Eruption resolves, the player canât exile the top card of their library multiple times at the same time, so they first choose which target they are considering, then they exile the top card of their library, and finally Soulfire Eruption deals damage to that target. They then repeat this process for the remaining target.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 608. Resolving Spells and Abilities : 608.2g
text: If an effect gives a player the option to pay mana, they may activate mana abilities before taking that action. If an effect specifically instructs or allows a player to cast a spell during resolution, they do so by following the steps in rules 601.2aâi, except no player receives priority after itâs cast. That spell becomes the topmost object on the stack, and the currently resolving spell or ability continues to resolve, which may include casting other spells this way. No other spells can normally be cast and no other abilities can normally be activated during resolution.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 608. Resolving Spells and Abilities : 608.2h
text: If an effect requires information from the game (such as the number of creatures on the battlefield), the answer is determined only once, when the effect is applied. If the effect requires information from a specific object, including the source of the ability itself, the effect uses the current information of that object if itâs in the public zone it was expected to be in; if itâs no longer in that zone, or if the effect has moved it from a public zone to a hidden zone, the effect uses the objectâs last known information. See rule 113.7a. If an ability states that an object does something, itâs the object as it existsâor as it most recently existedâthat does it, not the ability.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 608. Resolving Spells and Abilities : 608.2i
text: If an effect refers to certain characteristics, it checks only for the value of the specified characteristics, regardless of any related ones an object may also have.

name: Example for Rule : 608.2i
text: An effect that reads âDestroy all black creaturesâ destroys a white-and-black creature, but one that reads âDestroy all nonblack creaturesâ doesnât.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 608. Resolving Spells and Abilities : 608.2j
text: If an abilityâs effect refers to a specific untargeted object that has been previously referred to by that abilityâs cost or trigger condition, it still affects that object even if the object has changed characteristics.

name: Example for Rule : 608.2j
text: Wall of Tears says âWhenever Wall of Tears blocks a creature, return that creature to its ownerâs hand at end of combat.â If Wall of Tears blocks a creature, then that creature ceases to be a creature before the triggered ability resolves, the permanent will still be returned to its ownerâs hand.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 608. Resolving Spells and Abilities : 608.2k
text: If an instant spell, sorcery spell, or ability that can legally resolve leaves the stack once it starts to resolve, it will continue to resolve fully.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 608. Resolving Spells and Abilities : 608.2m
text: As the final part of an instant or sorcery spellâs resolution, the spell is put into its ownerâs graveyard. As the final part of an abilityâs resolution, the ability is removed from the stack and ceases to exist.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 608. Resolving Spells and Abilities : 608.2n
text: Once all possible steps described in 608.2câm are completed, any abilities that trigger when that spell or ability resolves trigger.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 608. Resolving Spells and Abilities : 608.3.
text: If the object thatâs resolving is a permanent spell, its resolution may involve several steps. The instructions in rules 608.3a and b are always performed first. Then one of the steps in rule 608.3câe is performed, if appropriate.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 608. Resolving Spells and Abilities : 608.3a
text: If the object thatâs resolving has no targets, it becomes a permanent and enters the battlefield under the control of the spellâs controller.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 608. Resolving Spells and Abilities : 608.3b
text: If the object thatâs resolving has a target, it checks whether the target is still legal, as described in 608.2b. If a spell with an illegal target is a bestowed Aura spell (see rule 702.103e) or a mutating creature spell (see rule 702.140b), it becomes a creature spell and will resolve as described in rule 608.3a. Otherwise, the spell doesnât resolve. It is removed from the stack and put into its ownerâs graveyard.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 608. Resolving Spells and Abilities : 608.3c
text: If the object thatâs resolving is an Aura spell, it becomes a permanent and is put onto the battlefield under the control of the spellâs controller attached to the player or object it was targeting.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 608. Resolving Spells and Abilities : 608.3d
text: If the object thatâs resolving is a mutating creature spell, the object representing that spell merges with the permanent it is targeting (see rule 726, âMerging with Permanentsâ).

name: Comprehensive Rules: 608. Resolving Spells and Abilities : 608.3e
text: If a permanent spell resolves but its controller canât put it onto the battlefield, that player puts it into its ownerâs graveyard.

name: Example for Rule : 608.3e
text: Worms of the Earth has the ability âLands canât enter the battlefield.â Clone says âYou may have Clone enter the battlefield as a copy of any creature on the battlefield.â If a player casts Clone and chooses to copy Dryad Arbor (a land creature) while Worms of the Earth is on the battlefield, Clone canât enter the battlefield from the stack. Itâs put into its ownerâs graveyard.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 608. Resolving Spells and Abilities : 608.3f
text: If the object thatâs resolving is a copy of a permanent spell, it will become a token permanent as it is put onto the battlefield in any of the steps above. A token put onto the battlefield this way is no longer a copy of a spell and is not âcreatedâ for the purposes of any rules or effects that refer to creating a token.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 608. Resolving Spells and Abilities : 608.3g
text: If the object thatâs resolving has a static ability that functions on the stack and creates a delayed triggered ability, that delayed triggered ability is created as that permanent is put onto the battlefield in any of the steps above. (See rules 702.109, âDash,â and rule 702.152, âBlitz.â)

name: Comprehensive Rules: 609. Effects : 609.1.
text: An effect is something that happens in the game as a result of a spell or ability. When a spell, activated ability, or triggered ability resolves, it may create one or more one-shot or continuous effects. Static abilities may create one or more continuous effects. Text itself is never an effect.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 609. Effects : 609.2.
text: Effects apply only to permanents unless the instructionâs text states otherwise or they clearly can apply only to objects in one or more other zones.

name: Example for Rule : 609.2.
text: An effect that changes all lands into creatures wonât alter land cards in playersâ graveyards. But an effect that says spells cost more to cast will apply only to spells on the stack, since a spell is always on the stack while a player is casting it.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 609. Effects : 609.3.
text: If an effect attempts to do something impossible, it does only as much as possible.

name: Example for Rule : 609.3.
text: If a player is holding only one card, an effect that reads âDiscard two cardsâ causes them to discard only that card. If an effect moves cards out of the library (as opposed to drawing), it moves as many as possible.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 609. Effects : 609.4.
text: Some effects state that a player may do something âas thoughâ some condition were true or a creature can do something âas thoughâ some condition were true. This applies only to the stated effect. For purposes of that effect, treat the game exactly as if the stated condition were true. For all other purposes, treat the game normally.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 609. Effects : 609.4a
text: If two effects state that a player may (or a creature can) do the same thing âas thoughâ different conditions were true, both conditions could apply. If one âas thoughâ effect satisfies the requirements for another âas thoughâ effect, then both effects will apply.

name: Example for Rule : 609.4a
text: A player controls Vedalken Orrery, an artifact that says âYou may cast spells as though they had flash.â That player casts Shamanâs Trance, an instant that says, in part, âYou may play lands and cast spells from other playersâ graveyards this turn as though those cards were in your graveyard.â The player may cast a sorcery with flashback from another playerâs graveyard as though it were in that playerâs graveyard and as though it had flash.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 609. Effects : 609.4b
text: If an effect allows a player to spend mana âas though it were mana of any [type or color],â this affects only how the player may pay a cost. It doesnât change that cost, and it doesnât change what mana was actually spent to pay that cost. The same is true for effects that say âmana of any type can be spent.â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 609. Effects : 609.5.
text: If an effect could result in a tie, the text of the spell or ability that created the effect will specify what to do in the event of a tie. The Magic game has no default for ties.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 609. Effects : 609.6.
text: Some continuous effects are replacement effects or prevention effects. See rules 614 and 615.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 609. Effects : 609.7.
text: Some effects apply to damage from a sourceâfor example, âThe next time a red source of your choice would deal damage to you this turn, prevent that damage.â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 609. Effects : 609.7a
text: If an effect requires a player to choose a source of damage, they may choose a permanent; a spell on the stack (including a permanent spell); any object referred to by an object on the stack, by a replacement or prevention effect thatâs waiting to apply, or by a delayed triggered ability thatâs waiting to trigger (even if that object is no longer in the zone it used to be in); or a face-up object in the command zone. A source doesnât need to be capable of dealing damage to be a legal choice. The source is chosen when the effect is created. If the player chooses a permanent, the effect will apply to the next damage dealt by that permanent, regardless of whether itâs combat damage or damage dealt as the result of a spell or ability. If the player chooses a permanent spell, the effect will apply to any damage dealt by that spell and any damage dealt by the permanent that spell becomes when it resolves.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 609. Effects : 609.7b
text: Some effects from resolved spells and abilities prevent or replace damage from sources with certain properties, such as a creature or a source of a particular color. When the source would deal damage, the âshieldâ rechecks the sourceâs properties. If the properties no longer match, the damage isnât prevented or replaced. If for any reason the shield prevents no damage or replaces no damage, the shield isnât used up.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 609. Effects : 609.7c
text: Some effects from static abilities prevent or replace damage from sources with certain properties. For these effects, the prevention or replacement applies to sources that are permanents with that property and to any sources that arenât on the battlefield that have that property.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 609. Effects : 609.8.
text: Some effects look back in time and consider previous game states and actions rather than considering the current game state. If such an effect refers to an object or group of objects, those objects donât need to be currently in the zone they were in at the time of the action, nor do they need to currently meet the criteria described in the action, as long as they did so at the specified time.

name: Example for Rule : 609.8.
text: A player attacks with Bear Cub. Later in the turn, an effect causes Bear Cub to become a noncreature permanent. The same player then casts Search Party Captain, a spell that says in part âThis spell costs {1} less to cast for each creature you attacked with this turn.â That spell costs {1} less because the player attacked with a creature, even though the Bear Cub they attacked with is no longer a creature.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 610. One-Shot Effects : 610.1.
text: A one-shot effect does something just once and doesnât have a duration. Examples include dealing damage, destroying a permanent, creating a token, and moving an object from one zone to another.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 610. One-Shot Effects : 610.2.
text: Some one-shot effects create a delayed triggered ability, which instructs a player to do something later in the game (usually at a specific time) rather than as the spell or ability thatâs creating the one-shot effect resolves. See rule 603.7.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 610. One-Shot Effects : 610.3.
text: Some one-shot effects cause an object to change zones âuntilâ a specified event occurs. A second one-shot effect is created immediately after the specified event. This second one-shot effect returns the object to its previous zone.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 610. One-Shot Effects : 610.3a
text: If a resolving spell or activated ability creates the initial one-shot effect that causes the object to change zones, and the specified event has already occurred before that one-shot effect would occur but after that spell or ability was put onto the stack, the object doesnât move.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 610. One-Shot Effects : 610.3b
text: If a resolving triggered ability creates the initial one-shot effect that causes the object to change zones, and the specified event has already occurred before that one-shot effect would occur but after that ability triggered, the object doesnât move.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 610. One-Shot Effects : 610.3c
text: An object returned to the battlefield this way returns under its ownerâs control unless otherwise specified.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 610. One-Shot Effects : 610.3d
text: If multiple one-shot effects are created this way immediately after one or more simultaneous events, those one-shot effects are also simultaneous.

name: Example for Rule : 610.3d
text: Two Banisher Priests have each exiled a card. All creatures are destroyed at the same time by Day of Judgment. The two exiled cards are returned to the battlefield at the same time.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 610. One-Shot Effects : 610.4.
text: Some one-shot effects cause a permanent to phase out âuntilâ a specified event occurs. A second one-shot effect is created immediately after the specified event. This second one-shot effect causes the permanent to phase in.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 610. One-Shot Effects : 610.4a
text: A permanent phased out this way doesnât phase in as a result of the turn-based action during a playerâs untap step (see rule 502.1). Other effects may cause it to phase in. If a permanent phased out this way phases in due to another effect, the second one-shot effect doesnât happen, even if that permanent has phased out again.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 610. One-Shot Effects : 610.4b
text: If a resolving spell or activated ability creates the initial one-shot effect that causes the permanent to phase out, and the specified event has already occurred before that one-shot effect would occur but after that spell or ability was put onto the stack, the permanent doesnât phase out.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 610. One-Shot Effects : 610.4c
text: If a resolving triggered ability creates the initial one-shot effect that causes the permanent to phase out, and the specified event has already occurred before that one-shot effect would occur but after that ability triggered, the permanent doesnât phase out.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 610. One-Shot Effects : 610.4d
text: If multiple one-shot effects are created this way immediately after one or more simultaneous events, those one-shot effects are also simultaneous.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 611. Continuous Effects : 611.1.
text: A continuous effect modifies characteristics of objects, modifies control of objects, or affects players or the rules of the game, for a fixed or indefinite period.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 611. Continuous Effects : 611.2.
text: A continuous effect may be generated by the resolution of a spell or ability.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 611. Continuous Effects : 611.2a
text: A continuous effect generated by the resolution of a spell or ability lasts as long as stated by the spell or ability creating it (such as âuntil end of turnâ). If no duration is stated, it lasts until the end of the game.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 611. Continuous Effects : 611.2b
text: Some continuous effects generated by the resolution of a spell or ability have durations worded âfor as long as . . . .â If the âfor as long asâ duration never starts, or it ends before the moment the effect would first be applied, the effect does nothing. It doesnât start and immediately stop again, and it doesnât last forever.

name: Example for Rule : 611.2b
text: Master Thief has the ability âWhen Master Thief enters the battlefield, gain control of target artifact for as long as you control Master Thief.â If you lose control of Master Thief before the ability resolves, it does nothing, because its durationâas long as you control Master Thiefâwas over before the effect began.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 611. Continuous Effects : 611.2c
text: If a continuous effect generated by the resolution of a spell or ability modifies the characteristics or changes the controller of any objects, the set of objects it affects is determined when that continuous effect begins. After that point, the set wonât change. (Note that this works differently than a continuous effect from a static ability.) A continuous effect generated by the resolution of a spell or ability that doesnât modify the characteristics or change the controller of any objects modifies the rules of the game, so it can affect objects that werenât affected when that continuous effect began. If a single continuous effect has parts that modify the characteristics or changes the controller of any objects and other parts that donât, the set of objects each part applies to is determined independently.

name: Example for Rule : 611.2c
text: An effect that reads âAll white creatures get +1/+1 until end of turnâ gives the bonus to all permanents that are white creatures when the spell or ability resolvesâeven if they change color laterâand doesnât affect those that enter the battlefield or turn white afterward.

name: Example for Rule : 611.2c
text: An effect that reads âPrevent all damage creatures would deal this turnâ doesnât modify any objectâs characteristics, so itâs modifying the rules of the game. That means the effect will apply even to damage from creatures that werenât on the battlefield when the continuous effect began. It also affects damage from permanents that become creatures later in the turn.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 611. Continuous Effects : 611.2d
text: If a resolving spell or ability that creates a continuous effect contains a variable such as X, the value of that variable is determined only once, on resolution. See rule 608.2h.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 611. Continuous Effects : 611.2e
text: If a resolving spell or ability both puts a nontoken permanent onto the battlefield and creates a continuous effect stating that the permanent âis [characteristic],â that continuous effect applies simultaneously with the permanent entering the battlefield. This characteristic is usually a color or a creature type. If the continuous effect says the permanent âbecomes [characteristic]â or âgains [an ability],â that effect applies after the permanent is on the battlefield.

name: Example for Rule : 611.2e
text: Arbiter of the Ideal puts an artifact, creature, or land card onto the battlefield and says, in part, âThat permanent is an enchantment in addition to its other types.â An ability that triggers whenever an enchantment enters the battlefield would trigger. The permanent doesnât enter the battlefield and then become an enchantment.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 611. Continuous Effects : 611.2f
text: Some spells and abilities generate a continuous effect that modifies the characteristics of the next spell a player casts, the next spell that fulfills certain conditions a player casts during some duration, or similar. These effects do not begin immediately. Rather, they begin to apply at the time that player next puts an appropriate spell on the stack, and they apply to that spell. See rule 601.2a.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 611. Continuous Effects : 611.3.
text: A continuous effect may be generated by the static ability of an object.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 611. Continuous Effects : 611.3a
text: A continuous effect generated by a static ability isnât âlocked inâ; it applies at any given moment to whatever its text indicates.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 611. Continuous Effects : 611.3b
text: The effect applies at all times that the permanent generating it is on the battlefield or the object generating it is in the appropriate zone.

name: Example for Rule : 611.3b
text: A permanent with the static ability âAll white creatures get +1/+1â generates an effect that continuously gives +1/+1 to each white creature on the battlefield. If a creature becomes white, it gets this bonus; a creature that stops being white loses it.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 611. Continuous Effects : 611.3c
text: Continuous effects that modify characteristics of permanents do so simultaneously with the permanent entering the battlefield. They donât wait until the permanent is on the battlefield and then change it. Because such effects apply as the permanent enters the battlefield, they are applied before determining whether the permanent will cause an ability to trigger when it enters the battlefield.

name: Example for Rule : 611.3c
text: A permanent with the static ability âAll white creatures get +1/+1â is on the battlefield. A creature spell that would normally create a 1/1 white creature instead creates a 2/2 white creature. The creature doesnât enter the battlefield as 1/1 and then change to 2/2.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 611. Continuous Effects : 611.3d
text: Continuous effects from static abilities may allow a player to play a land or cast a permanent spell, or may grant an ability to a permanent spell or card that allows it to be cast. If the effect also grants that object an ability that functions only on the battlefield, that ability lasts as long as stated by the effect granting that permission or ability. If no duration is stated, it lasts until the end of the game. This is an exception to rules 611.3aâb.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 612. Text-Changing Effects : 612.1.
text: Some continuous effects change an objectâs text. This can apply to any words or symbols printed on that object, but generally affects only that objectâs rules text (which appears in its text box) and/or the text that appears in its type line. Such an effect is a text-changing effect.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 612. Text-Changing Effects : 612.2.
text: A text-changing effect changes only those words that are used in the correct way (for example, a Magic color word being used as a color word, a land type word used as a land type, or a creature type word used as a creature type). An effect that changes a color word or a subtype canât change a card name, even if that name contains a word or a series of letters that is the same as a Magic color word, basic land type, or creature type.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 612. Text-Changing Effects : 612.2a
text: Most spells and abilities that create creature tokens use creature types to define both the creature types and the names of the tokens. A text-changing effect that affects such a spell or an object with such an ability can change these words because theyâre being used as creature types, even though theyâre also being used as names.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 612. Text-Changing Effects : 612.3.
text: Effects that add or remove abilities donât change the text of the objects they affect, so any abilities that are granted to an object canât be modified by text-changing effects that affect that object.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 612. Text-Changing Effects : 612.4.
text: A tokenâs subtypes and rules text are defined by the spell or ability that created the token. A text-changing effect that affects a token can change these characteristics.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 612. Text-Changing Effects : 612.5.
text: One card (Exchange of Words) instructs a player to exchange the text boxes of two objects. This replaces all of the rules text of each object with the rules text of the other object. (In games involving certain cards that arenât covered by these rules, other elements of the text box may also be exchanged. See rule 100.7.)

name: Comprehensive Rules: 612. Text-Changing Effects : 612.6.
text: One card (Volrathâs Shapeshifter) states that an object has the âfull textâ of another object. This changes not just the text that appears in the objectâs text box and type line, but also changes the text that represents its name, mana cost, color indicator, power, and toughness.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 612. Text-Changing Effects : 612.7.
text: One card (Spy Kit) states that an object has âall names of nonlegendary creature cards.â This changes the text that represents the objectâs name. That object has the name of each nonlegendary creature card in the Oracle card reference. (See rule 108.1.)

name: Comprehensive Rules: 612. Text-Changing Effects : 612.8.
text: Some cards create a continuous effect that sets the name of an object. This changes the text that represents the objectâs name. That object loses any names it had and has only the specified name.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 612. Text-Changing Effects : 612.9.
text: A name sticker on a permanent or on a card not on the battlefield creates a continuous effect that adds a word to the text that represents the objectâs name. (See rule 123.6.)

name: Comprehensive Rules: 612. Text-Changing Effects : 612.10.
text: A splice ability changes a spellâs text by adding the rules text of the card with splice to the spell, following that spellâs own rules text. It doesnât modify or replace any of that spellâs own text. (See rule 702.47, âSplice.â)

name: Comprehensive Rules: 613. Interaction of Continuous Effects : 613.1.
text: The values of an objectâs characteristics are determined by starting with the actual object. For a card, that means the values of the characteristics printed on that card. For a token or a copy of a spell or card, that means the values of the characteristics defined by the effect that created it. Then all applicable continuous effects are applied in a series of layers in the following order:

name: Comprehensive Rules: 613. Interaction of Continuous Effects : 613.1a
text: Layer 1: Rules and effects that modify copiable values are applied.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 613. Interaction of Continuous Effects : 613.1b
text: Layer 2: Control-changing effects are applied.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 613. Interaction of Continuous Effects : 613.1c
text: Layer 3: Text-changing effects are applied. See rule 612, âText-Changing Effects.â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 613. Interaction of Continuous Effects : 613.1d
text: Layer 4: Type-changing effects are applied. These include effects that change an objectâs card type, subtype, and/or supertype.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 613. Interaction of Continuous Effects : 613.1e
text: Layer 5: Color-changing effects are applied.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 613. Interaction of Continuous Effects : 613.1f
text: Layer 6: Ability-adding effects, keyword counters, ability-removing effects, and effects that say an object canât have an ability are applied.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 613. Interaction of Continuous Effects : 613.1g
text: Layer 7: Power- and/or toughness-changing effects are applied.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 613. Interaction of Continuous Effects : 613.2.
text: Within layer 1, apply effects in a series of sublayers in the order described below. Within each sublayer, apply effects in timestamp order (see rule 613.7). Note that dependency may alter the order in which effects are applied within a sublayer. (See rule 613.8.)

name: Comprehensive Rules: 613. Interaction of Continuous Effects : 613.2a
text: Layer 1a: Copiable effects are applied. This includes copy effects (see rule 707, âCopying Objectsâ) and changes to an objectâs characteristics determined by merging an object with a permanent (see rule 726, âMerging with Permanentsâ). âAs . . . enters the battlefieldâ and âas . . . is turned face upâ abilities generate copiable effects if they set power and toughness, even if they also define other characteristics.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 613. Interaction of Continuous Effects : 613.2b
text: Layer 1b: Face-down spells and permanents have their characteristics modified as defined in rule 708.2.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 613. Interaction of Continuous Effects : 613.2c
text: After all rules and effects in layer 1 have been applied, the objectâs characteristics are its copiable values. (See rule 707.2.)

name: Comprehensive Rules: 613. Interaction of Continuous Effects : 613.3.
text: Within layers 2â6, apply effects from characteristic-defining abilities first (see rule 604.3), then all other effects in timestamp order (see rule 613.7). Note that dependency may alter the order in which effects are applied within a layer. (See rule 613.8.)

name: Comprehensive Rules: 613. Interaction of Continuous Effects : 613.4.
text: Within layer 7, apply effects in a series of sublayers in the order described below. Within each sublayer, apply effects in timestamp order. (See rule 613.7.) Note that dependency may alter the order in which effects are applied within a sublayer. (See rule 613.8.)

name: Comprehensive Rules: 613. Interaction of Continuous Effects : 613.4a
text: Layer 7a: Effects from characteristic-defining abilities that define power and/or toughness are applied. See rule 604.3.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 613. Interaction of Continuous Effects : 613.4b
text: Layer 7b: Effects that set power and/or toughness to a specific number or value are applied. Effects that refer to the base power and/or toughness of a creature apply in this layer.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 613. Interaction of Continuous Effects : 613.4c
text: Layer 7c: Effects and counters that modify power and/or toughness (but donât set power and/or toughness to a specific number or value) are applied.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 613. Interaction of Continuous Effects : 613.4d
text: Layer 7d: Effects that switch a creatureâs power and toughness are applied. Such effects take the value of power and apply it to the creatureâs toughness, and take the value of toughness and apply it to the creatureâs power.

name: Example for Rule : 613.4d
text: A 1/3 creature is given +0/+1 by an effect. Then another effect switches the creatureâs power and toughness. Its new power and toughness is 4/1. A new effect gives the creature +5/+0. Its âunswitchedâ power and toughness would be 6/4, so its actual power and toughness is 4/6.

name: Example for Rule : 613.4d
text: A 1/3 creature is given +0/+1 by an effect. Then another effect switches the creatureâs power and toughness. Its new power and toughness is 4/1. If the +0/+1 effect ends before the switch effect ends, the creature becomes 3/1.

name: Example for Rule : 613.4d
text: A 1/3 creature is given +0/+1 by an effect. Then another effect switches the creatureâs power and toughness. Then another effect switches its power and toughness again. The two switches essentially cancel each other, and the creature becomes 1/4.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 613. Interaction of Continuous Effects : 613.5.
text: The application of continuous effects as described by the layer system is continually and automatically performed by the game. All resulting changes to an objectâs characteristics are instantaneous.

name: Example for Rule : 613.5.
text: Honor of the Pure is an enchantment that reads âWhite creatures you control get +1/+1.â Honor of the Pure and a 2/2 black creature are on the battlefield under your control. If an effect then turns the creature white (layer 5), it gets +1/+1 from Honor of the Pure (layer 7c), becoming 3/3. If the creatureâs color is later changed to red (layer 5), Honor of the Pureâs effect stops applying to it, and it will return to being 2/2.

name: Example for Rule : 613.5.
text: Gray Ogre, a 2/2 creature, is on the battlefield. An effect puts a +1/+1 counter on it (layer 7c), making it 3/3. A spell targeting it that says âTarget creature gets +4/+4 until end of turnâ resolves (layer 7c), making it 7/7. An enchantment that says âCreatures you control get +0/+2â enters the battlefield (layer 7c), making it 7/9. An effect that says âTarget creature becomes 0/1 until end of turnâ is applied to it (layer 7b), making it 5/8 (0/1, with +4/+4 from the resolved spell, +0/+2 from the enchantment, and +1/+1 from the counter).

name: Comprehensive Rules: 613. Interaction of Continuous Effects : 613.6.
text: If an effect should be applied in different layers and/or sublayers, the parts of the effect each apply in their appropriate ones. If an effect starts to apply in one layer and/or sublayer, it will continue to be applied to the same set of objects in each other applicable layer and/or sublayer, even if the ability generating the effect is removed during this process.

name: Example for Rule : 613.6.
text: An effect that reads âWild Mongrel gets +1/+1 and becomes the color of your choice until end of turnâ is both a power- and toughness-changing effect and a color-changing effect. The âbecomes the color of your choiceâ part is applied in layer 5, and then the âgets +1/+1â part is applied in layer 7c.

name: Example for Rule : 613.6.
text: Act of Treason has an effect that reads âGain control of target creature until end of turn. Untap that creature. It gains haste until end of turn.â This is both a control-changing effect and an effect that adds an ability to an object. The âgain controlâ part is applied in layer 2, and then the âit gains hasteâ part is applied in layer 6.

name: Example for Rule : 613.6.
text: An effect that reads âAll noncreature artifacts become 2/2 artifact creatures until end of turnâ is both a type-changing effect and a power- and toughness-setting effect. The type-changing effect is applied to all noncreature artifacts in layer 4 and the power- and toughness-setting effect is applied to those same permanents in layer 7b, even though those permanents arenât noncreature artifacts by then.

name: Example for Rule : 613.6.
text: Svogthos, the Restless Tomb, is on the battlefield. An effect that says âUntil end of turn, target land becomes a 3/3 creature thatâs still a landâ is applied to it (layers 4 and 7b). An effect that says âTarget creature gets +1/+1 until end of turnâ is applied to it (layer 7c), making it a 4/4 land creature. Then while you have ten creature cards in your graveyard, you activate Svogthosâs ability: âUntil end of turn, Svogthos, the Restless Tomb becomes a black and green Plant Zombie creature with âThis creatureâs power and toughness are each equal to the number of creature cards in your graveyard.â Itâs still a land.â (layers 4, 5, and 7b). It becomes an 11/11 land creature. If a creature card enters or leaves your graveyard, Svogthosâs power and toughness will be modified accordingly. If the first effect is applied to it again, it will become a 4/4 land creature again.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 613. Interaction of Continuous Effects : 613.7.
text: Within a layer or sublayer, determining which order effects are applied in is usually done using a timestamp system. An effect with an earlier timestamp is applied before an effect with a later timestamp.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 613. Interaction of Continuous Effects : 613.7a
text: A continuous effect generated by a static ability has the same timestamp as the object the static ability is on, or the timestamp of the effect that created the ability, whichever is later. If the effect that created the ability has the later timestamp and the object the ability is on receives a new timestamp, each continuous effect generated by static abilities of that object receives a new timestamp as well, but the relative order of those timestamps remains the same.

name: Example for Rule : 613.7a
text: Rune of Flight is an Aura that grants enchanted Equipment âEquipped creature has flying.â A player attaches Rune of Flight to Colossus Hammer, an Equipment with âEquipped creature gets +10/+10 and loses flying.â The ability granted by Rune of Flight shares Rune of Flightâs timestamp because it is later than Colossus Hammerâs timestamp. If Colossus Hammer becomes attached to a creature, both of its abilities receive new timestamps (see rule 613.7e), but the relative order of those timestamps remains the same.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 613. Interaction of Continuous Effects : 613.7b
text: A continuous effect generated by the resolution of a spell or ability receives a timestamp at the time itâs created.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 613. Interaction of Continuous Effects : 613.7c
text: Each counter receives a timestamp as itâs put on an object or player. If that object or player already has a counter of that kind on it, each counter of that kind receives a new timestamp identical to that of the new counter.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 613. Interaction of Continuous Effects : 613.7d
text: An object receives a timestamp at the time it enters a zone.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 613. Interaction of Continuous Effects : 613.7e
text: An Aura, Equipment, or Fortification receives a new timestamp each time it becomes attached to an object or player.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 613. Interaction of Continuous Effects : 613.7f
text: A permanent receives a new timestamp each time it turns face up or face down.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 613. Interaction of Continuous Effects : 613.7g
text: A transforming double-faced permanent receives a new timestamp each time it transforms or converts.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 613. Interaction of Continuous Effects : 613.7h
text: A face-up plane card, phenomenon card, or scheme card receives a timestamp at the time itâs turned face up.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 613. Interaction of Continuous Effects : 613.7i
text: A face-up vanguard card receives a timestamp at the beginning of the game.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 613. Interaction of Continuous Effects : 613.7j
text: A conspiracy card receives a timestamp at the beginning of the game. If itâs face down, it receives a new timestamp at the time it turns face up.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 613. Interaction of Continuous Effects : 613.7k
text: A sticker receives a new timestamp each time itâs put on an object. If the object a sticker is on receives a new timestamp, the sticker receives a new timestamp immediately after that one. If the object a sticker is on becomes part of a merged permanent on the battlefield, the sticker receives a new timestamp at that time. If an object has more than one sticker on it as it enters a zone or becomes part of a merged permanent, the relative timestamp order of those stickers remains unchanged.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 613. Interaction of Continuous Effects : 613.7m
text: If two or more objects would receive a timestamp simultaneously, such as by entering a zone simultaneously or becoming attached simultaneously, their relative timestamps are determined in APNAP order (see rule 101.4). Objects controlled by the active player (or owned by the active player, if they have no controller) have an earlier relative timestamp in the order of that playerâs choice, followed by each other player in turn order.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 613. Interaction of Continuous Effects : 613.8.
text: Within a layer or sublayer, determining which order effects are applied in is sometimes done using a dependency system. If a dependency exists, it will override the timestamp system.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 613. Interaction of Continuous Effects : 613.8a
text: An effect is said to âdepend onâ another if (a) itâs applied in the same layer (and, if applicable, sublayer) as the other effect; (b) applying the other would change the text or the existence of the first effect, what it applies to, or what it does to any of the things it applies to; and (c) neither effect is from a characteristic-defining ability or both effects are from characteristic-defining abilities. Otherwise, the effect is considered to be independent of the other effect.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 613. Interaction of Continuous Effects : 613.8b
text: An effect dependent on one or more other effects waits to apply until just after all of those effects have been applied. If multiple dependent effects would apply simultaneously in this way, theyâre applied in timestamp order relative to each other. If several dependent effects form a dependency loop, then this rule is ignored and the effects in the dependency loop are applied in timestamp order.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 613. Interaction of Continuous Effects : 613.8c
text: After each effect is applied, the order of remaining effects is reevaluated and may change if an effect that has not yet been applied becomes dependent on or independent of one or more other effects that have not yet been applied.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 613. Interaction of Continuous Effects : 613.9.
text: One continuous effect can override another. Sometimes the results of one effect determine whether another effect applies or what another effect does.

name: Example for Rule : 613.9.
text: Two effects are affecting the same creature: one from an Aura that says âEnchanted creature has flyingâ and one from an Aura that says âEnchanted creature loses flying.â Neither of these depends on the other, since nothing changes what they affect or what theyâre doing to it. Applying them in timestamp order means the one that was generated last âwins.â The same process would be followed, and the same result reached, if either of the effects had a duration (such as âTarget creature loses flying until end of turnâ) or came from a non-Aura source (such as âAll creatures lose flyingâ).

name: Example for Rule : 613.9.
text: One effect reads, âWhite creatures get +1/+1,â and another reads, âEnchanted creature is white.â The enchanted creature gets +1/+1 from the first effect, regardless of its previous color.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 613. Interaction of Continuous Effects : 613.10.
text: Some continuous effects affect players rather than objects. For example, an effect might give a player protection from red. All such effects are applied in timestamp order after the determination of objectsâ characteristics. See also the rules for timestamp order and dependency (rules 613.7 and 613.8).

name: Comprehensive Rules: 613. Interaction of Continuous Effects : 613.11.
text: Some continuous effects affect game rules rather than objects. For example, effects may modify a playerâs maximum hand size, or say that a creature must attack this turn if able. These effects are applied after all other continuous effects have been applied. Continuous effects that affect the costs of spells or abilities are applied according to the order specified in rule 601.2f. All other such effects are applied in timestamp order. See also the rules for timestamp order and dependency (rules 613.7 and 613.8).

name: Comprehensive Rules: 614. Replacement Effects : 614.1.
text: Some continuous effects are replacement effects. Like prevention effects (see rule 615), replacement effects apply continuously as events happenâthey arenât locked in ahead of time. Such effects watch for a particular event that would happen and completely or partially replace that event with a different event. They act like âshieldsâ around whatever theyâre affecting.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 614. Replacement Effects : 614.1a
text: Effects that use the word âinsteadâ are replacement effects. Most replacement effects use the word âinsteadâ to indicate what events will be replaced with other events.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 614. Replacement Effects : 614.1b
text: Effects that use the word âskipâ are replacement effects. These replacement effects use the word âskipâ to indicate what events, steps, phases, or turns will be replaced with nothing.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 614. Replacement Effects : 614.1c
text: Effects that read â[This permanent] enters the battlefield with . . . ,â âAs [this permanent] enters the battlefield . . . ,â or â[This permanent] enters the battlefield as . . . â are replacement effects.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 614. Replacement Effects : 614.1d
text: Continuous effects that read â[This permanent] enters the battlefield . . .â or â[Objects] enter the battlefield . . .â are replacement effects.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 614. Replacement Effects : 614.1e
text: Effects that read âAs [this permanent] is turned face up . . . ,â are replacement effects.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 614. Replacement Effects : 614.2.
text: Some replacement effects apply to damage from a source. See rule 609.7.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 614. Replacement Effects : 614.3.
text: There are no special restrictions on casting a spell or activating an ability that generates a replacement effect. Such effects last until theyâre used up or their duration has expired.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 614. Replacement Effects : 614.4.
text: Replacement effects must exist before the appropriate event occursâthey canât âgo back in timeâ and change something thatâs already happened. Spells or abilities that generate these effects are often cast or activated in response to whatever would produce the event and thus resolve before that event would occur.

name: Example for Rule : 614.4.
text: A player can activate an ability to regenerate a creature in response to a spell that would destroy it. Once the spell resolves, though, itâs too late to regenerate the creature.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 614. Replacement Effects : 614.5.
text: A replacement effect doesnât invoke itself repeatedly; it gets only one opportunity to affect an event or any modified events that may replace that event.

name: Example for Rule : 614.5.
text: A player controls two permanents, each with an ability that reads âIf a creature you control would deal damage to a permanent or player, it deals double that damage to that permanent or player instead.â A creature that normally deals 2 damage will deal 8 damageânot just 4, and not an infinite amount.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 614. Replacement Effects : 614.6.
text: If an event is replaced, it never happens. A modified event occurs instead, which may in turn trigger abilities. Note that the modified event may contain instructions that canât be carried out, in which case the impossible instruction is simply ignored.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 614. Replacement Effects : 614.7.
text: If a replacement effect would replace an event, but that event never happens, the replacement effect simply doesnât do anything.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 614. Replacement Effects : 614.7a
text: If a source would deal 0 damage, it does not deal damage at all. Replacement effects that would increase the damage dealt by that source, or would have that source deal that damage to a different object or player, have no event to replace, so they have no effect.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 614. Replacement Effects : 614.8.
text: Regeneration is a destruction-replacement effect. The word âinsteadâ doesnât appear on the card but is implicit in the definition of regeneration. âRegenerate [permanent]â means âThe next time [permanent] would be destroyed this turn, instead remove all damage marked on it and its controller taps it. If itâs an attacking or blocking creature, remove it from combat.â Abilities that trigger from damage being dealt still trigger even if the permanent regenerates. See rule 701.15.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 614. Replacement Effects : 614.9.
text: Some effects replace damage dealt to one battle, creature, planeswalker, or player with the same damage dealt to another battle, creature, planeswalker, or player; such effects are called redirection effects. If one of those permanents is no longer on the battlefield when the damage would be redirected, or is no longer a battle, creature, or planeswalker when the damage would be redirected, the effect does nothing. If damage would be redirected to or from a player who has left the game, the effect does nothing.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 614. Replacement Effects : 614.10.
text: An effect that causes a player to skip an event, step, phase, or turn is a replacement effect. âSkip [something]â is the same as âInstead of doing [something], do nothing.â Once a step, phase, or turn has started, it can no longer be skippedâany skip effects will wait until the next occurrence.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 614. Replacement Effects : 614.10a
text: Anything scheduled for a skipped step, phase, or turn wonât happen. Anything scheduled for the ânextâ occurrence of something waits for the first occurrence that isnât skipped. If two effects each cause a player to skip their next occurrence, that player must skip the next two; one effect will be satisfied in skipping the first occurrence, while the other will remain until another occurrence can be skipped.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 614. Replacement Effects : 614.10b
text: Some effects cause a player to skip a step, phase, or turn, then take another action. That action is considered to be the first thing that happens during the next step, phase, or turn to actually occur.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 614. Replacement Effects : 614.11.
text: Some effects replace card draws. These effects are applied even if no cards could be drawn because there are no cards in the affected playerâs library.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 614. Replacement Effects : 614.11a
text: If an effect replaces a draw within a sequence of card draws, all actions required by the replacement are completed, if possible, before resuming the sequence.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 614. Replacement Effects : 614.11b
text: If an effect would have a player both draw a card and perform an additional action on that card, and the draw is replaced, the additional action is not performed on any cards that are drawn as a result of that replacement effect.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 614. Replacement Effects : 614.12.
text: Some replacement effects modify how a permanent enters the battlefield. (See rules 614.1câd.) Such effects may come from the permanent itself if they affect only that permanent (as opposed to a general subset of permanents that includes it). They may also come from other sources. To determine which replacement effects apply and how they apply, check the characteristics of the permanent as it would exist on the battlefield, taking into account replacement effects that have already modified how it enters the battlefield (see rule 616.1), continuous effects from the permanentâs own static abilities that would apply to it once itâs on the battlefield, and continuous effects that already exist and would apply to the permanent.

name: Example for Rule : 614.12.
text: Voice of All says âAs Voice of All enters the battlefield, choose a colorâ and âVoice of All has protection from the chosen color.â An effect creates a token thatâs a copy of Voice of All. As that token is created, the tokenâs controller chooses a color for it.

name: Example for Rule : 614.12.
text: Yixlid Jailer says âCards in graveyards lose all abilities.â Scarwood Treefolk says âScarwood Treefolk enters the battlefield tapped.â A Scarwood Treefolk thatâs put onto the battlefield from a graveyard enters the battlefield tapped.

name: Example for Rule : 614.12.
text: Orb of Dreams is an artifact that says âPermanents enter the battlefield tapped.â It wonât affect itself, so Orb of Dreams enters the battlefield untapped.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 614. Replacement Effects : 614.12a
text: If a replacement effect that modifies how a permanent enters the battlefield requires a choice, that choice is made before the permanent enters the battlefield.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 614. Replacement Effects : 614.12b
text: Some replacement effects cause a permanent to enter the battlefield with its controllerâs choice of one of two abilities, each marked with an anchor word and preceded by a bullet point. â[Anchor word] â [ability]â means âAs long as [anchor word] was chosen as this permanent entered the battlefield, this permanent has [ability].â The abilities preceded by anchor words are each linked to the ability that causes a player to choose between them. See rule 607, âLinked Abilities.â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 614. Replacement Effects : 614.13.
text: An effect that modifies how a permanent enters the battlefield may cause other objects to change zones.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 614. Replacement Effects : 614.13a
text: While applying an effect that modifies how a permanent enters the battlefield, you may have to choose a number of objects that will also change zones. You canât choose the object that will become that permanent or any other object entering the battlefield at the same time as that object.

name: Example for Rule : 614.13a
text: Sutured Ghoul says, in part, âAs Sutured Ghoul enters the battlefield, exile any number of creature cards from your graveyard.â If Sutured Ghoul and Runeclaw Bear enter the battlefield from your graveyard at the same time, you canât choose to exile either of them when applying Sutured Ghoulâs replacement effect.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 614. Replacement Effects : 614.13b
text: The same object canât be chosen to change zones more than once when applying replacement effects that modify how a single permanent enters the battlefield.

name: Example for Rule : 614.13b
text: Jund (a plane card) says, âWhenever a player casts a black, red, or green creature spell, it gains devour 5.â A player controls Runeclaw Bear and casts Thunder-Thrash Elder, a red creature spell with devour 3. As Thunder-Thrash Elder enters the battlefield, its controller can choose to sacrifice Runeclaw Bear when applying the devour 3 effect or when applying the devour 5 effect, but not both. Thunder-Thrash Elder will enter the battlefield with zero, three, or five +1/+1 counters, depending on this choice.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 614. Replacement Effects : 614.13c
text: While applying a replacement effect that modifies how a permanent enters the battlefield, another replacement effect may cause a player to mill cards or exile cards from the top of a library. In that case, any card that is entering the battlefield from that library wonât be included in that effect, even though those cards are in the library as the effect is applied.

name: Example for Rule : 614.13c
text: Ashiok, Wicked Manipulator has an ability that reads âIf you would pay life while your library has at least that many cards in it, exile that many cards from the top of your library instead.â Breeding Pool is a land that reads, in part, âAs Breeding Pool enters the battlefield, you may pay 2 life.â If an effect allows a player to play Breeding Pool from the top of their library while they control Ashiok, and they choose to pay life as Breeding Pool enters, Ashiokâs replacement effect will ignore Breeding Pool, because it is entering the battlefield, and the next two cards will be exiled.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 614. Replacement Effects : 614.14.
text: An object may have one ability printed on it that generates a replacement effect which causes one or more cards to be exiled, and another ability that refers either to âthe exiled cardsâ or to cards âexiled with [this object].â These abilities are linked: the second refers only to cards in the exile zone that were put there as a direct result of the replacement event caused by the first. If another object gains a pair of linked abilities, the abilities will be similarly linked on that object. They canât be linked to any other ability, regardless of what other abilities the object may currently have or may have had in the past. See rule 607, âLinked Abilities.â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 614. Replacement Effects : 614.15.
text: Some replacement effects are not continuous effects. Rather, they are an effect of a resolving spell or ability that replace part or all of that spell or abilityâs own effect(s). Such effects are called self-replacement effects. The text creating a self-replacement effect is usually part of the ability whose effect is being replaced, but the text can be a separate ability, particularly when preceded by an ability word. When applying replacement effects to an event, self-replacement effects are applied before other replacement effects.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 614. Replacement Effects : 614.16.
text: Some replacement effects apply âif an effect would create one or more tokensâ or âif an effect would put one or more counters on a permanent.â These replacement effects apply if the effect of a resolving spell or ability creates a token or puts a counter on a permanent, and they also apply if another replacement or prevention effect does so, even if the original event being modified wasnât itself an effect.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 614. Replacement Effects : 614.17.
text: Some effects state that something canât happen. These effects arenât replacement effects, but follow similar rules.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 614. Replacement Effects : 614.17a
text: âCanâtâ effects must exist before the appropriate event occursâthey canât âgo back in timeâ and change something thatâs already happened.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 614. Replacement Effects : 614.17b
text: If an event canât happen, a player canât choose to pay a cost that includes that event.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 614. Replacement Effects : 614.17c
text: If an event canât happen, it can only be replaced by a self-replacement effect (see rule 614.15). Other replacement and/or prevention effects canât modify or replace it.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 614. Replacement Effects : 614.17d
text: Some âcanâtâ effects modify how a permanent enters the battlefield or whether it can enter the battlefield. Such effects may come from the permanent itself if they affect only that permanent (as opposed to a general subset of permanents that includes it). They may also come from other sources. To determine which âcanâtâ effects apply, check the characteristics of the permanent as it would exist on the battlefield, taking into account replacement effects that have already modified how it enters the battlefield (see rule 616.1), continuous effects from the permanentâs own static abilities that would apply to it once itâs on the battlefield, and continuous effects that already exist and would apply to the permanent.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 615. Prevention Effects : 615.1.
text: Some continuous effects are prevention effects. Like replacement effects (see rule 614), prevention effects apply continuously as events happenâthey arenât locked in ahead of time. Such effects watch for a damage event that would happen and completely or partially prevent the damage that would be dealt. They act like âshieldsâ around whatever theyâre affecting.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 615. Prevention Effects : 615.1a
text: Effects that use the word âpreventâ are prevention effects. Prevention effects use âpreventâ to indicate what damage will not be dealt.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 615. Prevention Effects : 615.2.
text: Many prevention effects apply to damage from a source. See rule 609.7.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 615. Prevention Effects : 615.3.
text: There are no special restrictions on casting a spell or activating an ability that generates a prevention effect. Such effects last until theyâre used up or their duration has expired.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 615. Prevention Effects : 615.4.
text: Prevention effects must exist before the appropriate damage event occursâthey canât âgo back in timeâ and change something thatâs already happened. Spells or abilities that generate these effects are often cast or activated in response to whatever would produce the event and thus resolve before that event would occur.

name: Example for Rule : 615.4.
text: A player can activate an ability that prevents damage in response to a spell that would deal damage. Once the spell resolves, though, itâs too late to prevent the damage.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 615. Prevention Effects : 615.5.
text: Some prevention effects also include an additional effect, which may refer to the amount of damage that was prevented. The prevention takes place at the time the original event would have happened; the rest of the effect takes place immediately afterward.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 615. Prevention Effects : 615.6.
text: If damage that would be dealt is prevented, it never happens. A modified event may occur instead, which may in turn trigger abilities. Note that the modified event may contain instructions that canât be carried out, in which case the impossible instruction is simply ignored.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 615. Prevention Effects : 615.7.
text: Some prevention effects generated by the resolution of a spell or ability refer to a specific amount of damageâfor example, âPrevent the next 3 damage that would be dealt to any target this turn.â These work like shields. Each 1 damage that would be dealt to the âshieldedâ permanent or player is prevented. Preventing 1 damage reduces the remaining shield by 1. If damage would be dealt to the shielded permanent or player by two or more applicable sources at the same time, the player or the controller of the permanent chooses which damage the shield prevents. Once the shield has been reduced to 0, any remaining damage is dealt normally. Such effects count only the amount of damage; the number of events or sources dealing it doesnât matter.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 615. Prevention Effects : 615.8.
text: Some prevention effects generated by the resolution of a spell or ability refer to the next time a specific source would deal damage. These effects prevent the next instance of damage from that source, regardless of how much damage that is. Once an instance of damage from that source has been prevented, any subsequent instances of damage that would be dealt by that source are dealt normally.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 615. Prevention Effects : 615.9.
text: Some effects generated by the resolution of a spell or ability prevent damage from a source of a playerâs choice with certain properties. When the source would deal damage, the shield rechecks the sourceâs properties. If the properties no longer match, the damage isnât prevented or replaced and the shield isnât used up. See rule 609.7b.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 615. Prevention Effects : 615.10.
text: Some prevention effects generated by static abilities refer to a specific amount of damageâfor example, âIf a source would deal damage to you, prevent 1 of that damage.â Such an effect prevents only the indicated amount of damage in any applicable damage event at any given time. It will apply separately to damage from other applicable events that would happen at the same time, or at a different time.

name: Example for Rule : 615.10.
text: Daunting Defender says âIf a source would deal damage to a Cleric creature you control, prevent 1 of that damage.â Pyroclasm says âPyroclasm deals 2 damage to each creature.â Pyroclasm will deal 1 damage to each Cleric creature controlled by Daunting Defenderâs controller. It will deal 2 damage to each other creature.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 615. Prevention Effects : 615.11.
text: Some prevention effects prevent the next N damage that would be dealt to each of a number of untargeted creatures. Such an effect creates a prevention shield for each applicable creature when the spell or ability that generates that effect resolves.

name: Example for Rule : 615.11.
text: Wojek Apothecary has an ability that says â{T}: Prevent the next 1 damage that would be dealt to target creature and each other creature that shares a color with it this turn.â When the ability resolves, it gives the target creature and each other creature on the battlefield that shares a color with it at that time a shield preventing the next 1 damage that would be dealt to it. Changing creaturesâ colors after the ability resolves doesnât add or remove shields, and creatures that enter the battlefield later in the turn donât get the shield.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 615. Prevention Effects : 615.12.
text: Some effects state that damage âcanât be prevented.â If unpreventable damage would be dealt, any applicable prevention effects are still applied to it. Those effects wonât prevent any damage, but any additional effects they have will take place. Existing damage prevention shields wonât be reduced by damage that canât be prevented.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 615. Prevention Effects : 615.12a
text: A prevention effect is applied to any particular unpreventable damage event just once. It wonât invoke itself repeatedly trying to prevent that damage.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 615. Prevention Effects : 615.13.
text: Some triggered abilities trigger when damage that would be dealt is prevented. Such an ability triggers each time a prevention effect is applied to one or more simultaneous damage events and prevents some or all of that damage.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 616. Interaction of Replacement and/or Prevention Effects : 616.1.
text: If two or more replacement and/or prevention effects are attempting to modify the way an event affects an object or player, the affected objectâs controller (or its owner if it has no controller) or the affected player chooses one to apply, following the steps listed below. If two or more players have to make these choices at the same time, choices are made in APNAP order (see rule 101.4).
url: https://blogs.magicjudges.org/rules/cr616. Interaction of Replacement and/or Prevention Effects/

metadata.chapter: 616. Interaction of Replacement and/or Prevention Effects

name: Comprehensive Rules: 616. Interaction of Replacement and/or Prevention Effects : 616.1a
text: If any of the replacement and/or prevention effects are self-replacement effects (see rule 614.15), one of them must be chosen. If not, proceed to rule 616.1b.
url: https://blogs.magicjudges.org/rules/cr616. Interaction of Replacement and/or Prevention Effects/

metadata.chapter: 616. Interaction of Replacement and/or Prevention Effects

name: Comprehensive Rules: 616. Interaction of Replacement and/or Prevention Effects : 616.1b
text: If any of the replacement and/or prevention effects would modify under whose control an object would enter the battlefield, one of them must be chosen. If not, proceed to rule 616.1c.
url: https://blogs.magicjudges.org/rules/cr616. Interaction of Replacement and/or Prevention Effects/

metadata.chapter: 616. Interaction of Replacement and/or Prevention Effects

name: Comprehensive Rules: 616. Interaction of Replacement and/or Prevention Effects : 616.1c
text: If any of the replacement and/or prevention effects would cause an object to become a copy of another object as it enters the battlefield, one of them must be chosen. If not, proceed to rule 616.1d.
url: https://blogs.magicjudges.org/rules/cr616. Interaction of Replacement and/or Prevention Effects/

metadata.chapter: 616. Interaction of Replacement and/or Prevention Effects

name: Comprehensive Rules: 616. Interaction of Replacement and/or Prevention Effects : 616.1d
text: If any of the replacement and/or prevention effects would cause a card to enter the battlefield with its back face up, one of them must be chosen (See rule 701.28, âTransform,â and rule 701.50, âConvert.â). If not, proceed to 616.1e.
url: https://blogs.magicjudges.org/rules/cr616. Interaction of Replacement and/or Prevention Effects/

metadata.chapter: 616. Interaction of Replacement and/or Prevention Effects

name: Comprehensive Rules: 616. Interaction of Replacement and/or Prevention Effects : 616.1e
text: Any of the applicable replacement and/or prevention effects may be chosen.
url: https://blogs.magicjudges.org/rules/cr616. Interaction of Replacement and/or Prevention Effects/

metadata.chapter: 616. Interaction of Replacement and/or Prevention Effects

name: Comprehensive Rules: 616. Interaction of Replacement and/or Prevention Effects : 616.1f
text: Once the chosen effect has been applied, this process is repeated (taking into account only replacement or prevention effects that would now be applicable) until there are no more left to apply.
url: https://blogs.magicjudges.org/rules/cr616. Interaction of Replacement and/or Prevention Effects/

metadata.chapter: 616. Interaction of Replacement and/or Prevention Effects

name: Example for Rule : 616.1f
text: Two permanents are on the battlefield. One is an enchantment that reads âIf a card would be put into a graveyard from anywhere, instead exile it,â and the other is a creature that reads âIf [this creature] would die, instead shuffle it into its ownerâs library.â If the creature is destroyed, its controller decides which replacement to apply first; the other does nothing.
url: https://blogs.magicjudges.org/rules/cr616. Interaction of Replacement and/or Prevention Effects/

metadata.chapter: 616. Interaction of Replacement and/or Prevention Effects

name: Example for Rule : 616.1f
text: Essence of the Wild reads âCreatures you control enter the battlefield as a copy of Essence of the Wild.â A player who controls Essence of the Wild casts Rusted Sentinel, which normally enters the battlefield tapped. As it enters the battlefield, the copy effect from Essence of the Wild is applied first. As a result, it no longer has the ability that causes it to enter the battlefield tapped. Rusted Sentinel will enter the battlefield as an untapped copy of Essence of the Wild.
url: https://blogs.magicjudges.org/rules/cr616. Interaction of Replacement and/or Prevention Effects/

metadata.chapter: 616. Interaction of Replacement and/or Prevention Effects

name: Comprehensive Rules: 616. Interaction of Replacement and/or Prevention Effects : 616.1g
text: While following the steps in 616.1aâf, one replacement or prevention effect may apply to an event, and another may apply to an event contained within the first event. In this case, the second effect canât be chosen until after the first effect has been chosen.
url: https://blogs.magicjudges.org/rules/cr616. Interaction of Replacement and/or Prevention Effects/

metadata.chapter: 616. Interaction of Replacement and/or Prevention Effects

name: Example for Rule : 616.1g
text: A player is instructed to create a token thatâs a copy of Voice of All, which has the ability âAs Voice of All enters the battlefield, choose a color.â Doubling Season has an ability that reads âIf an effect would create one or more tokens under your control, it creates twice that many of those tokens instead.â Because entering the battlefield is an event contained within the event of creating a token, the effect of Doubling Season must be applied first, and then the effects of the two Voice of All tokens may be applied in either order.
url: https://blogs.magicjudges.org/rules/cr616. Interaction of Replacement and/or Prevention Effects/

metadata.chapter: 616. Interaction of Replacement and/or Prevention Effects

name: Comprehensive Rules: 616. Interaction of Replacement and/or Prevention Effects : 616.2.
text: A replacement or prevention effect can become applicable to an event as the result of another replacement or prevention effect that modifies the event.
url: https://blogs.magicjudges.org/rules/cr616. Interaction of Replacement and/or Prevention Effects/

metadata.chapter: 616. Interaction of Replacement and/or Prevention Effects

name: Example for Rule : 616.2.
text:
One effect reads âIf you would gain life, draw that many cards instead,â and another reads âIf you would draw a card, return a card from your graveyard to your hand instead.â Both effects combine (regardless of the order they came into existence): Instead of gaining 1 life, the player puts a card from their graveyard into their hand.
