name: Comprehensive Rules: 700. General : 700.1.
text: Anything that happens in a game is an event. Multiple events may take place during the resolution of a spell or ability. The text of triggered abilities and replacement effects defines the event theyâre looking for. One âhappeningâ may be treated as a single event by one ability and as multiple events by another.

name: Example for Rule : 700.1.
text: If an attacking creature is blocked by two creatures, this is one event for a triggered ability that reads âWhenever [this creature] becomes blockedâ but two events for a triggered ability that reads âWhenever [this creature] becomes blocked by a creature.â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 700. General : 700.2.
text: A spell or ability is modal if it has two or more options in a bulleted list preceded by instructions for a player to choose a number of those options, such as âChoose one â.â Each of those options is a mode. Modal cards printed prior to the Khans of Tarkirâ¢ set didnât use bulleted lists for the modes; these cards have received errata in the Oracle card reference so the modes do appear in a bulleted list.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 700. General : 700.2a
text: The controller of a modal spell or activated ability chooses the mode(s) as part of casting that spell or activating that ability. If one of the modes would be illegal (due to an inability to choose legal targets, for example), that mode canât be chosen. (See rule 601.2b.)

name: Comprehensive Rules: 700. General : 700.2b
text: The controller of a modal triggered ability chooses the mode(s) as part of putting that ability on the stack. If one of the modes would be illegal (due to an inability to choose legal targets, for example), that mode canât be chosen. If no mode is chosen, the ability is removed from the stack. (See rule 603.3c.)

name: Comprehensive Rules: 700. General : 700.2c
text: If a spell or ability targets one or more targets only if a particular mode is chosen for it, its controller will need to choose those targets only if they chose that mode. Otherwise, the spell or ability is treated as though it did not have those targets. (See rule 601.2c.)

name: Comprehensive Rules: 700. General : 700.2d
text: If a player is allowed to choose more than one mode for a modal spell or ability, that player normally canât choose the same mode more than once. However, some modal spells include the instruction âYou may choose the same mode more than once.â If a particular mode is chosen multiple times, the spell is treated as if that mode appeared that many times in sequence. If that mode requires a target, the same player or object may be chosen as the target for each of those modes, or different targets may be chosen.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 700. General : 700.2e
text: Some spells and abilities specify that a player other than their controller chooses a mode for it. In that case, the other player does so when the spell or abilityâs controller normally would do so. If there is more than one other player who could make such a choice, the spell or abilityâs controller decides which of those players will make the choice.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 700. General : 700.2f
text: Modal spells and abilities may have different targeting requirements for each mode. Changing a spell or abilityâs target canât change its mode.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 700. General : 700.2g
text: A copy of a modal spell or ability copies the mode(s) chosen for it. The controller of the copy canât choose a different mode. (See rule 707.10.)

name: Comprehensive Rules: 700. General : 700.3.
text: Some effects cause objects to be temporarily grouped into piles.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 700. General : 700.3a
text: Each of the affected objects must be put into exactly one of those piles, unless the effect specifies otherwise.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 700. General : 700.3b
text: Each object in a pile is still an individual object. The pile is not an object.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 700. General : 700.3c
text: Objects grouped into piles donât leave the zone theyâre currently in. If cards in a graveyard are split into piles, the order of the graveyard must be maintained.

name: Example for Rule : 700.3c
text: Fact or Fiction reads, âReveal the top five cards of your library. An opponent separates those cards into two piles. Put one pile into your hand and the other into your graveyard.â While an opponent is separating the revealed cards into piles, theyâre still in their ownerâs library. They donât leave the library until theyâre put into their ownerâs hand or graveyard.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 700. General : 700.3d
text: A pile can contain zero or more objects.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 700. General : 700.4.
text: The term dies means âis put into a graveyard from the battlefield.â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 700. General : 700.5.
text: A playerâs devotion to [color] is equal to the number of mana symbols of that color among the mana costs of permanents that player controls. A playerâs devotion to [color 1] and [color 2] is equal to the number of mana symbols among the mana costs of permanents that player controls that are [color 1], [color 2], or both colors.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 700. General : 700.5a
text: A playerâs devotion to each color and combination of colors, taking into account any effects that modify devotion, is calculated after considering any copy, control, or text-changing effects but before any other effects that modify the characteristics of permanents. This is an exception to 613.10. See also rule 613, âInteraction of Continuous Effects.â

name: Example for Rule : 700.5a
text: Altar of the Pantheon is an artifact with no colored mana in its cost and an ability that says âYour devotion to each color and each combination of colors is increased by one.â Purphoros, God of the Forge is a permanent mana cost {3}{R} and an ability that says âAs long as your devotion to red is less than five, Purphoros isnât a creature.â If a player controls both of these permanents and another permanent that costs {R}{R}{R}, that playerâs devotion to red is calculated to be five before Purphorosâs type-changing effect is applied, and Purphoros is a creature.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 700. General : 700.6.
text: The term historic refers to an object that has the legendary supertype, the artifact card type, or the Saga subtype.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 700. General : 700.7.
text: If an ability uses a phrase such as âthis [something]â to identify an object, where [something] is a characteristic, it is referring to that particular object, even if it isnât the appropriate characteristic at the time.

name: Example for Rule : 700.7.
text: An ability reads âTarget creature gets +2/+2 until end of turn. Destroy that creature at the beginning of the next end step.â The ability will destroy the object it gave +2/+2 to even if that object isnât a creature at the beginning of the next end step.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 700. General : 700.8.
text: Some cards refer to a playerâs party. A playerâs party consists of up to one Cleric creature that player controls, up to one Rogue creature they control, up to one Warrior creature they control, and up to one Wizard creature they control.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 700. General : 700.8a
text: If a spell, ability, or effect needs to determine the number of creatures in a playerâs party, the calculation of that number is performed automatically by the game and results in a number between zero and four. Players donât declare which specific creatures they control are in their party for such an effect.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 700. General : 700.8b
text: If a creature has multiple creature types for which it could be the party member, it is counted as the party member for only one of those types. If there are different ways to count such a creature that results in different numbers of creatures in a playerâs party, it is counted in such a way to get the highest result.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 700. General : 700.8c
text: A player has a full party if there are four creatures in that playerâs party.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 700. General : 700.8d
text: One card, Stick Together, instructs players to choose a party from among creatures they control. To do so, for each of the creature types listed in rule 700.8, each player chooses up to one creature they control of that type.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 700. General : 700.9.
text: Some cards refer to modified creatures. A creature is modified if it has one or more counters on it (see rule 122), if it is equipped (see rule 301.5), or if it is enchanted by an Aura that is controlled by that creatureâs controller. (see rule 303.4). If an ability of a permanent checks to see whether that permanent is modified, the answer is always no if that permanent isnât a currently a creature.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 700. General : 700.10.
text: Some effects refer to a permanent âthat was activated this turn.â This means that the permanent was the source of an ability that was activated this turn, regardless of whether that permanent still has that activated ability or the player who activated it is still in the game.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 700. General : 700.11.
text: Some effects refer to whether a player has âdescended this turn.â This means that a permanent card has been put into that playerâs graveyard from anywhere this turn. âThe number of times [a player] descended this turnâ means âthe number of permanent cards put into [that playerâs] graveyard from anywhere this turn.â In both cases, no permanent cards put into the playerâs graveyard that turn are required to still be in that graveyard.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 701. Keyword Actions : 701.1.
text: Most actions described in a cardâs rules text use the standard English definitions of the verbs within, but some specialized verbs are used whose meanings may not be clear. These âkeywordsâ are game terms; sometimes reminder text summarizes their meanings.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 701. Keyword Actions Activate: 701.2a
text: To activate an activated ability is to put it onto the stack and pay its costs, so that it will eventually resolve and have its effect. Only an objectâs controller (or its owner, if it doesnât have a controller) can activate its activated ability unless the object specifically says otherwise. A player may activate an ability if they have priority. See rule 602, âActivating Activated Abilities.â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 701. Keyword Actions Attach: 701.3a
text: To attach an Aura, Equipment, or Fortification to an object or player means to take it from where it currently is and put it onto that object or player. If something is attached to a permanent on the battlefield, itâs customary to place it so that itâs physically touching the permanent. An Aura, Equipment, or Fortification canât be attached to an object or player it couldnât enchant, equip, or fortify, respectively.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 701. Keyword Actions Attach: 701.3b
text: If an effect tries to attach an Aura, Equipment, or Fortification to an object or player it canât be attached to, the Aura, Equipment, or Fortification doesnât move. If an effect tries to attach an Aura, Equipment, or Fortification to the object or player itâs already attached to, the effect does nothing. If an effect tries to attach an object that isnât an Aura, Equipment, or Fortification to another object or player, the effect does nothing and the first object doesnât move.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 701. Keyword Actions Attach: 701.3c
text: Attaching an Aura, Equipment, or Fortification on the battlefield to a different object or player causes the Aura, Equipment, or Fortification to receive a new timestamp.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 701. Keyword Actions Attach: 701.3d
text: To âunattachâ an Equipment from a creature means to move it away from that creature so the Equipment is on the battlefield but is not equipping anything. It should no longer be physically touching any creature. If an Aura, Equipment, or Fortification that was attached to an object or player ceases to be attached to it, that counts as âbecoming unattached [from that object or player]â; this includes if that Aura, Equipment, or Fortification leaves the battlefield, the object leaves the zone it was in, or that player leaves the game.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 701. Keyword Actions Cast: 701.4a
text: To cast a spell is to take it from the zone itâs in (usually the hand), put it on the stack, and pay its costs, so that it will eventually resolve and have its effect. A player may cast a spell if they have priority. See rule 601, âCasting Spells.â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 701. Keyword Actions Cast: 701.4b
text: To cast a card is to cast it as a spell.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 701. Keyword Actions Counter: 701.5a
text: To counter a spell or ability means to cancel it, removing it from the stack. It doesnât resolve and none of its effects occur. A countered spell is put into its ownerâs graveyard.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 701. Keyword Actions Counter: 701.5b
text: The player who cast a countered spell or activated a countered ability doesnât get a ârefundâ of any costs that were paid.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 701. Keyword Actions Create: 701.6a
text: To create one or more tokens with certain characteristics, put the specified number of tokens with the specified characteristics onto the battlefield.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 701. Keyword Actions Create: 701.6b
text: If a replacement effect applies to a token being created, that effect applies before considering any continuous effects that will modify the characteristics of that token. If a replacement effect applies to a token entering the battlefield, that effect applies after considering any continuous effects that will modify the characteristics of that token.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 701. Keyword Actions Create: 701.6c
text: Previously, an effect that created tokens instructed a player to âput [those tokens] onto the battlefield.â Cards that were printed with that text have received errata in the Oracle card reference so they now âcreateâ those tokens.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 701. Keyword Actions Destroy: 701.7a
text: To destroy a permanent, move it from the battlefield to its ownerâs graveyard.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 701. Keyword Actions Destroy: 701.7b
text: The only ways a permanent can be destroyed are as a result of an effect that uses the word âdestroyâ or as a result of the state-based actions that check for lethal damage (see rule 704.5g) or damage from a source with deathtouch (see rule 704.5h). If a permanent is put into its ownerâs graveyard for any other reason, it hasnât been âdestroyed.â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 701. Keyword Actions Destroy: 701.7c
text: A regeneration effect replaces a destruction event. See rule 701.15, âRegenerate.â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 701. Keyword Actions Discard: 701.8a
text: To discard a card, move it from its ownerâs hand to that playerâs graveyard.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 701. Keyword Actions Discard: 701.8b
text: By default, effects that cause a player to discard a card allow the affected player to choose which card to discard. Some effects, however, require a random discard or allow another player to choose which card is discarded.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 701. Keyword Actions Discard: 701.8c
text: If a card is discarded, but an effect causes it to be put into a hidden zone instead of into its ownerâs graveyard without being revealed, all values of that cardâs characteristics are considered to be undefined. If a card is discarded this way to pay a cost that specifies a characteristic about the discarded card, that cost payment is illegal; the game returns to the moment before the cost was paid (see rule 729, âHandling Illegal Actionsâ).

name: Comprehensive Rules: 701. Keyword Actions Double: 701.9a
text: Doubling a creatureâs power and/or toughness creates a continuous effect. This effect modifies that creatureâs power and/or toughness but doesnât set those characteristics to a specific value. See rule 613.4c.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 701. Keyword Actions Double: 701.9b
text: To double a creatureâs power, that creature gets +X/+0, where X is that creatureâs power as the spell or ability that doubles its power resolves. Similarly, an effect that doubles a creatureâs toughness gives it +0/+X, where X is that creatureâs toughness. Doubling a creatureâs power and toughness gives it +X/+Y, where X is its power and Y is its toughness.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 701. Keyword Actions Double: 701.9c
text: If a creatureâs power is less than 0 when itâs doubled, doubling that creatureâs power instead means that the creature gets -X/-0, where X is the difference between 0 and its power. Similarly, if its toughness is less than 0 when doubled, it gets -0/-X. If one characteristicâs value is negative but the other isnât when both are doubled, it gets -X/+Y or +X/-Y, as appropriate.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 701. Keyword Actions Double: 701.9d
text: To double a playerâs life total, the player gains or loses an amount of life such that their new life total is twice its current value.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 701. Keyword Actions Double: 701.9e
text: To double the number of a kind of counters on a player or permanent, give that player or permanent as many of those counters as that player or permanent already has.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 701. Keyword Actions Double: 701.9f
text: To double the amount of a type of mana in a playerâs mana pool, that player adds an amount of mana of that type equal to the amount they already have.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 701. Keyword Actions Exchange: 701.10a
text: A spell or ability may instruct players to exchange something (for example, life totals or control of two permanents) as part of its resolution. When such a spell or ability resolves, if the entire exchange canât be completed, no part of the exchange occurs.

name: Example for Rule Exchange: 701.10a
text: If a spell attempts to exchange control of two target creatures but one of those creatures is destroyed before the spell resolves, the spell does nothing to the other creature.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 701. Keyword Actions Exchange: 701.10b
text: When control of two permanents is exchanged, if those permanents are controlled by different players, each of those players simultaneously gains control of the permanent that was controlled by the other player. If, on the other hand, those permanents are controlled by the same player, the exchange effect does nothing.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 701. Keyword Actions Exchange: 701.10c
text: When life totals are exchanged, each player gains or loses the amount of life necessary to equal the other playerâs previous life total. Replacement effects may modify these gains and losses, and triggered abilities may trigger on them. A player who canât gain life canât be given a higher life total this way, and a player who canât lose life canât be given a lower life total this way (see rules 119.7â8).

name: Comprehensive Rules: 701. Keyword Actions Exchange: 701.10d
text: Some spells or abilities may instruct a player to exchange cards in one zone with cards in a different zone (for example, exiled cards and cards in a playerâs hand). These spells and abilities work the same as other âexchangeâ spells and abilities, except they can exchange the cards only if all the cards are owned by the same player, and they can exchange the cards even if one zone is empty.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 701. Keyword Actions Exchange: 701.10e
text: If a card in one zone is exchanged with a card in a different zone, and either of them is attached to an object, that card stops being attached to that object and the other card becomes attached to that object.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 701. Keyword Actions Exchange: 701.10f
text: If a spell or ability instructs a player to simply exchange two zones, and one of the zones is empty, the cards in the zones are still exchanged.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 701. Keyword Actions Exchange: 701.10g
text: A spell or ability may instruct a player to exchange two numerical values. In such an exchange, each value becomes equal to the previous value of the other. If either of those values is a life total, the affected player gains or loses the amount of life necessary to equal the other value. Replacement effects may modify this gain or loss, and triggered abilities may trigger on it. A player who canât gain life canât be given a higher life total this way, and a player who canât lose life canât be given a lower life total this way (see rules 119.7â8). If either of those values is a power or toughness, a continuous effect is created setting that power or toughness to the other value (see rule 613.4b). This rule does not apply to spells and abilities that switch a creatureâs power and toughness.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 701. Keyword Actions Exchange: 701.10h
text: One card (Exchange of Words) instructs a player to exchange the text boxes of two creatures. This creates a text-changing effect (see rule 612, âText-Changing Effectsâ). In such an exchange, the rules text of each permanent becomes the previous rules text of the other.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 701. Keyword Actions Exile: 701.11a
text: To exile an object, move it to the exile zone from wherever it is. See rule 406, âExile.â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 701. Keyword Actions Fight: 701.12a
text: A spell or ability may instruct a creature to fight another creature or it may instruct two creatures to fight each other. Each of those creatures deals damage equal to its power to the other creature.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 701. Keyword Actions Fight: 701.12b
text: If one or both creatures instructed to fight are no longer on the battlefield or are no longer creatures, neither of them fights or deals damage. If one or both creatures are illegal targets for a resolving spell or ability that instructs them to fight, neither of them fights or deals damage.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 701. Keyword Actions Fight: 701.12c
text: If a creature fights itself, it deals damage to itself equal to twice its power.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 701. Keyword Actions Fight: 701.12d
text: The damage dealt when a creature fights isnât combat damage.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 701. Keyword Actions Mill: 701.13a
text: For a player to mill a number of cards, that player puts that many cards from the top of their library into their graveyard.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 701. Keyword Actions Mill: 701.13b
text: A player canât mill a number of cards greater than the number of cards in their library. If given the choice to do so, they canât choose to take that action. If instructed to do so, they mill as many as possible. Similarly, the player canât pay a cost that includes milling a number of cards greater than the number of cards in their library.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 701. Keyword Actions Mill: 701.13c
text: An effect that refers to a milled card can find that card in the zone it moved to from the library, as long as that zone is a public zone.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 701. Keyword Actions Mill: 701.13d
text: If an ability checks information about a single milled card but more than one card was milled, that ability refers to each of the milled cards. If that ability asks for any information about the milled card, such as a characteristic or mana value, it gets multiple answers. If these answers are used to determine the value of a variable, the sum of the answers is used. If that ability performs any actions on âtheâ card, it performs that action on each milled card. If that ability performs any actions on âaâ card, the controller of the ability chooses which card is affected.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 701. Keyword Actions Play: 701.14a
text: To play a land means to put it onto the battlefield from the zone itâs in (usually the hand). A player may play a land if they have priority, itâs the main phase of their turn, the stack is empty, and they havenât played a land this turn. Playing a land is a special action (see rule 116), so it doesnât use the stack; it simply happens. Putting a land onto the battlefield as the result of a spell or ability isnât the same as playing a land. See rule 305, âLands.â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 701. Keyword Actions Play: 701.14b
text: To play a card means to play that card as a land or to cast that card as a spell, whichever is appropriate.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 701. Keyword Actions Play: 701.14c
text: Some effects instruct a player to âplayâ with a certain aspect of the game changed, such as âPlay with the top card of your library revealed.â âPlayâ in this sense means to play the Magic game.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 701. Keyword Actions Play: 701.14d
text: Previously, the action of casting a spell, or casting a card as a spell, was referred to on cards as âplayingâ that spell or that card. Cards that were printed with that text have received errata in the Oracle card reference so they now refer to âcastingâ that spell or that card.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 701. Keyword Actions Play: 701.14e
text: Previously, the action of using an activated ability was referred to on cards as âplayingâ that ability. Cards that were printed with that text have received errata in the Oracle card reference so they now refer to âactivatingâ that ability.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 701. Keyword Actions Regenerate: 701.15a
text: If the effect of a resolving spell or ability regenerates a permanent, it creates a replacement effect that protects the permanent the next time it would be destroyed this turn. In this case, âRegenerate [permanent]â means âThe next time [permanent] would be destroyed this turn, instead remove all damage marked on it and its controller taps it. If itâs an attacking or blocking creature, remove it from combat.â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 701. Keyword Actions Regenerate: 701.15b
text: If the effect of a static ability regenerates a permanent, it replaces destruction with an alternate effect each time that permanent would be destroyed. In this case, âRegenerate [permanent]â means âInstead remove all damage marked on [permanent] and its controller taps it. If itâs an attacking or blocking creature, remove it from combat.â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 701. Keyword Actions Regenerate: 701.15c
text: Neither activating an ability that creates a regeneration shield nor casting a spell that creates a regeneration shield is the same as regenerating a permanent. Effects that say that a permanent canât be regenerated donât preclude such abilities from being activated or such spells from being cast; rather, they cause regeneration shields to not be applied.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 701. Keyword Actions Reveal: 701.16a
text: To reveal a card, show that card to all players for a brief time. If an effect causes a card to be revealed, it remains revealed for as long as necessary to complete the parts of the effect that card is relevant to. If the cost to cast a spell or activate an ability includes revealing a card, the card remains revealed from the time the spell or ability is announced until the time it leaves the stack. If revealing a card causes a triggered ability to trigger, the card remains revealed until that triggered ability leaves the stack. If that ability isnât put onto the stack the next time a player would receive priority, the card ceases to be revealed.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 701. Keyword Actions Reveal: 701.16b
text: Revealing a card doesnât cause it to leave the zone itâs in.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 701. Keyword Actions Reveal: 701.16c
text: If cards in a playerâs library are shuffled or otherwise reordered, any revealed cards that are reordered stop being revealed and become new objects.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 701. Keyword Actions Reveal: 701.16d
text: Some effects instruct a player to look at one or more cards. Looking at a card follows the same rules as revealing a card, except that the card is shown only to the specified player.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 701. Keyword Actions Sacrifice: 701.17a
text: To sacrifice a permanent, its controller moves it from the battlefield directly to its ownerâs graveyard. A player canât sacrifice something that isnât a permanent, or something thatâs a permanent they donât control. Sacrificing a permanent doesnât destroy it, so regeneration or other effects that replace destruction canât affect this action.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 701. Keyword Actions Scry: 701.18a
text: To âscry Nâ means to look at the top N cards of your library, then put any number of them on the bottom of your library in any order and the rest on top of your library in any order.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 701. Keyword Actions Scry: 701.18b
text: If a player is instructed to scry 0, no scry event occurs. Abilities that trigger whenever a player scries wonât trigger.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 701. Keyword Actions Scry: 701.18c
text: If multiple players scry at once, each of those players looks at the top cards of their library at the same time. Those players decide in APNAP order (see rule 101.4) where to put those cards, then those cards move at the same time.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 701. Keyword Actions Scry: 701.18d
text: An ability that triggers whenever a player scries triggers after the process described in rule 701.18a is complete, even if some or all of those actions were impossible.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 701. Keyword Actions Search: 701.19a
text: To search for a card in a zone, look at all cards in that zone (even if itâs a hidden zone) and find a card that matches the given description.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 701. Keyword Actions Search: 701.19b
text: If a player is searching a hidden zone for cards with a stated quality, such as a card with a certain card type or color, that player isnât required to find some or all of those cards even if theyâre present in that zone.

name: Example for Rule Search: 701.19b
text: Splinter says âExile target artifact. Search its controllerâs graveyard, hand, and library for all cards with the same name as that artifact and exile them. Then that player shuffles their library.â A player casts Splinter targeting Howling Mine (an artifact). Howling Mineâs controller has another Howling Mine in her graveyard and two more in her library. Splinterâs controller must find the Howling Mine in the graveyard, but may choose to find zero, one, or two of the Howling Mines in the library.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 701. Keyword Actions Search: 701.19c
text: If a player is instructed to search a hidden zone for cards that match an undefined quality, that player may still search that zone but canât find any cards.

name: Example for Rule Search: 701.19c
text: Lobotomy says âTarget player reveals their hand, then you choose a card other than a basic land card from it. Search that playerâs graveyard, hand, and library for all cards with the same name as the chosen card and exile them. Then that player shuffles their library.â If the target player has no cards in their hand when Lobotomy resolves, the player who cast Lobotomy searches the specified zones but doesnât exile any cards.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 701. Keyword Actions Search: 701.19d
text: If a player is searching a hidden zone simply for a quantity of cards, such as âa cardâ or âthree cards,â that player must find that many cards (or as many as possible, if the zone doesnât contain enough cards).

name: Comprehensive Rules: 701. Keyword Actions Search: 701.19e
text: If the effect that contains the search instruction doesnât also contain instructions to reveal the found card(s), then theyâre not revealed.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 701. Keyword Actions Search: 701.19f
text: If searching a zone is replaced with searching a portion of that zone, any other instructions that refer to searching the zone still apply. Any abilities that trigger on a library being searched will trigger.

name: Example for Rule Search: 701.19f
text: Aven Mindcensor says, in part, âIf an opponent would search a library, that player searches the top four cards of that library instead.â Veteran Explorer says âWhen Veteran Explorer dies, each player may search their library for up to two basic land cards and put them onto the battlefield. Then each player who searched their library this way shuffles it.â An opponent who searched the top four cards of their library because of Veteran Explorerâs ability would shuffle the entire library.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 701. Keyword Actions Search: 701.19g
text: If an effect offers a player a choice to search a zone and take additional actions with the cards found, that player may choose to search even if the additional actions are illegal or impossible.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 701. Keyword Actions Search: 701.19h
text: An effect may instruct a player to search a library for one or more cards more than once before instructing a player to shuffle that library. This is the same as a single instruction for that player to search that library for all those cards. The player searches that library only once.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 701. Keyword Actions Search: 701.19i
text: If multiple players search at once, each of those players looks at the appropriate cards at the same time, then those players decide in APNAP order (see rule 101.4) which card to find.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 701. Keyword Actions Search: 701.19j
text: If an effect instructs a player to search outside the game for a card, that player may choose an appropriate card they own from outside the game.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 701. Keyword Actions Shuffle: 701.20a
text: To shuffle a library or a face-down pile of cards, randomize the cards within it so that no player knows their order.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 701. Keyword Actions Shuffle: 701.20b
text: Some effects cause a player to search a library for a card or cards, shuffle that library, then put some or all of the found cards into a different zone or in a certain position in that library. In such cases, the found cards arenât included in the shuffle, even though they remain in the library at that time. Rather, all the cards in that library except those are shuffled. Abilities that trigger when a library is shuffled will still trigger. See also rule 401, âLibrary.â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 701. Keyword Actions Shuffle: 701.20c
text: If an effect would cause a player to shuffle one or more specific objects into a library, that library is shuffled even if none of those objects are in the zone theyâre expected to be in or an effect causes all of those objects to be moved to another zone or remain in their current zone.

name: Example for Rule Shuffle: 701.20c
text: Guile says, in part, âWhen Guile is put into a graveyard from anywhere, shuffle it into its ownerâs library.â Itâs put into a graveyard and its ability triggers, then a player exiles it from that graveyard in response. When the ability resolves, the library is shuffled.

name: Example for Rule Shuffle: 701.20c
text: Black Sunâs Zenith says, in part, âShuffle Black Sunâs Zenith into its ownerâs library.â Black Sunâs Zenith is in a graveyard, has gained flashback (due to Recoup, perhaps), and is cast from that graveyard. Black Sunâs Zenith will be exiled, and its ownerâs library will be shuffled.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 701. Keyword Actions Shuffle: 701.20d
text: If an effect would cause a player to shuffle a set of objects into a library, that library is shuffled even if there are no objects in that set.

name: Example for Rule Shuffle: 701.20d
text: Loaming Shaman says âWhen Loaming Shaman enters the battlefield, target player shuffles any number of target cards from their graveyard into their library.â It enters the battlefield, its ability triggers, and no cards are targeted. When the ability resolves, the targeted player will still have to shuffle their library.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 701. Keyword Actions Shuffle: 701.20e
text: If an effect causes a player to shuffle a library containing zero or one cards, abilities that trigger when a library is shuffled will still trigger.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 701. Keyword Actions Shuffle: 701.20f
text: If two or more effects cause a library to be shuffled multiple times simultaneously, abilities that trigger when that library is shuffled will trigger that many times.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 701. Keyword Actions Shuffle: 701.20g
text: If an effect would cause a player to shuffle a library at the same time that an object would be put into a certain position in that library, the result is a shuffled library thatâs randomized except that the object is in the specified position.

name: Example for Rule Shuffle: 701.20g
text: Darksteel Colossus and Gravebane Zombie are put into a playerâs graveyard from the battlefield at the same time. Darksteel Colossus says in part âIf Darksteel Colossus would be put into a graveyard from anywhere, reveal Darksteel Colossus and shuffle it into its ownerâs library instead.â Gravebane Zombie says âIf Gravebane Zombie would die, put Gravebane Zombie on top of its ownerâs library instead.â The player shuffles Darksteel Colossus into their library and puts Gravebane Zombie on top of that library.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 701. Keyword Actions Tap and Untap: 701.21a
text: To tap a permanent, turn it sideways from an upright position. Only untapped permanents can be tapped.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 701. Keyword Actions Tap and Untap: 701.21b
text: To untap a permanent, rotate it back to the upright position from a sideways position. Only tapped permanents can be untapped.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 701. Keyword Actions Fateseal: 701.22a
text: To âfateseal Nâ means to look at the top N cards of an opponentâs library, then put any number of them on the bottom of that library in any order and the rest on top of that library in any order.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 701. Keyword Actions Clash: 701.23a
text: To clash, a player reveals the top card of their library. That player may then put that card on the bottom of their library.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 701. Keyword Actions Clash: 701.23b
text: âClash with an opponentâ means âChoose an opponent. You and that opponent each clash.â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 701. Keyword Actions Clash: 701.23c
text: Each clashing player reveals the top card of their library at the same time. Then those players decide in APNAP order (see rule 101.4) where to put those cards, then those cards move at the same time.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 701. Keyword Actions Clash: 701.23d
text: A player wins a clash if that player revealed a card with a higher mana value than all other cards revealed in that clash.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 701. Keyword Actions Planeswalk: 701.24a
text: A player may planeswalk only during a Planechase game. Only the planar controller may planeswalk. See rule 901, âPlanechase.â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 701. Keyword Actions Planeswalk: 701.24b
text: To planeswalk is to put each face-up plane card and phenomenon card on the bottom of its ownerâs planar deck face down, then move the top card of your planar deck off that planar deck and turn it face up.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 701. Keyword Actions Planeswalk: 701.24c
text: A player may planeswalk as the result of the âplaneswalking abilityâ (see rule 901.8), because the owner of a face-up plane card or phenomenon card leaves the game (see rule 901.10), or because a phenomenonâs triggered ability leaves the stack (see rule 704.6f). Abilities may also instruct a player to planeswalk.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 701. Keyword Actions Planeswalk: 701.24d
text: The plane card thatâs turned face up is the plane the player planeswalks to. The plane card thatâs turned face down or that leaves the game is the plane the player planeswalks away from. The same is true with respect to phenomena.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 701. Keyword Actions Set in Motion: 701.25a
text: Only a scheme card may be set in motion, and only during an Archenemy game. Only the archenemy may set a scheme card in motion. See rule 314, âSchemes,â and rule 904, âArchenemy.â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 701. Keyword Actions Set in Motion: 701.25b
text: To set a scheme in motion, move it off the top of your scheme deck if itâs on top of your scheme deck and turn it face up if it isnât face up. That scheme is considered to have been set in motion even if neither of these actions was performed on it.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 701. Keyword Actions Set in Motion: 701.25c
text: Schemes may only be set in motion one at a time. If a player is instructed to set multiple schemes in motion, that player sets a scheme in motion that many times.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 701. Keyword Actions Abandon: 701.26a
text: Only a face-up ongoing scheme card may be abandoned, and only during an Archenemy game. See rule 314, âSchemes,â and rule 904, âArchenemy.â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 701. Keyword Actions Abandon: 701.26b
text: To abandon a scheme, turn it face down and put it on the bottom of its ownerâs scheme deck.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 701. Keyword Actions Proliferate: 701.27a
text: To proliferate means to choose any number of permanents and/or players that have a counter, then give each one additional counter of each kind that permanent or player already has.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 701. Keyword Actions Proliferate: 701.27b
text: In a Two-Headed Giant game, poison counters are shared by the team. If more than one player on a team is chosen this way, only one of those players can be given an additional poison counter. The player who proliferates chooses which player that is. See rule 810, âTwo-Headed Giant Variant.â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 701. Keyword Actions Transform: 701.28a
text: To transform a permanent, turn it over so that its other face is up. Only transforming tokens and permanents represented by transforming double-faced cards can transform. (See rule 712, âDouble-Faced Cards.â)

name: Comprehensive Rules: 701. Keyword Actions Transform: 701.28b
text: Although transforming a permanent uses the same physical action as turning a permanent face up or face down, they are different game actions. Abilities that trigger when a permanent is turned face down wonât trigger when that permanent transforms, and so on.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 701. Keyword Actions Transform: 701.28c
text: If a spell or ability instructs a player to transform a permanent that isnât represented by a transforming token or a transforming double-faced card, nothing happens.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 701. Keyword Actions Transform: 701.28d

name: Comprehensive Rules: 701. Keyword Actions Transform: 701.28f
text: If an activated or triggered ability of a permanent that isnât a delayed triggered ability of that permanent tries to transform it, the permanent does so only if it hasnât transformed or converted since the ability was put onto the stack. If a delayed triggered ability of a permanent tries to transform that permanent, the permanent does so only if it hasnât transformed or converted since that delayed triggered ability was created. In both cases, if the permanent has already transformed or converted, an instruction to do either is ignored.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 701. Keyword Actions Transform: 701.28g
text: Some spells and abilities refer to a âtransformed permanent.â This phrase refers to a permanent on the battlefield with its back face up thatâs also a transforming double-faced card or a transforming token. A permanent with its front face up is never considered a transformed permanent, even if it had its back face up previously.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 701. Keyword Actions Vote: 701.32a
text: Some spells and abilities instruct players to vote for one choice from a list of options to determine some aspect of the effect of that spell or ability. To vote, each player, starting with a specified player and proceeding in turn order, chooses one of those choices.

text: To manifest a card, turn it face down. It becomes a 2/2 face-down creature card with no text, no name, no subtypes, and no mana cost. Put that card onto the battlefield face down. name: Comprehensive Rules: 701. Keyword Actions Manifest: 701.34c
text: If a card with morph is manifested, its controller may turn that card face up using either the procedure described in rule 702.37e to turn a face-down permanent with morph face up or the procedure described above to turn a manifested permanent face up.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 701. Keyword Actions Manifest: 701.34d
text: If a card with disguise is manifested, its controller may turn that card face up using either the procedure described in rule 702.168d to turn a face-down permanent with disguise face up or the procedure described above to turn a manifested permanent face up.

text: If an effect instructs a player to manifest a card and a rule or effect prohibits the face-down object from entering the battlefield, that card isnât manifested. Its characteristics remain unmodified and it remains in its previous zone. If it was face up, it remains face up.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 702. Keyword Abilities : 702.1.
text: Most abilities describe exactly what they do in the cardâs rules text. Some, though, are very common or would require too much space to define on the card. In these cases, the object lists only the name of the ability as a âkeywordâ; sometimes reminder text summarizes the game rule.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 702. Keyword Abilities : 702.1a
text: If an effect refers to a â[keyword ability] cost,â it refers only to the variable costs for that keyword.

name: Example for Rule : 702.1a
text: Varolz, the Scar-Striped has an ability that says âEach creature card in your graveyard has scavenge. The scavenge cost is equal to its mana cost.â A creature cardâs scavenge cost is an amount of mana equal to its mana cost, and the activation cost of the scavenge ability is that amount of mana plus âExile this card from your graveyard.â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 702. Keyword Abilities : 702.1b
text: An effect that grants an object a keyword ability may define a variable in that ability based on characteristics of that object or other information about the game state. For these abilities, the value of that variable is constantly reevaluated.

name: Example for Rule : 702.1b
text: Volcano Hellion has the ability âVolcano Hellion has echo {X}, where X is your life total.â If your life total is 10 when Volcano Hellionâs echo ability triggers but 5 when it resolves, the echo cost to pay is {5}.

name: Example for Rule : 702.1b
text: Fire//Ice is a split card whose halves have the mana costs {1}{R} and {1}{U}. Past in Flames reads âEach instant and sorcery card in your graveyard gains flashback until end of turn. The flashback cost is equal to its mana cost.â Fire//Ice has âFlashback {2}{U}{R}â while it is in your graveyard, but if you choose to cast Fire, the resulting spell has âFlashback {1}{R}.â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 702. Keyword Abilities : 702.1c
text: An effect may state that âthe same is true forâ a list of keyword abilities or similar. If one of those keyword abilities has variants or variables and the effect grants that keyword or counters of that keyword to one or more objects and/or players, it grants each appropriate variant and variable of that keyword.

name: Example for Rule : 702.1c
text: Concerted Effort is an enchantment that reads âAt the beginning of each upkeep, creatures you control gain flying until end of turn if a creature you control has flying. The same is true for fear, first strike, double strike, landwalk, protection, trample, and vigilance.â As that triggered ability resolves, each landwalk and protection ability from among creatures you control is granted to each creature you control.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 702. Keyword Abilities : 702.1d
text: An effect may refer to an object âwith [keyword ability]â or âthat has [keyword ability].â This means the same thing as an object âwith a [keyword ability] abilityâ or an object âthat has a [keyword ability] ability.â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 702. Keyword Abilities Deathtouch: 702.2a
text: Deathtouch is a static ability.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 702. Keyword Abilities Deathtouch: 702.2b
text: A creature with toughness greater than 0 thatâs been dealt damage by a source with deathtouch since the last time state-based actions were checked is destroyed as a state-based action. See rule 704.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 702. Keyword Abilities Deathtouch: 702.2c
text: Any nonzero amount of combat damage assigned to a creature by a source with deathtouch is considered to be lethal damage for the purposes of determining if a proposed combat damage assignment is valid, regardless of that creatureâs toughness. See rules 510.1câd.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 702. Keyword Abilities Deathtouch: 702.2d
text: The deathtouch rules function no matter what zone an object with deathtouch deals damage from.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 702. Keyword Abilities Deathtouch: 702.2e
text: If an object changes zones before an effect causes it to deal damage, its last known information is used to determine whether it had deathtouch.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 702. Keyword Abilities Deathtouch: 702.2f
text: Multiple instances of deathtouch on the same object are redundant.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 702. Keyword Abilities Defender: 702.3a
text: Defender is a static ability.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 702. Keyword Abilities Defender: 702.3b
text: A creature with defender canât attack.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 702. Keyword Abilities Defender: 702.3c
text: Multiple instances of defender on the same creature are redundant.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 702. Keyword Abilities Double Strike: 702.4a
text: Double strike is a static ability that modifies the rules for the combat damage step. (See rule 510, âCombat Damage Step.â)

name: Comprehensive Rules: 702. Keyword Abilities Double Strike: 702.4b
text: If at least one attacking or blocking creature has first strike (see rule 702.7) or double strike as the combat damage step begins, the only creatures that assign combat damage in that step are those with first strike or double strike. After that step, instead of proceeding to the end of combat step, the phase gets a second combat damage step. The only creatures that assign combat damage in that step are the remaining attackers and blockers that had neither first strike nor double strike as the first combat damage step began, as well as the remaining attackers and blockers that currently have double strike. After that step, the phase proceeds to the end of combat step.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 702. Keyword Abilities Double Strike: 702.4c
text: Removing double strike from a creature during the first combat damage step will stop it from assigning combat damage in the second combat damage step.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 702. Keyword Abilities Double Strike: 702.4d
text: Giving double strike to a creature with first strike after it has already dealt combat damage in the first combat damage step will allow the creature to assign combat damage in the second combat damage step.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 702. Keyword Abilities Double Strike: 702.4e
text: Multiple instances of double strike on the same creature are redundant.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 702. Keyword Abilities Enchant: 702.5a
text: Enchant is a static ability, written âEnchant [object or player].â The enchant ability restricts what an Aura spell can target and what an Aura can enchant.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 702. Keyword Abilities Enchant: 702.5b
text: For more information about Auras, see rule 303, âEnchantments.â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 702. Keyword Abilities Enchant: 702.5c
text: If an Aura has multiple instances of enchant, all of them apply. The Auraâs target must follow the restrictions from all the instances of enchant. The Aura can enchant only objects or players that match all of its enchant abilities.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 702. Keyword Abilities Enchant: 702.5d
text: Auras that can enchant a player can target and be attached to players. Such Auras canât target permanents and canât be attached to permanents.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 702. Keyword Abilities Equip: 702.6a
text: Equip is an activated ability of Equipment cards. âEquip [cost]â means â[Cost]: Attach this permanent to target creature you control. Activate only as a sorcery.â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 702. Keyword Abilities Equip: 702.6b
text: For more information about Equipment, see rule 301, âArtifacts.â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 702. Keyword Abilities Equip: 702.6c
text: Equip abilities may further restrict what creatures may be chosen as legal targets. Such restrictions usually appear in the form âEquip [quality]â or âEquip [quality] creature.â These equip abilities may legally target only a creature thatâs controlled by the player activating the ability and that has the chosen quality. Additional restrictions for an equip ability donât restrict what the Equipment may be attached to.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 702. Keyword Abilities Equip: 702.6d
text: If a permanent has multiple equip abilities, any of its equip abilities may be activated.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 702. Keyword Abilities Equip: 702.6e
text: âEquip planeswalkerâ is a variant of the equip ability. âEquip planeswalker [cost]â means â[Cost]: Attach this permanent to target planeswalker you control as though that planeswalker were a creature. Activate only as a sorcery.â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 702. Keyword Abilities First Strike: 702.7a
text: First strike is a static ability that modifies the rules for the combat damage step. (See rule 510, âCombat Damage Step.â)

name: Comprehensive Rules: 702. Keyword Abilities First Strike: 702.7b
text: If at least one attacking or blocking creature has first strike or double strike (see rule 702.4) as the combat damage step begins, the only creatures that assign combat damage in that step are those with first strike or double strike. After that step, instead of proceeding to the end of combat step, the phase gets a second combat damage step. The only creatures that assign combat damage in that step are the remaining attackers and blockers that had neither first strike nor double strike as the first combat damage step began, as well as the remaining attackers and blockers that currently have double strike. After that step, the phase proceeds to the end of combat step.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 702. Keyword Abilities First Strike: 702.7c
text: Giving first strike to a creature without it after combat damage has already been dealt in the first combat damage step wonât preclude that creature from assigning combat damage in the second combat damage step. Removing first strike from a creature after it has already dealt combat damage in the first combat damage step wonât allow it to also assign combat damage in the second combat damage step (unless the creature has double strike).

name: Comprehensive Rules: 702. Keyword Abilities First Strike: 702.7d
text: Multiple instances of first strike on the same creature are redundant.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 702. Keyword Abilities Flash: 702.8a
text: Flash is a static ability that functions in any zone from which you could play the card itâs on. âFlashâ means âYou may play this card any time you could cast an instant.â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 702. Keyword Abilities Flash: 702.8b
text: Multiple instances of flash on the same object are redundant.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 702. Keyword Abilities Flying: 702.9a
text: Flying is an evasion ability.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 702. Keyword Abilities Flying: 702.9b
text: A creature with flying canât be blocked except by creatures with flying and/or reach. A creature with flying can block a creature with or without flying. (See rule 509, âDeclare Blockers Step,â and rule 702.17, âReach.â)

name: Comprehensive Rules: 702. Keyword Abilities Flying: 702.9c
text: Multiple instances of flying on the same creature are redundant.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 702. Keyword Abilities Haste: 702.10a
text: Haste is a static ability.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 702. Keyword Abilities Haste: 702.10b
text: If a creature has haste, it can attack even if it hasnât been controlled by its controller continuously since their most recent turn began. (See rule 302.6.)

name: Comprehensive Rules: 702. Keyword Abilities Haste: 702.10c
text: If a creature has haste, its controller can activate its activated abilities whose cost includes the tap symbol or the untap symbol even if that creature hasnât been controlled by that player continuously since their most recent turn began. (See rule 302.6.)

name: Comprehensive Rules: 702. Keyword Abilities Haste: 702.10d
text: Multiple instances of haste on the same creature are redundant.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 702. Keyword Abilities Hexproof: 702.11a
text: Hexproof is a static ability.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 702. Keyword Abilities Hexproof: 702.11b
text: âHexproofâ on a permanent means âThis permanent canât be the target of spells or abilities your opponents control.â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 702. Keyword Abilities Hexproof: 702.11c
text: âHexproofâ on a player means âYou canât be the target of spells or abilities your opponents control.â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 702. Keyword Abilities Hexproof: 702.11d
text: âHexproof from [quality]â is a variant of the hexproof ability. âHexproof from [quality]â on a permanent means âThis permanent canât be the target of [quality] spells your opponents control or abilities your opponents control from [quality] sources.â A âhexproof from [quality]â ability is a hexproof ability.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 702. Keyword Abilities Hexproof: 702.11e
text: Any effect that causes an object to lose hexproof will cause an object to lose all âhexproof from [quality]â abilities. Any effect that allows a player to choose a creature with hexproof as a target as though it didnât have hexproof will allow a player to choose a creature with a âhexproof from [quality]â ability. Any effect that looks for a card with hexproof will find a card with a âhexproof from [quality]â ability.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 702. Keyword Abilities Hexproof: 702.11f
text: âHexproof from [quality A] and from [quality B]â is shorthand for âhexproof from [quality A]â and âhexproof from [quality B]â; it behaves as two separate hexproof abilities. If an effect causes an object with such an ability to lose hexproof from [quality A], for example, that object would still have hexproof from [quality B].

name: Comprehensive Rules: 702. Keyword Abilities Hexproof: 702.11g
text: Multiple instances of the same hexproof ability on the same permanent or player are redundant.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 702. Keyword Abilities Indestructible: 702.12a
text: Indestructible is a static ability.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 702. Keyword Abilities Indestructible: 702.12b
text: A permanent with indestructible canât be destroyed. Such permanents arenât destroyed by lethal damage, and they ignore the state-based action that checks for lethal damage (see rule 704.5g).

name: Comprehensive Rules: 702. Keyword Abilities Indestructible: 702.12c
text: Multiple instances of indestructible on the same permanent are redundant.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 702. Keyword Abilities Intimidate: 702.13a
text: Intimidate is an evasion ability.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 702. Keyword Abilities Intimidate: 702.13b
text: A creature with intimidate canât be blocked except by artifact creatures and/or creatures that share a color with it. (See rule 509, âDeclare Blockers Step.â)

name: Comprehensive Rules: 702. Keyword Abilities Intimidate: 702.13c
text: Multiple instances of intimidate on the same creature are redundant.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 702. Keyword Abilities Landwalk: 702.14a
text: Landwalk is a generic term that appears within an objectâs rules text as â[type]walk,â where [type] is usually a land type, but it can also be the card type land plus any combination of land types, card types, and/or supertypes.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 702. Keyword Abilities Landwalk: 702.14b
text: Landwalk is an evasion ability.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 702. Keyword Abilities Landwalk: 702.14c
text: A creature with landwalk canât be blocked as long as the defending player controls at least one land with the specified land type (as in âislandwalkâ), with the specified type or supertype (as in âartifact landwalkâ), without the specified type or supertype (as in ânonbasic landwalkâ), or with both the specified type or supertype and the specified subtype (as in âsnow swampwalkâ). (See rule 509, âDeclare Blockers Step.â)

name: Comprehensive Rules: 702. Keyword Abilities Landwalk: 702.14d
text: Landwalk abilities donât âcancelâ one another.

name: Example for Rule Landwalk: 702.14d
text: If a player controls a snow Forest, that player canât block an attacking creature with snow forestwalk even if they also control a creature with snow forestwalk.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 702. Keyword Abilities Landwalk: 702.14e
text: Multiple instances of the same kind of landwalk on the same creature are redundant.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 702. Keyword Abilities Lifelink: 702.15a
text: Lifelink is a static ability.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 702. Keyword Abilities Lifelink: 702.15b
text: Damage dealt by a source with lifelink causes that sourceâs controller, or its owner if it has no controller, to gain that much life (in addition to any other results that damage causes). See rule 120.3.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 702. Keyword Abilities Lifelink: 702.15c
text: If an object changes zones before an effect causes it to deal damage, its last known information is used to determine whether it had lifelink.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 702. Keyword Abilities Lifelink: 702.15d
text: The lifelink rules function no matter what zone an object with lifelink deals damage from.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 702. Keyword Abilities Lifelink: 702.15e
text: If multiple sources with lifelink deal damage at the same time, they cause separate life gain events (see rules 119.9â10).

name: Example for Rule Lifelink: 702.15e
text: A player controls Ajaniâs Pridemate, which reads âWhenever you gain life, put a +1/+1 counter on Ajaniâs Pridemate,â and two creatures with lifelink. The creatures with lifelink deal combat damage simultaneously. Ajaniâs Pridemateâs ability triggers twice.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 702. Keyword Abilities Lifelink: 702.15f
text: Multiple instances of lifelink on the same object are redundant.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 702. Keyword Abilities Protection: 702.16a
text: Protection is a static ability, written âProtection from [quality].â This quality is usually a color (as in âprotection from blackâ) but can be any characteristic value or information. If the quality happens to be a card name, it is treated as such only if the protection ability specifies that the quality is a name. If the quality is a card type, subtype, or supertype, the ability applies to sources that are permanents with that card type, subtype, or supertype and to any sources not on the battlefield that are of that card type, subtype, or supertype. This is an exception to rule 109.2.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 702. Keyword Abilities Protection: 702.16b
text: A permanent or player with protection canât be targeted by spells with the stated quality and canât be targeted by abilities from a source with the stated quality.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 702. Keyword Abilities Protection: 702.16c
text: A permanent or player with protection canât be enchanted by Auras that have the stated quality. Such Auras attached to the permanent or player with protection will be put into their ownersâ graveyards as a state-based action. (See rule 704, âState-Based Actions.â)

name: Comprehensive Rules: 702. Keyword Abilities Protection: 702.16d
text: A permanent with protection canât be equipped by Equipment that have the stated quality or fortified by Fortifications that have the stated quality. Such Equipment or Fortifications become unattached from that permanent as a state-based action, but remain on the battlefield. (See rule 704, âState-Based Actions.â)

name: Comprehensive Rules: 702. Keyword Abilities Protection: 702.16e
text: Any damage that would be dealt by sources that have the stated quality to a permanent or player with protection is prevented.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 702. Keyword Abilities Protection: 702.16f
text: Attacking creatures with protection canât be blocked by creatures that have the stated quality.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 702. Keyword Abilities Protection: 702.16g
text: âProtection from [quality A] and from [quality B]â is shorthand for âprotection from [quality A]â and âprotection from [quality B]â; it behaves as two separate protection abilities. If an effect causes an object with such an ability to lose protection from [quality A], for example, that object would still have protection from [quality B].

name: Comprehensive Rules: 702. Keyword Abilities Protection: 702.16h
text: âProtection from all [characteristic]â is shorthand for âprotection from [quality A],â âprotection from [quality B],â and so on for each possible quality the listed characteristic could have; it behaves as multiple separate protection abilities. If an effect causes an object with such an ability to lose protection from [quality A], for example, that object would still have protection from [quality B], [quality C], and so on.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 702. Keyword Abilities Protection: 702.16i
text: âProtection from each [set of characteristics, qualities, or players]â is shorthand for âprotection from [A],â âprotection from [B],â and so on for each characteristic, quality, or player in the set. It behaves as multiple separate protection abilities.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 702. Keyword Abilities Protection: 702.16j
text: âProtection from everythingâ is a variant of the protection ability. A permanent or player with protection from everything has protection from each object regardless of that objectâs characteristic values. Such a permanent or player canât be targeted by spells or abilities and canât be enchanted by Auras. Such a permanent canât be equipped by Equipment, fortified by Fortifications, or blocked by creatures. All damage that would be dealt to such a permanent or player is prevented.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 702. Keyword Abilities Protection: 702.16k
text: âProtection from [a player]â is a variant of the protection ability. A permanent or player with protection from a specific player has protection from each object that player controls and protection from each object that player owns not controlled by another player, regardless of that objectâs characteristic values. Such a permanent or player canât be targeted by spells or abilities the specified player controls and canât be enchanted by Auras that player controls. Such a permanent canât be equipped by Equipment that player controls, fortified by Fortifications that player controls, or blocked by creatures that player controls. All damage that would be dealt to such a permanent or player by sources controlled by the specified player or owned by that player but not controlled by another player is prevented.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 702. Keyword Abilities Protection: 702.16m
text: Multiple instances of protection from the same quality on the same permanent or player are redundant.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 702. Keyword Abilities Protection: 702.16n
text: Some Auras both give the enchanted creature protection from a quality and say âthis effect doesnât removeâ either that specific Aura or all Auras. This means that the specified Auras arenât put into their ownersâ graveyards as a state-based action. If the creature has other instances of protection from the same quality, those instances affect Auras as normal.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 702. Keyword Abilities Protection: 702.16p
text: One Aura (Benevolent Blessing) gives the enchanted creature protection from a quality and says the effect doesnât remove certain permanents that are âalready attached toâ that creature. This means that, when the protection effect starts to apply, any objects with the stated quality that are already attached to that creature (including the Aura giving that creature protection) will not be put into their ownersâ graveyards as a state-based action. Other permanents with the stated quality canât become attached to the creature. If the creature has other instances of protection from the same quality, those instances affect attached permanents as normal.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 702. Keyword Abilities Reach: 702.17a
text: Reach is a static ability.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 702. Keyword Abilities Reach: 702.17b
text: A creature with flying canât be blocked except by creatures with flying and/or reach. (See rule 509, âDeclare Blockers Step,â and rule 702.9, âFlying.â)

name: Comprehensive Rules: 702. Keyword Abilities Reach: 702.17c
text: Multiple instances of reach on the same creature are redundant.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 702. Keyword Abilities Shroud: 702.18a
text: Shroud is a static ability. âShroudâ means âThis permanent or player canât be the target of spells or abilities.â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 702. Keyword Abilities Shroud: 702.18b
text: Multiple instances of shroud on the same permanent or player are redundant.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 702. Keyword Abilities Trample: 702.19a
text: Trample is a static ability that modifies the rules for assigning an attacking creatureâs combat damage. The ability has no effect when a creature with trample is blocking or is dealing noncombat damage. (See rule 510, âCombat Damage Step.â)

name: Comprehensive Rules: 702. Keyword Abilities Trample: 702.19b
text: The controller of an attacking creature with trample first assigns damage to the creature(s) blocking it. Once all those blocking creatures are assigned lethal damage, any excess damage is assigned as its controller chooses among those blocking creatures and the player, planeswalker, or battle the creature is attacking. When checking for assigned lethal damage, take into account damage already marked on the creature and damage from other creatures thatâs being assigned during the same combat damage step, but not any abilities or effects that might change the amount of damage thatâs actually dealt. The attacking creatureâs controller need not assign lethal damage to all those blocking creatures but in that case canât assign any damage to the player or planeswalker itâs attacking.

name: Example for Rule Trample: 702.19b
text: A 2/2 creature that can block an additional creature blocks two attackers: a 1/1 with no abilities and a 3/3 with trample. The active player could assign 1 damage from the first attacker and 1 damage from the second to the blocking creature, and 2 damage to the defending player from the creature with trample.

name: Example for Rule Trample: 702.19b
text: A 6/6 green creature with trample is blocked by a 2/2 creature with protection from green. The attacking creatureâs controller must assign at least 2 damage to the blocker, even though that damage will be prevented by the blockerâs protection ability. The attacking creatureâs controller can divide the rest of the damage as they choose between the blocking creature and the defending player.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 702. Keyword Abilities Trample: 702.19c
text: Trample over planeswalkers is a variant of trample that modifies the rules for assigning combat damage to planeswalkers. The controller of a creature with trample over planeswalkers assigns that creatureâs combat damage as described in rule 702.19b, with one exception. If that creature is attacking a planeswalker, after lethal damage is assigned to all blocking creatures and damage at least equal to the loyalty of the planeswalker the creature is attacking is assigned to that planeswalker, further excess damage may be assigned as the attacking creatureâs controller chooses among those blocking creatures, that planeswalker, and that planeswalkerâs controller. When checking for assigned damage equal to a planeswalkerâs loyalty, take into account damage from other creatures thatâs being assigned during the same combat damage step, but not any abilities or effects that might change the amount of damage thatâs actually dealt.

name: Example for Rule Trample: 702.19c
text: A player controls a planeswalker with three loyalty counters that is being attacked by a 1/1 with no abilities and a 7/7 with trample over planeswalkers. The active player could assign 1 damage from the first attacker and 2 damage from the second to the planeswalker and 5 damage to the defending player from the creature with trample over planeswalkers.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 702. Keyword Abilities Trample: 702.19d
text: If an attacking creature with trample or trample over planeswalkers is blocked, but there are no creatures blocking it when damage is assigned, its damage is assigned to the defending player and/or planeswalker as though all blocking creatures have been assigned lethal damage.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 702. Keyword Abilities Trample: 702.19e
text: If a creature with trample over planeswalkers is attacking a planeswalker and that planeswalker is removed from combat, the creatureâs damage may be assigned to the defending player once all blocking creatures have been dealt lethal damage or, if there are no blocking creatures when damage is assigned, all its damage is assigned to the defending player. This is an exception to rule 506.4c, and it does not cause the creature to be attacking that player.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 702. Keyword Abilities Trample: 702.19f
text: If a creature without trample over planeswalkers is attacking a planeswalker, none of its combat damage can be assigned to the defending player, even if that planeswalker has been removed from combat or the damage the attacking creature could assign is greater than the planeswalkerâs loyalty.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 702. Keyword Abilities Trample: 702.19g
text: Multiple instances of trample on the same creature are redundant. Multiple instances of trample over planeswalkers on the same creature are redundant.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 702. Keyword Abilities Vigilance: 702.20a
text: Vigilance is a static ability that modifies the rules for the declare attackers step.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 702. Keyword Abilities Vigilance: 702.20b
text: Attacking doesnât cause creatures with vigilance to tap. (See rule 508, âDeclare Attackers Step.â)

name: Comprehensive Rules: 702. Keyword Abilities Vigilance: 702.20c
text: Multiple instances of vigilance on the same creature are redundant.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 702. Keyword Abilities Ward: 702.21a
text: Ward is a triggered ability. Ward [cost] means âWhenever this permanent becomes the target of a spell or ability an opponent controls, counter that spell or ability unless that player pays [cost].â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 702. Keyword Abilities Ward: 702.21b
text: Some ward abilities include an X in their cost and state what X is equal to. This value is determined at the time the ability resolves, not locked in as the ability triggers.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 702. Keyword Abilities Banding: 702.22a
text: Banding is a static ability that modifies the rules for combat.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 702. Keyword Abilities Banding: 702.22b
text: âBands with otherâ is a special form of banding. If an effect causes a permanent to lose banding, the permanent loses all âbands with otherâ abilities as well.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 702. Keyword Abilities Banding: 702.22c
text: As a player declares attackers, they may declare that one or more attacking creatures with banding and up to one attacking creature without banding (even if it has âbands with otherâ) are all in a âband.â They may also declare that one or more attacking [quality] creatures with âbands with other [quality]â and any number of other attacking [quality] creatures are all in a band. A player may declare as many attacking bands as they want, but each creature may be a member of only one of them. (Defending players canât declare bands but may use banding in a different way; see rule 702.22j.)

name: Comprehensive Rules: 702. Keyword Abilities Visit: 702.159b
text: Some Attractions instruct a player to âclaim the prize,â followed by a second paragraph that starts with the word âPrizeâ and a long dash. This text is part of its visit ability. To claim the prize of an Attraction, perform the actions listed after the long dash.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 702. Keyword Abilities Prototype: 702.160a
text: Prototype is a static ability that appears on prototype cards that have a secondary set of power, toughness, and mana cost characteristics. A player who casts a spell with prototype can choose to cast that card âprotoyped.â If they do, the alternative set of its power, toughness, and mana cost characteristics are used. See 718, âPrototype Cards.â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 702. Keyword Abilities Living Metal: 702.161a
text: Living metal is a keyword ability found on some Vehicles. âLiving metalâ means âDuring your turn, this permanent is an artifact creature in addition to its other types.â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 702. Keyword Abilities Living Metal: 702.162.
text: More Than Meets the Eye

name: Comprehensive Rules: 702. Keyword Abilities Living Metal: 702.162a
text: More Than Meets the Eye represents a static ability that functions in any zone from which the spell may be cast. âMore Than Meets the Eye [cost]â means âYou may cast this card converted by paying [cost] rather than its mana cost.â Casting a spell using its More Than Meets the Eye ability follows the rules for paying alternative costs (see 601.2b and 601.2fâh). See rule 701.50, âConvert.â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 702. Keyword Abilities For Mirrodin!: 702.163a
text: For Mirrodin! is a triggered ability. âFor Mirrodin!â means âWhen this Equipment enters the battlefield, create a 2/2 red Rebel creature token, then attach this Equipment to it.â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 702. Keyword Abilities Toxic: 702.164a
text: Toxic is a static ability. It is written âtoxic N,â where N is a number.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 702. Keyword Abilities Toxic: 702.164b
