text: Some rules and effects refer to a creatureâs âtotal toxic value.â A creatureâs total toxic value is the sum of all N values of toxic abilities that creature has.

name: Example for Rule Toxic: 702.164b
text: If a creature with toxic 2 gains toxic 1 due to another effect, its total toxic value is 3.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 702. Keyword Abilities Toxic: 702.164c
text: Combat damage dealt to a player by a creature with toxic causes that creatureâs controller to give the player a number of poison counters equal to that creatureâs total toxic value, in addition to the damageâs other results. See rule 120.3.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 702. Keyword Abilities Backup: 702.165a
text: Backup is a triggered ability. âBackup Nâ means âWhen this creature enters the battlefield, put N +1/+1 counters on target creature. If thatâs another creature, it also gains the non-backup abilities of this creature printed below this one until end of turn.â Cards with backup have one or more abilities printed after the backup ability. (Some cards with backup also have abilities printed before the backup ability.)

name: Comprehensive Rules: 702. Keyword Abilities Backup: 702.165b
text: If a permanent enters the battlefield as a copy of a permanent with a backup ability or a token is created that is a copy of that permanent, the order of abilities printed on it is maintained.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 702. Keyword Abilities Backup: 702.165c
text: Only abilities printed on the object with backup are granted by its backup ability. Any abilities gained by a permanent, whether due to a copy effect, an effect that grants an ability to a permanent, or an effect that creates a token with certain abilities, are not granted by a backup ability.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 702. Keyword Abilities Backup: 702.165d
text: The abilities that a backup ability grants are determined as the ability is put on the stack. They wonât change if the permanent with backup loses any abilities after the ability is put on the stack but before it resolves.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 702. Keyword Abilities Bargain: 702.166a
text: Bargain is a static ability that functions while the spell with bargain is on the stack. âBargainâ means âAs an additional cost to cast this spell, you may sacrifice an artifact, enchantment, or token.â Paying a spellâs bargain cost follows the rules for paying additional costs in rules 601.2b and 601.2fâh.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 702. Keyword Abilities Bargain: 702.166b
text: If a spellâs controller declares the intention to pay that spellâs bargain cost, that spell has been âbargained.â See rule 601.2b.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 702. Keyword Abilities Bargain: 702.166c
text: Objects with bargain have additional abilities that specify what happens if they were bargained. These abilities are linked to the bargain ability printed on that object: they can refer only to that specific bargain ability. See rule 607, âLinked Abilities.â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 702. Keyword Abilities Bargain: 702.166d
text: If part of a spellâs ability has its effect only if that spell was bargained and that part of the ability includes any targets, the spellâs controller chooses those targets only if that spell was bargained. Otherwise, the spell is cast as if it did not have those targets. See rule 601.2c.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 702. Keyword Abilities Craft: 702.167a
text: Craft represents an activated ability. It is written as âCraft with [materials] [cost],â where [materials] is a description of one or more objects. It means â[Cost], Exile this permanent, Exile [materials] from among permanents you control and/or cards in your graveyard: Return this card to the battlefield transformed under its ownerâs control. Activate only as a sorcery.â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 702. Keyword Abilities Craft: 702.167b
text: If an object in the [materials] of a craft ability is described using only a card type or subtype without the word âcard,â it refers to either a permanent on the battlefield that is that type or subtype or a card in a graveyard that is that type or subtype. This is an exception to rule 109.2.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 702. Keyword Abilities Craft: 702.167c
text: An ability of a permanent may refer to the exiled cards used to craft it. This refers to cards in exile that were exiled to pay the activation cost of the craft ability that put this permanent onto the battlefield.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 702. Keyword Abilities Disguise: 702.168a
text: Disguise is a static ability that functions in any zone from which you could play the card itâs on, and the disguise effect works any time the card is face down. âDisguise [cost]â means âYou may cast this card as a 2/2 face-down creature with ward {2}, no name, no subtypes, and no mana cost by paying {3} rather than paying its mana cost.â (See rule 708, âFace-Down Spells and Permanents.â)

name: Comprehensive Rules: 702. Keyword Abilities Disguise: 702.168b
text: To cast a card using its disguise ability, turn the card face down and announce that you are using a disguise ability. It becomes a 2/2 face-down creature card with ward {2}, no name, no subtypes, and no mana cost. Any effects or prohibitions that would apply to casting a card with these characteristics (and not the face-up cardâs characteristics) are applied to casting this card. These values are the copiable values of that objectâs characteristics. (See rule 613, âInteraction of Continuous Effects,â and rule 707, âCopying Objects.â) Put it onto the stack (as a face-down spell with the same characteristics), and pay {3} rather than pay its mana cost. This follows the rules for paying alternative costs. You can use a disguise ability to cast a card from any zone from which you could normally cast it. When the spell resolves, it enters the battlefield with the same characteristics the spell had. The disguise effect applies to the face-down object wherever it is, and it ends when the permanent is turned face up.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 702. Keyword Abilities Disguise: 702.168c
text: You canât normally cast a card face down. A disguise ability allows you to do so.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 702. Keyword Abilities Disguise: 702.168d
text: Any time you have priority, you may turn a face-down permanent you control with a disguise ability face up. This is a special action; it doesnât use the stack (see rule 116). To do this, show all players what the permanentâs disguise cost would be if it were face up, pay that cost, then turn the permanent face up. (If the permanent wouldnât have a disguise cost if it were face up, it canât be turned face up this way.) The disguise effect on it ends, and it regains its normal characteristics. Any abilities relating to the permanent entering the battlefield donât trigger when itâs turned face up and donât have any effect, because the permanent has already entered the battlefield.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 702. Keyword Abilities Disguise: 702.168e
text: If a permanentâs disguise cost includes X, other abilities of that permanent may also refer to X. The value of X in those abilities is equal to the value of X chosen as the disguise special action was taken.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 702. Keyword Abilities Disguise: 702.168f
text: See rule 708, âFace-Down Spells and Permanents,â for more information about how to cast cards with a disguise ability.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 702. Keyword Abilities Solved: 702.169a
text: Solved is a keyword ability found on Case cards. See rule 719, âCase Cards.â âSolvedâ is followed by ability text. Together, they represent a static ability, a triggered ability, or an activated ability.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 702. Keyword Abilities Solved: 702.169b
text: For a static ability, âSolved â [Ability text]â means âAs long as this Case is solved, [ability text].â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 702. Keyword Abilities Solved: 702.169c
text: For a triggered ability, âSolved â [Ability text]â means â[Ability text]. This ability triggers only if this Case is solved.â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 702. Keyword Abilities Solved: 702.169d
text: For an activated ability, âSolved â [Ability text]â means â[Ability text]. Activate only if this Case is solved.â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 703. Turn-Based Actions : 703.1.
text: Turn-based actions are game actions that happen automatically when certain steps or phases begin, or when each step and phase ends. Turn-based actions donât use the stack.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 703. Turn-Based Actions : 703.1a
text: Abilities that watch for a specified step or phase to begin are triggered abilities, not turn-based actions. (See rule 603, âHandling Triggered Abilities.â)

name: Comprehensive Rules: 703. Turn-Based Actions : 703.2.
text: Turn-based actions are not controlled by any player.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 703. Turn-Based Actions : 703.3.
text: Whenever a step or phase begins, if itâs a step or phase that has any turn-based action associated with it, those turn-based actions are automatically dealt with first. This happens before state-based actions are checked, before triggered abilities are put on the stack, and before players receive priority.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 703. Turn-Based Actions : 703.4.
text: The turn-based actions are as follows:

name: Comprehensive Rules: 703. Turn-Based Actions : 703.4a
text: Immediately after the untap step begins, all phased-in permanents with phasing that the active player controls phase out, and all phased-out permanents that the active player controlled when they phased out phase in. This all happens simultaneously. See rule 502.1.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 703. Turn-Based Actions : 703.4b
text: Immediately after the phasing action has been completed during the untap step, if the game has either the day or night designation, it checks to see whether that designation should change. If itâs neither day nor night, this check doesnât happen. See rule 502.2.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 703. Turn-Based Actions : 703.4c
text: Immediately after the game checks to see if its day or night designation should change during the untap step or, if the game doesnât have a day or night designation, immediately after the phasing action has been completed during the untap step, the active player determines which permanents they control will untap. Then they untap them all simultaneously. See rule 502.3.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 703. Turn-Based Actions : 703.4d
text: Immediately after the draw step begins, the active player draws a card. See rule 504.1.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 703. Turn-Based Actions : 703.4e
text: In an Archenemy game (see rule 904), immediately after the archenemyâs precombat main phase begins, that player sets the top card of their scheme deck in motion. See rule 701.25.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 703. Turn-Based Actions : 703.4f
text: Immediately after a playerâs precombat main phase begins, that player puts a lore counter on each Saga enchantment they control. In an Archenemy game, this happens after the archenemyâs scheme action. See rule 714, âSaga Cards.â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 703. Turn-Based Actions : 703.4g
text: Immediately after the action of placing lore counters has been completed, if the active player controls any Attractions, that player rolls to visit their Attractions. See rule 701.49, âRoll to Visit Your Attractions.â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 703. Turn-Based Actions : 703.4h
text: Immediately after the beginning of combat step begins, if the game being played is a multiplayer game in which the active playerâs opponents donât all automatically become defending players, the active player chooses one of their opponents. That player becomes the defending player. See rule 507.1.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 703. Turn-Based Actions : 703.4i
text: Immediately after the declare attackers step begins, the active player declares attackers. See rule 508.1.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 703. Turn-Based Actions : 703.4j
text: Immediately after the declare blockers step begins, the defending player declares blockers. See rule 509.1.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 703. Turn-Based Actions : 703.4k
text: Immediately after blockers have been declared during the declare blockers step, for each attacking creature thatâs become blocked by multiple creatures, the active player announces the damage assignment order among the blocking creatures. See rule 509.2.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 703. Turn-Based Actions : 703.4m
text: Immediately after the active player has announced damage assignment orders (if necessary) during the declare blockers step, for each creature thatâs blocking multiple creatures, the defending player announces the damage assignment order among the attacking creatures. See rule 509.3.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 703. Turn-Based Actions : 703.4n
text: Immediately after the combat damage step begins, each player in APNAP order announces how each attacking or blocking creature they control assigns its combat damage. See rule 510.1.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 703. Turn-Based Actions : 703.4p
text: Immediately after combat damage has been assigned during the combat damage step, all combat damage is dealt simultaneously. See rule 510.2.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 703. Turn-Based Actions : 703.4q
text: Immediately after the cleanup step begins, if the active playerâs hand contains more cards than their maximum hand size (normally seven), they discard enough cards to reduce their hand size to that number. See rule 514.1.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 703. Turn-Based Actions : 703.4r
text: Immediately after the active player has discarded cards (if necessary) during the cleanup step, all damage is removed from permanents and all âuntil end of turnâ and âthis turnâ effects end. These actions happen simultaneously. See rule 514.2.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 703. Turn-Based Actions : 703.4s
text: When each step or phase ends, any unused mana left in a playerâs mana pool empties. See rule 500.4.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 704. State-Based Actions : 704.1.
text: State-based actions are game actions that happen automatically whenever certain conditions (listed below) are met. State-based actions donât use the stack.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 704. State-Based Actions : 704.1a
text: Abilities that watch for a specified game state are triggered abilities, not state-based actions. (See rule 603, âHandling Triggered Abilities.â)

name: Comprehensive Rules: 704. State-Based Actions : 704.2.
text: State-based actions are checked throughout the game and are not controlled by any player.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 704. State-Based Actions : 704.3.
text: Whenever a player would get priority (see rule 117, âTiming and Priorityâ), the game checks for any of the listed conditions for state-based actions, then performs all applicable state-based actions simultaneously as a single event. If any state-based actions are performed as a result of a check, the check is repeated; otherwise all triggered abilities that are waiting to be put on the stack are put on the stack, then the check is repeated. Once no more state-based actions have been performed as the result of a check and no triggered abilities are waiting to be put on the stack, the appropriate player gets priority. This process also occurs during the cleanup step (see rule 514), except that if no state-based actions are performed as the result of the stepâs first check and no triggered abilities are waiting to be put on the stack, then no player gets priority and the step ends.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 704. State-Based Actions : 704.4.
text: Unlike triggered abilities, state-based actions pay no attention to what happens during the resolution of a spell or ability.

name: Example for Rule : 704.4.
text: A player controls a creature with the ability âThis creatureâs power and toughness are each equal to the number of cards in your handâ and casts a spell whose effect is âDiscard your hand, then draw seven cards.â The creature will temporarily have toughness 0 in the middle of the spellâs resolution but will be back up to toughness 7 when the spell finishes resolving. Thus the creature will survive when state-based actions are checked. In contrast, an ability that triggers when the player has no cards in hand goes on the stack after the spell resolves, because its trigger event happened during resolution.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 704. State-Based Actions : 704.5.
text: The state-based actions are as follows:

name: Comprehensive Rules: 704. State-Based Actions : 704.5a
text: If a player has 0 or less life, that player loses the game.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 704. State-Based Actions : 704.5b
text: If a player attempted to draw a card from a library with no cards in it since the last time state-based actions were checked, that player loses the game.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 704. State-Based Actions : 704.5c
text: If a player has ten or more poison counters, that player loses the game. Ignore this rule in Two-Headed Giant games; see rule 704.6b instead.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 704. State-Based Actions : 704.5d
text: If a token is in a zone other than the battlefield, it ceases to exist.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 704. State-Based Actions : 704.5e
text: If a copy of a spell is in a zone other than the stack, it ceases to exist. If a copy of a card is in any zone other than the stack or the battlefield, it ceases to exist.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 704. State-Based Actions : 704.5f
text: If a creature has toughness 0 or less, itâs put into its ownerâs graveyard. Regeneration canât replace this event.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 704. State-Based Actions : 704.5g
text: If a creature has toughness greater than 0, it has damage marked on it, and the total damage marked on it is greater than or equal to its toughness, that creature has been dealt lethal damage and is destroyed. Regeneration can replace this event.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 704. State-Based Actions : 704.5h
text: If a creature has toughness greater than 0, and itâs been dealt damage by a source with deathtouch since the last time state-based actions were checked, that creature is destroyed. Regeneration can replace this event.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 704. State-Based Actions : 704.5i
text: If a planeswalker has loyalty 0, itâs put into its ownerâs graveyard.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 704. State-Based Actions : 704.5j
text: If two or more legendary permanents with the same name are controlled by the same player, that player chooses one of them, and the rest are put into their ownersâ graveyards. This is called the âlegend rule.â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 704. State-Based Actions : 704.5k
text: If two or more permanents have the supertype world, all except the one that has had the world supertype for the shortest amount of time are put into their ownersâ graveyards. In the event of a tie for the shortest amount of time, all are put into their ownersâ graveyards. This is called the âworld rule.â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 704. State-Based Actions : 704.5m
text: If an Aura is attached to an illegal object or player, or is not attached to an object or player, that Aura is put into its ownerâs graveyard.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 704. State-Based Actions : 704.5n
text: If an Equipment or Fortification is attached to an illegal permanent or to a player, it becomes unattached from that permanent or player. It remains on the battlefield.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 704. State-Based Actions : 704.5p
text: If a battle or creature is attached to an object or player, it becomes unattached and remains on the battlefield. Similarly, if any nonbattle, noncreature permanent thatâs neither an Aura, an Equipment, nor a Fortification is attached to an object or player, it becomes unattached and remains on the battlefield.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 704. State-Based Actions : 704.5q
text: If a permanent has both a +1/+1 counter and a -1/-1 counter on it, N +1/+1 and N -1/-1 counters are removed from it, where N is the smaller of the number of +1/+1 and -1/-1 counters on it.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 704. State-Based Actions : 704.5r
text: If a permanent with an ability that says it canât have more than N counters of a certain kind on it has more than N counters of that kind on it, all but N of those counters are removed from it.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 704. State-Based Actions : 704.5s
text: If the number of lore counters on a Saga permanent is greater than or equal to its final chapter number and it isnât the source of a chapter ability that has triggered but not yet left the stack, that Sagaâs controller sacrifices it. See rule 714, âSaga Cards.â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 704. State-Based Actions : 704.5t
text: If a playerâs venture marker is on the bottommost room of a dungeon card, and that dungeon card isnât the source of a room ability that has triggered but not yet left the stack, the dungeon cardâs owner removes it from the game. See rule 309, âDungeons.â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 704. State-Based Actions : 704.5u
text: If a permanent with space sculptor and any creatures without a sector designation are on the battlefield, each player who controls one or more of those creatures and doesnât control a permanent with space sculptor chooses a sector designation for each of those creatures they control. Then, each other player who controls one or more of those creatures chooses a sector designation for each of those creatures they control. See rule 702.158, âSpace Sculptor.â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 704. State-Based Actions : 704.5v
text: If a battle has defense 0 and it isnât the source of an ability that has triggered but not yet left the stack, itâs put into its ownerâs graveyard.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 704. State-Based Actions : 704.5w
text: If a battle has no player in the game designated as its protector and no attacking creatures are currently attacking that battle, that battleâs controller chooses an appropriate player to be its protector based on its battle type. If no player can be chosen this way, the battle is put into its ownerâs graveyard. See rule 310, âBattles.â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 704. State-Based Actions : 704.5x
text: If a Siegeâs controller is also its designated protector, that player chooses an opponent to become its protector. If no player can be chosen this way, the battle is put into its ownerâs graveyard. See rule 310, âBattles.â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 704. State-Based Actions : 704.5y
text: If a permanent has more than one Role controlled by the same player attached to it, each of those Roles except the one with the most recent timestamp is put into its ownerâs graveyard.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 704. State-Based Actions : 704.6.
text: Some variant games include additional state-based actions that arenât normally applicable:

name: Comprehensive Rules: 704. State-Based Actions : 704.6a
text: In a Two-Headed Giant game, if a team has 0 or less life, that team loses the game. See rule 810, âTwo-Headed Giant Variant.â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 704. State-Based Actions : 704.6b
text: In a Two-Headed Giant game, if a team has fifteen or more poison counters, that team loses the game. See rule 810, âTwo-Headed Giant Variant.â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 704. State-Based Actions : 704.6c
text: In a Commander game, a player whoâs been dealt 21 or more combat damage by the same commander over the course of the game loses the game. See rule 903, âCommander.â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 704. State-Based Actions : 704.6d
text: In a Commander game, if a commander is in a graveyard or in exile and that object was put into that zone since the last time state-based actions were checked, its owner may put it into the command zone. See rule 903, âCommander.â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 704. State-Based Actions : 704.6e
text: In an Archenemy game, if a non-ongoing scheme card is face up in the command zone, and no triggered abilities of any scheme are on the stack or waiting to be put on the stack, that scheme card is turned face down and put on the bottom of its ownerâs scheme deck. See rule 904, âArchenemy.â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 704. State-Based Actions : 704.6f
text: In a Planechase game, if a phenomenon card is face up in the command zone, and it isnât the source of a triggered ability that has triggered but not yet left the stack, the planar controller planeswalks. See rule 901, âPlanechase.â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 704. State-Based Actions : 704.7.
text: If multiple state-based actions would have the same result at the same time, a single replacement effect will replace all of them.

name: Example for Rule : 704.7.
text: You control Lichâs Mirror, which says âIf you would lose the game, instead shuffle your hand, your graveyard, and all permanents you own into your library, then draw seven cards and your life total becomes 20.â Thereâs one card in your library and your life total is 1. A spell causes you to draw two cards and lose 2 life. The next time state-based actions are checked, youâd lose the game due to rule 704.5a and rule 704.5b. Instead, Lichâs Mirror replaces that game loss and you keep playing.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 704. State-Based Actions : 704.8.
text: If a state-based action results in a permanent leaving the battlefield at the same time other state-based actions were performed, that permanentâs last known information is derived from the game state before any of those state-based actions were performed.

name: Example for Rule : 704.8.
text: You control Young Wolf, a 1/1 creature with undying, and it has a +1/+1 counter on it. A spell puts three -1/-1 counters on Young Wolf. Before state-based actions are performed, Young Wolf has one +1/+1 counter and three -1/-1 counters on it. After state-based actions are performed, Young Wolf is in the graveyard. When it was last on the battlefield, it had a +1/+1 counter on it, so undying will not trigger.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 705. Flipping a Coin : 705.1.
text: Some cards refer to flipping a coin. A coin used in a flip must be a two-sided object with easily distinguished sides and equal likelihood that either side lands face up. If the coin thatâs being flipped doesnât have an obvious âheadsâ or âtails,â designate one side to be âheads,â and the other side to be âtails.â Other methods of randomization may be substituted for flipping a coin as long as there are two possible outcomes of equal likelihood and all players agree to the substitution. For example, the player may roll an even-sided die and call âoddsâ or âevens,â or roll an even-sided die and designate that âoddsâ means âheadsâ and âevensâ means âtails.â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 705. Flipping a Coin : 705.2.
text: Some effects that instruct a player to flip a coin care only about whether the coin comes up heads or tails. No player wins or loses a coin flip for this kind of effect. For all other effects that instruct a player to flip a coin, the player that flips the coin calls âheadsâ or âtails.â If the call matches the result, the player wins the flip. Otherwise, the player loses the flip. Only the player who flips the coin wins or loses the flip; no other players are involved.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 706. Rolling a Die : 706.1.
text: An effect that instructs a player to roll a die will specify what kind of die to roll and how many of those dice to roll.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 706. Rolling a Die : 706.1a
text: Such an effect may refer to an âN-sided die,â âN-sided dice,â or one or more âdN,â where N is a positive integer. In those cases, the die must have N equally likely outcomes, numbered from 1 to N. For example, a d20 is a twenty-sided die with possible outcomes from 1 to 20.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 706. Rolling a Die : 706.1b
text: Players may agree to use an alternate method for rolling a die, including a digital substitute, as long as the method used has the same number of equally likely outcomes as the die specified in the instruction.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 706. Rolling a Die : 706.2.
text: After the roll, the number indicated on the top face of the die before any modifiers is the natural result. The instruction may include modifiers to the roll which add to or subtract from the natural result. Modifiers may also come from other sources. After considering all applicable modifiers, the final number is the result of the die roll.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 706. Rolling a Die : 706.2a
text: Modifiers may be optional and/or have associated costs. If a modifier has an associated mana cost, the player who rolled has the chance to activate mana abilities before applying it.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 706. Rolling a Die : 706.2b
text: If two or more effects are attempting to modify the natural result, the player who rolled chooses one to apply, following these steps: First, consider any effects that modify the result of a die roll by rerolling that die. Second, consider any effects that modify the result of a die roll by increasing or decreasing that result by a specified amount.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 706. Rolling a Die : 706.3.
text: Some abilities that instruct a player to roll one or more dice include a results table.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 706. Rolling a Die : 706.3a
text: The results table appears as a list or as a chart with multiple striations. Each list item or striation includes possible results and an effect associated with those results. The possible results indicated could be a single number, a range of numbers with two endpoints in the form âN1âN2,â or a range with a single endpoint in the form âN+.â Each one means âIf the result was in this range, [effect].â After a die roll, use the result to determine which effect listed on the results table happens, if any.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 706. Rolling a Die : 706.3b
text: An instruction to roll one or more dice, any instructions to modify that roll printed in the same paragraph, any additional instructions based on the result of the roll, and the associated results table are all part of one ability.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 706. Rolling a Die : 706.3c
text: Some effects in results charts include the text âRoll again.â This additional roll uses the same kind of and number of dice originally called for, including any applicable modifiers.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 706. Rolling a Die : 706.4.
text: Some abilities that instruct a player to roll one or more dice do not include a results table. The text of those abilities will indicate how to use the results of the die rolls, if at all.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 706. Rolling a Die : 706.5.
text: One card (Celebr-8000) has an ability that instructs a player to roll two dice and has an additional effect if that player ârolled doubles.â A player has rolled doubles if the result of each of those rolls is equal to the other.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 706. Rolling a Die : 706.6.
text: If a player is instructed to ignore a roll, that roll is considered to have never happened. No abilities trigger because of the ignored roll, and no effects apply to that roll. If that player was instructed to ignore the lowest roll and multiple results are tied for the lowest, the player chooses one of those rolls to be ignored.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 706. Rolling a Die : 706.7.
text: In a Planechase game, rolling the planar die will cause any ability that triggers whenever a player rolls one or more dice to trigger. However, any effect that refers to a numerical result of a die roll, including ones that exchange the results of that roll with another value or compare the results of that roll to other rolls or to a given number, ignores the rolling of the planar die. See rule 901, âPlanechase.â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 706. Rolling a Die : 706.8.
text: One card (Centaur of Attention) has an ability that instructs a player to roll dice and âstoreâ those results on it and another ability that allows a player to reroll any number of those results.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 706. Rolling a Die : 706.8a
text: To store the result of a die roll on a permanent means to note both the kind of die rolled and the result of that roll. That noted information is considered a âstored resultâ of that permanent, and the result is the âvalueâ of that stored result.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 706. Rolling a Die : 706.8b
text: To reroll one or more stored results of a permanent, roll one of the kind of die noted for each of them. If one kind of die is noted for more than one of those results, roll that many of that kind of die. The results you rerolled stop being stored results, and you store the results of each of the new die rolls on that permanent.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 706. Rolling a Die : 706.8c
text: If a permanent has an ability that stores results on it and another ability that refers to the stored results, those abilities are linked. (See rule 607.2e.)

name: Comprehensive Rules: 707. Copying Objects : 707.1.
text: Some objects become or turn another object into a âcopyâ of a spell, permanent, or card. Some effects create a token thatâs a copy of another object. (Certain older cards were printed with the phrase âsearch for a copy.â This section doesnât cover those cards, which have received new text in the Oracle card reference.)

name: Comprehensive Rules: 707. Copying Objects : 707.2.
text: When copying an object, the copy acquires the copiable values of the original objectâs characteristics and, for an object on the stack, choices made when casting or activating it (mode, targets, the value of X, whether it was kicked, how it will affect multiple targets, and so on). The copiable values are the values derived from the text printed on the object (that text being name, mana cost, color indicator, card type, subtype, supertype, rules text, power, toughness, and/or loyalty), as modified by other copy effects, by its face-down status, and by âas . . . enters the battlefieldâ and âas . . . is turned face upâ abilities that set power and toughness (and may also set additional characteristics). Other effects (including type-changing and text-changing effects), status, counters, and stickers are not copied.

name: Example for Rule : 707.2.
text: Chimeric Staff is an artifact that reads, â{X}: Chimeric Staff becomes an X/X artifact creature until end of turn.â Clone is a creature that reads, âYou may have Clone enter the battlefield as a copy of any creature on the battlefield.â After a Staff has become a 5/5 artifact creature, a Clone enters the battlefield as a copy of it. The Clone is an artifact, not a 5/5 artifact creature. (The copy has the Staffâs ability, however, and will become a creature if that ability is activated.)

name: Example for Rule : 707.2.
text: Clone enters the battlefield as a copy of a face-down Grinning Demon (a creature with morph {2}{B}{B}). The Clone is a colorless 2/2 creature with no name, no types, no abilities, and no mana cost. It will still be face up. Its controller canât pay {2}{B}{B} to turn it face up.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 707. Copying Objects : 707.2a
text: A copy acquires the color of the object itâs copying because that value is derived from its mana cost or color indicator. A copy acquires the abilities of the object itâs copying because those values are derived from its rules text. A copy doesnât wind up with two values of each ability (that is, it doesnât copy the objectâs abilities and its rules text, then have that rules text define a new set of abilities).

name: Comprehensive Rules: 707. Copying Objects : 707.2b
text: Once an object has been copied, changing the copiable values of the original object wonât cause the copy to change.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 707. Copying Objects : 707.2c
text: If a static ability generates a continuous effect thatâs a copy effect, the copiable values that effect grants are determined only at the time that effect first starts to apply.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 707. Copying Objects : 707.3.
text: The copyâs copiable values become the copied information, as modified by the copyâs status (see rule 110.5). Objects that copy the object will use the new copiable values.

name: Example for Rule : 707.3.
text: Vesuvan Doppelganger reads, âYou may have Vesuvan Doppelganger enter the battlefield as a copy of any creature on the battlefield, except it doesnât copy that creatureâs color and it has âAt the beginning of your upkeep, you may have this creature become a copy of target creature, except it doesnât copy that creatureâs color and it has this ability.ââ A Vesuvan Doppelganger enters the battlefield as a copy of Runeclaw Bear (a 2/2 green Bear creature with no abilities). Then a Clone enters the battlefield as a copy of the Doppelganger. The Clone is a 2/2 blue Bear named Runeclaw Bear that has the Doppelgangerâs upkeep-triggered ability.

name: Example for Rule : 707.3.
text: Tomoya the Revealer (a flipped flip card) becomes a copy of Nezumi Shortfang (an unflipped flip card). Tomoyaâs characteristics become the characteristics of Stabwhisker the Odious, which is the flipped version of Nezumi Shortfang.

name: Example for Rule : 707.3.
text: A face-down Grinning Demon (a creature with morph) becomes a copy of a face-up Branchsnap Lorian (a 4/1 green creature with trample and morph {G}). The Demonâs characteristics become the characteristics of Branchsnap Lorian. However, since the creature is face down, it remains a 2/2 colorless creature with no name, types, or abilities, and no mana cost. It can be turned face up for {G}. If itâs turned face up, it will have the characteristics of Branchsnap Lorian.

name: Example for Rule : 707.3.
text: A face-down Grinning Demon (a creature with morph) becomes a copy of Wandering Ones (a 1/1 blue Spirit creature that doesnât have morph). It will be a face-down Wandering Ones. It remains a 2/2 colorless creature with no name, types, or abilities, and no mana cost. Its controller canât turn it face up as a special action. If an effect turns it face up, it will have the characteristics of Wandering Ones.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 707. Copying Objects : 707.4.
text: Some effects cause a permanent thatâs copying a permanent to copy a different object while remaining on the battlefield. The change doesnât trigger enters-the-battlefield or leaves-the-battlefield abilities. This also doesnât change any noncopy effects presently affecting the permanent.

name: Example for Rule : 707.4.
text: Unstable Shapeshifter reads, âWhenever a creature enters the battlefield, Unstable Shapeshifter becomes a copy of that creature and gains this ability.â Itâs affected by Giant Growth, which reads âTarget creature gets +3/+3 until end of turn.â If a creature enters the battlefield later this turn, Unstable Shapeshifter will become a copy of that creature, but it will still get +3/+3 from the Giant Growth.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 707. Copying Objects : 707.5.
text: An object that enters the battlefield âas a copyâ or âthatâs a copyâ of another object becomes a copy as it enters the battlefield. It doesnât enter the battlefield, and then become a copy of that permanent. If the text thatâs being copied includes any abilities that replace the enters-the-battlefield event (such as âenters the battlefield withâ or âas [this] enters the battlefieldâ abilities), those abilities will take effect. Also, any enters-the-battlefield triggered abilities of the copy will have a chance to trigger.

name: Example for Rule : 707.5.
text: Skyshroud Behemoth reads, âFading 2 (This creature enters the battlefield with two fade counters on it. At the beginning of your upkeep, remove a fade counter from it. If you canât, sacrifice it.)â and âSkyshroud Behemoth enters the battlefield tapped.â A Clone that enters the battlefield as a copy of a Skyshroud Behemoth will also enter the battlefield tapped with two fade counters on it.

name: Example for Rule : 707.5.
text: Wall of Omens reads, âWhen Wall of Omens enters the battlefield, draw a card.â A Clone enters the battlefield as a copy of Wall of Omens. The Clone has the Wallâs enters-the-battlefield triggered ability, so the Cloneâs controller draws a card.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 707. Copying Objects : 707.6.
text: When copying a permanent, any choices that have been made for that permanent arenât copied. Instead, if an object enters the battlefield as a copy of another permanent, the objectâs controller will get to make any âas [this] enters the battlefieldâ choices for it.

name: Example for Rule : 707.6.
text: A Clone enters the battlefield as a copy of Adaptive Automaton. Adaptive Automaton reads, in part, âAs Adaptive Automaton enters the battlefield, choose a creature type.â The Clone wonât copy the creature type choice of the Automaton; rather, the controller of the Clone will get to make a new choice.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 707. Copying Objects : 707.7.
text: If a pair of linked abilities are copied, those abilities will be similarly linked to one another on the object that copied them. One ability refers only to actions that were taken or objects that were affected by the other. They canât be linked to any other ability, regardless of what other abilities the copy may currently have or may have had in the past. See rule 607, âLinked Abilities.â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 707. Copying Objects : 707.8.
text: When copying a melded permanent or other double-faced permanent, use the copiable values of the face thatâs currently up to determine the characteristics of the copy. See rule 712, âDouble-Faced Cards.â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 707. Copying Objects : 707.8a
text: If an effect creates a token that is a copy of a transforming permanent or a transforming double-faced card not on the battlefield, the resulting token is a transforming token that has both a front face and a back face. The characteristics of each face are determined by the copiable values of the same face of the permanent it is a copy of, as modified by any other copy effects that apply to that permanent. If the token is a copy of a transforming permanent with its back face up, the token enters the battlefield with its back face up. This rule does not apply to tokens that are created with their own set of characteristics and enter the battlefield as a copy of a transforming permanent due to a replacement effect.

name: Example for Rule : 707.8a
text: Afflicted Deserter is the front face of a transforming double-faced card, and the name of its back face is Werewolf Ransacker. If an effect creates a token that is a copy of that transforming permanent, the token also has the same two faces and can transform. It enters the battlefield with the same face up as the permanent that it is a copy of.

name: Example for Rule : 707.8a
text: Clone is not a transforming double-faced card, so a token that is created as a copy of a Clone is not a transforming token, even if it enters the battlefield as a copy of a transforming permanent due to Cloneâs replacement effect.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 707. Copying Objects : 707.9.
text: Copy effects may include modifications or exceptions to the copying process.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 707. Copying Objects : 707.9a
text: Some copy effects cause the copy to gain an ability as part of the copying process. This ability becomes part of the copiable values for the copy, along with any other abilities that were copied.

name: Example for Rule : 707.9a
text: Quirion Elves enters the battlefield and an Unstable Shapeshifter copies it. The copiable values of the Shapeshifter now match those of the Elves, except that the Shapeshifter also has the ability âWhenever a creature enters the battlefield, Unstable Shapeshifter becomes a copy of that creature, except it has this ability.â Then a Clone enters the battlefield as a copy of the Unstable Shapeshifter. The Clone copies the new copiable values of the Shapeshifter, including the ability that the Shapeshifter gave itself when it copied the Elves.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 707. Copying Objects : 707.9b
text: Some copy effects modify a characteristic as part of the copying process. The final set of values for that characteristic becomes part of the copiable values of the copy.

name: Example for Rule : 707.9b
text: Copy Artifact is an enchantment that reads, âYou may have Copy Artifact enter the battlefield as a copy of any artifact on the battlefield, except itâs an enchantment in addition to its other types.â It enters the battlefield as a copy of Juggernaut. The copiable values of the Copy Artifact now match those of Juggernaut with one modification: its types are now artifact, creature, and enchantment.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 707. Copying Objects : 707.9c
text: Some copy effects specifically state that they donât copy certain characteristics and the affected objects instead retain their original values. Copy effects may also simply state that certain characteristics are not copied.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 707. Copying Objects : 707.9d
text: When applying a copy effect that doesnât copy a certain characteristic, retains one or more original values for a certain characteristic, or provides a specific set of values for a certain characteristic, any characteristic-defining ability (see rule 604.3) of the object being copied that defines that characteristic is not copied. If that characteristic is color, any color indicator (see rule 204) of that object is also not copied. This rule does not apply to copy effects with exceptions that state the object is a certain card type, supertype, and/or subtype âin addition to its other types.â In those cases, any characteristic-defining ability that defines card type, supertype, and/or subtype is copied.

name: Example for Rule : 707.9d
text: Quicksilver Gargantuan is a creature that reads, âYou may have Quicksilver Gargantuan enter the battlefield as a copy of any creature on the battlefield, except itâs 7/7.â Quicksilver Gargantuan enters the battlefield as a copy of Tarmogoyf, which has a characteristic-defining ability that defines its power and toughness. Quicksilver Gargantuan does not have that ability. It will be 7/7.

name: Example for Rule : 707.9d
text: Glasspool Mimic is a creature that reads âYou may have Glasspool Mimic enter the battlefield as a copy of a creature you control, except itâs a Shapeshifter Rogue in addition to its other types.â Glasspool Mimic enters the battlefield as a copy of a creature with changeling. Glasspool Mimic will have changeling and will have all creature types.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 707. Copying Objects : 707.9e
text: Some replacement effects that generate copy effects include an exception thatâs an additional effect rather than a modification of the affected objectâs characteristics. If another copy effect is applied to that object after applying the copy effect with that exception, the exceptionâs effect doesnât happen.

name: Example for Rule : 707.9e
text: Altered Ego reads, âYou may have Altered Ego enter the battlefield as a copy of any creature on the battlefield, except it enters with X additional +1/+1 counters on it.â You choose for it to enter the battlefield as a copy of Clone, which reads âYou may have Clone enter the battlefield as a copy of any creature on the battlefield,â for which no creature was chosen as it entered the battlefield. If you then choose a creature to copy as you apply the replacement effect Altered Ego gains by copying Clone, Altered Egoâs replacement effect wonât cause it to enter the battlefield with any +1/+1 counters on it.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 707. Copying Objects : 707.9f
text: Some exceptions to the copying process apply only if the copy is or has certain characteristics. To determine whether such an exception applies, consider what the resulting permanentâs characteristics would be if the copy effect were applied without that exception, taking into account any other exceptions that effect includes.

name: Example for Rule : 707.9f
text: Moritte of the Frost says, in part, âYou may have Moritte of the Frost enter the battlefield as a copy of a permanent you control, except itâs legendary and snow in addition to its other types and, if itâs a creature, it enters with two additional +1/+1 counters on it and it has changeling.â Moritte of the Frost copies a land that has become a creature until end of turn. It would enter as a noncreature permanent, so it wonât enter with two additional +1+1 counters on it and it wonât have changeling, even if it becomes a creature later in the turn.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 707. Copying Objects : 707.9g
text: Some replacement effects that generate copy effects are linked to triggered abilities written in the same paragraph. (See rule 603.11.) If another copy effect is applied to that object after applying the copy effect with the linked triggered ability, the ability doesnât trigger.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 707. Copying Objects : 707.10.
text: To copy a spell, activated ability, or triggered ability means to put a copy of it onto the stack; a copy of a spell isnât cast and a copy of an activated ability isnât activated. A copy of a spell or ability copies both the characteristics of the spell or ability and all decisions made for it, including modes, targets, the value of X, and additional or alternative costs. (See rule 601, âCasting Spells.â) Choices that are normally made on resolution are not copied. If an effect of the copy refers to objects used to pay its costs, it uses the objects used to pay the costs of the original spell or ability. A copy of a spell is owned by the player under whose control it was put on the stack. A copy of a spell or ability is controlled by the player under whose control it was put on the stack. A copy of a spell is itself a spell, even though it has no spell card associated with it. A copy of an ability is itself an ability.

name: Example for Rule : 707.10.
text: A player casts Fork, targeting an Emerald Charm. Fork reads, âCopy target instant or sorcery spell, except that the copy is red. You may choose new targets for the copy.â Emerald Charm is a modal green instant. When the Fork resolves, it puts a copy of the Emerald Charm on the stack except the copy is red, not green. The copy has the same mode that was chosen for the original Emerald Charm. It does not necessarily have the same target, but only because Fork allows choosing of new targets.

name: Example for Rule : 707.10.
text: Fling is an instant that reads, âAs an additional cost to cast this spell, sacrifice a creatureâ and âFling deals damage equal to the sacrificed creatureâs power to any target.â When determining how much damage a copy of Fling deals, it checks the power of the creature sacrificed to pay for the original Fling.

name: Example for Rule : 707.10.
text: Dawnglow Infusion is a sorcery that reads, âYou gain X life if {G} was spent to cast this spell and X life if {W} was spent to cast it.â Because mana isnât an object, a copy of Dawnglow Infusion wonât cause you to gain any life, no matter what mana was spent to cast the original spell.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 707. Copying Objects : 707.10a
text: If a copy of a spell is in a zone other than the stack, it ceases to exist. If a copy of a card is in any zone other than the stack or the battlefield, it ceases to exist. These are state-based actions. See rule 704.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 707. Copying Objects : 707.10b
text: A copy of an ability has the same source as the original ability. If the ability refers to its source by name, the copy refers to that same object and not to any other object with the same name. The copy is considered to be the same ability by effects that count how many times that ability has resolved during the turn.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 707. Copying Objects : 707.10c
text: Some effects copy a spell or ability and state that its controller may choose new targets for the copy. The player may leave any number of the targets unchanged, even if those targets would be illegal. If the player chooses to change some or all of the targets, the new targets must be legal. Once the player has decided what the copyâs targets will be, the copy is put onto the stack with those targets.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 707. Copying Objects : 707.10d
text: Some effects copy a spell or ability for each player or object it âcould target.â The copies are put onto the stack with those targets in the order of their controllerâs choice. If the spell or ability has more than one target, each of its targets must be the same player or object. If that player or object isnât a legal target for each instance of the word âtarget,â a copy isnât created for that player or object.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 707. Copying Objects : 707.10e
text: Some effects copy a spell or ability and specify a new target for the copy. If the spell or ability has more than one target, each of the copyâs targets must be that player or object. If that player or object isnât a legal target for each instance of the word âtarget,â the copy isnât created.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 707. Copying Objects : 707.10f
text: Some effects copy a permanent spell. As that copy resolves, it ceases being a copy of a spell and becomes a token permanent. (See rule 608.3f.)

name: Comprehensive Rules: 707. Copying Objects : 707.10g
text: If an effect creates a copy of a transforming permanent spell, the copy is also a transforming permanent spell that has both a front face and a back face. The characteristics of its front and back face are determined by the copiable values of the same face of the spell it is a copy of, as modified by any other copy effects. If the spell it is a copy of has its back face up, the copy is created with its back face up. The token thatâs put onto the battlefield as that spell resolves is a transforming token.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 707. Copying Objects : 707.11.
text: If an effect refers to a permanent by name, the effect still tracks that permanent even if it changes names or becomes a copy of something else.

name: Example for Rule : 707.11.
text: An Unstable Shapeshifter copies a Crazed Armodon. Crazed Armodon reads, â{G}: Crazed Armodon gets +3/+0 and gains trample until end of turn. Destroy Crazed Armodon at the beginning of the next end step. Activate only once each turn.â If this ability of the Shapeshifter is activated, the Shapeshifter will be destroyed at the beginning of the next end step, even if itâs no longer a copy of Crazed Armodon at that time.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 707. Copying Objects : 707.12.
text: An effect that instructs a player to cast a copy of an object (and not just copy a spell) follows the rules for casting spells, except that the copy is created in the same zone the object is in and then cast while another spell or ability is resolving. Casting a copy of an object follows steps 601.2aâh of rule 601, âCasting Spells,â and then the copy becomes cast. Once cast, the copy is a spell on the stack, and just like any other spell it can resolve or be countered.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 707. Copying Objects : 707.13.
text: One card (Garth One-Eye) instructs a player to create a copy of a card defined by name rather than by indicating an object to be copied. To do so, the player uses the Oracle card reference to determine the characteristics of the copy and creates the copy outside of the game.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 707. Copying Objects : 707.14.
text: One card (Magar of the Magic Strings) instructs a player to note the name of a particular card in a graveyard and create a copy of the card with the noted name. To do so, use the characteristics of that card as it last existed in the graveyard to determine the copiable values of the copy. (See rule 608.2h.)

name: Comprehensive Rules: 708. Face-Down Spells and Permanents : 708.1.
text: Some cards allow spells and permanents to be face down.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 708. Face-Down Spells and Permanents : 708.2.
text: Face-down spells and face-down permanents have no characteristics other than those listed by the ability or rules that allowed the spell or permanent to be face down. Any listed characteristics are the copiable values of that objectâs characteristics. (See rule 613, âInteraction of Continuous Effects,â and rule 707, âCopying Objects.â)

name: Comprehensive Rules: 708. Face-Down Spells and Permanents : 708.2a
text: If a face-up permanent is turned face down by a spell or ability that doesnât list any characteristics for that object, it becomes a 2/2 face-down creature with no text, no name, no subtypes, and no mana cost. A permanent that enters the battlefield face down also has these characteristics unless otherwise specified by the effect that put it onto the battlefield face down or allowed it to be cast face down. These values are the copiable values of that objectâs characteristics.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 708. Face-Down Spells and Permanents : 708.2b
text: A face-down permanent canât be turned face-down. If a spell or ability attempts to turn a face-down permanent face down, nothing happens and that effect doesnât change any of its characteristics or their copiable values.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 708. Face-Down Spells and Permanents : 708.3.
text: Objects that are put onto the battlefield face down are turned face down before they enter the battlefield, so the permanentâs enters-the-battlefield abilities wonât trigger (if triggered) or have any effect (if static).

name: Comprehensive Rules: 708. Face-Down Spells and Permanents : 708.4.
text: Objects that are cast face down are turned face down before they are put onto the stack, so effects that care about the characteristics of a spell will see only the face-down spellâs characteristics. Any effects or prohibitions that would apply to casting an object with these characteristics (and not the face-up objectâs characteristics) are applied to casting this object. The permanent the spell becomes will be a face-down permanent.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 708. Face-Down Spells and Permanents : 708.5.
text: At any time, you may look at a face-down spell you control on the stack or a face-down permanent you control (even if itâs phased out). You canât look at face-down cards in any other zone or face-down spells or permanents controlled by another player.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 708. Face-Down Spells and Permanents : 708.6.
text: If you control multiple face-down spells or face-down permanents, you must ensure at all times that your face-down spells and permanents can be easily differentiated from each other. This includes, but is not limited to, knowing what ability or rules caused the permanents to be face down, the order spells were cast, the order that face-down permanents entered the battlefield, which creature(s) attacked last turn, and any other differences between face-down spells or permanents. Common methods for distinguishing between face-down objects include using counters or dice to mark the different objects, or clearly placing those objects in order on the table.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 708. Face-Down Spells and Permanents : 708.7.
text: The ability or rules that allow a permanent to be face down may also allow the permanentâs controller to turn it face up. Spells normally canât be turned face up.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 708. Face-Down Spells and Permanents : 708.8.
text: As a face-down permanent is turned face up, its copiable values revert to its normal copiable values. Any effects that have been applied to the face-down permanent still apply to the face-up permanent. Any abilities relating to the permanent entering the battlefield donât trigger and donât have any effect, because the permanent has already entered the battlefield.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 708. Face-Down Spells and Permanents : 708.9.
text: If a face-down permanent or a face-down component of a merged permanent moves from the battlefield to any other zone, its owner must reveal it to all players as they move it. If a face-down spell moves from the stack to any zone other than the battlefield, its owner must reveal it to all players as they move it. If a player leaves the game, all face-down permanents, face-down components of merged permanents, and face-down spells owned by that player must be revealed to all players. At the end of each game, all face-down permanents, face-down components of merged permanents, and face-down spells must be revealed to all players.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 708. Face-Down Spells and Permanents : 708.10.
text: If a face-down permanent becomes a copy of another permanent, its copiable values become the copiable values of that permanent, as modified by its face-down status. Its characteristics therefore remain the same: the characteristics listed by the ability or rules that allowed it to be turned face down. However, if it is turned face up, its copiable values become the values it copied from the other permanent. See rule 707.3.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 708. Face-Down Spells and Permanents : 708.11.
text: If a face-down permanent would have an âAs [this permanent] is turned face up . . .â ability after itâs turned face up, that ability is applied while that permanent is being turned face up, not afterward.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 709. Split Cards : 709.1.
text: Split cards have two card faces on a single card. The back of a split card is the normal Magic card back.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 709. Split Cards : 709.2.
text: Although split cards have two castable halves, each split card is only one card. For example, a player who has drawn or discarded a split card has drawn or discarded one card, not two.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 709. Split Cards : 709.3.
text: A player chooses which half of a split card they are casting before putting it onto the stack.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 709. Split Cards : 709.3a
text: Only the chosen half is evaluated to see if it can be cast. Only that half is considered to be put onto the stack.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 709. Split Cards : 709.3b
text: While on the stack, only the characteristics of the half being cast exist. The other halfâs characteristics are treated as though they didnât exist.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 709. Split Cards : 709.3c
text: An effect may create a copy of a split card and allow a player to cast the copy. That copy retains the characteristics of the two halves separated into the same two halves as the original card. (See rule 707.12.)

name: Comprehensive Rules: 709. Split Cards : 709.4.
text: In every zone except the stack, the characteristics of a split card are those of its two halves combined. This is a change from previous rules.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 709. Split Cards : 709.4a
text: Each split card has two names. If an effect instructs a player to choose a card name and the player wants to choose a split cardâs name, the player must choose one of those names and not both. An object has the chosen name if one of its names is the chosen name.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 709. Split Cards : 709.4b
text: The mana cost of a split card is the combined mana costs of its two halves. A split cardâs colors and mana value are determined from its combined mana cost. An effect that refers specifically to the symbols in a split cardâs mana cost sees the separate symbols rather than the whole mana cost.

name: Example for Rule : 709.4b
text: Assault//Batteryâs mana cost is {3}{R}{G}. Itâs a red and green card with a mana value of 5. If you cast Assault, the resulting spell is a red spell with a mana value of 1.

name: Example for Rule : 709.4b
text: Fire//Iceâs mana cost is {2}{U}{R}. It has the same mana cost as Steam Augury, but an effect such as that of Jegantha, the Wellspring sees that it contains the mana symbol {1} twice.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 709. Split Cards : 709.4c
text: A split card has each card type specified on either of its halves and each ability in the text box of each half.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 709. Split Cards : 709.4d
text: The characteristics of a fused split spell on the stack are also those of its two halves combined (see rule 702.102, âFuseâ).

name: Comprehensive Rules: 710. Flip Cards : 710.1.
text: Flip cards have a two-part card frame on a single card. The text that appears right side up on the card defines the cardâs normal characteristics. Additional alternative characteristics appear upside down on the card. The back of a flip card is the normal Magic card back.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 710. Flip Cards : 710.1a
text: The top half of a flip card contains the cardâs normal name, text box, type line, power, and toughness. The text box usually contains an ability that causes the permanent to âflipâ if certain conditions are met.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 710. Flip Cards : 710.1b
text: The bottom half of a flip card contains an alternative name, text box, type line, power, and toughness. These characteristics are used only if the permanent is on the battlefield and only if the permanent is flipped.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 710. Flip Cards : 710.1c
text: A flip cardâs color and mana cost donât change if the permanent is flipped. Also, any changes to it by external effects will still apply.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 710. Flip Cards : 710.2.
text: In every zone other than the battlefield, and also on the battlefield before the permanent flips, a flip card has only the normal characteristics of the card. Once a permanent is flipped, its normal name, text box, type line, power, and toughness donât apply and the alternative versions of those characteristics apply instead.

name: Example for Rule : 710.2.
text: Akki Lavarunner is a nonlegendary creature that flips into a legendary creature named Tok-Tok, Volcano Born. An effect that says âSearch your library for a legendary cardâ canât find this flip card. An effect that says âLegendary creatures get +2/+2â doesnât affect Akki Lavarunner, but it does affect Tok-Tok.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 710. Flip Cards : 710.3.
text: You must ensure that itâs clear at all times whether a permanent you control is flipped or not, both when itâs untapped and when itâs tapped. Common methods for distinguishing between flipped and unflipped permanents include using coins or dice to mark flipped objects.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 710. Flip Cards : 710.4.
text: Flipping a permanent is a one-way process. Once a permanent is flipped, itâs impossible for it to become unflipped. However, if a flipped permanent leaves the battlefield, it retains no memory of its status. See rule 110.5.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 710. Flip Cards : 710.5.
text: If an effect instructs a player to choose a card name and the player wants to choose a flip cardâs alternative name, the player may do so.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 711. Leveler Cards : 711.1.
text: Each leveler card has a striated text box and three power/toughness boxes. The text box of a leveler card contains two level symbols.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 711. Leveler Cards : 711.2.
text: A level symbol is a keyword ability that represents a static ability. The level symbol includes either a range of numbers, indicated here as âN1-N2,â or a single number followed by a plus sign, indicated here as âN3+.â Any abilities printed within the same text box striation as a level symbol are part of its static ability. The same is true of the power/toughness box printed within that striation, indicated here as â[P/T].â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 711. Leveler Cards : 711.2a
text: â{LEVEL N1-N2} [Abilities] [P/T]â means âAs long as this creature has at least N1 level counters on it, but no more than N2 level counters on it, it has base power and toughness [P/T] and has [abilities].â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 711. Leveler Cards : 711.2b
text: â{LEVEL N3+} [Abilities] [P/T]â means âAs long as this creature has N3 or more level counters on it, it has base power and toughness [P/T] and has [abilities].â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 711. Leveler Cards : 711.3.
text: The text box striations have no game significance other than clearly demarcating which abilities and which power/toughness box are associated with which level symbol. Leveler cards each contain only one text box.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 711. Leveler Cards : 711.4.
text: Any ability a leveler card has that isnât preceded by a level symbol is treated normally. In particular, each leveler permanent has its level up ability (see rule 702.87) at all times; it may be activated regardless of how many level counters are on that permanent.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 711. Leveler Cards : 711.5.
text: If the number of level counters on a leveler creature is less than N1 (the first number printed in its {LEVEL N1-N2} symbol), it has the power and toughness denoted by its uppermost power/toughness box.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 711. Leveler Cards : 711.6.
text: In every zone other than the battlefield, a leveler card has the power and toughness denoted by its uppermost power/toughness box.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 711. Leveler Cards : 711.7.
text: Some enchantments have the subtype Class and associated abilities that give them a class level. These are not level up abilities and class levels do not interact with level counters. See rule 716, âClass Cards.â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 712. Double-Faced Cards : 712.1.
text: A double-faced card has a Magic card face on one side and either a Magic card face or half of an oversized card face on the other. (It does not have a Magic card back.) There are three kinds of double-faced cards: transforming double-faced cards, modal double-faced cards, and meld cards.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 712. Double-Faced Cards : 712.2.
text: Transforming double-faced cards have a Magic card face on each side and include abilities on one or both of their faces that allow the card to either âtransformâ or âconvertâ (turn over to its other face) and/or allow the card to be cast or enter the battlefield âtransformedâ or âconvertedâ (with its back face up).

name: Comprehensive Rules: 712. Double-Faced Cards : 712.2a
text: A transforming double-faced cardâs front face is marked by a front-face symbol in its upper left corner. On cards printed starting with The Brothersâ Warâ¢ release, that symbol is a single white triangle pointed upward inside a black circle. Transforming double-faced cards printed in older sets have different front-face symbols. On Magic Originsâ¢ and Core Set 2019 double-faced cards, the front-face symbol is a modified Planeswalker icon. On cards in the InnistradÂ® block, Shadows over Innistrad set, and Innistrad: Midnight Hunt set, as well as on Ulrich of the Krallenhorde in the Eldritch Moonâ¢ set, the front-face symbol is a sun. On other Eldritch Moon double-faced cards, the front-face symbol is a full moon. On IxalanÂ® and Rivals of Ixalanâ¢ cards, the front-face symbol is a compass rose. On KamigawaÂ®: Neon Dynasty double-faced cards, the front-face symbol is a closed fan.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 712. Double-Faced Cards : 712.2b
text: A transforming double-faced cardâs back face is marked by a back-face symbol in its upper left or upper right corner. On cards printed starting with The Brothersâ War release, that symbol is a single white triangle pointed downward inside a black circle. Transforming double-faced cards printed in older sets have different front-face symbols. On Magic Origins and Core Set 2019 double-faced cards, the back-face symbol is a full Planeswalker icon. On cards in the Innistrad block, Shadows over Innistrad set, and Innistrad: Midnight Hunt set, as well as on Ulrich, Uncontested Alpha in the Eldritch Moon set, the back-face symbol is a crescent moon. On other Eldritch Moon double-faced cards, the back-face symbol is a stylized image of Emrakul. On Ixalan and Rivals of Ixalan cards, the back-face symbol is a land icon. On Kamigawa: Neon Dynasty double-faced cards, the back-face symbol is an open fan.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 712. Double-Faced Cards : 712.2c
text: The front face of a transforming double-faced card whose back face is a creature has the back faceâs power and toughness printed in gray above the power and toughness box. This is reminder text and has no effect on game play.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 712. Double-Faced Cards : 712.3.
text: Modal double-faced cards have a Magic card face on each side. These faces are independent from one another.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 712. Double-Faced Cards : 712.3a
text: A modal double-faced cardâs front face is marked by a front-face symbol in its upper left corner. The front-face symbol is a single black triangle inside a sideways teardrop.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 712. Double-Faced Cards : 712.3b
text: A modal double-faced cardâs back face is marked by a back-face symbol in its upper left corner. The back-face symbol is two white triangles inside a sideways teardrop.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 712. Double-Faced Cards : 712.3c
text: Each face of a modal double-faced card includes a hint bar in the lower left corner with information about the opposite face. This is reminder text and has no effect on game play.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 712. Double-Faced Cards : 712.4.
text: Meld cards have a Magic card face on one side and half of an oversized card face on the other.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 712. Double-Faced Cards : 712.4a
text: One card in each meld pair has an ability that exiles both that object and its counterpart and melds them. To meld the two cards in a meld pair, put them onto the battlefield with their back faces up and combined (see rule 701.37, âMeldâ). The resulting permanent is a single object represented by two cards.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 712. Double-Faced Cards : 712.4b
text: The back faces of a meld pair are used only to determine the characteristics of the melded permanent that pair becomes on the battlefield. If a rule or effect references the back face of a meld card when not part of a melded permanent on the battlefield, it fails to determine its characteristics, regardless of which parts of the melded permanent is represented on that cardâs back face.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 712. Double-Faced Cards : 712.5.
text: There are six specific meld pairs.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 712. Double-Faced Cards : 712.5a
text: Midnight Scavengers and Graf Rats meld to form Chittering Host.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 712. Double-Faced Cards : 712.5b
text: Hanweir Garrison and Hanweir Battlements meld to form Hanweir, the Writhing Township.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 712. Double-Faced Cards : 712.5c
text: Bruna, the Fading Light and Gisela, the Broken Blade meld to form Brisela, Voice of Nightmares.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 712. Double-Faced Cards : 712.5d
text: Phyrexian Dragon Engine and Mishra, Claimed by Gix meld to form Mishra, Lost to Phyrexia.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 712. Double-Faced Cards : 712.5e
text: The Mightstone and Weakstone and Urza, Lord Protector meld to form Urza, Planeswalker.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 712. Double-Faced Cards : 712.5f
text: Argoth, Sanctum of Nature and Titania, Voice of Gaea meld to form Titania, Gaea Incarnate.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 712. Double-Faced Cards : 712.6.
text: Players who are allowed to look at a double-faced card may look at both sides of that card.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 712. Double-Faced Cards : 712.7.
text: Players must ensure that double-faced cards in hidden zones are indistinguishable from other cards in the same zone. To do this, the owner of a double-faced card may use completely opaque card sleeves and/or a substitute card (see rule 713). Sanctioned tournaments have additional rules for playing with double-faced cards. See rule 100.6.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 712. Double-Faced Cards : 712.8.
text: Each face of a transforming or modal double-faced card has its own set of characteristics. The front face of each meld card and the combined face formed by a meld pair each has its own set of characteristics.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 712. Double-Faced Cards : 712.8a
text: While a double-faced card is outside the game or in a zone other than the battlefield or stack, it has only the characteristics of its front face.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 712. Double-Faced Cards : 712.8b
text: A meld card on the stack has only the characteristics of its front face.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 712. Double-Faced Cards : 712.8c
text: Normally, a transforming double-faced spell has its front face up while on the stack and has only the characteristics of its front face. However, if an effect allows a player to cast a transforming double-faced card âtransformedâ or âconverted,â the resulting spell will have its back face up and have only the characteristics of its back face. Its mana value is calculated using the mana cost of its front face.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 712. Double-Faced Cards : 712.8d
text: While a double-faced permanent has its front face up, it has only the characteristics of its front face.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 712. Double-Faced Cards : 712.8e
text: While a transforming double-faced permanent has its back face up, it has only the characteristics of its back face. However, its mana value is calculated using the mana cost of its front face. If a permanent is copying the back face of a transforming double-faced permanent (even if the object representing that copy is itself a double-faced permanent), the mana value of that permanent is 0. See rule 202.3b.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 712. Double-Faced Cards : 712.8f
text: While a modal double-faced spell is on the stack or a modal double-faced permanent is on the battlefield, it has only the characteristics of the face thatâs up.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 712. Double-Faced Cards : 712.8g
text: While the two cards of a meld pair are on the battlefield as a melded permanent, the object represented by those cards has only the characteristics of the combined back face, and its mana value is the sum of the mana values of its front faces. If a permanent is copying a melded permanent, the mana value of the copy is 0. See rule 202.3c.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 712. Double-Faced Cards : 712.9.
text: Only transforming tokens and permanents represented by transforming double-faced cards can transform or convert. (See rule 701.28, âTransform,â and rule 701.50, âConvert.â) If a spell or ability instructs a player to transform or convert any permanent that isnât a transforming token or isnât represented by a transforming double-faced card, nothing happens.

name: Example for Rule : 712.9.
text: A Clone enters the battlefield as a copy of Wildblood Pack (the back face of a transforming double-faced card). The Clone will be a copy of the Wildblood Pack. Because the Clone is itself not a transforming double-faced card, it canât transform.

name: Example for Rule : 712.9.
