text: A player casts Cytoshape, causing a Kruin Outlaw (the front face of a transforming double-faced card) to become a copy of Elite Vanguard (a 2/1 Human Soldier creature) until end of turn. The player then casts Moonmist, which reads, in part, âTransform all Humans.â Because the copy of Elite Vanguard is a transforming double-faced card, it will transform. The resulting permanent will have its back face up, but it will still be a copy of Elite Vanguard that turn.

name: Example for Rule : 712.9.
text: A player controls Blackbloom Rogue, a Human Rogue thatâs the front face of a modal double-faced card. They cast Moonmist. Blackbloom Rogue doesnât transform.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 712. Double-Faced Cards : 712.10.
text: If a spell or ability instructs a player to transform or convert a permanent, and the face that permanent would transform or convert into is represented by an instant or sorcery card face, or is a transforming token that was created with an instant or sorcery face, nothing happens.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 712. Double-Faced Cards : 712.11.
text: A double-faced spell is cast with its front face up by default. See rule 601, âCasting Spells.â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 712. Double-Faced Cards : 712.11a
text: If a transforming double-faced card or a copy of a transforming double-faced card is cast as a spell âtransformedâ or âconverted,â itâs put on the stack with its back face up.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 712. Double-Faced Cards : 712.11b
text: A player casting a modal double-faced card or a copy of a modal double-faced card as a spell chooses which face they are casting before putting it onto the stack.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 712. Double-Faced Cards : 712.11c
text: Only the face that will be face up on the stack is evaluated to determine if it can be cast. Only that face is considered to be put onto the stack.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 712. Double-Faced Cards : 712.11d
text: If an ability of a transforming double-faced cardâs front face allows it to be cast âtransformedâ or âconverted,â that ability is also considered when evaluating that spell to determine if it can be cast. This is an exception to 712.11c.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 712. Double-Faced Cards : 712.12.
text: A player playing a modal double-faced card or a copy of a modal double-faced card as a land chooses one of its faces thatâs a land before putting it onto the battlefield. It enters the battlefield with that face up. See rule 305, âLands.â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 712. Double-Faced Cards : 712.13.
text: By default, a resolving double-faced spell that becomes a permanent is put onto the battlefield with the same face up that was face up on the stack.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 712. Double-Faced Cards : 712.13a
text: Some abilities may cause a transforming double-faced spell with its front face up on the stack to enter the battlefield transformed or converted. If the back face of the card that represents that spell is an instant or sorcery card, or that spell is a copy of a double-faced card created with an instant or sorcery back face, it doesnât enter the battlefield, and is instead put into its ownerâs graveyard.

name: Example for Rule : 712.13a
text: A player controls both Mycosynth Lattice and March of the Machines, the combined effects of which make all permanents artifact creatures in addition to their other types. They also control a Clone on the battlefield that is a copy of Bird Admirer, a creature with daybound. It is currently night, but that permanent canât transform because it isnât represented by a double-faced card. Its controller casts Mystic Reflection targeting it, then casts Invasion of Kylem, a Siege battle whose back face is a sorcery. Because Invasion of Kylem is entering the battlefield as a creature, Mystic Reflectionâs replacement effect applies to it and it tries to enter the battlefield as a copy of Bird Admirer. Since it is night, the daybound ability would normally cause it to enter with its back face up. However, since its back face is a sorcery, it is instead put into its ownerâs graveyard.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 712. Double-Faced Cards : 712.14.
text: A double-faced card put onto the battlefield from a zone other than the stack enters the battlefield with its front face up by default.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 712. Double-Faced Cards : 712.14a
text: If a spell or ability puts a transforming double-faced card onto the battlefield âtransformedâ or âconverted,â it enters the battlefield with its back face up. If a player is instructed to put a card that isnât a transforming double-faced card onto the battlefield transformed or converted, that card stays in its current zone.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 712. Double-Faced Cards : 712.14b
text: If a player is instructed to put a modal double-faced card onto the battlefield and its front face isnât a permanent card, the card stays in its current zone.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 712. Double-Faced Cards : 712.14c
text: If a meld card is being melded with its counterpart, those cards enter the battlefield as a single permanent with their back faces up.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 712. Double-Faced Cards : 712.15.
text: If an effect allows a player to cast a double-faced card as a face-down creature spell, or if a double-faced card enters the battlefield face down, it will have the characteristics given to it by the rule or effect that caused it to be face down. That card remains hidden, using a face-down substitute card (see rule 713) and/or opaque sleeves. See rule 708, âFace-Down Spells and Permanents.â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 712. Double-Faced Cards : 712.15a
text: While face down, a transforming double-faced permanent canât transform or convert. If itâs turned face up, it will have its front face up.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 712. Double-Faced Cards : 712.16.
text: Melded permanents and other double-faced permanents canât be turned face down. If a spell or ability tries to turn a double-faced permanent face down, nothing happens.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 712. Double-Faced Cards : 712.17.
text: A double-faced card that is exiled face down remains hidden, using a face-down substitute card and/or opaque sleeves. See rule 713, âSubstitute Cards.â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 712. Double-Faced Cards : 712.18.
text: When a transforming double-faced permanent transforms or converts, it doesnât become a new object. Any effects that applied to that permanent will continue to apply to it.

name: Example for Rule : 712.18.
text: An effect gives Village Ironsmith (the front face of a transforming double-faced card) +2/+2 until end of turn and then Village Ironsmith transforms into Ironfang. Ironfang will continue to get +2/+2 until end of turn.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 712. Double-Faced Cards : 712.19.
text: If an effect instructs a player to choose a card name, the player may choose the name of either face of a transforming or modal double-faced card but not both. Similarly, they may choose either the name of a front face of a meld card or the combined back face of a meld pair.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 712. Double-Faced Cards : 712.20.
text: If a transforming double-faced card would have an âAs [this permanent] transforms . . .â ability after it transforms or converts, that ability is applied while that permanent is transforming or converting, not afterward.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 712. Double-Faced Cards : 712.21.
text: If a melded permanent leaves the battlefield, one permanent leaves the battlefield and two cards are put into the appropriate zone.

name: Example for Rule : 712.21.
text: Chittering Host, a melded permanent, dies. An ability that triggers âwhenever a creature diesâ triggers once. An ability that triggers âwhenever a card is put into a graveyard from anywhereâ triggers twice.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 712. Double-Faced Cards : 712.21a
text: If a melded permanent is put into its ownerâs graveyard or library, that player may arrange the two cards in any order. If itâs put into its ownerâs library, that player doesnât reveal the order.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 712. Double-Faced Cards : 712.21b
text: If a player exiles a melded permanent, that player determines the relative timestamp order of the two cards at that time. This is an exception to the procedure described in rule 613.7m.

name: Example for Rule : 712.21b
text: Duplicant is a card with the abilities âWhen Duplicant enters the battlefield, you may exile target nontoken creatureâ and âAs long as a card exiled with Duplicant is a creature card, Duplicant has the power, toughness, and creature types of the last creature card exiled with Duplicant. Itâs still a Shapeshifter.â As Duplicantâs first ability exiles Chittering Host, a melded permanent, Duplicantâs controller chooses whether the last creature card exiled is Midnight Scavengers or Graf Rats.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 712. Double-Faced Cards : 712.21c
text: If an effect can find the new object that a melded permanent becomes as it leaves the battlefield, it finds both cards. (See rule 400.7.) If that effect causes actions to be taken upon those cards, the same actions are taken upon each of them.

name: Example for Rule : 712.21c
text: Otherworldly Journey is an instant that reads âExile target creature. At the beginning of the next end step, return that card to the battlefield under its ownerâs control with a +1/+1 counter on it.â A player casts Otherworldly Journey targeting Chittering Host, a melded permanent. Chittering Host is exiled. At the beginning of the next end step, Midnight Scavengers and Graf Rats are both returned to the battlefield, each with a +1/+1 counter on it.

name: Example for Rule : 712.21c
text: False Demise is an Aura with the ability âWhen enchanted creature dies, return that card to the battlefield under your control.â A Chittering Host enchanted by False Demise dies. The triggered ability returns both Midnight Scavengers and Graf Rats to the battlefield.

name: Example for Rule : 712.21c
text: Mimic Vat is an artifact that reads, in part, âWhenever a nontoken creature dies, you may exile that card.â A Chittering Host dies. As Mimic Vatâs triggered ability resolves, its controller makes a single choice and both cards that represented Chittering Host are either exiled or not.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 712. Double-Faced Cards : 712.21d
text: If multiple replacement effects could be applied to the event of a melded permanent leaving the battlefield or being put into the new zone, applying one of those replacement effects to one of the two cards affects both cards. If the melded permanent is a commander, it may be exempt from this rule; see rules 903.9bâc.

name: Example for Rule : 712.21d
text: Leyline of the Void is an enchantment that reads, in part, âIf a card would be put into an opponentâs graveyard from anywhere, exile it instead.â Wheel of Sun and Moon is an Aura with enchant player and the ability âIf a card would be put into enchanted playerâs graveyard from anywhere, instead that card is revealed and put on the bottom of its ownerâs library.â If the controller of Chittering Host is affected by both cardsâ effects, that player chooses one effect to apply to the event and Midnight Scavengers and Graf Rats are both moved to the appropriate zone.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 712. Double-Faced Cards : 712.21e
text: If an effect needs to know the number of objects that changed zones, a melded permanent among those objects counts as one object that moved. If the effect needs to know the number of cards that changed zones, that melded permanent counts as two cards that moved.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 713. Substitute Cards : 713.1.
text: A substitute card is a game supplement that can be used to represent a double-faced card or meld card. A substitute card has a normal Magic card back.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 713. Substitute Cards : 713.2.
text: Each substitute card must clearly indicate the name of at least the front face of the card that it represents. Other information from the printed card (e.g. card type, mana cost, and power and toughness) may also be written on the substitute card.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 713. Substitute Cards : 713.2a
text: Some substitute cards list the names and mana costs of the cards they can represent. Exactly one of the fill-in circles must be marked to denote which card the substitute card represents. This style of substitute card was found in Magic products that released 2011â2018.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 713. Substitute Cards : 713.2b
text: Some substitute cards represent one specific listed card. This style of substitute card was found in the Core Set 2019 release, and it represents the card Nicol Bolas, the Ravager.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 713. Substitute Cards : 713.2c
text: Some substitute cards can represent any modal double-faced card. These substitute cards include the front-face and back-face symbols on the front face of the card. To use one of them, write in the name of each face of the card it represents. This style of substitute card is found in the Zendikar Rising release.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 713. Substitute Cards : 713.3.
text: If a substitute card is used in a deck, the card it represents is set aside prior to the beginning of the game (see rule 103.2a) and must remain available throughout the game. A substitute card canât be included in a deck unless it is representing a double-faced card or a meld card.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 713. Substitute Cards : 713.4.
text: For all game purposes, the substitute card is considered to be the card itâs representing.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 713. Substitute Cards : 713.5.
text: If the substitute card is face up in a public zone, it should be set aside and the double-faced card or meld card that it represents should be used instead.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 714. Saga Cards : 714.1.
text: Each Saga card has a striated text box containing a number of chapter symbols. Its illustration is vertically oriented on the right side of the card, and its type line is along the bottom of the card.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 714. Saga Cards : 714.2.
text: A chapter symbol is a keyword ability that represents a triggered ability referred to as a chapter ability.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 714. Saga Cards : 714.2a
text: A chapter symbol includes a Roman numeral, indicated here as â{rN}.â The numeral I represents 1, II represents 2, III represents 3, and so on.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 714. Saga Cards : 714.2b
text: â{rN}â[Effect]â means âWhen one or more lore counters are put onto this Saga, if the number of lore counters on it was less than N and became at least N, [effect].â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 714. Saga Cards : 714.2c
text: â{rN1}, {rN2}â[Effect]â means the same as â{rN1}â[Effect]â and â{rN2}â[Effect].â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 714. Saga Cards : 714.2d
text: A Sagaâs final chapter number is the greatest value among chapter abilities it has. If a Saga somehow has no chapter abilities, its final chapter number is 0.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 714. Saga Cards : 714.2e
text: A Sagaâs final chapter ability is the chapter ability which has its final chapter number in its chapter symbol.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 714. Saga Cards : 714.3.
text: Sagas use lore counters to track their progress.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 714. Saga Cards : 714.3a
text: As a Saga without the read ahead ability enters the battlefield, its controller puts a lore counter on it. As a Saga with the read ahead ability enters the battlefield, its controller chooses a number from one to that Sagaâs final chapter number. That Saga enters the battlefield with the chosen number of lore counters on it. (See rule 702.155, âRead Ahead.â)

name: Comprehensive Rules: 714. Saga Cards : 714.3b
text: As a playerâs precombat main phase begins, that player puts a lore counter on each Saga they control. This turn-based action doesnât use the stack.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 714. Saga Cards : 714.4.
text: If the number of lore counters on a Saga permanent is greater than or equal to its final chapter number, and it isnât the source of a chapter ability that has triggered but not yet left the stack, that Sagaâs controller sacrifices it. This state-based action doesnât use the stack.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 715. Adventurer Cards : 715.1.
text: Adventurer cards have a two-part card frame, with a smaller frame inset within their text box.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 715. Adventurer Cards : 715.2.
text: The text that appears in the inset frame on the left defines alternative characteristics that the object may have while itâs a spell. The cardâs normal characteristics appear as usual, although with a smaller text box on the right.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 715. Adventurer Cards : 715.2a
text: If an effect refers to a card, spell, or permanent that âhas an Adventure,â it refers to an object for which these alternative characteristics exist, even if the object currently doesnât use them.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 715. Adventurer Cards : 715.2b
text: The existence and values of these alternative characteristics is part of the objectâs copiable values.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 715. Adventurer Cards : 715.2c
text: Although adventurer cards are printed with multiple sets of characteristics, each adventurer card is only one card. For example, a player who has drawn or discarded an adventurer card has drawn or discarded one card, not two.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 715. Adventurer Cards : 715.3.
text: As a player casts an adventurer card, the player chooses whether they cast the card normally or as an Adventure.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 715. Adventurer Cards : 715.3a
text: When casting an adventurer card as an Adventure, only the alternative characteristics are evaluated to see if it can be cast.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 715. Adventurer Cards : 715.3b
text: While on the stack as an Adventure, the spell has only its alternative characteristics.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 715. Adventurer Cards : 715.3c
text: If an Adventure spell is copied, the copy is also an Adventure. It has the alternative characteristics of the spell and not the normal characteristics of the card that represents the Adventure spell. Any rule or effect that refers to a spell cast as an Adventure refers to the copy as well.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 715. Adventurer Cards : 715.3d
text: Instead of putting a spell that was cast as an Adventure into its ownerâs graveyard as it resolves, its controller exiles it. For as long as that card remains exiled, that player may cast it. It canât be cast as an Adventure this way, although other effects that allow a player to cast it may allow a player to cast it as an Adventure.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 715. Adventurer Cards : 715.4.
text: In every zone except the stack, and while on the stack not as an Adventure, an adventurer card has only its normal characteristics.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 715. Adventurer Cards : 715.5.
text: If an effect instructs a player to choose a card name and the player wants to choose an adventurer cardâs alternative name, the player may do so.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 716. Class Cards : 716.1.
text: Each Class card has a striated text box containing two class level bars. Its illustration is vertically oriented on the left side of the card, and its type line is along the bottom of the card.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 716. Class Cards : 716.2.
text: A class level bar is a keyword ability that represents both an activated ability and a static ability. A class level bar includes the activation cost of its activated ability and a level number. Any abilities printed within the same text box section as the class level bar are part of its static ability.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 716. Class Cards : 716.2a
text: â[Cost]: Level N â [Abilities]â means â[Cost]: This Classâs level becomes N. Activate only if this Class is level N-1 and only as a sorceryâ and âAs long as this Class is level N or greater, it has [abilities].â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 716. Class Cards : 716.2b
text: A level is a designation that any permanent can have. A Class retains its level even if it stops being a Class. Levels are not a copiable characteristic.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 716. Class Cards : 716.2c
text: The phrase âto gain a Class levelâ means âto activate an ability indicated by a class level barâ

name: Comprehensive Rules: 716. Class Cards : 716.2d
text: If a rule or effect refers to a permanentâs level and that permanent doesnât have a level, it is treated as though its level is 1.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 716. Class Cards : 716.3.
text: Any ability printed on a Class card that isnât preceded by a class level bar is treated normally. In particular, the Class has the ability printed in its top text box section at all times. That ability may affect the game if itâs a static ability, it may trigger if itâs a triggered ability, and it can be activated if itâs an activated ability.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 716. Class Cards : 716.4.
text: Some older creature cards, called leveler cards, have level up abilities that add level counters to them. These are not the same as class level abilities. Level counters do not interact with Class cards, and class levels do not interact with leveler cards. See rule 702.87, âLevel Up,â and rule 711, âLeveler Cards.â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 717. Attraction Cards : 717.1.
text: Attraction is an artifact subtype seen only on nontraditional Magic cards. Each Attraction has an âAstrotoriumâ card back rather than a traditional Magic card back and has a column of circled numbers on the right side of its text box. Numbers in white text on a brightly colored background are said to be âlit upâ on those cards. Note that multiple Attraction cards with the same English name may have different numbers lit up. You can see each Attraction cardâs possible combinations of lights at Gatherer.Wizards.com.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 717. Attraction Cards : 717.2.
text: Attraction cards do not begin the game in a playerâs deck and do not count toward maximum or minimum deck sizes. Rather, a player who chooses to play with Attraction cards begins the game with a supplementary Attraction deck that exists in the command zone. Each Attraction deck is shuffled before the game begins (see rule 103.3a).

name: Comprehensive Rules: 717. Attraction Cards : 717.2a
text: In constructed play, an Attraction deck must contain at least ten Attraction cards and each card in an Attraction deck must have a different English name.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 717. Attraction Cards : 717.2b
text: In limited play, an Attraction deck must contain at least three Attraction cards from that playerâs card pool, and may contain multiple Attractions cards with the same English name.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 717. Attraction Cards : 717.3.
text: Effects can cause an Attraction card to enter the battlefield from the command zone. See rule 701.48, âOpen an Attraction.â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 717. Attraction Cards : 717.4.
text: As a playerâs precombat main phase begins, a player who controls one or more Attractions rolls to visit their Attractions. See rules 703.4g and 701.49, âRoll to Visit Your Attractions.â This turn-based action doesnât use the stack.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 717. Attraction Cards : 717.5.
text: Each Attraction card has an ability that begins with the word âVisitâ followed by a long dash in its rules text. This is a visit ability. A visit ability triggers whenever you roll to visit your Attractions and the result matches one of the lit-up numbers. See rule 702.159, âVisit.â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 717. Attraction Cards : 717.6.
text: If a card with an Astrotorium card back would be put into a zone other than the battlefield, exile, or the command zone from anywhere, instead its owner puts it into the command zone. This replacement effect may apply more than once to the same event. This is an exception to rule 614.5.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 717. Attraction Cards : 717.6a
text: Each card owned by the same player that has been put in the command zone this way is kept in a single face-up pile separate from any playerâs Attraction deck. This pile is informally referred to as that playerâs âjunkyard.â The pile is not its own zone.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 718. Prototype Cards : 718.1.
text: Prototype cards have a two-part frame, with a smaller frame inset below the type line of the card. The inset frame contains the prototype keyword ability as well as a second set of power, toughness, and mana cost characteristics.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 718. Prototype Cards : 718.2.
text: The mana cost, power, and toughness in the inset frame represent alternative characteristics that the object may have while it is a spell or while it is a permanent on the battlefield. The cardâs normal characteristics appear as usual.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 718. Prototype Cards : 718.2a
text: The existence and values of these alternative characteristics are part of the objectâs copiable values.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 718. Prototype Cards : 718.3.
text: As a player casts a prototype card, the player chooses whether they cast the card normally or cast it as a prototyped spell using the prototype keyword ability (see rule 702.160, âPrototypeâ).

name: Comprehensive Rules: 718. Prototype Cards : 718.3a
text: While casting a prototyped spell, use only its alternative power, toughness, and mana cost when evaluating those characteristics to see if it can be cast.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 718. Prototype Cards : 718.3b
text: Both a prototyped spell and the permanent it becomes have only its alternative set of power, toughness, and mana cost characteristics. If that mana cost includes one or more colored mana symbols, the spell and the permanent it becomes are also that color or colors (see rule 105.2).

name: Comprehensive Rules: 718. Prototype Cards : 718.3c
text: If a prototyped spell is copied, the copy is also a prototyped spell. It has the alternative power, toughness, and mana cost characteristics of the spell and not the normal power, toughness, and mana cost characteristics of the card that represents the prototyped spell. Any rule or effect that refers to a prototyped spell refers to the copy as well.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 718. Prototype Cards : 718.3d
text: If a permanent that was a prototyped spell is copied, the copy has the alternative power, toughness, and mana cost characteristics of the permanent and not the normal power and toughness characteristics of the card that represents that permanent. Any rule or effect that refers to a permanent that was a prototyped spell refers to the copy as well.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 718. Prototype Cards : 718.4.
text: In every zone except the stack or the battlefield, and while on the stack or the battlefield when not cast as a prototyped spell, a prototype card has only its normal characteristics.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 718. Prototype Cards : 718.5.
text: A prototype cardâs characteristics other than its power, toughness, and mana cost (and other than color) remain the same whether it was cast as a prototyped spell or cast normally.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 719. Case Cards : 719.1.
text: Each Case cardâs illustration is vertically oriented on the left side of the card, and its type line is along the bottom of the card.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 719. Case Cards : 719.2.
text: The Case frame has no additional rules meaning.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 719. Case Cards : 719.3.
text: Case cards have two special keyword abilities that appear before a long dash and represent a triggered ability and an ability that may be static, triggered, or activated.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 719. Case Cards : 719.3a
text: âTo solve â [Condition]â means âAt the beginning of your end step, if [condition] and this Case is not solved, this Case becomes solved.â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 719. Case Cards : 719.3b
text: Solved is a designation a permanent can have. It has no rules meaning other than to act as a marker that spells and abilities can identify. Once a permanent becomes solved, it stays solved until it leaves the battlefield. The solved designation is neither an ability nor part of the permanentâs copiable values.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 719. Case Cards : 719.3c
text: If a Case has the solved designation, âSolved â [Ability text]â is an ability that may affect the game if itâs a static ability, it may trigger if itâs a triggered ability, and it can be activated if itâs an activated ability. See rule 702.169, âSolved.â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 720. Controlling Another Player : 720.1.
text: Some cards allow a player to control another player during that playerâs next turn. This effect applies to the next turn that the affected player actually takes. The affected player is controlled during the entire turn; the effect doesnât end until the beginning of the next turn.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 720. Controlling Another Player : 720.1a
text: Multiple player-controlling effects that affect the same player overwrite each other. The last one to be created is the one that works.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 720. Controlling Another Player : 720.1b
text: If a turn is skipped, any pending player-controlling effects wait until the player who would be affected actually takes a turn.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 720. Controlling Another Player : 720.2.
text: Two cards (Word of Command and Opposition Agent) allow a player to control another player for a limited duration.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 720. Controlling Another Player : 720.3.
text: Only control of the player changes. All objects are controlled by their normal controllers. A player whoâs being controlled during their turn is still the active player.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 720. Controlling Another Player : 720.4.
text: If information about an object in the game would be visible to the player being controlled, itâs visible to both that player and the controller of the player. If information about cards outside the game would be visible to the player being controlled, itâs visible only to that player, not the controller of the player.

name: Example for Rule : 720.4.
text: The controller of a player can see that playerâs hand and the face of any face-down creatures they control.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 720. Controlling Another Player : 720.5.
text: While controlling another player, a player makes all choices and decisions the controlled player is allowed to make or is told to make by the rules or by any objects. This includes choices and decisions about what to play, and choices and decisions called for by spells and abilities.

name: Example for Rule : 720.5.
text: The controller of another player decides which spells that player casts and what those spells target, and makes any required decisions when those spells resolve.

name: Example for Rule : 720.5.
text: The controller of another player decides which of that playerâs creatures attack, which player or planeswalker each one attacks, what the damage assignment order of the creatures that block them is (if any of the attacking creatures are blocked by multiple creatures), and how those attacking creatures assign their combat damage.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 720. Controlling Another Player : 720.5a
text: The controller of another player can use only that playerâs resources (cards, mana, and so on) to pay costs for that player.

name: Example for Rule : 720.5a
text: If the controller of a player decides that the controlled player will cast a spell with an additional cost of discarding cards, the cards are discarded from the controlled playerâs hand.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 720. Controlling Another Player : 720.5b
text: The controller of another player canât make choices or decisions for that player that arenât called for by the rules or by any objects. The controller also canât make any choices or decisions for the player that would be called for by the tournament rules.

name: Example for Rule : 720.5b
text: The player whoâs being controlled still decides if they will leave to visit the restroom, trade a card to someone else, agree to an intentional draw, or call a judge about an error or infraction.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 720. Controlling Another Player : 720.6.
text: The controller of another player canât make that player concede. A player may concede the game at any time, even if they are controlled by another player. See rule 104.3a.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 720. Controlling Another Player : 720.7.
text: The effect that gives control of a player to another player may restrict the actions the controlled player is allowed to take or specify actions that the controlled player must take.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 720. Controlling Another Player : 720.8.
text: A player who controls another player also continues to make their own choices and decisions.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 720. Controlling Another Player : 720.9.
text: A player may gain control of themselves. That player will make their own decisions and choices as normal.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 721. Ending Turns and Phases : 721.1.
text: Some cards end the turn. When an effect ends the turn, follow these steps in order, as they differ from the normal process for resolving spells and abilities (see rule 608, âResolving Spells and Abilitiesâ).

name: Comprehensive Rules: 721. Ending Turns and Phases : 721.1a
text: If there are any triggered abilities that triggered before this process began but havenât been put onto the stack yet, those abilities cease to exist. They wonât be put onto the stack. This rule does not apply to abilities that trigger during this process (see rule 721.1f).

name: Comprehensive Rules: 721. Ending Turns and Phases : 721.1b
text: Exile every object on the stack, including the object thatâs resolving. All objects not on the battlefield or in the command zone that arenât represented by cards will cease to exist the next time state-based actions are checked (see rule 704, âState-Based Actionsâ).

name: Comprehensive Rules: 721. Ending Turns and Phases : 721.1c
text: Check state-based actions. No player gets priority, and no triggered abilities are put onto the stack.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 721. Ending Turns and Phases : 721.1d
text: The current phase and/or step ends. If this happens during combat, remove all creatures and planeswalkers from combat. The game skips straight to the cleanup step; skip any phases or steps between this phase or step and the cleanup step. If an effect ends the turn during the cleanup step, a new cleanup step begins.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 721. Ending Turns and Phases : 721.1e
text: Even though the turn ends, âat the beginning of the end stepâ triggered abilities donât trigger because the end step is skipped.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 721. Ending Turns and Phases : 721.1f
text: No player gets priority during this process, so triggered abilities are not put onto the stack. If any triggered abilities have triggered since this process began, those abilities are put onto the stack during the cleanup step, then the active player gets priority and players can cast spells and activate abilities. Then there will be another cleanup step before the turn finally ends. If no triggered abilities have triggered during this process, no player gets priority during the cleanup step. See rule 514, âCleanup Step.â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 721. Ending Turns and Phases : 721.2.
text: One card (Mandate of Peace) ends the combat phase. When an effect ends the combat phase, follow these steps in order, as they differ from the normal process for resolving spells and abilities (see rule 608, âResolving Spells and Abilitiesâ).

name: Comprehensive Rules: 721. Ending Turns and Phases : 721.2a
text: If there are any triggered abilities that triggered before this process began but havenât been put onto the stack yet, those abilities cease to exist. They wonât be put onto the stack. This rule does not apply to abilities that trigger during this process (see rule 721.2f).

name: Comprehensive Rules: 721. Ending Turns and Phases : 721.2b
text: Exile every object on the stack, including the object thatâs resolving. All objects not on the battlefield or in the command zone that arenât represented by cards will cease to exist the next time state-based actions are checked (see rule 704, âState-Based Actionsâ).

name: Comprehensive Rules: 721. Ending Turns and Phases : 721.2c
text: Check state-based actions. No player gets priority, and no triggered abilities are put onto the stack.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 721. Ending Turns and Phases : 721.2d
text: The current combat phase ends. Remove all creatures and planeswalkers from combat. Effects that last âuntil end of combatâ expire. The game skips straight to the next phase, usually the postcombat main phase; skip any steps between this step and that phase.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 721. Ending Turns and Phases : 721.2e
text: Even though the combat phase ends, âat end of combatâ triggered abilities donât trigger because the end of combat step is skipped.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 721. Ending Turns and Phases : 721.2f
text: No player gets priority during this process, so triggered abilities are not put onto the stack. If any triggered abilities have triggered since this process began, those abilities are put onto the stack during the following phase, then the active player gets priority and players can cast spells and activate abilities.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 721. Ending Turns and Phases : 721.2g
text: If an effect attempts to end the combat phase at any time thatâs not a combat phase, nothing happens.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 722. The Monarch : 722.1.
text: The monarch is a designation a player can have. There is no monarch in a game until an effect instructs a player to become the monarch.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 722. The Monarch : 722.2.
text: There are two inherent triggered abilities associated with being the monarch. These triggered abilities have no source and are controlled by the player who was the monarch at the time the abilities triggered. This is an exception to rule 113.8. The full texts of these abilities are âAt the beginning of the monarchâs end step, that player draws a cardâ and âWhenever a creature deals combat damage to the monarch, its controller becomes the monarch.â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 722. The Monarch : 722.3.
text: Only one player can be the monarch at a time. As a player becomes the monarch, the current monarch ceases to be the monarch.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 722. The Monarch : 722.4.
text: If the monarch leaves the game, the active player becomes the monarch at the same time as that player leaves the game. If the active player is leaving the game or if there is no active player, the next player in turn order becomes the monarch. If no player still in the game can become the monarch, the game continues with no monarch.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 722. The Monarch : 722.5.
text: If the result of a continuous effect generated by a static ability is determined based on who is currently the monarch, but there is no monarch in the game as that effect begins to apply, that effect does nothing until a player becomes the monarch. See rule 613, âContinuous Effects.â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 723. The Initiative : 723.1.
text: The initiative is a designation a player can have. There is no initiative in a game until an effect instructs a player to take the initiative. A player who currently has the initiative designation is said to have the initiative.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 723. The Initiative : 723.2.
text: There are three inherent triggered abilities associated with having the initiative. These triggered abilities have no source and are controlled by the player who had the initiative at the time the abilities triggered. This is an exception to rule 113.8. The full text of these abilities are âAt the beginning of the upkeep of the player who has the initiative, that player ventures into Undercity,â âWhenever one or more creatures a player controls deal combat damage to the player who has the initiative, the controller of those creatures takes the initiative,â and âWhenever a player takes the initiative, that player ventures into Undercity.â See rule 701.46, âVenture into the Dungeon.â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 723. The Initiative : 723.3.
text: Only one player can have the initiative at a time. As a player takes the initiative, the player who currently has the initiative ceases to have it.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 723. The Initiative : 723.4.
text: If the player who has the initiative leaves the game, the active player takes the initiative at the same time that player leaves the game. If the active player is leaving the game or if there is no active player, the next player in turn order takes the initiative.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 723. The Initiative : 723.5.
text: If the player who currently has the initiative is instructed to take the initiative, this causes the last triggered ability in 723.2 to trigger but does not create a second initiative designation.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 724. Restarting the Game : 724.1.
text: One card (Karn Liberated) restarts the game. A game that is restarted immediately ends. No players in that game win, lose, or draw that game. All players in that game when it ended then start a new game following the procedures set forth in rule 103, âStarting the Game,â with the following exception:

name: Comprehensive Rules: 724. Restarting the Game : 724.1a
text: The starting player in the new game is the player who controlled the spell or ability that restarted the game.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 724. Restarting the Game : 724.2.
text: All Magic cards involved in the game that was restarted when it ended, including phased-out permanents and nontraditional Magic cards, are involved in the new game, even if those cards were not originally involved in the restarted game. Ownership of cards in the new game doesnât change, regardless of their location when the new game begins.

name: Example for Rule : 724.2.
text: A player casts Living Wish, bringing a creature card into the game from outside the game. Then that game is restarted. The creature card will be part of that playerâs library when the new game begins.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 724. Restarting the Game : 724.3.
text: Because each player draws seven cards when the new game begins, any player with fewer than seven cards in their library will lose the game when state-based actions are checked during the upkeep step of the first turn, regardless of any mulligans that player takes. (See rule 704, âState-Based Actions.â)

name: Comprehensive Rules: 724. Restarting the Game : 724.4.
text: The effect that restarts the game finishes resolving just before the first turnâs untap step. If the spell or ability that generated that effect has additional instructions, those instructions are followed at this time. No player has priority, and any triggered abilities that trigger as a result will go on the stack the next time a player receives priority, usually during the first turnâs upkeep step.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 724. Restarting the Game : 724.5.
text: Effects may exempt certain cards from the procedure that restarts the game. These cards are not in their ownerâs deck as the new game begins.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 724. Restarting the Game : 724.5a
text: In a Commander game, a commander that has been exempted from the procedure that restarts the game wonât begin the new game in the command zone. However, it remains that deckâs commander for the new game. See rule 903, âCommander.â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 724. Restarting the Game : 724.6.
text: If a Magic subgame (see rule 724) is restarted, the main game is unaffected. Main-game effects that refer to the winner or loser of the subgame now refer to the winner or loser of the restarted subgame.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 724. Restarting the Game : 724.7.
text: If a multiplayer game using the limited range of influence option (see rule 801) is restarted, all players in the game are involved, regardless of the range of influence of the player who controls the ability that restarted the game.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 725. Subgames : 725.1.
text: One card (Shahrazad) allows players to play a Magic subgame.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 725. Subgames : 725.1a
text: A âsubgameâ is a completely separate Magic game created by an effect. Essentially, itâs a game within a game. The âmain gameâ is the game in which the spell or ability that created the subgame was cast or activated. The main game is temporarily discontinued while the subgame is in progress. It resumes when the subgame ends.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 725. Subgames : 725.1b
text: No effects or definitions created in either the main game or the subgame have any meaning in the other, except as defined by the effect that created the subgame. For example, the effect may say that something happens in the main game to the winner or loser of the subgame.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 725. Subgames : 725.2.
text: As the subgame starts, an entirely new set of game zones is created. Each player takes all the cards in their main-game library, moves them to their subgame library, and shuffles them. No other cards in a main-game zone are moved to their corresponding subgame zone, except as specified in rules 725.2aâc. Randomly determine which player goes first. The subgame proceeds like a normal game, following all other rules in rule 103, âStarting the Game.â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 725. Subgames : 725.2a
text: As a subgame begins, if one or more supplementary decks of nontraditional cards are being used, each player moves each of their supplementary decks from the main-game command zone to the subgame command zone and shuffles it. (Face-up nontraditional cards remain in the main-game command zone.)

name: Comprehensive Rules: 725. Subgames : 725.2b
text: As a subgame of a Vanguard game starts, each player moves their vanguard card from the main-game command zone to the subgame command zone.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 725. Subgames : 725.2c
text: As a subgame of a Commander game starts, each player moves their commander from the main-game command zone (if itâs there) to the subgame command zone.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 725. Subgames : 725.3.
text: Because each player draws seven cards when a game begins, any player with fewer than seven cards in their deck will lose the subgame when state-based actions are checked during the upkeep step of the first turn, regardless of any mulligans that player takes. (See rule 704, âState-Based Actions.â)

name: Comprehensive Rules: 725. Subgames : 725.4.
text: All objects in the main game and all cards outside the main game are considered outside the subgame (except those specifically brought into the subgame). All players not currently in the subgame are considered outside the subgame.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 725. Subgames : 725.4a
text: Some effects can bring cards into a game from outside of it. If a card is brought into a subgame from a main game, abilities in the main game that trigger on objects leaving a main-game zone will trigger, but they wonât be put onto the stack until the main game resumes.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 725. Subgames : 725.4b
text: A playerâs main-game counters arenât considered part of the subgame, although the player will still have them when the main game resumes. Similarly, any counters a player gets during a subgame will cease to exist when the subgame ends.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 725. Subgames : 725.5.
text: At the end of a subgame, each player takes all traditional cards they own that are in the subgame other than those in the subgame command zone, puts them into their main-game library, then shuffles them. This includes cards in the subgameâs exile zone and cards that represent phased-out permanents as the subgame ends. Except as specified in rules 725.5aâc, all other objects in the subgame cease to exist, as do the zones created for the subgame. The main game continues from the point at which it was discontinued: First, the spell or ability that created the subgame finishes resolving, even if it was created by a spell card thatâs no longer on the stack. Then, if any main-game abilities triggered while the subgame was in progress due to cards being removed from the main game, those abilities are put onto the stack.

name: Example for Rule : 725.5.
text: If a card was brought into the subgame either from the main game or from outside the main game, that card will be put into its ownerâs main-game library when the subgame ends.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 725. Subgames : 725.5a
text: At the end of a subgame, each nontraditional card not in a supplementary deck that began the subgame in a supplementary deck is turned face down and put on the bottom of that deck. Then each player moves each of their supplementary decks from the subgame command zone to the main-game command zone and shuffles it.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 725. Subgames : 725.5b
text: At the end of a subgame of a Vanguard game, each player moves their vanguard card from the subgame command zone to the main-game command zone. This is an exception to rule 313.2.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 725. Subgames : 725.5c
text: At the end of a subgame of a Commander game, each player moves their commander from the subgame command zone (if itâs there) to the main-game command zone.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 725. Subgames : 725.6.
text: A subgame can be created within a subgame. The existing subgame becomes the main game in relation to the new subgame.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 726. Merging with Permanents : 726.1.
text: One keyword causes an object to merge with a permanent. See rule 702.140, âMutate.â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 726. Merging with Permanents : 726.2.
text: To merge an object with a permanent, place that object on top of or under that permanent. That permanent becomes a merged permanent represented by the card or copy that represented that object in addition to any other components that were representing it.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 726. Merging with Permanents : 726.2a
text: A merged permanent has only the characteristics of its topmost component, unless otherwise specified by the effect that caused them to merge. This is a copiable effect whose timestamp is the time the objects merged. (See rule 613.2.)

name: Comprehensive Rules: 726. Merging with Permanents : 726.2b
text: As an object merges with a permanent, that object leaves its previous zone and becomes part of an object on the battlefield, but the resulting permanent isnât considered to have just entered the battlefield.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 726. Merging with Permanents : 726.2c
text: Because a merged permanent is the same object that it was before, it hasnât just come under a playerâs control, any continuous effects that affected it continue to do so, and so on.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 726. Merging with Permanents : 726.2d
text: If a merged permanent contains a token, the resulting permanent is a token only if the topmost component is a token.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 726. Merging with Permanents : 726.2e
text: If a merged permanent contains face-up and face-down components, the permanentâs status is determined by its topmost component. If a face-down permanent becomes a face-up permanent as a result of an object merging with it, other effects donât count it as being turned face up.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 726. Merging with Permanents : 726.2f
text: If a merged permanent is turned face down, each face-up component that represents it is turned face down. If a face-down merged permanent is turned face up, each face-down component that represents it is turned face up.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 726. Merging with Permanents : 726.2g
text: A face-down merged permanent that contains an instant or sorcery card canât be turned face up. If such a permanent would turn face up, its controller reveals it and leaves it face down. Abilities that trigger when a permanent is turned face up wonât trigger.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 726. Merging with Permanents : 726.2h
text: If a merged permanent contains a flip card (see rule 710), that componentâs alternative characteristics are used instead of its normal characteristics if the merged permanent is flipped.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 726. Merging with Permanents : 726.2i
text: A merged permanent is not a double-faced permanent even if it contains one or more double-faced components. If a merged permanent contains one or more transforming double-faced components (see rule 712), transforming that permanent causes each of those double-faced components to turn so that its other face is up.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 726. Merging with Permanents : 726.2j
text: A face-up merged permanent that contains a double-faced component canât be turned face down.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 726. Merging with Permanents : 726.3.
text: If a merged permanent leaves the battlefield, one permanent leaves the battlefield and each of the individual components are put into the appropriate zone.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 726. Merging with Permanents : 726.3a
text: If a merged permanent is put into its ownerâs graveyard or library, that player may arrange the new objects in any order. If itâs put into its ownerâs library, that player doesnât reveal the order.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 726. Merging with Permanents : 726.3b
text: If a player exiles a merged permanent, that player determines the relative timestamp order of the cards at that time. This is an exception to the procedure described in rule 613.7m.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 726. Merging with Permanents : 726.3c
text: If an effect can find the new object that a merged permanent becomes as it leaves the battlefield, it finds all of those objects. (See rule 400.7.) If that effect causes actions to be taken upon those objects, the same actions are taken upon each of them.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 726. Merging with Permanents : 726.3d
text: If multiple replacement effects could be applied to the event of a merged permanent leaving the battlefield or being put into the new zone, applying one of those replacement effects to the object applies it to all components of the object. If the merged permanent is a commander, it may be exempt from this rule; see rules 903.9bâc.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 726. Merging with Permanents : 726.3e
text: If a replacement effect applies to a âcardâ being put into a zone without also including tokens, that effect applies to all components of the merged permanent if itâs not a token, including components that are tokens. If the merged permanent is a token but some of its components are cards, the merged permanent and its token components are put into the appropriate zone, and the components that are cards are moved by the replacement effect.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 727. Day and Night : 727.1.
text: Day and night are designations that the game itself can have. The game starts with neither designation. âIt becomes dayâ and âit becomes nightâ refer to the game gaining the day or night designation. It can become day or night through the daybound and nightbound keyword abilities (see rule 702.145). Other effects can also make it day or night. Once it has become day or night, the game will have exactly one of those designations from that point forward.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 727. Day and Night : 727.1a
text: The phrases âday becomes nightâ and ânight becomes dayâ refer to the game losing the first designation and gaining the second one.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 727. Day and Night : 727.2.
text: As the second part of the untap step, the game checks the previous turn to see if the gameâs day/night designation should change. See rule 502, âUntap Step.â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 727. Day and Night : 727.2a
text: If itâs day and the previous turnâs active player didnât cast any spells during that turn, it becomes night. Multiplayer games using the shared team turns option (see rule 805) use a modified rule: if itâs day and no player from the previous turnâs active team cast a spell during that turn, it becomes night.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 727. Day and Night : 727.2b
text: If itâs night, and previous turnâs active player cast two or more spells during the previous turn, it becomes day. Multiplayer games using the shared team turns option (see rule 805) use a modified rule: if itâs night and any player from the previous turnâs active team cast two or more spells during that turn, it becomes day.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 727. Day and Night : 727.2c
text: If itâs neither day nor night, this check doesnât happen and it remains neither.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 728. Taking Shortcuts : 728.1.
text: When playing a game, players typically make use of mutually understood shortcuts rather than explicitly identifying each game choice (either taking an action or passing priority) a player makes.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 728. Taking Shortcuts : 728.1a
text: The rules for taking shortcuts are largely informal. As long as each player in the game understands the intent of each other player, any shortcut system they use is acceptable.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 728. Taking Shortcuts : 728.1b
text: Occasionally the game gets into a state in which a set of actions could be repeated indefinitely (thus creating a âloopâ). In that case, the shortcut rules can be used to determine how many times those actions are repeated without having to actually perform them, and how the loop is broken.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 728. Taking Shortcuts : 728.1c
text: Tournaments use a modified version of the rules governing shortcuts and loops. These rules are covered in the Magic: The Gathering Tournament Rules (found at WPN.Wizards.com/en/resources/rules-documents). Whenever the Tournament Rules contradict these rules during a tournament, the Tournament Rules take precedence.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 728. Taking Shortcuts : 728.2.
text: Taking a shortcut follows the following procedure.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 728. Taking Shortcuts : 728.2a
text: At any point in the game, the player with priority may suggest a shortcut by describing a sequence of game choices, for all players, that may be legally taken based on the current game state and the predictable results of the sequence of choices. This sequence may be a non-repetitive series of choices, a loop that repeats a specified number of times, multiple loops, or nested loops, and may even cross multiple turns. It canât include conditional actions, where the outcome of a game event determines the next action a player takes. The ending point of this sequence must be a place where a player has priority, though it need not be the player proposing the shortcut.

name: Example for Rule : 728.2a
text: A player controls a creature enchanted by Presence of Gond, which grants the creature the ability â{T}: Create a 1/1 green Elf Warrior creature token,â and another player controls Intruder Alarm, which reads, in part, âWhenever a creature enters the battlefield, untap all creatures.â When the player has priority, they may suggest âIâll create a million tokens,â indicating the sequence of activating the creatureâs ability, all players passing priority, letting the creatureâs ability resolve and create a token (which causes Intruder Alarmâs ability to trigger), Intruder Alarmâs controller putting that triggered ability on the stack, all players passing priority, Intruder Alarmâs triggered ability resolving, all players passing priority until the player proposing the shortcut has priority, and repeating that sequence 999,999 more times, ending just after the last token-creating ability resolves.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 728. Taking Shortcuts : 728.2b
text: Each other player, in turn order starting after the player who suggested the shortcut, may either accept the proposed sequence, or shorten it by naming a place where they will make a game choice thatâs different than whatâs been proposed. (The player doesnât need to specify at this time what the new choice will be.) This place becomes the new ending point of the proposed sequence.

name: Example for Rule : 728.2b
text: The active player draws a card during her draw step, then says, âGo.â The nonactive player is holding Into the Fray (an instant that says âTarget creature attacks this turn if ableâ) and says, âIâd like to cast a spell during your beginning of combat step.â The current proposed shortcut is that all players pass priority at all opportunities during the turn until the nonactive player has priority during the beginning of combat step.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 728. Taking Shortcuts : 728.2c
text: Once the last player has either accepted or shortened the shortcut proposal, the shortcut is taken. The game advances to the last proposed ending point, with all game choices contained in the shortcut proposal having been taken. If the shortcut was shortened from the original proposal, the player who now has priority must make a different game choice than what was originally proposed for that player.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 728. Taking Shortcuts : 728.3.
text: Sometimes a loop can be fragmented, meaning that each player involved in the loop performs an independent action that results in the same game state being reached multiple times. If that happens, the active player (or, if the active player is not involved in the loop, the first player in turn order who is involved) must then make a different game choice so the loop does not continue.

name: Example for Rule : 728.3.
text: In a two-player game, the active player controls a creature with the ability â{0}: [This creature] gains flying,â the nonactive player controls a permanent with the ability â{0}: Target creature loses flying,â and nothing in the game cares how many times an ability has been activated. Say the active player activates his creatureâs ability, it resolves, then the nonactive player activates her permanentâs ability targeting that creature, and it resolves. This returns the game to a game state it was at before. The active player must make a different game choice (in other words, anything other than activating that creatureâs ability again). The creature doesnât have flying. Note that the nonactive player could have prevented the fragmented loop simply by not activating her permanentâs ability, in which case the creature would have had flying. The nonactive player always has the final choice and is therefore able to determine whether the creature has flying.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 728. Taking Shortcuts : 728.4.
text: If a loop contains only mandatory actions, the game is a draw. (See rules 104.4b and 104.4f.)

name: Comprehensive Rules: 728. Taking Shortcuts : 728.5.
text: No player can be forced to perform an action that would end a loop other than actions called for by objects involved in the loop.

name: Example for Rule : 728.5.
text: A player controls Seal of Cleansing, an enchantment that reads, âSacrifice Seal of Cleansing: Destroy target artifact or enchantment.â A mandatory loop that involves an artifact begins. The player is not forced to sacrifice Seal of Cleansing to destroy the artifact and end the loop.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 728. Taking Shortcuts : 728.6.
text: If a loop contains an effect that says â[A] unless [B],â where [A] and [B] are each actions, no player can be forced to perform [B] to break the loop. If no player chooses to perform [B], the loop will continue as though [A] were mandatory.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 729. Handling Illegal Actions : 729.1.
text: If a player takes an illegal action or starts to take an action but canât legally complete it, the entire action is reversed and any payments already made are canceled. No abilities trigger and no effects apply as a result of an undone action. If the action was casting a spell, the spell returns to the zone it came from. Each player may also reverse any legal mana abilities that player activated while making the illegal play, unless mana from those abilities or from any triggered mana abilities they caused to trigger was spent on another mana ability that wasnât reversed. Players may not reverse actions that moved cards to a library, moved cards from a library to any zone other than the stack, caused a library to be shuffled, or caused cards from a library to be revealed.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 729. Handling Illegal Actions : 729.2.
text:
When reversing illegal spells and abilities, the player who had priority retains it and may take another action or pass. The player may redo the reversed action in a legal way or take any other action allowed by the rules.

8. Multiplayer Rules

name: Comprehensive Rules: 800. General : 800.1.
text: A multiplayer game is a game that begins with more than two players. This section contains additional optional rules that can be used for multiplayer play.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 800. General : 800.2.
text: These rules consist of a series of options that can be added to a multiplayer game and a number of variant styles of multiplayer play. A single game may use multiple options but only one variant.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 800. General : 800.3.
text: Many multiplayer Magic tournaments have additional rules not included here, including rules for deck construction. See the most current Magic: The Gathering Tournament Rules for more information. They can be found at WPN.Wizards.com/en/resources/rules-documents.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 800. General : 800.4.
text: Unlike two-player games, multiplayer games can continue after one or more players have left the game.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 800. General : 800.4a
text: When a player leaves the game, all objects (see rule 109) owned by that player leave the game and any effects which give that player control of any objects or players end. Then, if that player controlled any objects on the stack not represented by cards, those objects cease to exist. Then, if there are any objects still controlled by that player, those objects are exiled. This is not a state-based action. It happens as soon as the player leaves the game. If the player who left the game had priority at the time they left, priority passes to the next player in turn order whoâs still in the game.

name: Example for Rule : 800.4a
text: Alex casts Mind Control, an Aura that reads, âYou control enchanted creature,â on Biancaâs Assault Griffin. If Alex leaves the game, so does Mind Control, and Assault Griffin reverts to Biancaâs control. If, instead, Bianca leaves the game, so does Assault Griffin, and Mind Control is put into Alexâs graveyard.

name: Example for Rule : 800.4a
text: Alex casts Act of Treason, which reads, in part, âGain control of target creature until end of turn,â targeting Biancaâs Runeclaw Bears. If Alex leaves the game, Act of Treasonâs change-of-control effect ends and Runeclaw Bears reverts to Biancaâs control.

name: Example for Rule : 800.4a
text: Alex casts Bribery, which reads, âSearch target opponentâs library for a creature card and put that card onto the battlefield under your control. Then that player shuffles their library,â targeting Bianca. Alex puts Serra Angel onto the battlefield from Biancaâs library. If Bianca leaves the game, Serra Angel also leaves the game. If, instead, Alex leaves the game, Serra Angel is exiled.

name: Example for Rule : 800.4a
text: Alex controls Genesis Chamber, which reads, âWhenever a nontoken creature enters the battlefield, if Genesis Chamber is untapped, that creatureâs controller creates a 1/1 colorless Myr artifact creature token.â If Alex leaves the game, all such Myr tokens that entered the battlefield under Alexâs control leave the game, and all such Myr tokens that entered the battlefield under any other playerâs control remain in the game.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 800. General : 800.4b
text: If an object would change to the control of a player who has left the game, it doesnât. If a token would be created under the control of a player who has left the game, no token is created. If an object would be put onto the battlefield or onto the stack under the control of a player who has left the game, that object remains in its current zone. If a player would be controlled by a player who has left the game, they arenât.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 800. General : 800.4c
text: If an effect that gives a player still in the game control of an object ends, there is no other effect giving control of that object to another player in the game, and the player who controlled that object by default has left the game, the object is exiled. This is not a state-based action. It happens as soon as the control-changing effect ends.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 800. General : 800.4d
text: If an object that would be owned by a player who has left the game would be created in any zone, it isnât created. If a triggered ability that would be controlled by a player who has left the game would be put onto the stack, it isnât put on the stack.

name: Example for Rule : 800.4d
text: Astral Slide is an enchantment that reads, âWhenever a player cycles a card, you may exile target creature. If you do, return that creature to the battlefield under its ownerâs control at the beginning of the next end step.â During Alexâs turn, Bianca uses Astral Slideâs ability to exile Alexâs Hypnotic Specter. Before the end of that turn, Bianca leaves the game. At the beginning of the end step, the delayed triggered ability generated by Astral Slide that would return Hypnotic Specter to the battlefield triggers, but it isnât put on the stack. Hypnotic Specter never returns to the battlefield.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 800. General : 800.4e
text: If combat damage would be assigned to a player who has left the game, that damage isnât assigned.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 800. General : 800.4f
text: If an object requires a player who has left the game to pay a cost or choose whether to pay a cost, that cost is not paid.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 800. General : 800.4g
text: If an object requires a player who has left the game to make a choice other than whether to pay a cost, the controller of the object chooses another player to make that choice. If the original choice was to be made by an opponent of the controller of the object, that player chooses another opponent if possible.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 800. General : 800.4h
text: If a rule requires a player who has left the game to make a choice, the next player in turn order makes that choice.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 800. General : 800.4i
text: If an effect requires information about a specific player, the effect uses the current information about that player if they are still in the game; otherwise, the effect uses the last known information about that player before they left the game. If an effect requires information from the game about actions players have taken, the effect can find actions that were taken by a player who has left the game.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 800. General : 800.4j
text: If a player leaves the game during their turn, that turn continues to its completion without an active player. If the active player would receive priority, instead the next player in turn order receives priority, or the top object on the stack resolves, or the phase or step ends, whichever is appropriate.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 800. General : 800.4k
text: If a player who has left the game would begin a turn, that turn doesnât begin.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 800. General : 800.4m
text: When a player leaves the game, any continuous effects with durations that last until that playerâs next turn or until a specific point in that turn will last until that turn would have begun. They neither expire immediately nor last indefinitely.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 800. General : 800.4n
text: When a player leaves the game, objects that player owns in the ante zone do not leave the game. This is an exception to rule 800.4a. See rule 407, âAnte.â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 800. General : 800.4p
text: In a Planechase game, if the player designated as the planar controller would leave the game, instead the next player in turn order that wouldnât leave the game becomes the planar controller, then the old planar controller leaves the game. See rule 311.5.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 800. General : 800.5.
text: Unless a chosen variant or option prescribes otherwise, seating order is determined by any mutually agreeable method. For example, players could agree to remain where they were before the game began, roll dice to determine seating order, and so on.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 800. General : 800.6.
text: In a multiplayer game, the first mulligan a player takes doesnât count toward the number of cards that player will put on the bottom of their library or the number of mulligans that player may take. Subsequent mulligans are counted toward these numbers as normal.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 800. General : 800.7.
text: In a multiplayer game other than a Two-Headed Giant game, the starting player doesnât skip the draw step of their first turn. In a Two-Headed Giant game, the team who plays first skips the draw step of their first turn. See rule 103.8.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 801. Limited Range of Influence Option : 801.1.
text: Limited range of influence is an option that can be applied to most multiplayer games. Itâs always used in the Emperor variant (see rule 809), and itâs often used for games involving five or more players.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 801. Limited Range of Influence Option : 801.2.
text: A playerâs range of influence is the maximum distance from that player, measured in player seats, that the player can affect. Players within that many seats of the player are within that playerâs range of influence. Objects controlled by players within a playerâs range of influence are also within that playerâs range of influence. Range of influence covers spells, abilities, effects, damage dealing, attacking, making choices, and winning the game.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 801. Limited Range of Influence Option : 801.2a
text: The most commonly chosen limited ranges of influence are 1 seat and 2 seats. Different players may have different ranges of influence.

name: Example for Rule : 801.2a
text: A range of influence of 1 means that only you and the players seated directly next to you are within your range of influence.

name: Example for Rule : 801.2a
text: A range of influence of 2 means that you and the two players to your left and the two players to your right are within your range of influence.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 801. Limited Range of Influence Option : 801.2b
text: A player is always within their own range of influence.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 801. Limited Range of Influence Option : 801.2c
text: The particular players within each playerâs range of influence are determined as each turn begins.

name: Example for Rule : 801.2c
text: In a game with a range of influence of 1, Alex is seated to the left of Rob, and Carissa is seated to the right of Rob. Carissa is not in Alexâs range of influence. If Rob leaves the game, Carissa will enter Alexâs range of influence at the start of the next turn.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 801. Limited Range of Influence Option : 801.2d
text: An object is within a playerâs range of influence if itâs controlled by that player or by another player within that many seats of that player. In addition, a battle is within a playerâs range of influence if itâs protected by that player or by another player within that many seats of that player.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 801. Limited Range of Influence Option : 801.3.
text: Creatures can attack only opponents within their controllerâs range of influence, planeswalkers controlled by those opponents, and battles protected by those opponents. If no opponents are within a playerâs range of influence, creatures that player controls canât attack.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 801. Limited Range of Influence Option : 801.4.
text: Objects and players outside a playerâs range of influence canât be the targets of spells or abilities that player controls.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 801. Limited Range of Influence Option : 801.5.
text: Some cards require players to make choices. These cards work differently when the limited range of influence option is used.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 801. Limited Range of Influence Option : 801.5a
text: If a player is asked to choose an object or player, they must choose one within their range of influence.

name: Example for Rule : 801.5a
text: In a game with a range of influence of 1, Alex is seated to the left of Rob. Alex activates the ability of Cuombajj Witches, which reads, â{T}: Cuombajj Witches deals 1 damage to any target and 1 damage to any target of an opponentâs choice,â targeting Rob and choosing Rob as the opponent who picks the other target. Rob must choose a target thatâs in both his range of influence and in the range of influence of the controller of Cuombajj Witches. He must therefore choose himself, Alex, or a creature controlled by either himself or Alex.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 801. Limited Range of Influence Option : 801.5b
text: If a player is asked to choose between one or more options (and not between one or more objects or players), they can choose between those options even if those options refer to objects or players outside the playerâs range of influence.

name: Example for Rule : 801.5b
text: Alex, who has a range of influence of 2, is seated to the left of Rob, and Carissa, who has a range of influence of 1, is seated to the right of Rob. Alex casts a spell that reads, âAn opponent chooses one â You draw two cards; or each creature you control gets +2/+2 until end of turn,â and chooses Carissa to make that choice. Carissa can choose the mode even though Alex is out of her range.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 801. Limited Range of Influence Option : 801.5c
text: If an effect requires a choice and thereâs no player who can make that choice within its controllerâs range of influence, the closest appropriate player to its controllerâs left makes that choice.

name: Example for Rule : 801.5c
text: In an Emperor game in which all players have range of influence 1, an emperor casts Fact or Fiction, which reads, âReveal the top five cards of your library. An opponent separates those cards into two piles. Put one pile into your hand and the other into your graveyard.â Since no opponent is within the emperorâs range of influence, the nearest opponent to the emperorâs left separates the cards into piles.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 801. Limited Range of Influence Option : 801.6.
