text: A player canât activate the activated abilities of an object outside of their range of influence.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 801. Limited Range of Influence Option : 801.7.
text: A triggered ability doesnât trigger unless its trigger event happens entirely within the range of influence of its sourceâs controller.

name: Example for Rule : 801.7.
text: In a game in which all players have range of influence 1, Alex is seated to the left of Rob. Rob controls two Auras attached to Alexâs Runeclaw Bear: One with the trigger condition âWhenever enchanted creature becomes blocked,â and one with the trigger condition âWhenever enchanted creature becomes blocked by a creature.â Alexâs Runeclaw Bear attacks the player to Alexâs left and becomes blocked. The ability of Robâs first Aura triggers because the entire event (Runeclaw Bear becomes blocked) happens within Robâs range of influence. The ability of Robâs second Aura doesnât trigger, however, because that event includes the blocking creature, which is out of Robâs range.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 801. Limited Range of Influence Option : 801.7a
text: If a trigger event includes an object moving out of or into a playerâs range of influence, use the game state before or after the event as appropriate to determine whether the triggered ability will trigger. See rules 603.6 and 603.10.

name: Example for Rule : 801.7a
text: Carissa and Alex are outside each otherâs range of influence. Carissa controls a Runeclaw Bear owned by Alex and they each control an Extractor Demon, a creature which reads, in part, âWhenever another creature leaves the battlefield, you may have target player mill two cards.â The Runeclaw Bear is destroyed and is put into Alexâs graveyard. The ability of Alexâs Extractor Demon doesnât trigger because the leaves-the-battlefield event was outside Alexâs range of influence. The ability of Carissaâs Extractor Demon does trigger, even though the creature is going to a graveyard outside her range, because the leaves-the-battlefield event was within her range.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 801. Limited Range of Influence Option : 801.8.
text: An Aura canât enchant an object or player outside its controllerâs range of influence. If an Aura is attached to an illegal object or player, the Aura is put into its ownerâs graveyard as a state-based action. See rule 704.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 801. Limited Range of Influence Option : 801.9.
text: An Equipment canât equip an object outside its controllerâs range of influence, and a Fortification canât fortify an object outside its controllerâs range of influence. If an Equipment or Fortification is attached to an illegal permanent, it becomes unattached from that permanent but remains on the battlefield. This is a state-based action. See rule 704.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 801. Limited Range of Influence Option : 801.10.
text: Spells and abilities canât affect objects or players outside their controllerâs range of influence. The parts of the effect that attempt to affect an out-of-range object or player will do nothing. The rest of the effect will work normally.

name: Example for Rule : 801.10.
text: In a six-player game in which each player has range of influence 1, Alex casts Pyroclasm, which reads, âPyroclasm deals 2 damage to each creature.â Pyroclasm deals 2 damage to each creature controlled by Alex, the player to Alexâs left, and the player to Alexâs right. No other creatures are dealt damage.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 801. Limited Range of Influence Option : 801.11.
text: If a spell or ability requires information from the game, it gets only information from within its controllerâs range of influence. It doesnât see objects or events outside its controllerâs range of influence.

name: Example for Rule : 801.11.
text: In a six-player game where each player has range of influence 1, Alex controls Coat of Arms, which reads, âEach creature gets +1/+1 for each other creature on the battlefield that shares at least one creature type with it.â Coat of Arms will boost Alexâs creatures based only on what creatures are controlled by Alex, the player to Alexâs left, and the player to Alexâs right. It wonât take other creatures into account.

name: Example for Rule : 801.11.
text: In the same game, Rob is sitting to the right of Alex. Coat of Arms will boost Robâs creatures based on what creatures are controlled by players within Alexâs range of influence, including the player sitting to Alexâs left, whoâs out of Robâs range of influence.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 801. Limited Range of Influence Option : 801.12.
text: The âworld ruleâ (see rule 704.5k) applies to a permanent only if other world permanents are within its controllerâs range of influence.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 801. Limited Range of Influence Option : 801.13.
text: Replacement and prevention effects watch for a particular event to happen and then completely or partially replace that event. The limited range of influence option can cause the modified event to contain instructions that canât be carried out, in which case the player simply ignores the impossible instructions. See rule 614, âReplacement Effects,â and rule 615, âPrevention Effects.â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 801. Limited Range of Influence Option : 801.13a
text: If a replacement effect tries to cause a spell or ability to affect an object or player outside its controllerâs range of influence, that portion of the event does nothing.

name: Example for Rule : 801.13a
text: Alex casts Lava Axe (âLava Axe deals 5 damage to target player or planeswalker.â) targeting Rob. In response, Rob casts Captainâs Maneuver (âThe next X damage that would be dealt to target creature, planeswalker, or player this turn is dealt to another target creature, planeswalker, or player instead.â) with X equal to 3, targeting Carissa. Carissa isnât in Alexâs range of influence. When Lava Axe resolves, it deals 2 damage to Rob and no damage to Carissa.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 801. Limited Range of Influence Option : 801.13b
text: If a spell or ability creates an effect that prevents damage that would be dealt by a source, it can affect only sources within the spell or abilityâs controllerâs range of influence. If a spell or ability creates an effect that prevents damage that would be dealt to a permanent or player, it can affect only permanents and players within the spell or abilityâs controllerâs range of influence. If a spell or ability creates an effect that prevents damage, but neither the source nor the would-be recipient of the damage is specified, it prevents damage only if both the source and recipient of that damage are within the spell or abilityâs controllerâs range of influence.

name: Example for Rule : 801.13b
text: Rob is within Alexâs range of influence, but Carissa is not. Alex controls an enchantment that says, âPrevent all damage that would be dealt by creatures.â Carissa attacks Rob with a creature. The creature deals combat damage to Rob.

name: Example for Rule : 801.13b
text: Rob is within Alexâs range of influence, but Carissa is not. Carissa casts Lightning Blast (âLightning Blast deals 4 damage to any target.â) targeting Rob. In response, Alex casts Mending Hands (âPrevent the next 4 damage that would be dealt to any target this turn.â) targeting Rob. The damage to Rob is prevented.

name: Example for Rule : 801.13b
text: Rob is within Alexâs range of influence, but Carissa is not. Carissa attacks Rob with a creature, and Rob blocks with a creature. Alex casts Fog (âPrevent all combat damage that would be dealt this turn.â) Carissa and Robâs creatures deal combat damage to each other.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 801. Limited Range of Influence Option : 801.14.
text: If an effect states that a player wins the game, all of that playerâs opponents within that playerâs range of influence lose the game instead.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 801. Limited Range of Influence Option : 801.15.
text: If the effect of a spell or ability states that the game is a draw, the game is a draw for that spell or abilityâs controller and all players within that playerâs range of influence. They leave the game. All remaining players continue to play the game.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 801. Limited Range of Influence Option : 801.16.
text: If the game somehow enters a âloopâ of mandatory actions, repeating a sequence of events with no way to stop, the game is a draw for each player who controls an object thatâs involved in that loop, as well as for each player within the range of influence of any of those players. They leave the game. All remaining players continue to play the game.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 801. Limited Range of Influence Option : 801.17.
text: Effects that restart the game (see rule 723) are exempt from the limited range of influence option. All players in the game will be involved in the new game.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 801. Limited Range of Influence Option : 801.18.
text: In multiplayer Planechase games other than Grand Melee games, plane cards and phenomenon cards are exempt from the limited range of influence option. Their abilities, and the effects of those abilities, affect all applicable objects and players in the game. See rule 901, âPlanechase.â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 802. Attack Multiple Players Option : 802.1.
text: Some multiplayer games allow the active player to attack multiple other players. If this option is used, a player can also choose to attack only one player during a particular combat.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 802. Attack Multiple Players Option : 802.2.
text: As the combat phase starts, the attacking player doesnât choose an opponent to become the defending player. Instead, all the attacking playerâs opponents are defending players during the combat phase.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 802. Attack Multiple Players Option : 802.2a
text: Any rule, object, or effect that refers to a âdefending playerâ refers to one specific defending player, not to all of the defending players. If an ability of an attacking creature refers to a defending player, or a spell or ability refers to both an attacking creature and a defending player, then unless otherwise specified, the defending player itâs referring to is the player that creature is attacking, the controller of the planeswalker that creature is attacking, or the protector of the battle that player is attacking. If that creature is no longer attacking, the defending player itâs referring to is the player that creature was attacking before it was removed from combat, the controller of the planeswalker that creature was attacking before it was removed from combat, or the protector of the battle that player was attacking before it was removed from combat. If a spell or ability could apply to multiple attacking creatures, the appropriate defending player is individually determined for each of those attacking creatures. If there are multiple defending players that could be chosen, the controller of the spell or ability chooses one.

name: Example for Rule : 802.2a
text: Rob attacks Alex with Runeclaw Bear and attacks Carissa with a creature with mountainwalk. Whether the creature with mountainwalk can be blocked depends only on whether Carissa controls a Mountain.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 802. Attack Multiple Players Option : 802.3.
text: As the attacking player declares each attacking creature, they choose a defending player, a planeswalker controlled by a defending player, or a battle protected by a defending player for it to attack. See rule 508, âDeclare Attackers Step.â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 802. Attack Multiple Players Option : 802.3a
text: Restrictions and requirements that donât apply to attacking a specific player are evaluated based on the entire group of attacking creatures. Restrictions and requirements that apply to attacking a specific player apply only to creatures attacking that player. The entire group of attacking creatures must still be legal. See rule 508.1.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 802. Attack Multiple Players Option : 802.3b
text: Creatures in a band canât attack different players. See rule 702.22, âBanding.â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 802. Attack Multiple Players Option : 802.4.
text: If more than one player is being attacked, controls a planeswalker thatâs being attacked, or protects a battle thatâs being attacked, each defending player in APNAP order declares blockers as the declare blockers step begins. (See rule 101.4 and rule 509, âDeclare Blockers Step.â) The first defending player declares all their blocks, then the second defending player, and so on.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 802. Attack Multiple Players Option : 802.4a
text: A defending player can block only with creatures they control. Those creatures can block only creatures attacking that player, a planeswalker that player controls, or a battle that player protects.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 802. Attack Multiple Players Option : 802.4b
text: When determining whether a defending playerâs blocks are legal, ignore any creatures attacking other players and any blocking creatures controlled by other players.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 802. Attack Multiple Players Option : 802.5.
text: After blockers have been declared, if any creatures are blocking multiple creatures, each defending player in APNAP order announces the damage assignment order among the attacking creatures for each blocking creature they control. See rule 510, âCombat Damage Step.â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 802. Attack Multiple Players Option : 802.6.
text: Combat damage is assigned in APNAP order. Other than that, the combat damage step proceeds just as in a two-player game. See rule 510, âCombat Damage Step.â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 803. Attack Left and Attack Right Options : 803.1.
text: Some multiplayer games use the optional attack left or attack right rules.
url: https://blogs.magicjudges.org/rules/cr803. Attack Left and Attack Right Options/

metadata.chapter: 803. Attack Left and Attack Right Options

name: Comprehensive Rules: 803. Attack Left and Attack Right Options : 803.1a
text: If the attack left option is used, a player can attack only an opponent seated immediately to their left, a planeswalker that player controls, or a battle that player protects. If a playerâs nearest opponent to the left is more than one seat away, the player canât attack.
url: https://blogs.magicjudges.org/rules/cr803. Attack Left and Attack Right Options/

metadata.chapter: 803. Attack Left and Attack Right Options

name: Comprehensive Rules: 803. Attack Left and Attack Right Options : 803.1b
text: If the attack right option is used, a player can attack only an opponent seated immediately to their right, a planeswalker that player controls, or a battle that player protects. If a playerâs nearest opponent to the right is more than one seat away, the player canât attack.
url: https://blogs.magicjudges.org/rules/cr803. Attack Left and Attack Right Options/
