name: Comprehensive Rules: 804. Deploy Creatures Option : 804.1.
text: The Emperor variant always uses the deploy creatures option, and it can be used in other variants that allow players to compete in teams. Multiplayer formats in which players compete as individuals usually donât use this option.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 804. Deploy Creatures Option : 804.2.
text: Each creature has the ability â{T}: Target teammate gains control of this creature. Activate only as a sorcery.â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 805. Shared Team Turns Option : 805.1.
text: Some multiplayer games between teams use the shared team turns option. Itâs always used in the Two-Headed Giant variant (see rule 810) and the Archenemy casual variant (see rule 904). It can be used only if the members of each team are sitting in adjacent seats.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 805. Shared Team Turns Option : 805.2.
text: Within each team, the player seated in the rightmost seat from that teamâs perspective is the primary player. If the players on a team canât agree on a choice, such as which creatures attack or what order triggered abilities are put on the stack, the primary player makes that choice.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 805. Shared Team Turns Option : 805.3.
text: The methods described in rule 103.1 are used to determine which team will take the first turn. The team determined this way is the starting team.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 805. Shared Team Turns Option : 805.3a
text: The process for handling mulligans is altered accordingly. First, each player on the starting team, in whatever order that team likes, declares whether that player will take a mulligan. Then the players on each other team in turn order do the same. Teammates may consult while making their decisions. Then all mulligans are taken at the same time. Teammates may consult while choosing which cards, if any, to put on the bottom of their library. A player may take a mulligan even after a teammate has decided to keep their opening hand. See rule 103.5.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 805. Shared Team Turns Option : 805.3b
text: The process for handling cards that allow a player to begin the game with them on the battlefield is altered accordingly. First, each player on the starting team, in whatever order that team likes, may put any or all such cards onto the battlefield from that playerâs opening hand. Teammates may consult while making their decisions. Then each player on each other team in turn order does the same.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 805. Shared Team Turns Option : 805.4.
text: Each team takes turns rather than each player.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 805. Shared Team Turns Option : 805.4a
text: The team whose turn it is is the active team. Each other team is a nonactive team.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 805. Shared Team Turns Option : 805.4b
text: Each player on a team draws a card during that teamâs draw step.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 805. Shared Team Turns Option : 805.4c
text: Each player on a team may play a land during each of that teamâs turns.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 805. Shared Team Turns Option : 805.4d
text: An ability that triggers at the beginning of a step or phase may trigger multiple times if it triggers at the beginning of âeach playerâsâ or âeach opponentâsâ step or phase. These abilities trigger once for each appropriate player if the abilityâs trigger condition, effect, or intervening âifâ clause refers to âthat player,â âthat opponent,â or similar.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 805. Shared Team Turns Option : 805.5.
text: Teams have priority, not individual players.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 805. Shared Team Turns Option : 805.5a
text: A player may cast a spell, activate an ability, or take a special action when their team has priority.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 805. Shared Team Turns Option : 805.5b
text: If a team has priority and no player on that team wishes to do anything, that team passes. If all teams pass in succession (that is, if all teams pass without any player taking any actions in between passing), the top object on the stack resolves, then the active team receives priority. If the stack is empty when all teams pass in succession, the phase or step ends and the next one begins.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 805. Shared Team Turns Option : 805.6.
text: The Active Player, Nonactive Player order rule (see rule 101.4) is modified if the shared team turns option is used. If multiple teams would make choices and/or take actions at the same time, first the active team makes any choices required, then each nonactive team in turn order makes any choices required. If multiple players would make choices and/or take actions at the same time, first each player on the active team makes any choices required in whatever order they like, then the players on each nonactive team in turn order do the same. Once all choices have been made, the actions happen simultaneously.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 805. Shared Team Turns Option : 805.6a
text: If more than one player is instructed to draw cards in a game thatâs using the shared team turns option, first each player on the active team, in whatever order that team likes, performs that playerâs draws, then each player on each nonactive team in turn order does the same.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 805. Shared Team Turns Option : 805.7.
text: If multiple triggered abilities have triggered since the last time a team received priority, the members of the active team put all triggered abilities any of them controls on the stack in any order they choose, then the members of each nonactive team in turn order do the same.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 805. Shared Team Turns Option : 805.8.
text: If an effect gives a player an extra turn or adds a phase or step to that playerâs turn, that playerâs team takes the extra turn, phase, or step. If an effect causes a player to skip a step, phase, or turn, that playerâs team does so. If a single effect causes more than one player on the same team to add or skip the same step, phase, or turn, that team adds or skips only that step, phase, or turn. If an effect causes a player to control another player, the first player controls the affected playerâs team.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 805. Shared Team Turns Option : 805.9.
text: Any ability that refers to the âactive playerâ refers to one specific active player, not to all of the active players. The abilityâs controller chooses which one the ability refers to at the time its effect is applied.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 805. Shared Team Turns Option : 805.10.
text: The shared team turns option uses different combat rules than other multiplayer options.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 805. Shared Team Turns Option : 805.10a
text: Each teamâs creatures attack the other team as a group. During the combat phase, the active team is the attacking team and each player on the active team is an attacking player. Likewise, the nonactive team is the defending team and each player on the nonactive team is a defending player.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 805. Shared Team Turns Option : 805.10b
text: As the declare attackers step begins, the active team declares attackers. For each attacking creature, the attacking team announces which defending player, planeswalker, or battle that creature is attacking. The active team has one combined attack, and that set of attacking creatures must be legal as a whole. See rule 508.1.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 805. Shared Team Turns Option : 805.10c
text: Any rule, object, or effect that refers to an âattacking playerâ refers to one specific attacking player, not to all attacking players. If an ability of a blocking creature refers to an attacking player, or a spell or ability refers to both a blocking creature and an attacking player, then unless otherwise specified, the attacking player itâs referring to is the player who controls the attacking creature that blocking creature is blocking. If a spell or ability could apply to multiple blocking creatures, the appropriate attacking player is individually determined for each of those blocking creatures. If there are multiple attacking players that could be chosen, the controller of the spell or ability chooses one.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 805. Shared Team Turns Option : 805.10d
text: As the declare blockers step begins, the defending team declares blockers. Creatures controlled by the defending players can block creatures attacking any player on the defending team, attacking a planeswalker controlled by one of those players, or a battle protected by one of those players. The defending team has one combined block, and that set of blocking creatures must be legal as a whole. See rule 509.1.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 805. Shared Team Turns Option : 805.10e
text: Any rule, object, or effect that refers to a âdefending playerâ refers to one specific defending player, not to all of the defending players. If an ability of an attacking creature refers to a defending player, or a spell or ability refers to both an attacking creature and a defending player, then unless otherwise specified, the defending player itâs referring to is the player that creature is attacking, the controller of the planeswalker that creature is attacking, or the protector of the battle that creature is attacking. If that creature is no longer attacking, the defending player itâs referring to is the player that creature was attacking before it was removed from combat, the controller of the planeswalker that creature was attacking before it was removed from combat, or the protector of the battle that creature was attacking before it was removed from combat. If a spell or ability could apply to multiple attacking creatures, the appropriate defending player is individually determined for each of those attacking creatures. If there are multiple defending players that could be chosen, the controller of the spell or ability chooses one.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 805. Shared Team Turns Option : 805.10f
text: Once blockers have been declared, for each attacking creature thatâs become blocked by multiple creatures, the active team announces the damage assignment order among the blocking creatures. Then, for each creature thatâs blocking multiple creatures, the defending team announces the damage assignment order among the attacking creatures.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 805. Shared Team Turns Option : 805.10g
text: As the combat damage step begins, the active team announces how each attacking creature will assign its combat damage. Then the defending team announces how each blocking creature will assign its combat damage. See rule 510.1.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 806. Free-for-All Variant : 806.1.
text: In Free-for-All multiplayer games, a group of players compete as individuals against each other.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 806. Free-for-All Variant : 806.2.
text: Any multiplayer options used are determined before play begins. The Free-for-All variant uses the following default options.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 806. Free-for-All Variant : 806.2a
text: The limited range of influence option usually isnât used in Free-for-All games. If it is, each player has the same range of influence, which is determined before play begins. See rule 801, âLimited Range of Influence Option.â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 806. Free-for-All Variant : 806.2b
text: Exactly one of the attack left, attack right, and attack multiple players options must be used. See rule 803, âAttack Left and Attack Right Options,â and rule 802, âAttack Multiple Players Option.â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 806. Free-for-All Variant : 806.2c
text: The deploy creatures option isnât used in the Free-for-All variant.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 806. Free-for-All Variant : 806.3.
text: The players are randomly seated around the table.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 807. Grand Melee Variant : 807.1.
text: The Grand Melee variant is a modification of the Free-for-All variant, in which a group of players compete against each other as individuals. Grand Melee is normally used only in games begun with ten or more players.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 807. Grand Melee Variant : 807.2.
text: Any multiplayer options used are decided before play begins. The Grand Melee variant uses the following default options.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 807. Grand Melee Variant : 807.2a
text: Each player has a range of influence of 1 (see rule 801).

name: Comprehensive Rules: 807. Grand Melee Variant : 807.2b
text: The attack left option is used (see rule 803).

name: Comprehensive Rules: 807. Grand Melee Variant : 807.2c
text: The attack multiple players and deploy creatures options arenât used in the Grand Melee variant.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 807. Grand Melee Variant : 807.3.
text: The players are seated at random.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 807. Grand Melee Variant : 807.4.
text: The Grand Melee variant allows multiple players to take turns at the same time. Moving turn markers keep track of which players are currently taking turns. Each turn marker represents an active playerâs turn.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 807. Grand Melee Variant : 807.4a
text: There is one turn marker for each full four players in the game.

name: Example for Rule : 807.4a
text: A Grand Melee game with sixteen players has four turn markers. A game with fifteen players has three turn markers.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 807. Grand Melee Variant : 807.4b
text: The starting player in the game gets the first turn marker. The player four seats to that playerâs left (the fifth player) takes the second turn marker, and so on until all the turn markers have been handed out. Each turn marker is assigned a number in this way. Then all players with turn markers start their turns at the same time.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 807. Grand Melee Variant : 807.4c
text: After a player ends their turn, that player passes the turn marker to the player on their left. If a player with a turn marker leaves the game during their turn, the player to their left takes the turn marker after that turn ends. If a player with a turn marker leaves the game before their turn begins, the player to their left takes the turn marker immediately.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 807. Grand Melee Variant : 807.4d
text: A player who receives a turn marker canât begin their turn if any player in the three seats to their left has a turn marker. If this is the case, that player waits until the player four seats to their left takes the other turn marker.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 807. Grand Melee Variant : 807.4e
text: If a player leaves the game and that player leaving the game would reduce the number of turn markers in the game, the turn marker immediately to the departed playerâs right is designated for removal. If more than one player leaves the game simultaneously, those players leaving the game would reduce the number of turn markers in the game, and there are multiple turn markers that could be removed, the marker with the lowest number is designated for removal. A turn marker may be designated for removal multiple times.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 807. Grand Melee Variant : 807.4f
text: For the purposes of determining if one or more players leaving the game would reduce the number of turn markers in the game (see rule 807.4e), disregard turn markers already designated for removal.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 807. Grand Melee Variant : 807.4g
text: If a player whoâs taking a turn has a turn marker thatâs been designated for removal, that turn marker is removed rather than being passed after that turn ends. If a player whoâs not taking a turn has a turn marker thatâs been designated for removal, that turn marker is removed immediately. If a removed turn marker had been designated for removal multiple times, the turn marker to its right becomes designated for removal that many times minus one.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 807. Grand Melee Variant : 807.4h
text: If one or more consecutively seated players leave the game, the players that were on either side of those seats donât enter one anotherâs range of influence until the next turn begins.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 807. Grand Melee Variant : 807.4i
text: If an effect causes a player with a turn marker to take an extra turn after the current one, that player keeps the turn marker and starts their next turn after the current turn ends, unless another turn marker is too close on either side at that time. If a turn marker is within three seats on the playerâs left, the extra turn waits to begin until the player four seats to their left takes the other turn marker. If a turn marker is within three seats on the playerâs right, the player passes the turn marker to their left when the turn ends rather than keeping it, and the player will take the extra turn immediately before their next turn.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 807. Grand Melee Variant : 807.4j
text: If an effect would cause a player to take an extra turn after the current turn, but that player wouldnât have a turn marker at the start of that turn, that player will take the extra turn immediately before their next turn instead.

name: Example for Rule : 807.4j
text: During Alexâs turn, he casts Time Walk, which causes him to take an extra turn after this one. During the same turn, the player to Alexâs left leaves the game, which causes the number of turn markers to be reduced. After Alexâs current turn ends, his turn marker is removed. He wonât take the extra turn from Time Walk until just before his normal turn the next time he receives a turn marker.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 807. Grand Melee Variant : 807.5.
text: Rather than having a single stack, Grand Melee games contain multiple stacks. Each turn marker represents its own stack.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 807. Grand Melee Variant : 807.5a
text: A player gets priority for a particular turn markerâs stack only if the turn marker is within their range of influence or an object on that stack is controlled by a player within their range of influence.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 807. Grand Melee Variant : 807.5b
text: If a player has priority for multiple stacks and casts a spell, activates an ability, or a triggered ability they control triggers, the player must specify which one of those stacks the spell or ability is put on. If an object on one of those stacks caused the triggered ability to trigger, the player must put it on that stack. If a resolving spell or ability on one of those stacks causes a player to cast a spell or create a copy of a spell, the new spell must be put on the same stack. If a spell or ability targets an object on one of those stacks, it must be put on the same stack as its target; it canât target objects on multiple stacks.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 808. Team vs. Team Variant : 808.1.
text: Team vs. Team games are played with two or more teams. Each team may have any number of players on it.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 808. Team vs. Team Variant : 808.2.
text: Each team sits together on one side of the table. Each team decides the order in which its players sit.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 808. Team vs. Team Variant : 808.3.
text: Any multiplayer options used are determined before play begins. The Team vs. Team variant uses the following default options.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 808. Team vs. Team Variant : 808.3a
text: The attack multiple players option is used (see rule 802).

name: Comprehensive Rules: 808. Team vs. Team Variant : 808.3b
text: The deploy creatures options and limited range of influence options usually arenât used in the Team vs. Team variant.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 808. Team vs. Team Variant : 808.4.
text: To determine which player goes first, randomly choose a team. If that team has an odd number of players, the player in its center seat goes first. If that team has an even number of players, the player to the left of its midpoint goes first. Turn order goes to the playersâ left.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 808. Team vs. Team Variant : 808.5.
text: In the Team vs. Team variant, a teamâs resources (cards in hand, mana, and so on) are not shared. Teammates may review each otherâs hands and discuss strategies at any time. Teammates canât manipulate each otherâs cards or permanents.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 809. Emperor Variant : 809.1.
text: The Emperor variant involves two or more teams of three players each.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 809. Emperor Variant : 809.2.
text: Each team sits together on one side of the table. Each team decides the order in which itâs seated. Each team has one emperor, who sits in the middle of the team. The remaining players on the team are generals whose job is to protect the emperor.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 809. Emperor Variant : 809.3.
text: The Emperor variant uses the following default options.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 809. Emperor Variant : 809.3a
text: The range of influence is limited to 2 for emperors and 1 for generals. See rule 801, âLimited Range of Influence Option.â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 809. Emperor Variant : 809.3b
text: Emperor games use the deploy creatures option (see rule 804).

name: Comprehensive Rules: 809. Emperor Variant : 809.3c
text: A player can attack only an opponent seated immediately next to them, a planeswalker controlled by a player seated immediately next to them, or a battle protected by a player seated immediately next to them.

name: Example for Rule : 809.3c
text: At the start of an Emperor game, neither emperor can attack any opponents, even though both of the opposing generals are within their spell range.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 809. Emperor Variant : 809.4.
text: Randomly determine which emperor goes first. Turn order goes to the playersâ left.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 809. Emperor Variant : 809.5.
text: The Emperor variant includes the following specifications for winning and losing the game. All other rules for ending the game also apply. (See rule 104.)

name: Comprehensive Rules: 809. Emperor Variant : 809.5a
text: A team wins the game if its emperor wins.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 809. Emperor Variant : 809.5b
text: A team loses the game if its emperor loses.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 809. Emperor Variant : 809.5c
text: The game is a draw for a team if the game is a draw for its emperor.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 809. Emperor Variant : 809.6.
text: The Emperor variant can also be played with any number of equally sized teams. If the teams have more than three players, the range of influence of each player should be adjusted.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 809. Emperor Variant : 809.6a
text: Each generalâs range of influence should be the minimum number that allows one general from an opposing team to begin the game within their range of influence. Each emperorâs range of influence should be the minimum number that allows two generals from opposing teams to begin the game within their range of influence. Players should be seated such that no emperor begins the game within the range of influence of another emperor.

name: Example for Rule : 809.6a
text: In an Emperor game between two teams of four players each, the player configuration (either clockwise or counterclockwise around the table) should be: Team A general 1, Team A emperor, Team A general 2, Team A general 3, Team B general 1, Team B emperor, Team B general 2, Team B general 3. Each emperor has range of influence 3. Each general 2 has range of influence 2. Each general 1 and general 3 has range of influence 1.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 809. Emperor Variant : 809.7.
text: In the Emperor variant, a teamâs resources (cards in hand, mana, and so on) are not shared. Teammates may review each otherâs hands and discuss strategies at any time. Teammates canât manipulate each otherâs cards or permanents.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 810. Two-Headed Giant Variant : 810.1.
text: Two-Headed Giant games are played with two teams of two players each.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 810. Two-Headed Giant Variant : 810.2.
text: The Two-Headed Giant variant uses the shared team turns option. (See rule 805.)

name: Comprehensive Rules: 810. Two-Headed Giant Variant : 810.3.
text: Each team sits together on one side of the table. Each team decides the order in which its players sit.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 810. Two-Headed Giant Variant : 810.4.
text: Each team has a shared life total, which starts at 30 life.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 810. Two-Headed Giant Variant : 810.5.
text: With the exception of life total and poison counters, a teamâs resources (cards in hand, mana, and so on) are not shared in the Two-Headed Giant variant. Teammates may review each otherâs hands and discuss strategies at any time. Teammates canât manipulate each otherâs cards or permanents.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 810. Two-Headed Giant Variant : 810.6.
text: The team who plays first skips the draw step of its first turn.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 810. Two-Headed Giant Variant : 810.7.
text: The Two-Headed Giant variant uses the combat rules for the shared team turns option (see rule 805.10). This is a change from previous rules.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 810. Two-Headed Giant Variant : 810.8.
text: The Two-Headed Giant variant uses the normal rules for winning or losing the game (see rule 104), with the following additions and specifications.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 810. Two-Headed Giant Variant : 810.8a
text: Players win and lose the game only as a team, not as individuals. If either player on a team loses the game, the team loses the game. If either player on a team wins the game, the entire team wins the game. If an effect says that a player canât win the game, that playerâs team canât win the game. If an effect says that a player canât lose the game, that playerâs team canât lose the game.

name: Example for Rule : 810.8a
text: In a Two-Headed Giant game, a player controls Transcendence, which reads, in part, âYou donât lose the game for having 0 or less life.â If that playerâs teamâs life total is 0 or less, that team doesnât lose the game.

name: Example for Rule : 810.8a
text: In a Two-Headed Giant game, a player attempts to draw a card while there are no cards in that playerâs library. That player loses the game, so that playerâs entire team loses the game.

name: Example for Rule : 810.8a
text: In a Two-Headed Giant game, a player controls Platinum Angel, which reads, âYou canât lose the game and your opponents canât win the game.â Neither that player nor their teammate can lose the game while Platinum Angel is on the battlefield, and neither player on the opposing team can win the game.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 810. Two-Headed Giant Variant : 810.8b
text: If a player concedes, their team leaves the game immediately. That team loses the game.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 810. Two-Headed Giant Variant : 810.8c
text: If a teamâs life total is 0 or less, the team loses the game. (This is a state-based action. See rule 704.)

name: Comprehensive Rules: 810. Two-Headed Giant Variant : 810.8d
text: If a team has fifteen or more poison counters, that team loses the game. (This is a state-based action. See rule 704.)

name: Comprehensive Rules: 810. Two-Headed Giant Variant : 810.9.
text: Damage, loss of life, and gaining life happen to each player individually. The result is applied to the teamâs shared life total.

name: Example for Rule : 810.9.
text: In a Two-Headed Giant game, a player casts Flame Rift, which reads, âFlame Rift deals 4 damage to each player.â Each team is dealt a total of 8 damage.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 810. Two-Headed Giant Variant : 810.9a
text: If a cost or effect needs to know the value of an individual playerâs life total, that cost or effect uses the teamâs life total instead.

name: Example for Rule : 810.9a
text: In a Two-Headed Giant game, a player on a team that has 17 life is targeted by Beacon of Immortality, which reads, in part, âDouble target playerâs life total.â That player gains 17 life, so the team winds up at 34 life.

name: Example for Rule : 810.9a
text: In a Two-Headed Giant game, a player controls Test of Endurance, an enchantment that reads, âAt the beginning of your upkeep, if you have 50 or more life, you win the game.â At the beginning of that playerâs upkeep, the playerâs team wins the game if their teamâs life total is 50 or more.

name: Example for Rule : 810.9a
text: In a Two-Headed Giant game, a player on a team that has 11 life controls Lurking Evil, an enchantment that reads, âPay half your life, rounded up: Lurking Evil becomes a 4/4 Horror creature with flying.â To activate the ability, that player must pay 6 life. The team winds up at 5 life.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 810. Two-Headed Giant Variant : 810.9b
text: If a cost or effect allows both members of a team to pay life simultaneously, the total amount of life they pay may not exceed their teamâs life total. (Players can always pay 0 life.)

name: Comprehensive Rules: 810. Two-Headed Giant Variant : 810.9c
text: If an effect sets a single playerâs life total to a specific number, the player gains or loses the necessary amount of life to end up with the new total. The teamâs life total is adjusted by the amount of life that player gained or lost.

name: Example for Rule : 810.9c
text: In a Two-Headed Giant game, a player on a team that has 25 life is targeted by an ability that reads, âTarget playerâs life total becomes 10.â That playerâs life total is considered to be 25, so that player loses 15 life. The team winds up at 10 life.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 810. Two-Headed Giant Variant : 810.9d
text: If an effect would set the life total of each player on a team to a number, that team chooses one of its members. On that team, only that player is affected.

name: Example for Rule : 810.9d
text: In a Two-Headed Giant game, one team has 7 life and the other team has 13 life. A player casts Repay in Kind, which reads, âEach playerâs life total becomes the lowest life total among all players.â Each team chooses one of its members to be affected. The result is that the chosen player on the team that has 13 life loses 6 life, so that teamâs life total winds up at 7.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 810. Two-Headed Giant Variant : 810.9e
text: A player canât exchange life totals with their teammate. If an effect would cause that to occur, the exchange wonât happen.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 810. Two-Headed Giant Variant : 810.9f
text: If an effect instructs a player to redistribute any number of playersâ life totals, that player may not affect more than one member of each team this way.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 810. Two-Headed Giant Variant : 810.9g
text: If an effect says that a player canât gain life, no player on that playerâs team can gain life.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 810. Two-Headed Giant Variant : 810.9h
text: If an effect says that a player canât lose life, no player on that playerâs team can lose life or pay any amount of life other than 0.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 810. Two-Headed Giant Variant : 810.10.
text: Effects that cause players to get poison counters happen to each player individually. The poison counters are shared by the team.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 810. Two-Headed Giant Variant : 810.10a
text: If an effect needs to know how many poison counters an individual player has, that effect uses the number of poison counters that playerâs team has. If an effect needs to know how many poison counters a playerâs opponents have, that effect uses the number of poison counters opposing teams have.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 810. Two-Headed Giant Variant : 810.10b
text: If an effect says that a player loses poison counters, that playerâs team loses that many poison counters.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 810. Two-Headed Giant Variant : 810.10c
text: If an effect says that a player canât get poison counters, no player on that playerâs team can get poison counters.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 810. Two-Headed Giant Variant : 810.10d
text: If a rule or effect needs to know what kinds of counters an individual player has, that effect uses the kinds of counters that player has and the kinds of counters that playerâs team has. A player is âpoisonedâ if that playerâs team has one or more poison counters.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 810. Two-Headed Giant Variant : 810.11.
text: The Two-Headed Giant variant can also be played with equally sized teams of more than two players. For each player a team has beyond the second, that teamâs starting life total is increased by 15 and the number of poison counters required for the team to lose is increased by five. (These variants are called Three-Headed Giant, Four-Headed Giant, and so on.)

name: Comprehensive Rules: 811. Alternating Teams Variant : 811.1.
text: Alternating Teams games are played with two or more teams of equal size.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 811. Alternating Teams Variant : 811.2.
text: Any multiplayer options used are determined before play begins. The Alternating Teams variant uses the following default options.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 811. Alternating Teams Variant : 811.2a
text: The recommended range of influence is 2. See rule 801, âLimited Range of Influence Option.â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 811. Alternating Teams Variant : 811.2b
text: Exactly one of the attack left, attack right, and attack multiple players options must be used. See rule 803, âAttack Left and Attack Right Options,â and rule 802, âAttack Multiple Players Option.â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 811. Alternating Teams Variant : 811.2c
text: The deploy creatures option isnât normally used in the Alternating Teams variant.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 811. Alternating Teams Variant : 811.3.
text: At the start of the game, players are seated so that no one is next to a teammate and each team is equally spaced out.

name: Example for Rule : 811.3.
text: In an Alternating Teams game with three teams, A, B, and C, the seating around the table at the start of the game is A1, B1, C1, A2, B2, C2, A3, B3, C3, and so on.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 811. Alternating Teams Variant : 811.4.
text: A player canât attack opponents who arenât seated next to them, planeswalkers that arenât controlled by opponents seated next to them, or battles that arenât protected by opponents seated next to them.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 811. Alternating Teams Variant : 811.5.
text:
In the Alternating Teams variant, a teamâs resources (cards in hand, mana, and so on) are not shared. Teammates canât review each otherâs hands unless they are sitting next to each other. Teammates may discuss strategies at any time. Teammates canât manipulate each otherâs cards or permanents.


9. Casual Variants

name: Comprehensive Rules: 900. General : 900.1.
text: This section contains additional optional rules that can be used for certain casual game variants. It is by no means comprehensive.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 900. General : 900.2.
text: The casual variants detailed here use supplemental zones, rules, cards, and other game implements not used in traditional Magic games.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 901. Planechase : 901.1.
text: In the Planechase variant, plane cards and phenomenon cards add additional abilities and randomness to the game. The Planechase variant uses all the normal rules for a Magic game, with the following additions.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 901. Planechase : 901.2.
text: A Planechase game may be a two-player game or a multiplayer game. The default multiplayer setup is the Free-for-All variant with the attack multiple players option and without the limited range of influence option. See rule 806, âFree-for-All Variant.â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 901. Planechase : 901.3.
text: In addition to the normal game materials, each player needs a supplementary planar deck of at least ten plane and/or phenomenon cards and the game needs one planar die. No more than two cards in a planar deck can be phenomenon cards. Each card in a planar deck must have a different English name. (See rule 311, âPlanes,â and rule 312, âPhenomena.â)

name: Comprehensive Rules: 901. Planechase : 901.3a
text: A planar die is a six-sided die. One face has the Planeswalker symbol. One face has the chaos symbol. The other faces are blank.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 901. Planechase : 901.4.
text: All plane and phenomenon cards remain in the command zone throughout the game, both while theyâre part of a planar deck and while theyâre face up.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 901. Planechase : 901.5.
text: Once all players have kept their opening hands and used the abilities of cards that allow them to take an action with those cards from their opening hands, the starting player moves the top card of their planar deck off that planar deck and turns it face up. If itâs a phenomenon card, the player puts that card on the bottom of their planar deck and repeats this process until a plane card is turned face up. (See rule 103.7.) No abilities of any card turned face up this way trigger during this process. The face-up plane card becomes the starting plane.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 901. Planechase : 901.6.
text: The owner of a plane or phenomenon card is the player who started the game with it in their planar deck. The controller of a face-up plane or phenomenon card is the player designated as the planar controller. Normally, the planar controller is whoever the active player is. However, if the current planar controller would leave the game, instead the next player in turn order that wouldnât leave the game becomes the planar controller, then the old planar controller leaves the game. The new planar controller retains that designation until they leave the game or a different player becomes the active player, whichever comes first.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 901. Planechase : 901.7.
text: Any abilities of a face-up plane card or phenomenon card in the command zone function from that zone. The cardâs static abilities affect the game, its triggered abilities may trigger, and its activated abilities may be activated.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 901. Planechase : 901.7a
text: A face-up plane card or phenomenon card thatâs turned face down becomes a new object.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 901. Planechase : 901.8.
text: Planechase games have an inherent triggered ability known as the âplaneswalking ability.â The full text of this ability is âWhenever you roll the Planeswalker symbol on the planar die, planeswalk.â (See rule 701.24, âPlaneswalk.â) This ability has no source and is controlled by the player whose planar die roll caused it to trigger. This is an exception to rule 113.8.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 901. Planechase : 901.9.
text: Any time the active player has priority and the stack is empty, but only during a main phase of their turn, that player may roll the planar die. Taking this action costs a player an amount of mana equal to the number of times they have previously taken this action on that turn. This is a special action and doesnât use the stack. Note that this number wonât be equal to the number of times the player has rolled the planar die that turn if an effect has caused the player to roll the planar die that turn. (See rule 116.2i.)

name: Comprehensive Rules: 901. Planechase : 901.9a
text: If the die roll is a blank face, nothing happens. The active player gets priority.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 901. Planechase : 901.9b
text: If the die roll is the chaos symbol, chaos ensues (see rule 311.7). The active player gets priority.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 901. Planechase : 901.9c
text: If the die roll is the Planeswalker symbol, the âplaneswalking abilityâ triggers and is put on the stack. The active player gets priority. (See rule 901.8.)

name: Comprehensive Rules: 901. Planechase : 901.9d
text: Rolling the planar die will cause any ability that triggers whenever a player rolls one or more dice to trigger. However, any effect that refers to a numerical result of a die roll, including ones that compare the results of that roll to other rolls or to a given number, ignores the rolling of the planar die. See 706, âRolling a Die.â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 901. Planechase : 901.10.
text: When a player leaves the game, all objects owned by that player except abilities from phenomena leave the game. (See rule 800.4a.) If that includes a face-up plane card or phenomenon card, the planar controller turns the top card of their planar deck face up. This is not a state-based action. It happens as soon as the player leaves the game.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 901. Planechase : 901.10a
text: If a plane leaves the game while a âplaneswalking abilityâ is on the stack, that ability ceases to exist.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 901. Planechase : 901.10b
text: Abilities from phenomena owned by a player who left the game remain on the stack controlled by the new planar controller.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 901. Planechase : 901.11.
text: After the game has started, if a player moves the top card of their planar deck off that planar deck and turns it face up, that player has âplaneswalked.â Continuous effects with durations that last until a player planeswalks end. Abilities that trigger when a player planeswalks trigger. See rule 701.24.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 901. Planechase : 901.11a
text: A player may planeswalk as the result of the âplaneswalking abilityâ (see rule 901.8), because the owner of a face-up plane card or phenomenon card leaves the game (see rule 901.10), or because a phenomenonâs triggered ability leaves the stack (see rule 704.6f). Abilities may also instruct a player to planeswalk.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 901. Planechase : 901.11b
text: The plane card thatâs turned face up is the plane the player planeswalks to. The plane card or phenomenon card thatâs turned face down, or that leaves the game, is the plane or phenomenon the player planeswalks away from.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 901. Planechase : 901.11c
text: If a player planeswalks when there is more than one face-up plane card, that player planeswalks away from all such planes.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 901. Planechase : 901.12.
text: A Two-Headed Giant Planechase game uses all the rules for the Two-Headed Giant multiplayer variant and all the rules for the Planechase casual variant, with the following additions.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 901. Planechase : 901.12a
text: Each player has their own planar deck.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 901. Planechase : 901.12b
text: The planar controller is normally the primary player of the active team. However, if the current planar controllerâs team would leave the game, instead the primary player of the next team in turn order that wouldnât leave the game becomes the planar controller, then the old planar controllerâs team leaves the game. The new planar controller retains that designation until they leave the game or a different team becomes the active team, whichever comes first.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 901. Planechase : 901.12c
text: Even though the face-up plane or phenomenon is controlled by just one player, any ability of that plane or phenomenon that refers to âyouâ applies to both members of the planar controllerâs team.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 901. Planechase : 901.12d
text: Since each member of the active team is an active player, each of them may roll the planar die. Each playerâs cost to roll the planar die is based on the number of times that particular player has already rolled the planar die that turn.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 901. Planechase : 901.13.
text: In multiplayer formats other than Grand Melee, plane cards and phenomenon cards are exempt from the limited range of influence option. Their abilities, and the effects of those abilities, affect all applicable objects and players in the game. (See rule 801, âLimited Range of Influence Option.â)

name: Comprehensive Rules: 901. Planechase : 901.14.
text: In Grand Melee Planechase games, multiple plane cards or phenomenon cards may be face up at the same time.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 901. Planechase : 901.14a
text: Before the first turn of the game of the game, each player who will start the game with a turn marker sets a starting plane (see rule 901.5). Each of them is a planar controller.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 901. Planechase : 901.14b
text: If a player would leave the game and that player leaving the game would reduce the number of turn markers in the game, that player first ceases to be a planar controller (but no other player becomes a planar controller), then that player leaves the game. Each face-up plane card or phenomenon card that player controlled is put on the bottom of its ownerâs planar deck. No player is considered to have planeswalked.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 901. Planechase : 901.15.
text: Single Planar Deck Option

name: Comprehensive Rules: 901. Planechase : 901.15a
text: As an alternative option, a Planechase game may be played with just a single communal planar deck. In that case, the number of cards in the planar deck must be at least forty or at least ten times the number of players in the game, whichever is smaller. The planar deck canât contain more phenomenon cards than twice the number of players in the game. Each card in the planar deck must have a different English name.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 901. Planechase : 901.15b
text: In a Planechase game using the single planar deck option, the planar controller is considered to be the owner of all cards in the planar deck.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 901. Planechase : 901.15c
text: If any rule or ability refers to a playerâs planar deck, the communal planar deck is used.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 902. Vanguard : 902.1.
text: In the Vanguard variant, a vanguard card allows each player to play the role of a famous character. Each player will have one face-up vanguard card whose abilities and other characteristics affect the game. The Vanguard variant uses all the normal rules for a Magic game, with the following additions.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 902. Vanguard : 902.2.
text: A Vanguard game may be a two-player game or a multiplayer game.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 902. Vanguard : 902.3.
text: In addition to the normal game materials, each player needs a vanguard card. Each vanguard card is placed face up next to its ownerâs library before the game begins. All vanguard cards remain in the command zone throughout the game.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 902. Vanguard : 902.4.
text: Each playerâs starting life total is 20 plus or minus the life modifier of their vanguard card.

name: Example for Rule : 902.4.
text: The life modifier of a playerâs vanguard card is -3. That playerâs starting life total is 17.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 902. Vanguard : 902.5.
text: Each playerâs starting hand size is seven cards, as modified by the hand modifier of their vanguard card.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 902. Vanguard : 902.5a
text: If a player takes a mulligan in a Vanguard game, just like in a normal game, that player shuffles their hand back into their library, then draws a new hand equal to their starting hand size. (In a multiplayer game, a playerâs first mulligan is for the same number of cards as they had before.) See rule 103.5.

name: Example for Rule : 902.5a
text: The hand modifier of a playerâs vanguard card is +2. That player starts the game with a hand of 9 cards. If the player takes a mulligan three times before keeping, they draw a new hand of nine cards and put three of those on the bottom of their library.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 902. Vanguard : 902.5b
text: A playerâs maximum hand size is seven, as modified by the hand modifier of their vanguard card.

name: Example for Rule : 902.5b
text: The hand modifier of a playerâs vanguard card is -1. That playerâs maximum hand size is six. If that player has more than six cards in their hand as their cleanup step begins, they will discard all but six of them.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 902. Vanguard : 902.6.
text: The owner of a vanguard card is the player who started the game with it in the command zone. The controller of a face-up vanguard card is its owner.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 902. Vanguard : 902.7.
text: Any abilities of a face-up vanguard card in the command zone function from that zone. The cardâs static abilities affect the game, its triggered abilities may trigger, and its activated abilities may be activated.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 903. Commander : 903.1.
text: In the Commander variant, each deck is led by a legendary creature designated as that deckâs commander. The Commander variant was created and popularized by fans; an independent rules committee maintains additional resources at MTGCommander.net. The Commander variant uses all the normal rules for a Magic game, with the following additions.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 903. Commander : 903.2.
text: A Commander game may be a two-player game or a multiplayer game. The default multiplayer setup is the Free-for-All variant with the attack multiple players option and without the limited range of influence option. See rule 806, âFree-for-All Variant.â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 903. Commander : 903.3.
text: Each deck has a legendary creature card designated as its commander. This designation is not a characteristic of the object represented by the card; rather, it is an attribute of the card itself. The card retains this designation even when it changes zones.

name: Example for Rule : 903.3.
text: A commander thatâs been turned face down (due to Ixidronâs effect, for example) is still a commander. A commander thatâs copying another card (due to Cytoshapeâs effect, for example) is still a commander. A permanent thatâs copying a commander (such as a Body Double, for example, copying a commander in a playerâs graveyard) is not a commander.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 903. Commander : 903.3a
text: Some cards have an ability that states the card can be your commander. This ability modifies the rules for deck construction, and it functions before the game begins. See also rule 113.6n.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 903. Commander : 903.3b
text: If a playerâs commander is a meld card and itâs melded with the other member of its meld pair, the resulting melded permanent is that playerâs commander.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 903. Commander : 903.3c
text: If a playerâs commander is a component of a merged permanent, the resulting merged permanent is that playerâs commander.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 903. Commander : 903.3d
text: If an effect refers to controlling a commander, it refers to a permanent on the battlefield that is a commander. If an effect refers to casting a commander, it refers to a spell that is a commander. If an effect refers to a commander in a specific zone, it refers to a card in that zone that is a commander.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 903. Commander : 903.3e
text: If an effect refers to a characteristic of âyour commander,â it can find the appropriate playerâs commander and see its current characteristics, as modified by continuous effects and other rules, in all zones, including that playerâs library and hand.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 903. Commander : 903.4.
text: The Commander variant uses color identity to determine what cards can be in a deck with a certain commander. The color identity of a card is the color or colors of any mana symbols in that cardâs mana cost or rules text, plus any colors defined by its characteristic-defining abilities (see rule 604.3) or color indicator (see rule 204).

name: Example for Rule : 903.4.
text: Bosh, Iron Golem is a legendary artifact creature with mana cost {8} and the ability â{3}{R}, Sacrifice an artifact: Bosh, Iron Golem deals damage equal to the sacrificed artifactâs mana value to any target.â Boshâs color identity is red.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 903. Commander : 903.4a
text: Color identity is established before the game begins.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 903. Commander : 903.4b
text: If a commander has a static ability that causes a player to choose its color before the game begins, that choice applies during deck construction and throughout the game, even as the commander changes zones. That choice affects the commanderâs color identity. The player reveals that choice as they put their commander into the command zone before the game begins. See rules 103.2c and 607.2p.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 903. Commander : 903.4c
text: Reminder text is ignored when determining a cardâs color identity. See rule 207.2.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 903. Commander : 903.4d
text: The back face of a double-faced card (see rule 712) is included when determining a cardâs color identity. This is an exception to rule 712.8a.

name: Example for Rule : 903.4d
text: Civilized Scholar is the front face of a double-faced card with mana cost {2}{U}. Homicidal Brute is the back face of that double-faced card and has a red color indicator. The cardâs color identity is blue and red.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 903. Commander : 903.4e
text: If a card has any alternative characteristics, such as those of adventurer cards (see rule 715, âAdventurer Cardsâ), those characteristics are included when determining the cardâs color identity.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 903. Commander : 903.4f
text: If an ability refers to the colors or number of colors in a commanderâs color identity, that quality is undefined if that player doesnât have a commander. That part of the ability wonât do anything. Costs that refer to that quality are unpayable.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 903. Commander : 903.5.
text: Each Commander deck is subject to the following deck construction rules.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 903. Commander : 903.5a
text: Each deck must contain exactly 100 cards, including its commander. In other words, the minimum deck size and the maximum deck size are both 100.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 903. Commander : 903.5b
text: Other than basic lands, each card in a Commander deck must have a different English name. For the purposes of deck construction, cards with interchangeable names have the same English name (see rule 201.3).

name: Comprehensive Rules: 903. Commander : 903.5c
text: A card can be included in a Commander deck only if every color in its color identity is also found in the color identity of the deckâs commander.

name: Example for Rule : 903.5c
text: Wort, the Raidmother is a legendary creature with mana cost {4}{R/G}{R/G}. Wortâs color identity is red and green. Each card in a Wort Commander deck must be only red, only green, both red and green, or have no color. Each mana symbol in the mana cost or rules text of a card in this deck must be only red, only green, both red and green, or have no color.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 903. Commander : 903.5d
text: A card with a basic land type may be included in a Commander deck only if each color of mana it could produce is included in the commanderâs color identity.

name: Example for Rule : 903.5d
text: Wort, the Raidmotherâs color identity is red and green. A Wort Commander deck may include land cards with the basic land types Mountain and/or Forest. It canât include any land cards with the basic land types Plains, Island, or Swamp.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 903. Commander : 903.6.
text: At the start of the game, each player puts their commander from their deck face up into the command zone. Then each player shuffles the remaining cards of their deck so that the cards are in a random order. Those cards become the playerâs library.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 903. Commander : 903.7.
text: Once the starting player has been determined, each player sets their life total to 40 and draws a hand of seven cards.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 903. Commander : 903.8.
text: A player may cast a commander they own from the command zone. A commander cast from the command zone costs an additional {2} for each previous time the player casting it has cast it from the command zone that game. This additional cost is informally known as the âcommander tax.â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 903. Commander : 903.9.
text: A commander may return to the command zone during a Commander game.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 903. Commander : 903.9a
text: If a commander is in a graveyard or in exile and that object was put into that zone since the last time state-based actions were checked, its owner may put it into the command zone. This is a state-based action. See rule 704.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 903. Commander : 903.9b
text: If a commander would be put into its ownerâs hand or library from anywhere, its owner may put it into the command zone instead. This replacement effect may apply more than once to the same event. This is an exception to rule 614.5.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 903. Commander : 903.9c
text: If a commander is a melded permanent or a merged permanent and its owner chooses to put it into the command zone using the replacement effect described in rule 903.9b, that permanent and each component representing it that isnât a commander are put into the appropriate zone, and the card that represents it and is a commander is put into the command zone.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 903. Commander : 903.10.
text: The Commander variant includes the following specification for winning and losing the game. All other rules for ending the game also apply. (See rule 104.)

name: Comprehensive Rules: 903. Commander : 903.10a
text: A player whoâs been dealt 21 or more combat damage by the same commander over the course of the game loses the game. (This is a state-based action. See rule 704.)

name: Comprehensive Rules: 903. Commander : 903.11.
text: If a player is allowed to bring a card from outside the game into a Commander game, that player canât bring a card into the game this way if it has the same name as a card that player had in their starting deck, if it has the same name as a card that the player owns in the current game, or if any color in its color identity isnât in the color identity of the playerâs commander.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 903. Commander Brawl Option: 903.12a
text: Brawl is an option for a different style of Commander game. Brawl games use the normal rules for the Commander variant with the following modifications.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 903. Commander Brawl Option: 903.12b
text: Brawl decks are usually constructed using cards from the Standard format.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 903. Commander Brawl Option: 903.12c
text: A player designates either a legendary planeswalker or a legendary creature as their commander.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 903. Commander Brawl Option: 903.12d
text: A playerâs deck must contain exactly 60 cards, including its commander. In other words, the minimum deck size and the maximum deck size are both 60.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 903. Commander Brawl Option: 903.12e
text: If a playerâs commander has no colors in its color identity, that playerâs deck may contain any number of basic lands of one basic land type of their choice. This is an exception to rule 903.5d.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 903. Commander Brawl Option: 903.12f
text: In a two-player Brawl game, each playerâs starting life total is 25. In a multiplayer Brawl game, each playerâs starting life total is 30.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 903. Commander Brawl Option: 903.12g
text: In any Brawl game, the first mulligan a player takes doesnât count toward the number of cards that player will put on the bottom of their library or the number of mulligans that player may take. Subsequent mulligans are counted toward these numbers as normal.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 903. Commander Brawl Option: 903.12h
text: Brawl games do not use the state-based action described in rule 704.6c, which causes a player to lose the game if theyâve been dealt 21 or more combat damage by a commander.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 903. Commander Commander Draft: 903.13a
text: Commander Draft is an option for a different style of Commander game. It consists of a draft (a style of limited play where players choose cards from sealed booster packs to build their decks) followed by a multiplayer game. The Commander Draft option uses Commander Legends booster packs by default.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 903. Commander Commander Draft: 903.13b
text: A draft typically consists of three draft rounds. In each draft round, each player opens a booster pack, drafts two cards by placing them in a face-down pile in front of them, then passes the remaining cards to the next player. Each player then drafts two cards from the booster pack passed to them and passes the remaining cards. This procedure continues until all cards in that draft round have been drafted.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 903. Commander Commander Draft: 903.13c
text: In the first and third draft rounds, booster packs are passed to each playerâs left. In the second draft round, booster packs are passed to each playerâs right.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 903. Commander Commander Draft: 903.13d
text: During the draft, a player can look only at cards in the booster pack they are currently drafting from and cards they have already drafted. A player may not reveal drafted cards to other players unless an ability instructs them to.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 903. Commander Commander Draft: 903.13e
text: After the draft is complete, the cards a player drafted become that playerâs card pool. If the draft contained draft boosters from Commander Legends or Commander Masters, each player may add up to two cards named The Prismatic Piper to their card pool, but only if those cards are used as the playerâs commander(s). If the draft contained draft boosters from Commander Legends: Battle for Baldurâs GateÂ®, each player may add up to two cards named Faceless One to their card pool, but only if those cards are used as the playerâs commander(s).

name: Comprehensive Rules: 903. Commander Commander Draft: 903.13f
text: Commander Draft deck construction follows the same rules as Commander deck construction (see rule 903.5) with three exceptions: (1) A playerâs deck must contain at least 60 cards. There is no maximum deck size. (2) A playerâs deck may include any number of cards from that playerâs card pool with the same name. (3) If the draft contained draft boosters from Commander Masters, any card which can be a playerâs commander by itself and whose color identity includes one or fewer colors is considered to have the partner ability for the purposes of deckbuilding. (See rule 702.124, âPartner.â)

name: Comprehensive Rules: 903. Commander Commander Draft: 903.13g
text: Commander Draft games follow the same rules as Commander games. See rules 903.6â903.11.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 904. Archenemy : 904.1.
text: In the Archenemy variant, a team of players faces off against a single opponent strengthened with powerful scheme cards. The Archenemy variant uses all the normal rules for a Magic game, with the following additions.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 904. Archenemy : 904.2.
text: The default setup for an Archenemy game is the Team vs. Team multiplayer variant (see rule 808) involving exactly two teams. The attack multiple players option (see rule 802) and the shared team turns option (see rule 805) are used; no other multiplayer options are used.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 904. Archenemy : 904.2a
text: One of the teams consists of exactly one player, who is designated the archenemy.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 904. Archenemy : 904.2b
text: The other team consists of any number of players.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 904. Archenemy : 904.3.
text: In addition to the normal game materials, the archenemy needs a supplementary scheme deck of at least twenty scheme cards. A scheme deck may contain no more than two of any card with a particular English name. (See rule 314, âSchemes.â)

name: Comprehensive Rules: 904. Archenemy : 904.4.
text: All scheme cards remain in the command zone throughout the game, both while theyâre part of a scheme deck and while theyâre face up.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 904. Archenemy : 904.5.
text: The archenemyâs starting life total is 40. Each other playerâs starting life total is 20.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 904. Archenemy : 904.6.
text: Rather than a randomly determined player, the archenemy takes the first turn of the game.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 904. Archenemy : 904.7.
text: The owner of a scheme card is the player who started the game with it in the command zone. The controller of a face-up scheme card is its owner.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 904. Archenemy : 904.8.
text: Any abilities of a face-up scheme card in the command zone function from that zone. The cardâs static abilities affect the game, its triggered abilities may trigger, and its activated abilities may be activated.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 904. Archenemy : 904.9.
text: Immediately after the archenemyâs precombat main phase begins during each of their turns, that player moves the top card of their scheme deck off that scheme deck and turns it face up. This is called âsetting that scheme in motion.â (See rule 701.25.) This turn-based action doesnât use the stack. Abilities of that scheme card that trigger âWhen you set this scheme in motionâ trigger.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 904. Archenemy : 904.10.
text: If a non-ongoing scheme card is face up in the command zone, and no triggered abilities of any scheme are on the stack or waiting to be put on the stack, that scheme card is turned face down and put on the bottom of its ownerâs scheme deck the next time a player would receive priority. (This is a state-based action. See rule 704.)

name: Comprehensive Rules: 904. Archenemy : 904.11.
text: Once an ongoing scheme card is set in motion, it remains face up in the command zone until an ability causes it to be abandoned (see rule 701.26).

name: Comprehensive Rules: 904. Archenemy Supervillain Rumble Option: 904.12a
text: As an alternative option, players may play a Free-for-All game in which each player has their own scheme deck. The attack multiple players option (see rule 802) is used; no other multiplayer options are used.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 904. Archenemy Supervillain Rumble Option: 904.12b
text: Each player in this game is an archenemy.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 904. Archenemy Supervillain Rumble Option: 904.12c
text: As in a normal Free-for-All game, the starting player is randomly determined. All other rules that apply to the archenemy in an Archenemy game apply to each player in a Supervillain Rumble game.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 905. Conspiracy Draft : 905.1.
text: The Conspiracy Draft variant consists of a draft (a style of limited play where players choose cards from sealed booster packs to build their decks) followed by a multiplayer game. The Conspiracy Draft variant uses Magic: The GatheringâConspiracyÂ® and/or Conspiracy: Take the Crown booster packs by default.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 905. Conspiracy Draft : 905.1a
text: A draft typically consists of three draft rounds. In each draft round, each player opens a booster pack, drafts one card by placing that card in a face-down pile in front of the player, then passes the remaining cards to the next player. Each player then drafts a card from the booster pack passed to them and passes the remaining cards. This procedure continues until all cards in that draft round have been drafted.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 905. Conspiracy Draft : 905.1b
text: In the first and third draft rounds, booster packs are passed to each playerâs left. In the second draft round, booster packs are passed to each playerâs right.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 905. Conspiracy Draft : 905.1c
text: During the draft, a player can look only at cards in the booster pack they are currently drafting from, cards they have already drafted, cards that are currently revealed as described in rule 905.2b, and cards that have been drafted face up as described in rule 905.2c. A player may not reveal drafted cards to other players unless an ability instructs them to.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 905. Conspiracy Draft : 905.1d
text: After the draft and all actions that may be taken during or after the draft, all the cards a player has drafted become that playerâs card pool. The player builds their deck from only these cards and any number of basic land cards. See rules 100.2b and 100.4b.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 905. Conspiracy Draft : 905.2.
text: Some cards have abilities that function during the draft.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 905. Conspiracy Draft : 905.2a
text: During a draft, there is no active player or system of priority. If multiple players wish to take an action at the same time during the draft and canât agree on an order, those actions are taken in a random order.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 905. Conspiracy Draft : 905.2b
text: Some cards instruct players to reveal them as theyâre drafted and then note some information, such as a number or color. This information can be referred to by other abilities during the game. Any player can look at this information at any time during the draft or game. After the information is noted, the drafted card is turned face down and added to the playerâs drafted cards pile.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 905. Conspiracy Draft : 905.2c
text: Some cards instruct players to draft them face up. Each such card remains face up until the draft is complete, an effect instructs the person who drafted it to turn it face down, or the card leaves that playerâs drafted cards pile. While the card is face up, all players may look at it.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 905. Conspiracy Draft : 905.3.
text: A Conspiracy Draft game is a multiplayer game. The default multiplayer setup is the Free-for-All variant with the attack multiple players option and without the limited range of influence option. See rule 806, âFree-for-All Variant.â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 905. Conspiracy Draft : 905.4.
text: At the start of the game, before decks are shuffled, each player may put any number of conspiracy cards from their sideboard into the command zone.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 905. Conspiracy Draft : 905.4a
text: Conspiracy cards with hidden agenda are put into the command zone face down. Any time a player has priority, they may turn a face-down conspiracy card they control face up. See rule 702.106, âHidden Agenda.â

name: Comprehensive Rules: 905. Conspiracy Draft : 905.5.
text: The owner of a conspiracy card is the player who put it into the command zone at the start of the game. The controller of a conspiracy card is its owner.

name: Comprehensive Rules: 905. Conspiracy Draft : 905.6.
text: Once the starting player has been determined, each player sets their life total to 20 and draws a hand of seven cards.

name: Glossary:
text:
Abandon
To turn a face-up ongoing scheme card face down and put it on the bottom of its ownerâs scheme deck. See rule 701.26, âAbandon.â

Ability
1. Text on an object that explains what that object does or can do.
2. An activated or triggered ability on the stack. This kind of ability is an object.
